DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Ship's Reactor Started After 16 Years
DOC.TEXT: The reactor on Japan's only nuclear ship has been started for the first time since it was shut down 16 years ago due to a radiation leak. No leakage of radiation was recorded during Thursday's 12-hour test aboard the 8,242-ton Mutsu, anchored at Sekinehama in northern Japan, officials of the government's Atomic Energy Reserach Institute said. The freighter developed a leak in its radioactive shield on its maiden voyage in 1974, and drifted for 50 days before city residents allowed it to return temporarily. Several other cities refused to berth the stricken vessel. In 1981, government officials agreed to build a new port for the ship at Sekinehama, an isolated spot on the Pacific Ocean near its former home port, Mutsu City. The ship's reactor was extensively remodeled after the leak. The officials said the tests of the reactor would continue, and if successful, the Mutsu will conduct several test cruises to collect data for possible future development of nuclear-powered commercial vessels. It then will be scrapped, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Depiction of Nude Purdue President Removed from Display
DOC.TEXT: A graduate student whose 8-foot canvas of the Purdue University president clad only in socks was removed from an exhibit says he was simply trying to be provocative. Artist David Loewenstein, 23, said Thursday that his painting of President Steven C. Beering was tame and designed to spark discussion about the right to display controversial art. ``There's a lot more art that is done that is more explicit,'' Loewenstein said. Beering did not pose for the painting, nor has he made a public statement about it. ``I wanted to do something provocative and see how people would align themselves, while at the same time doing something risky, fun and mischievous,'' he said. ``It doesn't happen enough at Purdue.'' Gary Sudano, director of Purdue's department of creative arts, removed the painting from a campus art gallery after Loewenstein refused to withdraw it. ``We have exhibition space in our buildings which is reserved for the display of works of art that arise from the instructional program,'' Sudano said Thursday. ``We don't provide a forum for public displays of personal points of view. That's not our mission.'' Sudano said Loewenstein has other paintings on display in the three campus galleries, but all were from classes the student had taken.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: A self-described beach bum en route back to Pennsylvania won a one-year free pass on a Florida commuter rail line because he was its millionth passenger. ``This pass will do me a lot of good in Pennsylvania,'' said Scott Wilson of Reading, Pa., upon receiving the $720 ticket for the Tri-Rail commuter line. He planned on giving the ticket to a friend. Wilson, who was riding the line for the first time, was going to Miami International Airport on Wednesday when passengers on a train car decked with balloons were told to yell ``Surprise!'' to the fifth passenger who boarded. ``This is too wild. I've never won anything before,'' Wilson said. In Fort Lauderdale since September, the 24-year-old Wilson said he worked as a shipping manager for a few months, but for the past few weeks was a ``beach bum at spring break.'' ``I can't believe I missed it by just one,'' groaned Edward Barturen, the 999,999th passenger, who commutes daily on a 25-mile trip from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Miami. The rail service opened in January 1989. A one-way trip costs $2.

Both Demoratic and Republican Party veterans think it's crazy, but a couple running for the same House seat believe it increases their chances of winning. ``It's not important to us who wins,'' said Johnnie Luteran, who filed as a Democrat for the party primary Aug. 7. ``We are giving the people an opportunity to elect someone with drive and determination.'' His wife, Barbara Luteran, is a Republican candidate for the same 48th Distict seat. The GOP primary also is Aug. 7. ``That may take the cake,'' said Mike Wells, Democratic chairman of Jackson County. ``That's crazy,'' said Tony Feather, executive director of the Missouri Republican Party. ``That's the strangest thing I've ever heard of.'' Local politicians and party insiders cannot recall any couple ever running for the same job. Both Luterans face primary opponents. Republican incumbent Rep. Pat Kelley is seeking re-election, and Dixie L. Courtney is seeking the Democratic nod. ``It seems a little odd to me,'' Kelley said. ``I guess at this point I do not know what to say.''

DOC.HEAD: Space Telescope Safe Inside Orbiter
DOC.TEXT: The powerful, $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope is safe inside the shuttle Discovery, free from certain bugs but not others. Technicians installed the telescope Thursday after ridding a payload preparation room at the launch pad of 40 small mosquitolike insects called midges. Engineers feared the midges might damage the fragile instrument and its 8-foot primary optical mirror. About the time the last insect was snared, bugs of a more technical nature were discovered. A spark igniter on one of Discovery's three main engines did not receive continuous power and was replaced. And an electronics package on another engine needed to be replaced because of an internal circuitry problem. The problems were considered minor, and NASA today planned to test the electrical connections between the Hubble and Discovery. A final check will be made of the telescope's systems and its scientific instruments on Sunday. The 25,000-pound telescope will tested to ensure it is in remote communications with NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., and Lockheed Missiles and Space Co. in Sunnyvale, Calif. Discovery's payload bay doors will remain open until two days before the scheduled April 12 launch so the telescope's batteries can be charged. NASA has said the mission may be moved up a day or two because flight preparations are running ahead of schedule. The two-day delay in installing the Hubble had no effect on the launch schedule, said George Diller, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The telescope was transferred into the orbiter late Thursday afternoon in an operation that took five hours. ``Once the bugs were behind us ... it really went about as smoothly as it could have gone. That's the only thing that's been a surprise in any of this so far,'' Diller said. Discovery's five astronauts are to deploy the Hubble on the second day of the five-day mission. Once in orbit 370 miles above Earth, the telescope will be capable of looking seven times more deeply into space and detecting objects 50 times fainter than the best ground-based observatory. The telescope is named for the late U.S. astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who discovered during the 1920s that the universe constantly is expanding. His finding led to the big-bang theory that the universe was created about 15 billion years ago by a terrific explosion. The Hubble will enable astronomers to study stars and galaxies so distant that their light has been traveling toward Earth for 14 billion years.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Eager to Wave the Flag for Lithuania
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: President Bush may be reluctant to recognize Lithuania's new government, but customers at a colorful stand in Union Station's Main Hall are eager to wave the flag. They're so eager that there's been a run on Lithuanian flags, patches, key chains and lapel pins at Alamo Flags, where manager Dante Payne's order book amounts to a weathervane of world events. ``People will come by and say, `I heard about it on the news. Give me one.' They think freedom is great,'' Payne said. In the past week, Payne has sold about 100 of his 4-by-6-inch flags at $3.99 each, and 25 of the demonstration-size 3-by-5-foot banners for $35. ``I have to order at least twice a week,'' Payne said from his stand in Washington's elegantly renovated main train station. ``You can see we've almost sold out of patches. There's just one left.'' Patches sell for $4. For Lithuania supporters who want to show the yellow, green and red colors more discreetly, key chains and lapel pins are priced at $3.99 each. Payne said many of his customers are Americans with Lithuanian roots, others buy in bulk for demonstrations and the rest are mostly curious passers-by. Dan Raber, a 17-year-old high school student from Kingsport, Tenn., falls into another category: the motivated collector. ``I collect flags from different countries,'' he said. ``With all this going on and Lithuania becoming a brand-new nation, I thought it would be interesting to get a flag of theirs.'' While he was at it, Raber picked up little flags from Estonia and Latvia in case Lithuania's Baltic neighbors follow it down the tricky path toward independence from the Soviet Union. Some other Washington-based flag outlets reported no special increase in Lithuanian flag sales. ``I have had some calls, I wouldn't say dozens by any means,'' said Diane Wolter, a saleswoman for Betsy Ross Flag Girls Inc. But she said political currents do affect the flag business. ``Since the Berlin Wall came down, there's been a lot of interest in Eastern Europe,'' she said. ``When we had this flag-burning thing, that increased business tremendously.'' The extra sales were to flag supporters, she hastened to add, not to people wanting to set the stars and stripes ablaze. At Union Station, Payne said demand for the Lithuanian flag has not matched the rush for Czechoslovakian flags last November or for African National Congress banners when Nelson Mandela was freed in South Africa in February. Alamo Flags boasts that it stocks flags from every country and all 50 states. ``Namibia is the only one we don't have because it just became a country,'' Payne said. ``But we should have it by the end of the week.''

DOC.HEAD: Ouster of Homosexual Cadets Draws Fire from Capitol Hill
DOC.TEXT: One semester away from graduation at MIT and a commission in the Navy's prestigious Nuclear Propulsion Program, Cadet Robert Bettiker looked across the desk at his superior officer and said: ``I'm gay.'' The officer, R.W. Sherer answered without hesitation. ``Well then, we will consider the date of disenrollment,'' he said. That quickly, the military career of a cadet with nearly four years of government-financed education at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology was finished, a casualty of the Pentagon's policy of excluding homosexuals. Now Bettiker's case, and another like his, have drawn congressional attention. A Pentagon move to require Bettiker and Harvard cadet David Carney to pay back their tuition drew a letter of protest from two dozen House members Thursday. ``We believe that to compel these men to repay this money would not only be fundamentally unfair; it would also reflect an appalling mean-spiritedness which has no place in the Navy,'' the lawmakers said in a letter drafted by Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., an acknowledged homosexual. The Navy is showing no signs of wavering. Both Carney and Bettiker have been asked to sign one-page forms acknowledging their debt but have refused. For Carney, that translates into a $50,687 tab. For Bettiker, the bill comes to $38,612. Carney, 23, graduated from Harvard last spring after the Navy covered all his tuition and some fees. He spent the past year studying at Oxford University in England. Bettiker, 22, is to graduate from MIT this spring. The Navy stopped paying his tuition after the fall semester. Both men say they are balking at repaying the Navy because they are not trying to avoid their five years of obligatory military service and want to become commissioned officers. ``In my view, the U.S. Navy broke its contract with me, not vice versa,'' Carney said in an interview. Although Bettiker and Carney know one another and had the same commanding officer, the similar timing of their cases was coincidental, Bettiker said. Both told their ROTC superior that they had recently discovered their homosexuality. They said they had not concealed their circumstances from the ROTC and were not aware they were gay when they entered the service. Last month Studds, in a letter also signed by 23 congressmen, complained about a similar policy move by the Army ROTC against James Holobaugh, 24, who attended Washington University in St. Louis. In the Holobaugh case, a preliminary board recommended he repay his tuition. But in the Carney and Bettiker cases, the lower-level board called for no repayment. That recommendation was overruled by Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III, who routinely reviews such cases. Navy spokesman Jim Turner declined to comment in detail on the Carney and Bettiker cases but provided a written explanation of the Pentagon's policy excluding homosexuals. It said the Defense Department views homosexuality as ``incompatible with military service,'' for reasons of morale, chain of command, discipline and security. It indicated a concern about homosexual encounters among military personnel who must live and work close together and about the possibility that homosexual relationships could lead to breaches in security. Bettiker said that when he realized he was gay he inquired about the military's exclusion of homosexuals but decided to report his situaion anyway. ``I looked at the Navy's policy and was really angry that they could so arbitrarily decide that I was not fit for service,'' Bettiker said. ``I thought about it and decided that I couldn't lie to them and couldn't live a lie for four to five years.'' Sherer, in a telephone interview, described his response to Bettiker last Nov. 7, when Bettiker reported his homosexuality: ``I said I would have to disenroll him, that that was a disqualifying factor for commissioning,'' the Navy officer said. Although Sherer recommended that Carney and Bettiker not be forced to repay their tuition, he called the loss of tuition one option ``that's standard for anybody who is disenrolled'' under similar circumstances. Neither cadet has retained an attorney, but Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund in New York has taken an interest in the issue of gay men and lesbians in the military and is monitoring the Navy ROTC case. ``I'm very optimistic that they won't have to pay back the money,'' said Sandy Lowe, a Lambda attorney. ``In none of these instances is there any finding at all that they defrauded the services.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Tempt Veto With Ambitious Child Care Plan
DOC.TEXT: House Democrats are tempting a presidential veto by rejecting the White House version of a child-care bill in favor of their own more costly and ambitious plan. The House approved the measure, estimated to cost at least $27 billion over its first five years, just hours after a spokesman for President Bush issued a fresh veto threat Thursday. ``Rather than waving his veto pen, our president should match his warm words with good deeds and agree to sign our child-care bill,'' House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said after the vote. The bill still must go to a House-Senate conference to resolve differences with the Senate. But Democrats hoped the ultimate version would mirror the House bill and that election-year pressures would make Bush back down from his threat. The House plan would expand tax credits for poor families to offset the cost of child care and would provide federal money for local governments to set up new day-care programs in public schools. It would create a system of state-issued subsidy vouchers for parents who want to use religious day-care centers, expand the Head Start program for poor children, and establish minimum standards for day-care centers. Both parties embraced the cause of day-care assistance during the last presidential campaign, and Democrats were trying to seize the political advantage on the popular issue. Less than a week ago, Democrats reported being close to a bipartisan agreement on the issue in White House negotiations that ultimately collapsed. ``I think President Bush, as he examines the bill, will find a lot more to be comfortable with than not,'' said a sponsor, Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y. ``I think it will go down as a landmark bill, one of the great achievements of the Congress and this era in American government,'' said House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash. To offset part of the new child-care costs, the House plan would take away the income tax credit that more affluent families now receive for child care. That credit would be reduced for families earning $70,000 a year and eliminated for those earning more than $90,000. It also would make permanent the 3 percent telephone excise tax due to expire this year. But both revenue sources would not cover the full cost. The House approved the bill 265-145, after voting more narrowly to reject the less costly alternative that Bush had endorsed. That version's five-year cost was put at nearly $20 billion. The White House's budget office issued a statement calling the Democratic version ``an exercise in fiscal irresponsibility.'' Just hours before the vote, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater warned that Bush would veto the Democratic version if it reached his desk. The White House alternative was sponsored by Reps. Charles Stenholm, D-Texas, and Clay Shaw, R-Fla. It was defeated on a 225-195 vote that largely followed party lines. Fourteen Democratic governors and one Republican, Gov. John R. McKernan Jr. of Maine, signed a letter to Foley endorsing the Democratic version of the child-care bill and opposing the conservative alternative. Republicans attacked the Democratic version because it instructs states to set minimum standards for day-care centers, including a requirement that day-care workers receive 15 hours of training a year. The Senate's version, passed last year, would cost about the same as the version backed by Bush, though it would provide smaller tax credits. Like the House version, the Senate plan would provide vouchers for church-run centers, but it would place less emphasis on school-based programs. Sen. Chris Dodd, D-Conn., sponsor of the Senate version, praised the House action as signaling ``a national child care policy is within reach.'' Though popular in the polls, the issue of child care had been bogged down in the Congress _ largely due to internal disputes among Democrats. The House last year approved conflicting child-care bills without resolving the differences. ``If the child-care legislation were an actual child, Congress would be charged with abuse and neglect,'' said Rep. Olympia Snowe, R-Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Economy Headed for Radical Reworking
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union may follow the lead of neighboring Poland and begin a ``shock therapy'' plan to push the economy toward a market system, a senior official says. But Vyacheslav Senchagov, chief of the State Price Committee, also told deputies of the Supreme Soviet legislature that angry consumers could block such radical economic changes. The government favors a moderate approach toward a market system that includes a transition period, he said Thursday in remarks carried by the official Tass news agency. However, Tass said Senchagov acknowledged choosing the most radical approach is ``inevitable, if during the transitional period ... the population's confidence in the government does not fall so low as to make no reforms possible.'' The most radical of three alternatives being considered is likely to drastically raise prices for raw materials and consumer goods, reduce the value of the ruble and raise unemployment, he was quoted as saying. Senchagov said the government has not yet decided which approach it will try to put into effect. After being installed in a powerful presidency on March 15, Mikhail S. Gorbachev said his most important task was to take more radical steps to cure the economy. Last week, a source confirmed previous news reports that Gorbachev's economists are working on a 17-point program leading to a market system and convertibility of the Soviet Union's currency on world markets. The source, who is working on the program, said Soviet economists were encouraged by Poland's tough measures that went into effect on Jan. 1, but they were worried they might create huge unemployment and the need for a vast welfare program. The source spoke on condition of anonymity. Many reports in Moscow say radical economic changes will be put into effect this summer. Senchagov's bureaucracy sets prices without regard to costs, creating artificially low prices for oil and gas and many natural resources, as well as for food and basic consumer goods. But the artificially low return for Soviet industry stifles production and initiative. Subsidies to keep prices low now cost the government the equivalent of one-fifth the total volume of the country's retail trade, Senchagov reported. Consumers have become used to a system that offers a minimum of choice for low prices, and many react with alarm to reports that the government is planning to free prices. Public concern has forced the government to delay key price reforms several times. As a result of government management of prices, one videocassette costs about twice as much as a 1,200-mile airline trip. Also, the country has long told its people they have a right to a job. But many enterprises lose money because of bloated payrolls. Poland's prices have increased 1,366 percent during the 12-month period ending Feb. 28, the Warsaw government says, and more than 200,000 people are unemployed. But under Poland's drastic economic plan, inflation has dropped from 79 percent in January to an estimated 6 percent in March. Poland has restocked its store shelves, while Soviets see their stores becoming emptier and emptier. The most conservative of the three approaches in Moscow would raise some prices for raw materials and some manufactured goods by fixed amounts. Under the most radical approach, however, oil and coal prices will increase three to five times. The number of collective and state farms, known for their inefficiency, will drop by 80 percent, ``unprofitable enterprises will be closed and unemployment will increase fast,'' Tass quoted Senchagov as saying.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Bush Steering Clear Of Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Most of the allies are supportive, but President Bush is getting it from left and right here at home over his gentle approach to the Soviet Union on Lithuania. While the president has his congressional supporters _ most notably Democratic House Speaker Thomas Foley _ his critics are concerned that Bush's refusal to confront Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev could undercut Lithuania's chances of attaining independence. The opportunity is unique. Lithuania and its sister republics of Latvia and Estonia were incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940. This is the first real chance they have had to get away. By all indications, Bush and others in the administration are sympathetic. They do not recognize the incorporation as being legal and they support independence in principle. But they are not being very tough about it. ``Bush would sacrifice Lithuania,'' the conservative Washington Times said in a banner headline Thursday after a congressional delegation had visited Bush at the White House to complain about his policy. Nor is the consternation on Capitol Hill confined to Republicans. ``He's decided to stick with Gorbachev,'' said Rep. Bill Sarpalius, D-Texas, part of the group that met with Bush. ``There's a genuine concern ... that the U.S. faces a choice of political survival of Gorbachev and survival of Lithuania,'' said Richard Durbin, D-Ill., the delegation leader. The criticism cuts across the political spectrum. Liberal and conservative columnists are hammering away at Bush. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., called on the administration to challenge the Soviet Union's claim on Lithuania in the International Court of Justice in The Hague, Netherlands. Others are reluctant to criticize Bush. ``I don't criticize the president at this moment in recognizing that circumstances are very delicate, very serious,'' Foley said. ``I think he should be given the benefit of the doubt as he deals with this.'' Through it all, the president and his spokesmen have not wavered, though the weariness is beginning to show. ``We no longer find it beneficial to comment on every daily episode and contribute to what was an upward spiraling of the rhetoric,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Wednesday. ``We want to level off, if you will.'' From the start, Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III have taken a consistent tack: the Soviets and the Lithuanians should settle their differences peacefully. If the Kremlin applies force it could backfire. This is the policy Baker is conveying to Moscow through diplomatic channels. It is the same policy the administration is voicing in public. Critics find it too soft, too solicitous of Gorbachev, too concerned that U.S.-Soviet relations could suffer if the administration put more starch into its public and private statements. But Bush and Baker have concluded that a good relationship with Moscow under Gorbachev has produced dividends for the United States. Tensions have been reduced. The Soviets have agreed to pull tens of thousands of troops from Europe, along with tank divisions and other weapons. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze will hold talks with Baker at the State Department next Wednesday through Friday in preparation for a Bush-Gorbachev summit meeting in Washington in June. Bush and Baker clearly are banking on the proposition that they can maintain good relations without sacrificing Lithuanian independence. ``Nobody denies their right of self-determination,'' Sergei Chetverikov, minister-counselor of the Soviet Embassy, said Tuesday. And, he told reporters, ``the basic premise behind the actions of the Soviet Union is not to use force, but to find peaceful ways.'' The Soviet diplomat, an expert on constitutional law, acknowledged, however, that ``the situation is difficult.'' It is also difficult for Bush and Baker, who have been accused in the past of taking too soft an approach _ to China after the suppression of pro-democracy forces last June, for instance. Bush has wavered between a conservative and a moderate stance throughout his political career. Right-wing Republicans savored his attack on liberals during the 1988 presidential campaign against Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts, but they still are checking his credentials. Baker, Bush's guru during the campaign, also is suspected of being too pragmatic, of being inclined to put solutions ahead of ideology. Indeed, there is a strong element of pragmatism in the policy the administration is pursuing on Lithuania. But it also may succeed, without hurting either the Lithuanians or U.S.-Soviet relations
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid has covered U.S.-Soviet relations for The Associated Press since 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Critics Rip Israeli Military Aid to Ethiopia
DOC.TEXT: Israel's military aid to the Soviet-backed Ethiopia government could prolong civil strife in that famine-wracked country, lawmakers and others say. ``It really bothers me that Israel would jeopardize its position in Congress by supporting that butcher Mengistu,'' Rep. Dan Burton, R-Ind., said Thursday, referring to Ethiopia's leader, Hile Mengistu Mariam. Burton along with other members of Congress and the Bush administration have long attacked Mengistu for his human rights record and his policies that have contributed to thousands of starvation deaths over the last decade. Mengistu's government is waging a civil war with rebels in Eritrea and Tigre, two provinces in northern Ethiopia. Israel's aid to Mengistu comes at a crucial time because the Soviet Union has yanked the many of its advisers from Ethiopia and cut its military assistance, according to one U.S. official who spoke on condition of anonymity. State Department officials say they have told Israel that the United States opposes the aid. Herman J. Cohen, the assistant secretary of state for Africa, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee this week that he took a ``very hard line'' on weapons shipments to Ethiopia when he met with Reuven Marhav, director general of the Israeli Foreign Ministry. Israel has told the United States it is only providing small weapons such as rifles and a few advisers to Ethiopia, the State Department says. After a 20-year lapse, Israel renewed diplomatic relations last year with Ethiopia, one of the few African countries with which it has official ties. But Burton said he thinks Israeli military aid consists of more than simply rifles, and is important because Mengistu is in trouble. ``He is starting to make overtures to the United States _ it's a last-ditch effort,'' he said. Burton said he raised the issue of Israel's support for Ethiopia in a recent meeting with Israeli Ambassador Moshe Arad. He said he told the diplomat: ``Some members may use this issue as a wedge to curb support for aid to Israel.'' Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, also expressed ``grave concern'' about the Israeli arms shipments, said an aide who demanded anonymity. Metzenbaum confirmed the meeting but said his conversations were confidential. Gayle Smith of The Development Group for Alternative Policies, a non-profit group that specializes in development issues, said Israeli intervention in the Ethiopian civil war could turn the conflict into a broader war. Israel is supporting Ethiopia and, according to recent reports, the Saudis, the Iraqis and the Libyans are backing Mengistu's opposition, she said. ``In particular, Israeli involvement is serving to enhance the effectiveness of the Ethiopian air force, which comprises the centerpiece of Ethiopian military strategy,'' Smith told the Foreign Relations Committee. Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa, said the Ethiopian air force's MiG jets continue to bomb convoys of food as they move into the famine-stricken areas of Eritrea and Tigre. Wolpe has also expressed concern about Israeli help for Mengistu. Israel is backing the Mengistu government for several reasons. In part, the Israelis have said they are concerned for the welfare of about 15,000 black Jews live in Ethiopia. But Smith said she believes the Israelis are worried about the future of the Horn of Africa should the Eritreans secede. Such a development would bring ``complete Arab dominance of the Red Sea,'' she said. Moreover, Ethiopia also allows Israel overfly rights to South Africa, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Byrd Says He Won't Punish Aid Opponennts
With PM-Clean Air Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Robert C. Byrd said he wanted to be magnanimous in defeat after losing by a single vote a $500 million aid package for 5,000 coal miners who may lose their jobs if Congress passes a clean air bill. But it remains to be seen just how forgiving the veteran West Virginia Democrat, a key controller of the government's purse strings, will be after his measure succumbed to the opposition of congressional leaders and President Bush on Thursday. ``I know how hard it is to say no to the president of the United States,'' Byrd said with a touch of irritation after the 50-49 defeat. ``I've said no to the expert, Lyndon Johnson.'' Not since two years ago when Byrd, then his party's leader in the Senate, had a Republican colleague arrested and physically carried to the Senate floor to frustrate a filibuster had he put so much of his clout on the line. That time the effort was on behalf of his party, as part of failed drive to pass a campaign finance reform bill vigorously opposed by President Reagan and Republican lawmakers. On Thursday, fighting back tears, Byrd conceded defeat again. ``It's pretty tough to have to be confronted with the administration and the joint leadership,'' the 32-year Senate veteran told his colleagues. ``But I knew that when I started out. I have no regrets, no recriminations.'' As chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee that largely controls where tax dollars are spent, Byrd arguably is in a better position to take recriminations against colleagues than he was as majority leader. That kind of power, recognized and addressed by several lawmakers during two weeks of debate, was not lost on Byrd's chief foes _ Sen. George Mitchell, the Maine Democrat who last year succeeded him as majority leader, and GOP leader Bob Dole of Kansas. Mitchell, who has viewed air pollution as a top legislative priority his his nine years in the Senate, had negotiated a compromise with Dole and Bush on a comprehensive cleanup package costing an estimated $21 billion a year. Mitchell argued repeatedly that the cost of Byrd's amendment would raise the price of the bill to a level unacceptable to the White House. ``I don't have the influence the senator from West Virginia has but I have a little,'' Dole said. ``This could kill the bill.'' The amendment would have paid special benefits to miners of high-sulfur coal in the Midwest and Applachia whose jobs will be lost as utilities swith to less-polluting coal mined in the West in order to meet the new law's requirements. On the vote, only 15 Democrats sided with Mitchell, compared with the 37 who went with Byrd. Dole kept 34 Republicans in line with the administration, but Byrd got 11 GOP votes. Byrd's influence also was not lost on the interest groups lobbying behind the scenes. Despite urgings by Mitchell to them to stay out of the fight, both the AFL-CIO and the National Clean Air Coalition of environmental groups endorsed and actively lobbied for Byrd's amendment. Byrd actually was holding a 50-47 edge going into the closing minutes of the vote. Sen. Spark Matsunaga, D-Hawaii, a long-time ally of Byrd, arrived in a wheelchair after being absent for several weeks because of cancer treatments, to vote for the amendment. Many of the senators who stayed on the fence until the vote occurred also side with Byrd. Among them were Democrats Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island and Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico and Republicans Charles Grassley of Iowa and Thad Cochran of Mississippi. ``Three who said they would vote with me changed,'' Byrd grumbled afterward. ``They took wings ... with the help of people downtown (at the White House).'' One of the switchers was Sen. Steve Symms, R-Idaho, an opponent of most of the measures in the bill. Symms originally voted for Byrd's amendment, but he switched after a two-minute face-off with Dole and GOP Whip Alan Simpson of Wyoming on the Senate floor. While the ``ayes'' and ``nos'' were being shouted, Simpson rushed up to Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., and escorted him to the cloakroom to take a phone call from White House chief of staff John Sununu. ``He guaranteed me that the president was going to veto the bill (if the amendment passed),'' Biden said, explaining his vote against it. ``If this were not a dealbuster, if it would not kill this bill, I would vote with (Byrd).''

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Rushing Aid to Salvadoran Rebels, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: As Nicaragua's leftist government prepares to leave office, U.S. officials say there has been a marked increase in Sandinista military shipments to rebel forces in El Salvador. The officials said Thursday there has been a noticeable increase in the shipments, mostly ammunition and explosives, following the Sandinsta defeat in the Feb. 25 elections. According to the officials, who asked not to be identified, the Managua government is sending vessels loaded with equipment to an area off El Salvador's southeast coast. The cargo is then loaded onto large canoes with 55-horsepower engines, which deliver the goods to a swampy area along the Salvadoran coast, the sources said. The area is largely inaccessible to the Salvadoran Army because the FMLN rebels have planted mines there. The operations, carried out under cover of darkness, occur ``not daily but regularly,'' said one official. The Sandinistas have systematically denied any role in supporting the Salvadoran insurgency since 1981. The State Department has maintained that the link between the two has been unbroken almost since the Sandinistas came to power in 1979. As U.S. officials see it, the link will become uncertain after April 25 when President Daniel Ortega is scheduled to turn power over to President-elect Violeta Chamorro. The FMLN probably will have to shut down the command and control headquarters it has maintained in Managua, they said. Some rebel supplies have been sent from Cuba via Nicaragua. But this source is not expected to be available to the rebels once the Sandinistas are out of power, the officials said. U.S. intelligence picked up evidence a few months ago that Cuba had begun to ship weapons to the insurgents along a land route that begins in Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula and runs through Guatemala to El Salvador. The peninsula is only about 75 miles from Cuba's west coast. Mexico has denied that its territory has been used for transporting weaponry to the Salvadorans. There is some concern within the Bush adminstration that the Sandinistas, who are well-armed, may try to find ways to continue supplying equipment to their Salvadoran allies even after they surrender power. Still, officials said that with the Sandinista defeat, the rebels are facing an unfavorable political and military situation. They are more isolated politically than at any time since the insurgency began a decade ago and they used up many supplies in the offensive they launched in early November. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has said that this combination of factors has improved prospects for a negotiated settlement to the Salvadoran war, which is believed to have claimed more than 70,000 lives. He is hopeful a peace agreement can be reached this year.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Heavyweight champion James ``Buster'' Douglas recalled his family's struggle with poverty as he urged congressional support for a program to help the poor pay heating bills. The 232-pound boxer was the first witness Thursday before a Labor and Human Resources subcommittee. Wearing a starched white shirt and a black suit with a white hankerchief in the lapel, he read a two-page statement and answered questions from panelists. Douglas did not mention the Bush administration's proposed 25 percent cut for the 1991 fiscal year in the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program, which served 5.9 million households last year. Instead, he gave the Subcommittee on Children, Families, Drugs and Alcoholism a personal account of poverty in his hometown of Columbus, Ohio, and ended with a plea to ``do everything you can.'' ``I was 15 and we had a pretty terrible winter that year and we were behind on our gas bill,'' he said. A local aid program helped get the family through. ``I think that that had a great deal to do with me becoming heavyweight champion of the world,'' he said. ``In hard times, we had support.''

The Go-Go's reunited in concert for the first time in five years to promote a state ballot initiative, but the performance turned out to be a referendum on the group's future. ``After the show we took a vote,'' guitarist Jane Wiedlin said backstage amid talk of a fall tour. ``Maybe in September. September isn't for sure, but we're going to do something together.'' She said the band made no decisions on recording an album. Belinda Carlisle, Charlotte Caffey, Gina Schock, Kathy Valentine and Wiedlin had the Universal Amphitheatre audience on its feet throughout Wednesday night's show. The hometown crowd loved such early '80s hits as ``We Got the Beat,'' ``Vacation'' and ``Cool Jerk.'' The Go-Go's, who had only one week of rehearsal, were tougher critics. ``It was sloppy,'' Wiedlin admitted. The Go-Go's formed in the late 1970s and rose from the Los Angeles club scene to stardom. The group broke up in 1985 after three best-selling albums. Band members went on to solo projects or work with other groups. The concert was a benefit for an anti-pollution measure that needs 650,000 signatures to make the 1990 ballot.

Ted Turner credits his Cable News Network with awakening him to world problems. ``Until then, I was more interested in myself and my family,'' Turner told students at the McCallie School, which he attended from 1951 to 1956. After starting his 24-hour TV news station about 10 years ago, Turner told the students, he figured he'd better keep up more with the world's activities. ``And I came to the conclusion after studying it on my own that we had made a terrible mistake getting involved in the arms race.'' Of even greater concern, Turner said, are world overpopulation and threats to the environment from business and industry. ``I now look on development as bad,'' he said. ``When I see a new building going up, it makes me feel bad.''

A jury awarded $56,000 in libel damages to Queen Elizabeth II's nephew, Viscount Linley, over a newspaper story that claimed he was banned from a pub for throwing beer. The 28-year-old furniture designer, 12th in line to the throne, won the award Thursday against the Today newspaper. Today also will have to pay legal costs estimated at $121,500. Today admitted that its 1989 story was untrue, but two free-lance reporters and a Today staffer said their source was the pub's manager, Carolyn Peacock. She testified on Linley's behalf, however, and denied telling reporters about him. ``I would not have recognized Viscount Linley if I'd seen him, I'm afraid,'' she said. Today Editor David Montgomery called the verdict surprising and said the newspaper would appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Navy's Newest Missile At Sea
DOC.TEXT: The Navy has its most lethal ballistic missile at the ready, with the first Trident 2 missile deployed aboard the submarine USS Tennessee. ``This marks the start of an era,'' said Navy spokesman Lt. Cmdr. Craig Quigley. ``This missile will serve as one-third of the nation's strategic triad for many years to come.'' A military source who declined to be identified said the vessel left its base at King's Bay, Ga., about 7:30 a.m. EST Thursday. The Navy said in a statement that the Trident 2 program has handled all of its tests successfully. The service plans to build 24 Trident subs and purchase Trident 2, or D-5, missiles through fiscal year 2001. Greenpeace, an environmental group that has tried to halt testing of the weapons system at sea, said protestors aboard a 60-foot sailboat and three motorized inflatable rafts intercepted the Tennessee and Coast Guard escort boats 13 miles off the Atlantic coast on Thursday. Josh Handler, a Greenpeace spokesman, said a Coast Guard boat boarded one of the rafts and cut its fuel line. He said Greenpeace activists aboard another raft rescued two Coast Guard crew members who were dumped overboard as their boat cut across the raft's bow. The program encountered problems last year after two of its first three submarine-launch tests ended in failure when the missiles self-destructed. It was declared on track in January after a $125 million repair of the missile's nozzle system. However, the Navy statement said the program, which has cost $35 billion to date, ``was delivered two years early and was 12 percent below the budget originally provided.'' The program formally achieved what is called the initial operational capability, meaning ``it is declared ready for use,'' Quigley said. It marks the end of its land-based and submarine-based flight tests, as well as all readiness checks for its missiles, crew and equipment aboard the USS Tennessee, the statement said. The first eight Trident subs produced for the Navy have gone to sea with the Trident 1 missile, which is less accurate than the new version. The vessels are scheduled to be re-equipped with Trident 2 missiles during the 1990s as they are brought in for overhauls. Quigley said the Trident program could be hampered if the Energy Department is unable to resume production of warhead triggers by the end of June. The triggers are made at the Rocky Flats plant near Denver, which has been closed since last November for safety improvements. Quigley said Energy Secretary James D. Watkins had informed the Navy that it hoped to get Rocky Flats restarted by the end of June, but that no firm date had been set. ``If he doesn't meet that schedule ... then we'll have to reassess at that point'' the Trident missile deployment schedule, Quigley said, adding that Watkins so far had given the Navy no indication that it would be unable to meet its schedule.

DOC.HEAD: Black Congressman, Rapped as Bigot, Says Only Whites are Racist
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: Jewish organizations are calling Rep. Gus Savage a bigot for his attacks on a pro-Israel lobbying group, but the black House member says the only racists are white. Savage, D-Ill., held a news conference Thursday, insisting in advance on ``nonbelligerent'' questions. He denied that his attacks on the American-Israel Public Affairs Committee for supporting his opponent in a recent primary election were anti-Semitic. And he declared: ``Racism is white. There is no black racism.'' AIPAC spokeswoman Toby Dershowitz said, ``Savage's insertion of bigotry and anti-Semitism into the political arena is regretful and abhorrent. The American Jewish community has long prided itself on a high level of political involvement.'' Justin J. Finger, associate national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, said Savage's statements ``encourage hatred of Jews and Israel'' and are ``a reprehensible attempt to drive a wedge between blacks and Jews.'' Savage called the mostly restrained news conference to show reporters and interested House members a videotape of his attacks on AIPAC during a March 17 primary campaign rally in Chicago. Savage won the election. At the rally, Savage said supporters of AIPAC _ the main pro-Israel lobbying group _ provided most of the financing last January and February for his defeated opponent, Mel Reynolds. Savage insisted at the news conference there was ``nothing anti-Semitic'' in his statements. He said he read a list of Jewish contributors to Reynolds during the rally simply to show their connection to AIPAC. ``I was unaware I had been targeted by AIPAC. I thought that was wrong,'' Savage said, adding it was ``a disgrace'' that the lobby and contributors from outside the district had a major influence on Reynolds. He questioned whether a majority of Jews support the pro-Israel lobby and declared he was one of the ``very few members'' willing to publicly oppose AIPAC. Also during the news conference, Savage called the Academy Award-winning film ``Driving Miss Daisy'' _ about an elderly white woman and her chauffeur _ an insult to blacks, and made his oft-repeated statement that racist media were out to get him. Savage's remarks have been closely followed since the House ethics committee last month found that he made ``improper advances'' to a female Peace Corps worker during a trip to Zaire a year ago. The panel said Savage violated a House rule on members' conduct but took no action to punish him, citing a voluntary letter of apology to the woman. Savage said Thursday that ``a network of so-called journalists'' was out to ``deliberately distort'' news about him and that the white-dominated media have ``tried to paint me as crazy _ crazy Gus.'' Savage on occasion raised his voice to interrupt reporters who asked critical questions, and gave lengthy speeches about racism in America. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said Savage's remarks about AIPAC at the rally in Chicago ``created an impression of bigotry'' and ``can be legitimately construed as offensive.'' Foley said he has no control over Savage's comments. ``We have standards for conduct. Unfortunately, they don't require good sense or judgment always,'' he said. Asked whether Savage had exercised good judgment, Foley replied, ``Not on this issue certainly, and I think it went beyond just a matter of bad judgment ... into language and statements that are, can be legitimately construed as offensive.''

DOC.HEAD: VA Compensation Decision Doesn't Resolve Agent Orange Controversy
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: The decision by the Veterans Affairs Department to award compensation to Vietnam veterans suffering from one rare form of cancer doesn't resolve the dispute over exposure to Agent Orange. The decision, announced Thursday, could make it possible for the VA to close the doors to compensation for a host of ailments linked to the herbicide used in Vietnam from 1965 to 1970 to deny jungle cover to the enemy. Based on a study released the same day by the federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, VA Secretary Edward J. Derwinski said he would award 100 percent disability payments to any Vietnam veteran suffering from non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Payments would be retroactive, and widows and children would receive survivors' benefits as well. More than 1,800 veterans or their survivors could receive compensation as a result, according to VA data, at a cost of $23 million the first year and about $25 million in subsequent years. Veterans advocates were pleased with the immediate decision but remained skeptical about the study's application to the larger Agent Orange questions. The government has insisted there is no scientific proof of a link between the herbicide and a host of ailments, mostly cancers. ``When the study was designed, CDC admitted that the study population was significantly diluted with unexposed veterans, that it lacked a meaningful measure of exposure and that it lacked the statistical power to detect anything less than a 100 percent increase in certain cancers,'' said Sen. Thomas A. Daschle. Daschle, D-S.D., is co-chairman of the Vietnam-Era Veterans in Congress Caucus and wrote legislation to make the disease and others suspected of having a link with Agent Orange exposure service-connected. The CDC ``Selected Cancers Study'' looked at the occurrence of cancer in all Vietnam veterans in relation to men who did not serve in Vietnam. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma was the only cancer found in the study to have had an unusually high incidence. Derwinski was initially very careful to say his decision was not an Agent Orange decision, but he and his aides were fuzzier in later remarks. Derwinski at one point said he made his determination based at least in part on the work of a VA-commissioned panel of outside scientists. That group reported last November that it could not find, but neither could it rule out, a statistically significant association between Agent Orange exposure and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. As a result of that finding, Derwinski had said he would postpone a decision on Agent Orange compensation until after the CDC study. He had planned, however, to wait for the advisory panel's recommendation in May. Derwinski jumped the gun Thursday, but he insisted the panel would continue its work on the Agent Orange issue. Derwinski is also consulting with Elmo Zumwalt, the retired admiral who ordered Agent Orange spraying and whose son died of a cancer linked to exposure. Some 36,000 Agent Orange claims have been made for the lymphoma and other ailments have been made, and almost all have been rejected. About 230,000 veterans have asserted they have been exposed to Agent Orange. The CDC study left some questions unresolved. It noted, for example, that Navy veterans were more inclined to get the disease even though they were least likely to have been exposed to Agent Orange. It also said the lowest incidence was among veterans of III Corps, the area of highest Agent Orange use. John Hanson, an American Legion official, said the study neglected to point out that the III Corps area included Saigon, which wasn't sprayed. Deputy Veterans Secretary Anthony J. Principi said VA was making the presumption that any veteran who served in Vietnam was exposed to Agent Orange. But Hanson said such a determination dilutes any statistical sample to the point where an Agent Orange determination is impossible.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Killed in China's Traffic Accident
DOC.TEXT: A bus plunged into a river in the southwest Chinese city of Chongqing, killing at least 20 people, the official China News Service reported. The brief report, appearing today in local newspapers, said 10 others were missing after the accident Tuesday in Sichuan province. An investigation was under way, it said.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Activists Say Bush Must Back Words With Actions
DOC.TEXT: AIDS activists welcome President Bush's attention to the epidemic that has ravaged the gay community and is spreading among drug users, but they say he must match his sympathetic words with action. ``Compassion is important, but we need money,'' said Tim McFeeley of the Human Rights Campaign Fund. In a speech Thursday to the National Leadership Coalition on AIDS, Bush called on Congress to pass the Americans with Disabilities Act to bar discrimination against people with AIDS and those who are infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS. He also touted his administration's proposed fiscal 1991 budget proposal for spending $3.5 billion on AIDS treatment, research and education. But Jean McGuire, executive director of the AIDS Action Council, said ``the sensitivity we're seeing could mask the inaction we've had for the last decade'' under former President Reagan. ``If today is the beginning and not an end to the president's efforts, we can be hopeful,'' she said. ``But a decade of neglect requires a more aggressive and substantive and meaningful leadership than we heard today.'' Leaders of the National Commission on AIDS were more positive in their reaction to the president's first major speech on the disease, which has taken the lives of more than 70,000 Americans, most of them homosexuals or intravenous drug abusers. They called Bush's attention an important first step in escalating the public battle against the epidemic. Dr. June Osborn, the commission's chairwoman, said that even though the president offered no new initiatives, it was important that he showed concern about the issue and compassion for people with AIDS. ``In terms of changing the public mood, we desperately need that rhetoric,'' she said. ``We're on wartime footing'' at the National Institutes of Health and the Centers for Disease Control in the battle against AIDS, Bush told the coalition of business, labor, health and religious groups. But AIDS activists said the president was trying to inflate the administration's commitment to the AIDS battle by including, among other things, spending on Medicaid and Medicare patients who have AIDS. That amounts to more than $1 billion of Bush's total for AIDS spending. AIDS activists attending the conference said that with just one speech, Bush has done more than Reagan did for their cause. But they were disappointed Bush did not address some of the major issues relating to AIDS, including an immigration policy that bars people with the fatal disease from entering the country. Many activists had hoped the president would address the immigration policy, which has prompted dozens of organizations and agencies to boycott an international conference on AIDS planned for San Francisco in June. ``We have become an embarrassment in the global community that is dealing with this disease,'' said McGuire of the human rights fund. The administration has been granting waivers of the policy to people who enter the United States for conferences and to seek medical attention. But pressure is building on the White House and Congress to remove HIV infection from a list of contagious diseases that is grounds for barring people entry to the country. Robert Haas, chairman and chief executive officer of Levi Strauss & Co., told the leadership coalition that Bush's decision to address the group was of ``symbolic and historic importance.'' But Haas also criticized the president for proposing to eliminate funding for treatment of AIDS among low-income people not eligible for Medicaid. He said Bush also cut funding for home and community-based care demonstration projects for AIDS patients and said the president's budget for the war on drugs does not adequately support prevention and treatment of AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: Defeat of Byrd Amendment Casts Pall Over Miners
With PM-Clean Air, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Senate cast a pall over thousands of coal miners by rejecting a $500 million compensation plan for those who could lose their jobs under a proposed clean air bill, union officials say. ``It's a real tragedy,'' said Howard Green, international executive board representative for United Mine Workers District 17 in Charleston. Sen. Robert Byrd's amendment to the Clean Air Act would have compensated the more than 5,000 miners expected to lose their jobs over the next three years if the bill passes. The measure would require coal-fired power plants to severely cut emissions; that likely would cause some utilities to switch from high-sulfur coal to other fuels. The Senate rejected Byrd's amendment Thursday on a 50-49 vote. ``Let each senator ask himself the question, `Is this fair?''' said the West Virginia Democrat. ``What about what the president has said about this being a kinder, gentler nation? Does kinder and gentler stop at the edge of the coal fields?'' The restrictions on high-sulfur coal use could hit hard, siphoning off coal-mining jobs to areas with low-sulfur coal. UMW President Richard Trumka said the Senate ``failed to recognize the devastating effect that this clean air legislation will have on the nation's coal miners, their families and their communities.'' ``If the bill passes in its present state, we anticipate losing 2,000 West Virginia mining jobs,'' said Mike Burdiss, head of the union's Coal Miners Political Action Committee in Charleston. UMW officials said they're not exactly sure what will happen now that Byrd's efforts to aid the miners have been rebuffed. Green predicted ``major displacement'' of miners as they go off in search of jobs. ``We're just going to have to wait and see. There's a lot of ifs out there right now,'' said Eugene Claypool, president of UMW District 31 in northern West Virginia, which has much of the state's high-sulfur coal. ``Where it's going to occur and when it's going to occur, I don't know.'' Sens. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., Wendell Ford, D-Ky., and Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., voted for Byrd's amendment. Sens. Charles Robb, D-Va., and John Warner, R-Va., voted against it. Kentucky and West Virginia have more high-sulfur coal reserves than Virginia. ``It was a tough blow to see the two senators from Virginia voting against it,'' Green said. ``They didn't look beyond their borders. I just think those senators are insensitive to the coal industry.''

DOC.HEAD: Death Rates Down, Life Expectancy Up
DOC.TEXT: Life expectancy in the United States has never been higher, but disparities remain between whites and blacks, federal researchers say. Overall U.S. life expectancy rose to 75 years, according to 1987 data, the Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. That was up 0.2 years _ about 73 days _ from 1986, said Ken Kochanek, a statistician with the CDC's National Center for Health Statistics in Hyattsville, Md. The life-expectancy concept means that someone born in 1987 would live, on the average, 75 years. Women, on average, outlive men by 6.9 years. Overall, Americans can now expect to live about 12 years longer than they could expect 50 years ago; the life expectancy rate in 1940 was 62.9. But while average life expectancy for whites was 75.6 years _ up slightly from 1986 _ life expectancy for blacks was 69.4 years, same as the year before. And though the nation's mortality rate was down, annual black death rates were 50 percent higher than for whites _ 778.6 per 100,000 blacks, compared with 511.1 for whites. The greatest single disparity in death rates was for death by homicide. The black homicide rate in 1987 was six times higher than that for whites, the CDC reported. Meanwhile, the nation's overall mortality rate in 1987 _ the latest year for which analysis is available _ fell to a record low of 535.5 deaths for every 100,000 Americans. That's down 1 percent from a year earlier and down 7 percent from 1979. A total of 2,123,323 U.S. deaths were reported in 1987 _ the highest number ever, as the nation's population has grown. The decline in the overall death rate came as fatality rates dropped for 13 of the previous year's 15 leading causes of death, including the big four: heart disease, cancer, stroke and accidental injuries. The death rate from heart disease, the nation's leading killer, dropped 3.1 percent. The rate for cancer declined 0.2 percent, the rate for stroke and cerebrovascular disease fell 2.3 percent, and the rate for accidents dropped 1.7 percent. Among the 15 leading causes of death, the only increases were among diabetes, up 2.1 percent, and septicemia, or blood infections, up 4.7 percent. Year-by-year comparisons were unavailable for AIDS deaths because of 1987 changes in categorization in the mortality study, the CDC said. But CDC data on AIDS found a 32 percent increase in deaths between 1986 and 1987, and ``mortality from AIDS appears to be increasing more rapidly than mortality from other conditions,'' the Atlanta-based agency said. Acquired immune deficiency sydrome replaced birth defects as the 15th leading cause of death.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 29,980.45, down 1,045.71 points or 3.37 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Calls for Recheck of Nuclear Failsafe Systems
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee is calling for U.S.-Soviet reviews of failsafe systems because of concerns that unrest in the Baltic republics could put nuclear weapons in the wrong hands. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., suggested Thursday that the Bush administration urge the Soviet Union to join the United States in conducting separate, but parallel, studies of nuclear control programs. ``If nationalists or terrorists overran a Soviet nuclear storage site in one of the republics, would the superpowers coordinate their actions?'' Nunn said in a Senate floor speech. ``Have we thought through the problem of how we would respond to nuclear blackmail?'' Nunn suggested using the existing Nuclear Risk Reductions Centers for talks about how the two superpowers could avoid an inadvertent nuclear war. Ethnic unrest in Azerbaijan and Lithuania's declaration of independence March 11 have prompted Moscow to resort to military force. Nunn also acknowledged the lessening Soviet conventional threat and questioned whether the administration is correctly characterizing the Soviets' modernization of their strategic forces. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has said unequivocally that there has been no reduction in Soviet strategic forces and the only change has been in improving their forces. ``The administration has tended to overstate its case,'' Nunn said. He said U.S. intelligence has found a decrease in the Soviet's Blackjack bomber production. In addition, the Soviets have ceased patrolling U.S. coasts with its Yankee-class submarines and patrolling north of Canada with its nuclear-armed Bear-H bomber. Nunn also discussed his complaints in a speech last week that the administration's fiscal 1991 defense budget has several major blanks that Congress will fill if the Pentagon doesn't. Cheney, in a speech shortly after Nunn's address last week, disputed some of the chairman's claims and said the Defense Department is recognizing rapid changes in Eastern Europe in fashioning a spending plan for fiscal 1992 to 1997. ``It is crucial to note, however, that Secretary Cheney made no claim that the administration's fiscal 1991 budget request reflects all these assumptions,'' Nunn said Thursday as he urged the Pentagon chief to fill in the blanks quickly. Questioned about Nunn's comments, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said: ``It would be very difficult, if not dare one say, imprudent, to send up a '91 budget on the basis of things that haven't happened yet. As events change, we will adjust our plans accordingly.''

DOC.HEAD: Concern About Job Bias Behind Move to Drop Penalties
DOC.TEXT: Critics of a 4-year-old immigration law are pushing to repeal its penalties against employers who hire illegal aliens, citing a report that blames the law for widespread hiring discrimination. ``Unless Congress finds a way to end this discrimination, the sanctions must be repealed,'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said Thursday after the General Accounting Office issued its report on the immigration law. However, Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner Gene McNary said the GAO report was ``soft,'' and Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., said the facts did not justify the agency's findings of widespread discrimination. ``Today, I learned a whole new definition of the word widespread,'' said Simpson, who has played a major role in writing immigration laws. The law, designed to curb the flow of illegals over the southern border in search of high-paying jobs, calls for civil and criminal penalties against those who employ ineligible workers. Critics predicted when the measure was passed by Congress in 1986 that it would cause employers to discriminate against ``foreign-looking'' applicants. The GAO's report said the law ``is not an unnecessary burden on employers.'' It concluded that the measure has not caused frivolous complaints against employers and ``has apparently reduced illegal immigration.'' INS figures show that 383,375 illegals were apprehended on the southern border from October 1987 through February 1988, compared with 267,174 in the same period a year later. In the comparable period ending last month, apprehensions increased to 366,844. The INS' McNary told a news conference the number of apprehensions would have doubled had it not been for the 1986 immigration law, and the GAO report cited a study by the Urban Institute that found a slowing of illegal immigration. The GAO said ``many employers discriminated because the law's verification system does not provide a simple or reliable method to verify job applicants' eligibility to work.'' It said up to 10 percent of the 4.6 million employers considered under the GAO survey may be practicing job bias based on national origins because of confusion over the immigration law. Discrimination related to the law is ``serious but not pervasive,'' the 162-page report said. It said hiring bias might be reduced by more information for employers and a simpler and more reliable system for verifying work eligibility. Under the law, employers must complete an eligibility form for each newly hired worker. It allows the employees to establish their eligibility by presenting any one of 17 documents, such as a U.S. passport, birth certificate or alien registration card. In response to the report, the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights urged Congress to repeal the law's penalty provisions, saying ``evidence has been building rapidly in recent months that employer sanctions cause serious employment discrimination.'' ``This discrimination is unacceptable and its root cause _ employer sanctions _ should be eliminated,'' the independent, fact-finding agency said in a statement. The INS' McNary told reporters that some of the GAO's conclusions were ``soft because there is no base of comparison in the past.'' He also pointed to a statement in the document that said some interpreters might not agree with the findings. ``They own up to the fact that others may disagree and for good reason,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists See No Trend of Earth Warming In Satellite Data
DOC.TEXT: Scientists who analyzed 10 years of weather satellite data found no evidence that the Earth has warmed from the so-called greenhouse effect. In a paper published today in the journal Science, the scientists reported that the TIROS-N series of weather satellites accurately measured the Earth's temperature from 1979 through 1988 and found no evidence of climate change. ``We found that the Earth's atmosphere goes through fairly large year-to-year changes in temperature and over that 10-year period we saw no long-term warming or cooling trend,'' Roy W. Spencer of the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., said at a news conference Thursday. He said the data did prove, however, that satellites can be used to measure the Earth's temperature with a more global perspective than the limited ground-based instruments now in use. Spencer's fellow investigator, John R. Christy of the University of Alabama, said there were temperature swings ``that can be quite dramatic'' during the decade that was studied, but that on a global basis, the thermal changes tended to even out. ``The northern hemisphere goes up slightly during those 10 years and the southern hemisphere goes down slightly,'' said Christy. ``The net effect for the globe is basically zero.'' Detecting a climate trend, the scientists said, will take at least another decade of satellite measurements. ``There is no guarantee that if you take a 10-year segment out of a long time that you'll get the overall trend,'' said Christy. ``The data cannot be used to say we've got an enhanced greenhouse effect.'' Christy said the findings ``are enough to tantalize us ... but this is just a start'' and satellite measurements are continuing. The TIROS satellite data is the first to add global temperature data to the scientific debate about the greenhouse effect, Spencer said. Most other studies of temperature trends, some extending over more than a century, have come from the records of ground-based thermometers. These readings, Christy said, do not reflect the global temperature because there are very few temperature measurements for vast areas of the Earth's oceans. Some experts believe the Earth is beginning to warm as a result of carbon dioxide and other gases dumped into the atmosphere over the last 150 years. This warming, called the enhanced greenhouse effect, is a matter of controversy in the scientific community because of the difficulty in measuring small climate trends over a long period. Eric J. Barron, director of the Earth System Science Center at Pennsylvania State, said the analysis of the TIROS data by Spencer and Christy could be ``extremely valuable'' in the global warming debate, but he agreed that 10 years is too short a period to detect a climate trend. What is important about the study, Barron said, is that it proves satellite studies eventually may be able to settle the controversy. Science, which published the study today, is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Opponents Label Some Photographs Child Pornography
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of a planned exhibit of photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe say most of the pictures are innocuous, even beautiful, but that nine of the sexually explicit photos are unacceptable for Cincinnati. Those photographs from the 175-photo exhibit scheduled to open next week at the Contemporary Arts Center depict sadomasochistic or homoerotic sex acts or feature nude children, say members of Citizens for Community Values. ``We're saying: We want you to exercise your responsibility and delete the roughest images,'' Tom Grossmann, a lawyer for the group told a news conference Thursday. ``There is no doubt that Mapplethorpe has created some photographs that are art, but his homosexual material speaks so loudly that I stand here with'' the group, said the Rev. Freddie T. Piphus. In the face of strong public opposition, the center filed a lawsuit seeking a court ruling on whether the photographs are obscene. Last June, the exhibit was cancelled at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. Police and the Hamilton County sheriff have said they are considering filing obscenity charges if the museum displays the photographs. Arts Center Director Dennis Barrie was loudly applauded Thursday at the annual convention of the Ohio Museums Association when he said opposition and legal challenges to exhibits such as the Mapplethorpe show was a threat to the future of art museums. ``This is a museum that has had to go to court ... I think that's a very sad state of affairs,'' Barrie said. ``I think it's time you stood up to that challenge. Your whole world is at stake.'' In Washington, the head of the National Endowment for the Arts said Thursday he favored the Arts Center's decision to seek a court ruling. ``In my view this is precisely the forum in which this issue should be determined because obscenity is a local issue and they will make their decision based on community standards,'' John E. Frohnmayer said at a Capitol Hill hearing and later at a National Press Club luncheon. To quell opposition to the exhibit, the museum plans to post a warning sign and bar unaccompanied minors while the shows runs April 6 to May 25. ``They're trying to deflect the issue (by posting a warning),'' said Monty Lobb Jr., director of Citizens for Community Values, who denied that opponents are trying to force the museum into self-censorship. ``We're even going beyond the First Amendment or anything of that nature. We're going to the dignity of human life,'' Lobb said. He said he wanted the center ``to demonstrate civic responsibility'' and ``be sensitive to the community.'' Henry Dorfman, publisher of the weekly Greater Cincinnati Business Record, said two photographs showing nude or partially nude children might encourage child pornography. ``If in our art museums we freely display and tacitly advocate this kind of abuse of children, we are in serious trouble,'' Dorfman said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pokes Fun With Broadcasters
DOC.TEXT: President Bush traded quips with amateur and professional comedians at a broadcasters' banquet, but he said he didn't show up until the Secret Service swept the ballroom. ``The place was clean. No broccoli,'' Bush told the crowd of more than 2,000 people at the annual Radio and Television Correspondents Association dinner Thursday night. With his sirloin and salmon, Bush also had to digest a ribbing at the hands of both broadcasters and impressionist Jim Morris. CBS reporter Linda Taira, president of the association, got in several digs in her introduction. ``It's exciting for our print colleagues, Mr. President, to cover you. They bump against their deadlines trying to punctuate your sentences,'' she said. ``When my desk calls me in the middle of the night, I never know whether you've invaded another country or banned another vegetable.'' She advised Bush to ``never, ever, take a phone call from Hashemi Rafsanjani unless you get Caller I.D. in the Oval Office.'' The president said he was glad to be with ``all the big names in the electronic media,'' despite the hard time they gave him on the recent hoax phone call from a prankster posing as the Iranian president. ``Today I got him back. Called him up and asked if he had Prince Abdul in a can,'' Bush quipped. ``But then I forgot how to say, `Let him out,' in Farsi.'' Bush mocked his own disjointed speaking style, which Morris and other comics love to imitate, saying: ``I'll be honest. He's good _ too good. That's as far as I'll go. Not going to comment. Not going to criticize Jim Morris at this juncture. Wouldn't be prudent.'' Bush and his wife, Barbara, laughed along with most of the jokes told by Morris and talk show host Larry King, who served as emcee. Morris, fielding questions as if he were president, was asked why he had named the Panama invasion ``Operation Just Cause.'' The mock-Bush answered, ``Just cuz.'' ``Hey, it's Central America. It's America. It's ours,'' said Morris. Morris, who also performed at a gala for Ford's Theatre that the Bushes attended Sunday, quipped that ``the best thing we can do to reduce the deficit is see if we can convince the Japanese ... to produce 30 percent of their goods in a shoddy fashion.'' Morris scored one joke at the expense of a Bush critic, the House majority leader, saying, ``Dick Gephardt is a perfect example of where we have failed in our public schools.''

DOC.HEAD: Gap Between Rich and Poor Unchanged as Heart Disease Rates Drop
DOC.TEXT: The uneducated and poor still face the greatest threat from heart disease, although people of all social classes have reduced their risk equally in recent years, a study suggests. University of Minnesota epidemiologist Wayne Rosamond, who co-authored the study, presented the findings Thursday during the American Heart Association's annual conference on heart disease epidemiology, the study of disease among population groups. The results indicate lower socioeconomic classes ``obviously have not caught up with the relative advantages of being more educated and more affluent,'' said Dr. Elizabeth Barrett-Connor, a University of California, San Diego, researcher and chairwoman of the association's epidemiology council. The Minnesota researchers examined heart disease risk factors and socioeconomic status _ as reflected by education and family income levels _ of 3,816 randomly selected adults in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area in 1980-82, and of another 4,641 in 1985-87. Although people got slightly fatter during the study period, those in each socioeconomic group also made statistically equivalent reductions in blood cholesterol, blood pressure and cigarette smoking _ major factors in heart disease. ``But the difference between the highly educated and less educated is not narrowing at all,'' said Dr. Russell Luepker, chief author of the study and a professor of epidemiology and medicine at Minnesota. Lower socioeconomic groups still have the highest levels of blood pressure, blood cholesterol, cigarette smoking and obesity, he said. ``If we're going to continue to make progress, we have to target those groups who have been least affected by improvements in society,'' he said ``Those with lower income have higher risk and also are the least educated. They are not making the higher level of progress you would hope for.'' The study found, for example, that the proportion of men who smoked fell from 44 percent to 41 percent among those who didn't finish high school, dropped from 40 percent to 33 percent among those with some college, and declined from 25 percent to 21 percent among men who graduated college. Another example: The proportion of women with at least one risk factor for heart disease fell from 65 percent to 54 percent among those who didn't finish high school, declined from 57 percent to 46 percent among those with some college, and dropped from 43 percent to 34 percent among those who got a college degree. While the study found an increased risk of heart disease was related to both low education and low family income, the link with low education was stronger, Rosamond said. ``More educated people are taking better care of themselves and have less risk because of it,'' Luepker said. ``They're the people who are exercising, quitting smoking and eating healthier diets.'' The only exception to the link between disease risk and social status was that men in higher classes tended to have higher cholesterol levels that men in lower classes, Rosamond said.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Cost Estimate for B-2 Bomber Cited by Critics
RETRANSMITTING to fix byline.
DOC.TEXT: A leading Republican opponent of the B-2 bomber says a new estimate that the program will cost $76.7 billion provides additional ammunition for the battle against the stealth aircraft. ``When the program cost $70 billion, members said they couldn't believe it.
