Now it's $6.5 billion more. Clearly it bolsters our case dramatically,'' said Rep. John Kasich, R-Ohio, a member of the House Armed Services Committee. The Congressional Budget Office, in a letter to Kasich, increased its cost estimates for the B-2 based on inflation predictions and the Air Force's planned modifications to the plane. ``CBO estimates that the administration's program for the B-2 bomber would cost about $76.7 billion based on the best information we have,'' the office said in the letter. The Pentagon has said purchasing the fleet of 132 bombers will cost $70.2 billion. Recently, Air Force Secretary Donald Rice said the program may cost about $75 billion. Kasich, who requested the information from the CBO, has introduced legislation that would limit the B-2 purchase to the 15 planes already in production. In the letter, the CBO agreed with a recent report by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, that the cost of the program could exceed its estimates. ``Costs of new programs at the leading edge of technology are always hard to estimate,'' the CBO said. ``Furthermore, there are special estimating problems unique to the B-2 program.'' The CBO warned that the administration may not realize the savings it expects to gain from purchasing the radar-evading planes over a period of years. The office also agreed with officials at the General Accounting Office who said the bomber's cost will increase due to the strike at the Boeing Corp., a major subcontractor, and that future tests may expose costly problems.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Hopes for Consensus on New Label Regulations
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration is hoping for a consensus among health experts and food companies on how to make sure consumers striving for health and fitness aren't fooled by product labels and advertising. Executives from some of the country's largest food corporations met Thursday with federal officials at a conference prompted by FDA proposals to tighten regulation of food health claims. ``We're trying to define boundaries so consumers can believe what's on that label,'' said Fred Shank, the agency's director for food safety and applied nutrition. At the heart of the debate: a conflict over what diet and health messages should be allowed on food packaging and who should set the standards. ``It's clear that the current situation must change. Otherwise, the bad messages may drive out the good,'' said Frank Young, deputy secretary for the Department of Health and Human Services. The FDA hoped for agreement with the food industry, national health experts and other policy makers by today's wrap-up of the Tufts University-sponsored conference. The FDA plans to institute new regulations by year's end. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan announced the proposed regulations last month, calling them a ``mid-course correction'' of rules that have allowed food sellers to make health claims since 1987, when the Reagan administration abandoned a long-standing prohibition against such claims. The proposal generally would let companies make certain health claims that are backed up by studies by the Surgeon General and the National Academy of Sciences. Other claims would be allowed only in certain circumstances. The policy would allow health claims about fiber and colon cancer, fiber and heart disease, fats and cancer, fats and heart disease, sodium and high blood pressure, and calcium and osteoporosis, a softening of the bones found in the elderly. Many food company executives at the conference here said they have no major quarrel with more stringent FDA regulations. But almost all voiced concern that the FDA has failed to propose uniform national standards. They said they fear that allowing states to set some of the standards may lead to trade barriers between states. ``There are shortcomings, but we know there's an immense interest on the part of the public for information and we're glad to see some movement on that end,'' said Luther C. McKinney, a senior vice president of the Quaker Oats Co., which found itself caught in the debate over the cholesterol-lowering powers of oat bran. ``We simply want to argue strongly for federal uniformity. If we're going to have a meaningful national market, we can't deal with 50 different regulations.''

DOC.HEAD: FDA Recalls Drug Because of Mislabeled Bottles
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration is recalling two lots of an antidepressant drug called desipramine because some bottles may contain a blood-thinner that could cause serious bleeding, officials say. The manufacturer, Pharmaceutical Basics Inc. of Denver, told the FDA it was calling back the products after distributor H.L. Moore of New Britain, Conn., found a mislabeled bottle of the drug earlier this week. The bottle was labeled as containing 25 milligrams of desipramine, but it actually contained 5 milligram tablets of warfarin, a blood-thinner. The FDA said people taking the antidepressant should examine their tablets to see if any are marked with the name warfarin. Warfarin is a non-coated pink tablet with ``5'' on one side and ``832'' and the word ``warfarin'' on the other side. Desipramine is a coated, lavender tablet with the numbers ``832'' and G254'' imprinted on it. Pharmaceutical Basics is notifying Moore's 350 customers by phone of the possible label mix-up, the FDA said Thursday. The recall applies only to desipramine made by Pharmaceutical Basics for distribution by Moore. About six other manufacturers make desipramine.
DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Teach Parents To Care For Their Babies
DOC.TEXT: A proposed bill would teach parents prenatal care and ways to develop their babies' coordination, memory, language and social skills. ``We know that parental involvement in the education of their children is the key to long-term gains for youngsters,'' Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., said Thursday. ``Parents are their child's first and most influential teachers.'' Bond was joined in introducing the bill by Sen. Thad Cochran, R-Miss., and Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala. The bill would create a national ``Parents As Teachers'' program based on a Missouri model. A five-year, $100 million competitive grant program would be set up for states to begin or expand Parents As Teachers. The program, which operates in 26 states, employs home visits, group meetings, videotapes and written material to teach new and prospective parents the skills of raising an infant. There also are periodic health screenings of children. Bond said the average operating cost for a Parents As Teachers program in a school district is about $20,000 per year. He estimated that about 1,000 school districts nationwide could participate in the program annually with federal assistance. The bill would force states to eventually pick up the cost of the program, as federal funding would decline to 75 percent in the third year, 50 percent in the fourth year and 25 percent in the fifth year of the five-year authorization.
DOC.HEAD: Report: No One Overseeing Maintenance of Alaskan Oil Pipeline
DOC.TEXT: A government report says no one has been properly overseeing maintenance of the Alaskan oil pipeline to prevent a land spill as disastrous as the ocean spill in Prince William Sound. But since the Exxon Valdez ran aground and dumped nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into the Pacific Ocean off Alaska last year, the appropriate agencies are taking notice, said the study released Thursday by the General Accounting Office. People should remain skeptical, said Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., chairman of the House Interior subcommittee on offshore energy resources. Miller has been leading a congressional investigation of the March 24, 1989, spill and the safety of other oil industry operations in Alaska. ``The regulators and the regulated have been too cozy,'' he said of the relationship between the government and the oil industry. He said it's too early to tell if significant improvement has been made, but various studies under way by the government and the criminal case against Exxon for the spill should lead to improvements. The GAO said that while several federal and state agencies have authority over the trans-Alaska pipeline system, ``the pipeline has not received the systematic, comprehensive oversight needed to ensure compliance with operational safety, emergency response and environmental requirements.'' That's particularly worrisome because of recent news that the pipeline is corroding, James Duffus, director of the GAO's division on natural resources management, told Miller's subcommittee.

DOC.HEAD: Contras Take Guns, Head Home
DOC.TEXT: Most of the U.S.-backed Contra rebels in Honduran camps are returning to Nicaragua without waiting for a U.N. team that is supposed to monitor their disbanding, a rebel leader says. Oscar Sovalbarro, a military chief of the Nicaraguan Resistance, the rebels' umbrella group, said Thursday that most rebels left the camps, taking their weapons, and would reach Nicaragua by the end of this week. ``In our camps in Yamales there are few weapons and few combatants left,'' Sovalbarro said referring to an area 125 miles southwest of Tegucigalpa that had been used by an estimated 12,000 rebels in their nine-year war against Nicaragua's Sandinista government. He said ``only about 3,000 war-wounded and their families remain in the camps'' in Yamales, which became home to the bulk of the rebel force after U.S. military aid to the Contras ended in 1988. U.N. forces of about 200 were gathering in Managua and Tegucigalpa to monitor Nicaragua's transition from a decade-old leftist revolutionary government to the conservative United National Opposition. In an accord with representatives of Nicaraguan President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, Sovalbarro agreed the rebels in Honduran camps would disband and hand over their weapons by April 20, five days before the new administration takes over from the Sandinista's. Rebels in Nicaragua are to gather in U.N.-supervised security zones under the accord but there is no deadline for their demobilization. But Sovalbarro, 29, said Thursday most rebels returned to Nicaragua without waiting to hand in their guns to U.N. forces. The Contra leader, known as Commander Ruben, signed the agreement March 23 with the incoming government. ``We want to turn in our rifles in Nicaragua, because if there is going to be democracy in our country, then we will exchange our weapons for the plow to cultivate the land,'' Sovalbarro said. It was unclear whether the rebels' rank-and-file would honor the accord. Meanwhile, U.S. Ambassador Chris Arcos praised Honduran President Rafael Leonardo Callejas for his role in persuading the rebels to leave Honduras. ``The Contras have been dissolved ... and Callejas resolved that problem,'' Arcos said. Callejas sponsored the negotiations, in which Nicaraguan Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, archbishop of Managua, also participated. They followed the Sandinistas' loss in elections Feb. 25 to Mrs. Chamorro's U.S.-backed coalition. An estimated 80,000 Hondurans were displaced by the rebels, including 20,000 coffee producers. They were forced to move to the interior of the country or traveled illegally to the United States or Mexico to find work.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq's Development of High-Tech Weapons Stirs Alarm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th pvs, `Both incidents...' to UPDATE with report of missile launchers under construction; picks up 8th pvs, `Western intelligence...'
DOC.HEAD: AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's drive to eclipse Israel as the Middle East's paramount military power is gathering momentum, and its alleged attempt to acquire trigger devices for nuclear weapons underlines that the regional arms race has reached a new stage. Most analysts believe Iraq is still years away from producing a nuclear weapon. But, coupled with development of long-range missiles and chemical weapons, Iraqi efforts to acquire the trigger devices have raised concern that its nuclear program may be more advanced than anyone thought. The sophisticated devices are believed to be available only to a few major powers. The State Department called in Iraq's ambassador in Washington, Mohamed Al-Mashat, on Thursday and registered ``deep concern'' that Iraq is trying to circumvent U.S. restrictions on nuclear technology shipments. The department also reportedly reiterated U.S. opposition to the spread of missile technology in the Middle East. The arrest of three people in London on Wednesday on accusations they were trying to smuggle the triggers to Iraq was among the latest in a chain of indicators that Iraq is capable of developing high-technology weapons. In December, Iraq surprised other nations by launching a rocket it said could be used to put a satellite into space. It also claims to have developed missiles with a range of 750 miles. Both incidents demonstrated the advances the Iraqis have made. The New York Times reported today that Iraq for the first time is building missile launchers within range of Israel and the Syrian capital of Damascus. The newspaper, quoting unidenfied U.S. intelligence officials, said they believed the missiles in western Iraq are intended to discourage possible Israeli attack on Iraqi nuclear or chemical weapons facilities. Western intelligence sources said the rocket launch was less successful than at first believed. They said the rocket flew for just over two minutes, reaching an altitude of 12{ miles before plunging back to earth. Nonetheless, some analysts believed it put Iraq on the threshold of ballistic missile capability. Richard Murphy, former U.S. assistant secretary of state and a Middle East expert, told a conference on Iraq in London this month that Iraq's missile program has made ``extraordinary progress.'' He noted: ``This progress generally carries an ominous overtone and not just in the United States. Its genuine scientific achievements are clouded by associated reports of Iraqi progress in chemical weapons and biological warfare research.'' Iraq has achieved this despite the efforts of the United States and the six industrialized nations to halt the flow of sensitive technology to stem the proliferation of missiles. There is some evidence the Missile Technology Control Regime is having some effect. But Murphy noted: ``The problem is getting out of the control, if it hasn't already, of the superpowers. It's difficult to attract Middle Eastern countries into the regime.'' The superpowers' influence in restricting access to missile technology has been undercut by the emergence of sophisticated arms industries in Latin America, Asia and the Middle East. China has supplied weapons to Iran and Iraq, but says it has stopped doing so. Iran, Syria, Saudi Arabia and Libya are also developing or believed to be developing missiles. Israel, faced with the erosion of its technological superiority, now has the nuclear-capable Jericho-1 weapon, with an estimated range of up to 370 miles. It recently tested an advanced version, Jericho-II, with a reputed range of more than 1,000 miles, enough to hit targets anywhere in the region and even reach the Soviet Union. Iraqi officials deny Baghdad is seeking to build nuclear weapons. But the rapid strides it has made in military technology, along with President Saddam Hussein's regional ambitions and the lack of a formal peace treaty with Iran, have caused widespread concern. ``Iraq is being unnecessarily grandiose in its military preparations,'' Simon Henderson, editor of the London-based Mideast Markets newsletter, told the London conference. ``Western officials consider the amount it spends on defense to be totally out of proportion to that necessary to meet any threat of renewed hostilities with Iran. ``Instead, they foresee that by the end of the decade, Iraq will have the largest arsenal in the region of unconventional weapons _ principally medium-range missiles with sophisticated warheads, including chemical and nuclear weapons.'' In December, Mideast Markets reported that Iraq was trying to build a nuclear bomb with Chinese help. The newsletter said the Chinese had provided Baghdad with components for high-speed centrifuges that produce the highly enriched uranium needed for nuclear weapons. It said it could be 10 years before Iraq would be capable of testing such a weapon. But Israeli officials have said Iraq is probably much closer than that. Israeli warplanes bombed a French-built nuclear reactor near Baghdad in June 1981, alleging the Iraqis were developing nuclear weapons. Some analysts believe Baghdad's effort to get its hands on nuclear triggers indicates it is well down the road to nuclear weapon capability. But Don Kerr, a military specialist with the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies, said in a telephone interview that he believed Iraq's nuclear program ``is still essentially in the theoretical stage because of the problems of getting hold of weapons-grade material.'' He said Iraq's bid to acquire nuclear triggers was ``an attempt to take a short cut through the design and development process.'' At present, Israel is believed to be the only nuclear power in the Middle East. Israel denies that. But nuclear technician Mordechai Vanunu, imprisoned for revealing Israel's nuclear secrets to a London newspaper, said Israel has at least 100 nuclear weapons. The minister in charge of Iraq's rapidly expanding military industries, Gen. Hussein Kamel, was quoted by a Persian Gulf newspaper last year as saying Iraq was negotiating with the French to rebuild the bombed reactor ``for peaceful purposes.'' The French, Iraq's second-biggest arms supplier after the Soviet Union, denied that. However, King Fahd of Saudi Arabia said last year his country was ready to help the Iraqis rebuild the reactor. The Soviets, too, have been closely associated with Iraq's nuclear program and in 1984 agreed to provide $2 billion in credit to help build two nuclear power stations.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Ed Blanche is the AP's Middle East news editor and has covered the region since 1985.

DOC.HEAD: `Historic' School-System Overhaul Approved in Kentucky
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf `Under the ...' to fix `the' to `a' district.
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers have approved a new way to finance and run Kentucky's public schools, abolishing a system the state Supreme Court said shortchanged poor districts and dragged down test scores. The House voted 58-42 Thursday to approve the overhaul _ which includes a $1.26 billion tax increase and decentralization of control over day-to-day operation of the 570,000-student system _ and sent it to Gov. Wallace Wilkinson. The Senate passed the measure 30-8 on Wednesday. The governor has hailed the plan as ``history in the making.'' ``It's the first time that any state has scrapped its existing system and started over again,'' said Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States, a federally supported research organization. Courts in 10 states have overturned education funding systems since 1970 because of disparities in money available for rich and poor districts. But education experts said last year's ruling in Kentucky was perhaps the most sweeping. The court declared the entire school system unconstitutional because its quality varied so greatly between rich and poor districts. The court also found that Kentucky students were performing in the lowest quarter nationally on standardized tests. Student performance ``is fraught with inequalities and inequities throughout the 178 local school districts,'' Chief Justice Robert Stephens wrote. The Legislature responded by repealing and replacing all Kentucky laws on elementary and secondary education. The 900-page legislation would mean more money for schools in general and dramatically more money for poor districts. About half the money from the tax increase would be spent on schools. ``We're going to do innovative things in Kentucky for once,'' said Rep. Greg Stumbo, the Democratic majority floor leader. ``We're not going to be a follower anymore. We're going to be a leader.'' As in many states, school spending in Kentucky is based primarily on local property taxes and varies according to property values. Under the current system, spending ranges from $1,800 to $4,200 a year per student, depending on the district. Under the new plan, the minimum property tax would increase, and the state would establish a minimum spending level of $2,900 per student in the 1990-91 school year, making up the difference if a district could not raise enough money. Overall state financing for elementary and secondary education would increase from $1.5 billion this year to $1.9 billion next year. The state Education Department's role would be overhauled. Districts would gain control over curriculum and other day-to-day operations, while the state would manage a system of rewards _ including cash _ for employees of schools that improve each year. Under the bill, the state also can quickly take over school systems that fail to measure up. The bill doesn't spell out how the state would measure progress. The plan also calls for a large-scale investment in technology, emphasis on early childhood education and extra help for potential dropouts. Control of the system also would be shifted from an elected state superintendent to an appointed education commissioner. Rep. Roger Noe, chairman of the House Education Committee, said he considered the bill second only to Brown vs. Board of Education in the making of education law. The 1954 U.S. Supreme Court decision outlawed school segregation. Lawmakers in Texas also are considering education finance reform after that state's top court rejected the state's funding mechanism. Other states where courts overturned school finance systems, according to a study last year by Robert Berne, associate dean of New York University's Graduate School of Public Administration, are New Jersey, Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Connecticut, Washington, West Virginia, Wyoming, Arkansas and Montana.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Philippine Relations Hit New Snag As Bases Talks Approach
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-12 pvs, `Gallido never...' with 7 grafs to UPDATE with hotel report, quote by American, CORRECTS spelling of name; picks up 12th pvs, `It's not...'
DOC.TEXT: A tale of intrique _ complete with double agents, a self-styled American spy and even Imelda Marcos _ has clouded prospects for successful talks on the future of U.S. military bases here. The flap began last week when the Department of Justice released the text of testimony by Brig. Gen. Alejandro Galido, who the government claims infiltrated elements of the military who tried to overthrow President Corazon Aquino in December. In his testimony, Galido said he was approached in April by a man claiming to be a U.S. Air Force colonel, who offered to sell weapons to the rebels for $20 million. According to Galido, the alleged colonel said he was a member of the Defense Intelligence Agency and supported moves to topple Mrs. Aquino. Galido also claimed Mrs. Marcos, who is on trial in New York on racketeering charges, was aware of the conspiracy but was unable to finance the arms because of ``money problems.'' U.S. officials have repeatedly declared support for Mrs. Aquino. During the coup attempt, U.S. jets flew air cover in support of government forces. But many Filipinos, always suspicious of the country that ruled the archipelago from 1898 until 1946, believed Washington supported the conspirators, then double-crossed them to make Mrs. Aquino beholden to the United States. Galido never indicated whether the deal was consummated, nor whether he believed the purported American spy, whom he identified as Harold Maglio, actually worked for the U.S. government. On Thursday, the majority leader of the Philippine Senate demanded that the United States ``clear the air'' about Maglio. The senator, Teofisto Guingona, said Maglio produced a picture that he alleged was taken of Maglio upon his arrival at Manila's airport last year. The U.S. Embassy denied that Maglio was on its staff or involved in Philippine affairs. It is unclear how much the embassy knows about him because U.S. privacy laws limit disclosures of information about private citizens without their consent. The DIA also said Maglio doesn't work for the U.S. agency. An official of the Mandarin Hotel said a guest who registered as Harold Maglio checked in April 30 and left after two days. The official said the man gave his address as Wrightwood, Calif. The Associated Press in Manila telephoned Maglio in Wrightwood today, but he hung up after saying: ``I'm not talking to reporters.'' The disclosures have produced banner headlines in Manila newspapers about American duplicity. ``It's not difficult to imagine that the military right-wingers in the U.S. government have been encouraging and supporting right-wing coup plots while the State Department...has been assuring Mrs. Aquino that the U.S. government had nothing to do with rebel forces,'' wrote columnist Alvin Capino in the Philippine Daily Globe. Opponents of the U.S. bases, have seized on Galido's allegations to urge Mrs. Aquino to forgo talks on extending the lease on the six installations, which expires in 1991. Bases talks are expected to begin next month, and Mrs. Aquino has given no indication she will cancel them. Any agreement must be approved by two-thirds of the 23-member Senate. Sentiment against the military posts, already sharpened after cutbacks in promised U.S. aid, has hardened with the Galido allegations. ``How can we have exploratory talks this coming April unless the U.S. clears the air?'' Sen. Guingona asked. ``How do we continue the abiding friendship unless suspicions of inordinate intervention remain?''

DOC.HEAD: Engineer: Cooperating in Nuclear Sting the Right Thing to Do
DOC.TEXT: The president of a U.S. defense contractor says he cooperated with a sting that averted shipment of 40 nuclear detonators to Iraq because he feared nuclear weapons in the hands of ``irresponsible'' countries. The sting came as part of an 18-month investigation by U.S. and British customs agents that culminated in a federal indictment against five people and two British companies. Jerold Kowalsky, an engineer and president of CSI Technologies Inc., said he alerted U.S. agents in 1988 to inquiries from alleged representatives of Iraq into his company, which makes electronic triggers to military specifications. He said Thursday that the possibility of the devices falling into the hands of the Iraqi government disturbed him. ``I had no qualms in cooperating with the government from the beginning,'' Kowalsky said. ``I felt like I was doing the right thing and I would hope anybody in my shoes would have done the same thing.'' Iraqi officials deny their government is seeking to develop a nuclear arsenal. Two of the five people named as defendants in the Feb. 23 indictment, unsealed Thursday in San Diego, were arrested Wednesday in London. The three others, believed to be in Iraq, were identified as engineers for Al-Qaqaa State Establishment, a weapons development unit of Iraq's Ministry of Industry and Military Industrialization, U.S. Customs officials said. The indictment alleges that Euromac (London) Ltd, and Atlas Equipment (U.K.) Ltd. acted on behalf of the Iraqi government to illegally obtain the devices. Customs officials said Euromac was an official purchasing office of the Iraqi government and had done millions of dollars in business in procuring materials for the Iraqi government at the height of its war with Iran. CSI Technologies is a U.S. defense contractor. Kowalsky said he felt obliged to cooperate in the investigation. ``We can't afford to have nuclear weapons in the hands of countries that are irresponsible,'' he said. Among those charged in the indictment were Ali Daghir, identified by British authorities as the leader of the alleged smuggling operation, and Jeanine Speckman, a French woman released on bond Thursday. Daghir was identified in the indictment as managing director of the two companies, which allegedly acted as agents for Al-Qaqaa. Speckman was named in the indictment as an export executive for Euromac and secretary of Atlas Equipment. The indictment alleges that she suggested the triggers be shipped in boxes labeled as components for air conditioning in computer rooms. Customs officials said it was unlikely the three Iraqi engineers will ever be arrested. The indictment identifies them as Karim Dhaidas Omran, Dafir Al-Azawi and Wallid Issa Ahmad. The indictment charges that a conspiracy began in September 1988, when the two British companies allegedly contacted a London representative of CSI Technologies about obtaining the detonators. Kowalsky said his 21-year-old, 35-employee company makes electrical components for use in heart defibrillators, lasers and various transmitters and also has manufactured large quantities of capacitors for use in scientific research in Iraq. He said he received a telex from his London representative in late 1988 that said the Iraqis inquired about CSI Technologies manufacturing capacitors to military specifications. They also asked if the devices could endure severe shock. ``Within a couple of minutes of seeing the telex, my blood turned cold,'' Kowalsky said. ``I told myself, `These guys are building a nuclear bomb' and I immediately called the CIA and Customs Service.'' Customs agent Daniel Supnick, posing as a CSI executive, joined negotiations last fall with Daghir and Speckman, the indictment said. The indictment charged that the defendants did not seek export licenses as required by U.S. law after ordering the detonators from CSI Technologies. The company is based in San Marcos, Calif., about 40 miles north of San Diego. The defendants also are charged with money laundering, arising from the transfer of $10,400 from Britain to CSI's account with the Bank of America in Escondido, Calif., to pay for the detonators. U.S. Attorney William Braniff in San Diego said Speckman and Daghir would be prosecuted in Britain first before they could be extradited to the United States to face charges.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Drop More Than 1,000 Points in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today dropped more than 1,000 points in a market dominated by profit-taking and discouragement, while the dollar surged against the yen. The market's key index, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, lost 1,045.71 points, or 3.37 percent, in the market's seventh largest single-day decline. It ended the week at 29,981.45. The Nikkei fell 237.41 points Thursday. Securities dealers said prices fell on selling across the board due to a decline in the value of the yen against the dollar and an overnight fall on Wall Street. Brokerages remained on the sidelines because ``they knew that if they bought, they'd only be battered by heavy selling,'' said Yoshihiro Ito, general manager of stock trading at Okasan Securities. Wide expectations of a further weakening of the yen also sapped buying interest, said Shin Tokoi, deputy general manager of stock trading at County NatWest Securities. Volume was a relatively light 500 million shares. In currency dealings, the dollar rebounded to close at 157.65 yen, up 1.00 yen from Thursday's close of 156.65 yen. After opening at 156.80 yen, the currency ranged between 156.75 yen and 157.95 yen. It surged sharply higher at midday under what some dealers described as suspicious circumstances. Numerous dealers, Japanese and foreign, said a sudden rise to almost 158 yen smacked of collusion among the small number of banks involved in fixing the year-end rate, which was set at 158 yen. The banks involved appeared to have bid the dollar up to lock in windfall profits, they said. An official at the Bank of Japan said the central bank was considering investigating inquiries about the dollar's sudden rise. The year-end rate is used by many firms as a benchmark exchange rate. The dollar has been advancing against the yen for several weeks as Japanese corporations bought the currency, amid general pessimism about the yen, to help improve their balance sheets at the close of their fiscal year. On Thursday, the yen made a brief recovery in Tokyo after rebounding in New York Wednesday following intervention by the U.S. Federal Reserve. But most dealers saw the recovery as temporary. They said strong demand for dollars due to an outflow of capital from Japan is the single largest factor pushing the dollar's value higher against the yen. ``The demand for the dollar is very big,'' said a dealer at a long-term credit bank. The price of benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bond fell to 85.95 points as of 3 p.m., down from Thursday's close of 86.72, as banks sold off bond holdings. The yield rose to 7.36 percent from the previous day's close of 7.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: `Beauty and the Beast' Comes to Cable, Syndication
DOC.TEXT: ``Beauty and the Beast,'' canceled by CBS earlier this TV season despite its avid cult following, will return both to cable and syndicated television. The drama, about a Shakespeare-quoting subterranean brute and his love interest with a prosecutor, will make its debut on cable's The Family Channel come fall, Republic Pictures said Thursday. The package will feature three never-seen original episodes. The 56-episode package featuring Ron Perlman and Linda Hamilton will go into syndication next year, said Republic, a producer and distributor of TV programs. The show already has been sold into syndication to stations in New York, Dallas, Miami, Chicago, Boston, Houston, Philadelphia, Cleveland, Phoenix and Detroit, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: `If I'm Driving Irresponsibly, Call My Parents'
DOC.TEXT: Teen-agers caught speeding in this western New Mexico city can put the brakes on paying a ticket if they put a special bumper sticker on their car. Stickers that say, ``If I'm Driving Irresponsibly, Call My Parents,'' are part of a Municipal Court program started last month. ``It could be a deterrent to poor driving,'' Municipal Court Judge Russell Muffley said. ``Children could say they don't want one of those bumper stickers, so they'll drive a little more carefully. We're just trying to get teen-agers to slow down a little bit.'' The stickers stay on for 60 days. With the sticker alternative, citations are deferred. ``We're doing this with the blessings of the parents. If the parents have reservations and don't want this on the car for one reason or another, we won't do it,'' Muffley said. ``So far the response has been very good. ``I've had one parent who didn't want it on the car. But the rest have said, `Put it on there.' They are concerned.'' Muffley said judges Texas and elsewhere in New Mexico have called him for information about the program.

DOC.HEAD: JAMA Publishing Earlier to Get Jump on New England Journal of Medicine
DOC.TEXT: Even though the nation's most widely circulated medical journal is leap-frogging its New England-based rival to publish earlier in the week, the rival's editor pooh-poohed any threat to his publication. ``We're more academic. We publish the great majority of the scientific advances in medical research,'' said Dr. Arnold Relman, editor of the New England Journal of Medicine. ``We have always done that, and I believe we will continue to do so.'' Relman's Boston-based journal publishes on Thursdays. The Chicago-based Journal of the American Medical Association, which published on Fridays, will change its release date to Wednesdays next week. ``Improved production capabilities and the desire to publish important research findings as quickly as possible'' are the two top reasons for the change, JAMA says. It also wants to give news reporters more time at week's end to develop spinoff stories. But ``if you read the (AMA) press release carefully, they want to come out first,'' before the New England Journal of Medicine, Relman said Wednesday. ``I can't understand any other reason, beyond the obvious competitive one,'' he added in a telephone interview. Dr. George Lundberg, JAMA's editor, acknowledged in a news release announcing the change last month, ``I want JAMA to be poised to be able to publish new research findings before other medical and scientific journals.'' But Lundberg maintained on Thursday that competition is a lesser motive. Articles that appear each week in the New England journal and in JAMA are independent of each other, though they do cover overlapping subjects sometimes, Lundberg said. In such instances, ``we would prefer our authors to have an earlier publication date than theirs,'' he said. ``We at JAMA value media coverage greatly because one of our basic missions is to educate the public to lead healthier lives.'' Mark Bricklin, editor of Prevention magazine, said JAMA ``is more like the USA Today of medical journals. It's not as arcane. If there's an article in JAMA, it's apt to have a much greater application to the practicing physician.'' Both journals are heavily covered by the media, and their release dates have more to do with determining when their contents reach airwaves and newspapers than when they reach physicians. JAMA, published by the nation's largest organization of doctors, has a regular English-language circulation of 293,000, including the AMA's more than 290,000 members. The journal also has 290,000 copies going overseas each week in 12 languages, Lundberg said. The 178-year-old New England journal, the nation's oldest medical journal, is published by the Massachusetts Medical Society. It has a circulation of about 230,000, including 10,000 society members and about 50,000 overseas subscribers, Relman said. Statistics support Relman's claim to greater prestige, according to the Philadelphia-based Institute for Scientific Information, which tracks how many times articles in 3,200 journals are subsequently cited in published research. ``In 1988, out of these 3,200 journals (the institute tracks worldwide), the New England journal ranked seventh,'' said editor David Pendlebury. He said the six top finishers were non-medical journals, adding, ``The British (medical) journal Lancet ranked 17th, the Annals of Internal Medicine ranked 39th and JAMA was 86th.'' The New England journal also carries the ``hottest'' articles, Pendlebury said Thursday. A study about a year ago indicated that the 100 most-cited articles in life sciences in the previous year included nine from the New England journal and three from JAMA. ``We don't feel threatened by a change in their publication day,'' Relman said. ``It seems to me that the content of what is published is vastly more important than the day of the week on which it is published.'' Dr. Aran Ron, assistant to the medical director at Beth Israel Medical Center in New York City, and a reader of both journals, agreed, though for different reasons. ``I think that JAMA has more general interest-type articles and covers ground a little wider, while the the New England journal has more scientific, specialty and in-depth articles,'' Ron said. ``I don't perceive a big competition.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Rather than waving his veto pen, our president should match his warm words with good deeds and agree to sign our child-care bill.'' _ House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., following House approval of a plan that is more ambitious and expensive than the White House version of the bill.

``It's very tense. It could erupt again at any time. It's a terrible situation.'' _ Police Maj. Piet Kitching on black violence that has left at least 36 dead and hundreds wounded since Tuesday in South Africa's Natal Province.

``We can't afford to have nuclear weapons in the hands of countries that are irresponsible.'' _ Jerold Kowalsky, president of CSI Technologies Inc., who alerted U.S. agents to inquiries from alleged Iraqi representatives into his company, a manufacturer of nuclear warhead detonators.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Approves $31.2 Billion Budget Amid Protests
DOC.TEXT: The Parliament approved this year's budget today and tripled funding for religious parties, which have held the balance of power since the government fell after a no-confidence vote earlier this month. One legislator called Israel's leaders ``thieves in the night,'' for earmarking $110 million of the $31.2 billion budget for religious insitutions. The funding was put forward by the right-wing Likud bloc headed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. Shimon Peres' center-left Labor Party backed the move. Both parties need the backing of the small ultra-Orthodox factions to break the 60-60 parliamentary tie that arose after the no-confidence motion. Shamir is caretaker prime minister while Peres tries to form a government. Both Likud and Labor have wooed religious parties with offers of political jobs and funds for religious seminaries. The amount allocated to religious institutions in the 1990-91 fiscal year budget almost tripled last year's funding of $37.5 million. The budget was approved 40-10, with eight abstentions, after a heated debate that stretched more than 40 hours. The remaining 62 legislators did not show up to vote. The deadline for passage of the budget was Saturday. Likud and Labor also joined forces to push through $2.5 million for party-affiliated institutions and $10 million was added to the budget for Jewish settlements in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Before the budget debate, Haim Oron of the socialist Mapam Party criticized the moves by major parties to woo the religious factions. ``The expression `theives in the night' is not slander, it is not a bad term for the Parliament. It is a minimal description in polite words of what is going on,'' he said. Likud Justice Minister Dan Meridor said the budget suffered because of the political crisis. ``This budget has things that perhaps in an ordinary period could have been refrained from. We couldn't refrain from them all today,'' he said on Israel radio. But Yair Levy, a legislator of the six-seat ultra-Orthodox Shas party, was encouraged: ``Today we can say we have started the process of reducing the gaps between ultra-Orthodox education and regular schooling,'' he said on Israel radio. Israelis protested the higher funding for insitutions belonging to ultra-Orthodox Jews. Labor Party supporters, dressed in ultra-Orthodox fashion, with black hats and side curls, demonstrated outside Labor headquarters in Tel Aviv. They called on party leaders to stop bowing to religious parties, Israel radio reported. Peres has five more weeks to put together a colation and he said he will push for early elections for the 120-member Parliament if he fails, rather than give Likud an opportunity to establish a government. The coalition negotiations began after Shamir was toppled by a no- confidence motion in Parliament over his refusal to accept U.S.-backed Middle East peace proposals, which were supported by Labor.

DOC.HEAD: Severed Pig's Head Left On Jewish Councillor's Seat
DOC.TEXT: A severed pig's head wrapped in an Israeli flag was placed on the seat of a Jewish town councilman before a council meeting, a newspaper reported today. The Citizen newspaper said the incident took place Thursday night in the town of Boksburg outside Johannesburg. Independent councilman Issy Kramer, the target of the attack, expressed shock over the incident, the report said. Boksburg has attracted international attention because it is controlled by the pro-apartheid opposition Conservative Party. The Boksburg council has been fighting to keep strict apartheid despite opposition by the governing National Party. Jewish leaders have expressed concern about a recent wave of anti-Semitic incidents in South Africa that they have blamed on neo-Nazi groups.

DOC.HEAD: Hillary Warns Against Ecological Destruction of Himalayas
DOC.TEXT: Sir Edmund Hillary, who with his Sherpa guide was the first to reach the top of the world's highest mountain, today warned the majestic Himalayas were threatened by deforestation and litterbug trekkers. Recalling the remote valleys and foothills he traveled before his 1953 ascent to the top of Mount Everest, the 70-year-old New Zealander said: ``In 1951, the people lived a simple, hardy existence. Few of them had ever seem a railroad train or a bus. Tourism was unknown. ``Nowadays, tens of thousands are walking the hills tracks, floating down the rivers, landing in tiny airstrips in remote valleys. ... The living standards (of the Himalayan people) are increasing, but the beautiful tracks and valleys have been littered and the forests destroyed.'' He spoke at the opening session of the First International Conference on Environmental Protection of the Himalayas. The two-day conference is sponsored by the Himalayan Adventure Trust, which Hillary helped found two years ago, and by the Indian Mountaineering Foundation. Hillary, who reached the top of Mount Everest in Nepal on May 29, 1953, with Sherpa guide Tenzing Norgay, said tourism in the Himalayas must be spread more thinly and visitors must take their trash with them when they leave. ``Tourist agents must be pressured to make sure their customers leave the hills and valleys beautiful,'' he said. He said huge population increases have sent more farmers into the Himalayas in search of survival. ``The local people are forced higher and higher to cut trees and make terraces for their crops. When will it ever stop?'' he asked. Maneka Gandhi, India's minister of state for environment and forests, warned deforestation and pollution would have disastrous results reaching far beyond the Himalayan highlands. ``Today the Himalayas are crumbling,'' said Mrs. Gandhi, the sister-in-law of ex-Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. ``The disappearance of the Himalayas will mean the desertification of India and neighboring areas. We have to preserve the Himalayas or we perish.'' She said the new government of Prime Minister V.P. Singh, whose Janata Dal coalition ousted Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party in last November's elections, was considering a $175 million plan ``to re-green the Himalayas.''

DOC.HEAD: Rain Along East Coast, Fog in South
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell early today along the East Coast, and fog shrouded a swath of the South and parts of the Midwest. Snow fell in Denver early today, and the mountains of northern New Mexico, southeastern Utah and northwestern Arizona were expected to get accumulations. Rain fell in Little Rock, Ark. Drizzle was reported in parts of the South, including Charlestons, S.C., Macon, Ga., and Richmond, Va. Detroit also had drizzle. Along the East Coast, rain fell early today in New York City, Philadelphia and Washington, D.C. Fog stretched across much of the South, with the thick mist reported in Atlanta, Jacksonville, Fla., Nashville, Tenn. and St. Louis. It also was reported at Cincinnati, Chicago, Des Moines, Iowa, Indianapolis, Kansas City and Omaha, Neb. On Thursday, rain fell across much of the South, and parts of the Midwest and the Mid-Atlantic states. Tornadoes touched down at three towns near Houston. No injuries were reported but the storms left damage. There were also unconfirmed reports of tornadoes late Thursday in Louisiana, but the National Weather Service said some probably were very strong wind gusts. Thunderstorms produced golfball-sized hail, wind gusts up to 75 mph and dropped five inches of rain at Port O'Conner, Texas. The nation's high on Thursday was 88 degrees at Lakeland, Fla. Marie 32 cloudy; San Antonio 62 cloudy. _WEST: Albuquerque 38 showery; Anchorage 38 partly cloudy; Boise 38 fair; Casper 31 fair; Fairbanks 30 cloudy; Great Falls 38 fair; Honolulu 69 fair; Las Vegas 55 partly cloudy; Los Angeles 54 cloudy; Medford 42 fair; Pendleton 43 fair; Phoenix 55 cloudy; Portland, Ore., 45 fair; Reno 33 fair; Salt Lake City 37 fair; San Diego 55 cloudy; San Francisco 49 fair; Seattle 45 fair; Spokane 42 fair. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 41 fair; Montreal 19 fair; Ottawa 21 fair; Regina 34 fair; Toronto 34 snow; Winnipeg 36 foggy; Acapulco 75 fair; San Juan 70 fair.

DOC.HEAD: Leader of Art Deco Preservation Movement Dies
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Baer Capitman, a leader in the art deco preservation movement whose stubbornness and media savvy helped save hundreds of Miami Beach's historic hotels, has died of heart failure. She was 69. Ms. Capitman, who suffered from diabetes and heart tremors, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Medical Center, where she had been a patient for several days, hospital spokesman Arthur Ehrlich said. A diminutive woman with a quavery voice, she used her public relations know-how and her love of architecture to capitalize on renewed interest nationwide in art deco buildings. Ms. Capitman's outspoken nature may have been the key to her success, but it made her enemies as well. In 1976 she helped found the Miami Design Preservation League, which won federal historic designation for the South Beach district in 1979, but later she was ousted from the group. ``I don't know where it says you have to compromise,'' she told The Miami Herald in an interview Monday. ``It's been a struggle, but the struggle isn't over.'' In 1988, police had to carry her off the steps of the Senator Hotel when it was demolished to make way for a parking lot. She was hospitalized that day. ``She would push and agitate and cause trouble until half the people wouldn't speak to her. She was interested in results, not social sensitivities,'' said Michael Kinerk, a close friend and chairman of the Art Deco Weekend festival. The preservation league had to overcome opposition from the city manager and chamber of commerce to get the South Beach district listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It's the only district with 20th century architecture on the register. The historic status brought federal tax breaks to the economically depressed area, now in the midst of an economic and cultural renaissance that even Ms. Capitman's harshest critics credit to the movement she began. ``It was a tremendous achievement by one person, one little old lady,'' her son Andrew said Thursday. ``Barbara Capitman deserves her reputation as the indomitable champion of the art deco treasures of Miami Beach,'' said billionaire investor Robert Bass, chairman of the National Trust for Historic Preservation. She also helped found chapters of the Art Deco Society in New York, Washington, D.C., Chicago, San Francisco and Los Angeles. President of the Art Deco Society of American, she was organizing the first World Congress on Art Deco when she died. It was to be held next February during the city's Art Deco Weekend, a festival that drew 420,000 people this year. She also was working on a book about the origin and resurgence of art deco, titled ``Art Deco U.S.A.'' Her book on the history of Miami Beach's district, titled ``Deco Delights,'' was published in 1989. Art deco, a sleek, elegant style associated with wealth and sophistication, took hold as the nation entered the Depression. Radio City Music Hall and the Chrysler building in New York are some of the best examples of art deco's geometric shapes and streamlined forms.

DOC.HEAD: Sampling in Soviet Union Finds Anti-Semitic Element
DOC.TEXT: A recent sampling of Moscow residents shows more than half of them could be mobilized by anti-Semites, the American Jewish Committee says. Committee President Sholom D. Comay told reporters Thursday the survey indicates a significant part of the Soviet population openly dislikes Jews, holds negative stereotypes about them or ``is at best neutral about Jews and thus open to manipulation.'' The sampling of 509 adults during February and March found 18 percent indicated they disliked Jews, 65 percent indicated they were neutral and 18 percent indicated they liked Jews. The 65 percent who were neutral about Jews are ``open to manipulation by enemies of Jews'' and likely ``can be mobilized by anti-Semites,'' committee research director David Singer said. ``History teaches that Jews are secure only when people have genuinely positive feelings toward them,'' he said. ``It is not enough that people be non-anti-Semitic.'' The committee called on President Mikhail Gorbachev and the Soviet leadership to ``condemn manifestations of anti-Semitism.'' Of those surveyed, 91 percent said, ``Jews should be free to decide for themselves whether they want to remain in the Soviet Union or emigrate.'' And 90 percent agreed that the ``government should make every effort to see that the rights of Jews to equal educational opportunities are respected'' and 88 percent favored equal employment opportunities for Jews. The study was conducted under the auspices of the Institute of Sociology of the Soviet Academy of Sciences and directed by political scientists James Gibson and Raymond Duch of the University of Houston. The study, funded by the committee, the National Science Foundation and the University of Houston, involved questions on 350 items. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percentage points. Other findings included: _Thirty-three percent maintained that ``when it comes to choosing between people and money, Jews will choose money.'' Twenty-nine percent were uncertain and 38 percent disagreed. _Twenty-three percent agreed that ``Jews have too much influence over Russian culture,'' while 21 percent were uncertain and 56 percent disagreed. _Ten percent felt that ``Jews deserved to be punished because they killed Christ,'' while 15 percent were uncertain, and 75 percent disagreed. _Eight percent agreed that Jews, more than any other group, ``are responsible for the problems the Soviet Union is experiencing today.'' Thirteen percent were uncertain and 79 percent disagreed. Concerning views about other people's anti-Semitism, 48 percent said that ``anti-Jewish feeling is on the rise around here today,'' while 44 percent termed it ``about the same.'' Only 5 percent saw it diminishing. Seventeen percent said ``most people in the Soviet Union are anti-Jewish,'' 60 percent said ``only some people are anti-Jewish'' and 19 percent said ``very few people are anti-Jewish.''

DOC.HEAD: At Least Two Killed As Cease-Fire Collapses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with casualties; pickup 5th pvs, `Police said...'
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian militias today renewed savage combat in east Beirut and in hills northeast of the city, ending a nearly monthlong cease-fire. Police said two people were killed. Thunderous blasts reverberated across Beirut and black clouds of smoke hung over the city and nearby hills as fires burned out of control. Thousands of families huddled in basements and underground shelters and radios blared hospital appeals for blood donations. At least two people were killed and one person wounded in the clashes, police said. The patriarch of the Maronite Church today threatened to excommunicate both Gen. Michel Aoun and rival Christian warlord Samir Geagea, whose struggle for domination of Lebanon's Christian enclave has killed at least 778 people and wounded 2,157 since Jan. 30. Police said Aoun's army and Geagea's Lebanese Gorces militia were locked in combat in the central sector of Christian east Beirut and in the mountains of Kesrouan province, 20 miles northeast of the capital. ``The cease-fire has collapsed. It's past history,'' said a police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing rules. ``It's all-out war again.'' The police spokesman said no casualty report could be compiled yet, ``but there are indications there are plenty of killed and wounded people.'' The warring factions accused each other of torpedoing a March 3 cease-fire called by neutral Christian mediators to halt the power struggle, the most savage intra-Christian fighting in the 15-year-old Lebanese civil war. Aoun's army command said that Geagea's Lebanese Forces launched tank-led thrusts on two fronts at first light to break through army lines in Beirut's Christian sector and the mountains in Kesrouan province. ``Both assaults were repulsed. The attackers suffered heavy losses in lives and equipment in east Beirut's Badaro district and Kesrouan's Kleiat-Dareya axis,'' said a communique from Aoun's command. A Lebanese Forces communique said Aoun's tanks and armored personnel carriers were mounting charges from east Beirut into the resort town of Kleiat behind massive artillery bombardment in an attempt to open the way for his troops to capture Kesrouan. ``The Lebanese Forces are preventing Aoun's units from accomplishing their objectives although they are using phosphorous and cluster bombs,'' the communique said. The militia's chief spokesman, George Abdul-Massih, later told The Associated Press the Lebanese Forces pushed Aoun's army ``almost completely'' out of Kleiat and were advancing towrds the nearby town of Dareya. Before the outbreak of the new fighting, Aoun's army held a quarter of Kleiat. The rest was under Lebanese Forces control. As the fighting escalated, Aoun's and Geagea's radio stations canceled their regular programs to broadcast only martial music, patriotic songs and war communiques. Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, spiritual head of the dominant Maronite Catholic community of which both Aoun and Geagea are members, made his excommmunication threat at midmorning from his seat in Bkirki, which overlooks the Mediterranean. It was his second since the fighting began. ``This horrific, destructive shelling which the army and the Lebanese Forces blame on each other .... has forced people to flee their homes and take shelter in forests,'' Sfeir said in the appeal that was broadcast by Christian radio stations. ``How dare they claim they are defending Christian land while they are turning it into scorched earth?'' Sfeir added. Aoun's 19,000 troops and Geagea's 6,000-member militia are fighting for control of the enclave where Lebanon's estimated 1 million Christians live. Aoun has refused to recognize the authority of elected President Elias Hrawi and has ignored his dismissal as army commander. Aoun, Geagea and Hrawi are all Maronites, the 900,000-strong Catholic sect that has dominated government since Lebanon's independence from France in 1943. Hrawi was elected president by Parliament to implement political reforms designed to give Moslems an equal share of power and end the civil war. That was part of an Arab League-brokered peace treaty endorsed by Lebanon's parliament in October. Aoun rejects that accord because it does not guarantee the withdrawal of the 40,000-member Syrian force, which he considers an army of occupation. Aoun considers them an army of occupation.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Apologize For the Death of Three Children In Ambush
DOC.TEXT: Communist rebels apologized today for killing three children and wounding civilians during attacks on two buses in the central Philippines. The attacks took place Saturday in Bongabon on the eastern coast of Mindoro island, 130 miles southeast of Manila, according to a handwritten statement from the Lucio de Guzman Command of the Communist New People's Army. ``We are asking for forgiveness for the killing and wounding of innocent civilians in a fight that we initiated,'' said the statement delivered to The Associated Press. ``We are promising these tragic incidents will not happen again.'' The statement said the deaths could have been prevented had the bus drivers refused to carry armed soldiers. The New People's Army has been waging a 21-year-old insurgency to establish a Marxist state in the Philippines. The guerrilla group said the children died inside one of the buses after an officer locked the door, forcing civilians to jump out the windows. Many of the 18 wounded were caught in the cross-fire, the statement said. In the second ambush, a soldier killed a rebel before the vehicle sped away, according to the statement. The military has said the rebel offensive was to mark the group's 21st anniversary Thursday. At least 85 people have died in violence nationwide during the week-old offensive.

DOC.HEAD: 3 Bills Stemming From Nation's Worst Drunk Driving Accident Fail in Kentucky
DOC.TEXT: State lawmakers failed to pass three bills stemming from the nation's worst drunken-driving accident. ``It's just a sad day for Kentucky that we can't get them through,'' said Sen. Virgil Pearman, whose nephew was the church bus driver killed with 26 other people in the fiery crash. The bills _ which would have toughened drunken-driving laws, added a left-side door to school buses and created a felony crime of vehicular homicide when a drunken driver caused traffic deaths _ effectively were defeated Thursday. Pearman said his advocacy of bills on other major state issues _ local control of solid waste and community health systems _ may have hurt the highway safety measures. ``Maybe I was shoving too much too fast on some hot topics,'' said Pearman, a Democrat. The bills cleared the Senate with little or no opposition but stalled in House committees during the final days of the 1990 legislative session. As a result, the legislature passed no bills directly related to the May 1988 crash. A pickup truck slammed into a church bus on Interstate 71 near Carrollton in northern Kentucky, killing 24 children and three adults returning from a church outing. Larry Mahoney was driving drunk when his pickup, on the wrong side of the highway, crashed head-on into the bus. Mahoney was convicted of manslaughter, assault, wanton endangerment and drunken driving, and was sentenced to 16 years in prison. He is appealing the case. Pearman's nephew, John, 37, was the bus driver. He died trying to save his passengers. His uncle believed the national attention given the crash and Mahoney's trial would help the legislation he backed. ``I thought it was possible with all the publicity,'' Pearman said. ``I'm devastated that the things are all dead. ``But that's the way the system works. You never know. I've been here for 15 years and I've had my ups and downs. This is just one of the down years.'' The drunken-driving bill would have made it illegal to drive with a certain blood-alcohol level. Kentucky is one of just a handful of states not to have such wording in their drunken-driving law. Instead, drivers in the state are merely presumed to be drunk when their blood-alcohol reading reaches .10 percent; critics say such wording makes it easier for people accused of drunken driving to avoid convictions. Another key section would have allowed the revocation of a driver's license before the trial of some people charged with DUI. That section had raised concerns from some Democratic House leaders. ``If you lose your driver's license ... and you live in a remote area of my couty, you don't have a mass transit system to get to work,'' said House Majority Leader Greg Stumbo.

DOC.HEAD: $510 Million Lawsuit Filed In Wake Of Social Club Fire
DOC.TEXT: An illegal social club served alcohol without a license to an already-drunk man who is accused of killing 87 people when he torched the place, a $510 million lawsuit says. The lawsuit was filed Thursday as relatives and friends of victims held funerals and wakes, and as the accused, Julio Gonzalez, appeared in Bronx Criminal Court for a hearing. About 1,000 mourners gathered Thursday night outside Ortiz Funeral Home in the Bronx for the wakes of six victims of the Happy Land Social Club fire. ``We want justice,'' said Edith Melendez, the girlfriend of Luis Drummond, who died in the fire Sunday. ``Give him (Gonzalez) to us. We could take him to the park, pour some gasoline on him like he did to our family and friends.'' The suit was filed in Bronx state Supreme Court, New York's trial-level court, by attorney Harry Lipsig on behalf of Jennie Mae Danzler, mother of another fire victim, 31-year-old Natalie Danzler. The suit names as defendants the social club itself; Clarendon Place Corp., owner of the premises; Little Peach Realty, lessee; Alex DiLorenzo III, Jay Weiss and Morris Jaffe, officers of Little Peach; Elena Colon, widow of club owner Elias Colon, who died in the fire; and Gonzalez. Weiss is the husband of actress Kathleen Turner. The suit seeks $10 million in compensatory damages and $500 million in punitive damages. It claims, among other things, that Happy Land served alcohol without a license and served it to Gonzalez when he already was intoxicated. Authorities Thursday continued to crack down on illegal social clubs, with more than 100 police officers transferred from the Tactical Narcotics Teams to a reactivated Social Club Task Force. The force has visited hundreds of social clubs citywide since Sunday's fire, closing about two dozen and issuing citations. Meanwhile, Criminal Court Judge Effrain Alvarado ruled Thursday at hearing over legal representation of Gonzales that the Legal Aid Society may continue as his counsel through the grand jury process. But the judge appointed lawyer Richard Berne to take over the case after that. Security was tight during the hearing. At one point, a man yelled, ``Julio, I'm going to watch you.'' The man was a friend of one of the fire victims. Gonzalez, a 36-year-old Cuban emigre, was arrested Sunday and charged with 87 counts of murder through depraved indifference, 87 counts of felony murder, and one count of attempted murder and arson. He allegedly set the fire after a fight with his ex-girlfriend, who worked at the club. Mayor David Dinkins on Thursday contested a published report that his director of Latino Affairs, William Nieves, had operated an illegal social club. Dinkins said the establishment, called El Caney, was really a cultural center. He acknowledged the site had been cited for building and fire code violations and should have been closed. Members of the City Council grilled top city officials about the fire Thursday during a meeting of the council's Public Safety Committee. They demanded to know why Happy Land was not padlocked after the city discovered it was operating illegally and unsafely. Fire and buildings department officials said the law was unclear whether a building could be padlocked without a hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Sources: Army Kills Ten Moslem Separatists on Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with 10 Moslems killed, CORRECTS Moslem leader's second name, number killed in valley. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Indian army shot and killed 10 Moslem separatists trying to slip into Pakistan-held territory today, sources said. In Srinagar, the center of the Moslem movement for secession from India, a leader of the movement was killed in a clash with police, authorities said. The battle along the India-Pakistan border occurred when militant Moslems fired on Indian soldiers who had spotted them trying to cross from the Indian-governed side of Kashmir, official sources said on condition of anonymity. The sources, speaking from Jammu, the winter capital of Jammu-Kashmir state, said the 12 surviving militants were arrested. The clash occurred near Dumari Gali, 45 miles north of Srinagar. In Srinagar, a leader of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front was killed by police as he attempted to throw a hand grenade into a police bunker, police said. A blast of automatic weapons fire from the bunker killed Ashfaq Majid Wani, the front's area commander, police said. Three other people died in the gunfire, witnesses and police said. Police sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Wani was killed as he drove by the bunker on a motor scooter, preparing to throw a grenade into the bunker in downtown Srinagar. Police said security forces in the bunker spotted him and opened fire. Wani, 28, was a senior official in the Moslem movement for secession of the northern Kashmir valley from mainly Hindu India. At least 231 people have been killed in the valley since Jan. 20, when the government launched a crackdown on the Moslem separatist movement. On Thursday, police killed at least 15 people in bursts of automatic weapons fire after a security officer was killed in a grenade attack. Earlier this week, Indian border guards shot and killed two Pakistani civilians when a crowd of about 100 people in Pakistan, chanting anti-Indian slogans, tried to storm the frontier that divides Kashmir into its Indian and Pakistani sections. India has accused Moslem Pakistan of causing the trouble in Kashmir, a region disputed between the two countries. Pakistan rejects the charge but demands that the people of Kashmir be given the right of self-determination. Pakistan and India have fought two wars over the territory. Both were won by India. A cease-fire line monitored by the United Nations divides the valley. The separatist movement in Kashmir has been a thorn in India's side since the end of British rule over the South Asian subcontinent and the division of Britain's colony into Hindu-majority India and Islamic Pakistan.

DOC.HEAD: Violinist Trades Life Underground for Highbrow Night at Lincoln Center
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Graseck, 36,...', to add that violinist expects to make profit. Fixes spelling of `paid' in 5th graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY10
DOC.TEXT: The place was highbrow, a concert hall at Lincoln Center, but the crowd was more used to seeing violinist James Graseck underground. Graseck has been entertaining commuters in subways for more than 20 years and used some of the coins tossed his way to throw a concert Thursday night for his straphanger fans. ``Elaine, from the World Trade Center stop! Good to see you,'' Graseck said, hugging one commuter after the classical performance at Alice Tully Hall. He waved to another, saying, ``Bob, I'll see you at the Long Island Railroad, OK?'' The hall was sold out by 1,096 people who paid $16 each. They clapped, hummed along and even shouted ``Ole!'' as Graseck played a program of Bach, Paganini and Schubert. ``I don't like classical music. I just like Jimmy,'' said Joe Abrams, a transit policeman who knows Graseck from Penn Station and brought his wife to the concert. Graseck, 36, saved $5,000 to rent the hall, partly from money he earned in subways and trains. With few other expenses for the concert and the sellout crowd Thursday, he stands to make a profit, he said. ``It is a dream come true in a way,'' he said before his performance. Graseck grinned throughout the show and at one juncture pointed to a group seated near the stage. ``From the Flushing (Queens) line, right?'' he asked. He ended with a dozen encores, classical excerpts running just three to five minutes each _ about the time one has to wait for a train. ``I learned these playing you-know-where,'' Graseck told the audience. He is a classically trained violinist who studied at Juilliard. Graseck's initial mass transit performance came in 1968 on a Long Island Railroad car headed for Brentwood, Graseck said. He made $10 in five minutes, and a star was born. ``At first I did it just for the money,'' he confessed. ``But the applause, the smiles, made me feel as though I was reaching the hearts of people. It's very spontaneous, very communicative.'' These days, a subway performer can make about $100 a day, said Graseck, who also does free-lance orchestra work. His favorite platform is at 53rd Street and Lexington Avenue, where concertgoer John Welch met him. ``I was amazed at his talent,'' Welch said. ``People miss their trains sometimes, listening to him.'' Tim Frost, who also attended the concert, said commuting is more than just commuting with Graseck around. ``Culture isn't just going to Lincoln Center,'' Frost said. ``It's also hearing him at the top of the escalator every Friday morning when I get off the No. 7 train in Grand Central.'' Lillian Binder said she's not the only one in her office to appreciate the violinist. ``One time I was late to work and told my boss, I'm sorry, I was listening to this guy in the subway play `Scheherazade,''' she said. ``My boss said, `I know that guy. He's great.'''

DOC.HEAD: East German Party Leader Examines His Secret Police Files
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with leader of Social Democrats examining files kep on him by former secret police. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The leader of one of East Germany's top political parties got a first-hand look today at files kept on him by the despised secret police, knowing his career hangs in the balance by what is revealed. Ibrahim Boehme, chairman of the left-leaning Social Democratic Party and one of the country's most charismatic politicians, has been wrestling with allegations that he was an informer for the now-disbanded secret police. The Social Democrats, who placed second in East Germany's March 18 elections, are in crucial negotiations with the winning conservative coalition about forming a ``grand coalition'' government. Boehme has denied allegations he had links to the Stasi secret police. He temporarily stepped down from the party chairman post last week, saying he wanted his name cleared. He demanded access to the records kept on him. Today, accompanied by two lawyers, Boehme entered the sprawling former secret police building in East Berlin to view the files. Wolfgang Schlauer, a member of a citizens committee controlling disbandment of the secret police, told reporters it could take several hours before Boehme reads through material compiled on him. Meanwhile, committees of the Social Democrats and the winning Christian Democratic Union met separately to discuss a possible coalition and organization of East Germany's first freely elected government. The process of forming the government has been overshadowed by allegations that many members of the new 400-member parliament worked with the Stasi. Among them is Lothar de Maiziere, the Christian Democratic chairman, who has also denied any links with the secret police. Despite the allegations, de Maiziere has said he hopes the new Parliament can convene next week. Outgoing Parliament Speaker Guenther Maleuda on Thursday also said he wants the Parliament to convene quickly to stabilize the drifting nation. Maleuda met with newly elected members of Parliament and recommended that the body hold its first session on April 5, the state news agency ADN said. The lawmakers elected in East Germany's first free elections March 18 have been bogged down in talks on forming a governing coalition that will determine the pace for unification with West Germany. But ADN said Maleuda, who leads the lame-duck Parliament that contains vestiges of the old Communist regime, wants new lawmakers to meet soon to give the nation some stability and leadership. After hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker was toppled Oct. 18 during massive nationwide demonstrations, the country has been run by a reform-minded interim government dominated by the Communists, who have little public support. Meanwhile, the two leading political factions of the new leadership said Thursday that they agreed on the basic points of forming a majority coalition. De Maiziere is trying to form a government with the Social Democrats. The groups said in a joint statement that they ``concurred on most basic points,'' and that their differences ``are negotiable.'' A coalition with the Social Democrats would give de Maziere the two-thirds majority he needs to control Parliament and muscle through his proposal for swift unification with wealthy West Germany. But the Social Democrats have expressed concern about whether they can work with the more conservative members of de Maiziere's three-party alliance. The Social Democrats also favor a more gradual process for unification than the conservatives. ``We are of the opinion that the situation we must negotiate, and the responsibility we have, is so serious, that we must each discuss it with our governing bodies,'' de Maiziere told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Franciscans Close Probe Into Sex Allegations Against Ritter
DOC.TEXT: The Franciscan religious order concluded an inquiry into allegations of sexual impropriety against the Rev. Bruce Ritter, and announced no results except a request that the founder of Covenant House live in a friary. ``It was a private investigation,'' the Rev. Juniper Alwell, a Franciscan provincial council official, said Thursday. ``The results are private. ... That's as far as we're going to go.'' Alwell said the Roman Catholic order conducted its investigation with no help from outside professionals and did not intend to act like a prosecutor. But the Franciscans will cooperate with civil authorities looking into other questions raised recently about a Covenant House charitable trust, the council said in a statement. Ritter, 62, resigned Feb. 27 as director of Covenant House, the shelter for runaway youths he founded and built into an $85 million-a-year international operation. The council said his resignation came ``with the prior knowledge and urging of his superiors.'' Four young men, runaways whom Ritter befriended, have been quoted as saying they had sex with him. The New York Times today quoted an anonymous church official as saying he expected Ritter to ask to leave the Franciscan order, although he might remain a priest. The order did not plan to give Ritter an assignment or ministry, the official said. In its statement, the Franciscan council said it decided Ritter should return to daily living with his Franciscan community. Ritter, who has not lived in a religious community for more than 20 years, will meet with church officials before they determine where he will go, Alwell said. Asked where Ritter was now, Alwell said: ``He did exactly what we asked him to do, which was to rest and recuperate as much as possible, remove himself from the media.'' District Attorney Robert Morgenthau has said he had found insufficient evidence of financial misconduct to charge Ritter with any crime. But Morgenthau said some ``questionable financial transactions'' had been made in connection with expenditures for Kevin Kite, a former male prostitute who alleged that Ritter had sex with him. Morgenthau also said the law may have been violated when Covenant House supplied Kite with a false identity using papers of a dead 10-year-old.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Protest Nation's New Name
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after 7th graf, `It said...' to UPDATE with petition to Slovak legislature to negotiate autonomy. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Slovaks gathered today outside the regional Parliament in Bratislava to protest the new name of the nation, the state news agency CTK reported. Some protesters called for a separate Slovak state, CTK said. The name ``Czechoslovak Federative Republic'' was adopted Thursday night after a daylong discussion in the federal Parliament and weeks of growing tensions between the Czechs and Slovaks. Deputies from the Czech lands favored the name Czechoslovak Federative Republic, while Slovak deputies wanted a hyphen in ``Czecho-Slovak Republic,'' to underline the equal status of the two constituent republics. A compromise was finally reached, allowing the Slovaks to hyphenate the country's title in writing as ``Czecho-Slovak Federative Republic.'' The protesters who gathered outside the Slovak Parliament in the southern city of Bratislava expressed their discontent with the compromise solution and called for the declaration of a sovereign Slovak state, CTK reported. It said the Slovak parliamentary chairman, Rudolf Schuster, and Deputy Jan Zelenay assured the protesters that their representatives had sought to settle the problem, which has dominated internal politics in recent weeks. Protesters read a petition to the Slovak regional parliament calling on the legislature to begin negotiations with the national parliament on the full recognition of Slovak sovereignty and autonomy, CTK reported.
