The petition claimed that the government does not recognize the existence of Slovakia, one of the country's two constituent republics. About one-third of the country's 15.5 million people are Slovaks. The country wanted to change its name, the Socialist Republic of Czechoslovakia, to eliminate the ``Socialist'' label. The term seemed outmoded following the popular uprising last year that ousted hard-line Communists and installed a non-Communist government.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Baltimore-dated 1st item in rdp, inserting 4 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, `He executed...', to to add how Neun got triple play. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Neun later...'.
DOC.TEXT: Johnny Neun, a former major-league manager and one of only nine players to execute an unassisted triple play, died Wednesday of pancreatic cancer. He was 89. Neun spent four years with the Detroit Tigers and ended his major-league career with the Boston Braves in 1931, compiling a lifetime .289 batting average. He executed his game-ending triple play on May 31, 1927, in Detroit when he was playing first base for the Tigers in a game against the Cleveland Indians. Detroit held a one-run lead in the top of the ninth when the first two Cleveland batters _ Glen Myatt and Charley Jamieson _ reached base. Homer Summa was at bat. ``Then, he (Summa) hit a line drive straight at me, and I caught it for the first out,'' Neun said in an interview with The Sun in 1964. ``Jamieson had started from first to second and was right in front of me, so I tagged him. Two out. ``I looked over and saw that Myatt was racing for third, apparently thinking Summa had got a hit. I ran over and touched second base, and the game was over,'' Neun said. Neun later managed in the New York Yankees farm system for 12 years, took over as Yankees manager temporarily in 1946 and managed the Cincinnati Reds in 1947 and 1948. He returned to the Yankees and spent 35 years with the organization, becoming a scout and player-development specialist. He also scouted for the Milwaukee Brewers until last year.

DOC.HEAD: Precede: CAMBRIDGE
Kohl Urges Poland to Acknowledge Mistreatment Of Germans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with further Kohl remarks on Poland, Polish reaction. Pickup 13th graf `Kohl and...'
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany today said a treaty confirming Poland's current borders should coincide with acknowledgment by Poland that it mistreated Germans who came under its rule after World War II. Kohl was asked at a news conference to amplify on a speech he made to an Anglo-German group in Cambridge Thursday night, in which he urged Poland to follow Czechoslovakia's example and recognize ``the injustice'' of expelling millions of Germans. In his reply, Kohl suggested that such a declaration should be made when a unified Germany signs a treaty enshrining the existing Oder-Neisse line as the legal and final German-Polish border. ``There is the question of recognition of the Oder-Neisse border, to anchor it in a treaty of a unified Germany with Poland,'' he said. ``That is a historic moment and I think it is very good thing if at such a moment one can actually find a word of reconciliation.'' He reiterated that he was not demanding an apology. He did not specify whether such a declaration should be oral or in the form of a document. Kohl's comments were seen in West Germany as a new effort to keep the German exiles and their offspring on his side in national elections Dec. 2. About 13 million Germans were expelled from prewar German territories that now are part of Poland and Czechoslovakia. In Warsaw, government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska said today that Nazi atrocities far outweighed those committed by Poles after the war, but she wanted to hear exactly what Kohl said before commenting further. She stressed at a news conference that Poles have spoken repeatedly of reconciliation. She referred to a historic 1965 letter from Polish bishops to West German church leaders which said the Poles forgave and asked forgiveness. ``We think we have made so many statements on this issue that it's clear,'' she said. Kohl recalled that Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel already has expressed remorse over the postwar expulsion of the Germans from his country. ``If between Germans and Poles we could find similar words, and we could talk to each other like that, then this is a real peace, and this is what I hope for,'' he said. The German leader was clearly aware of the sensitivity of such remarks, given Nazi atrocities in Poland during the war. On Thursday he departed from his prepared text to tone it down so as not to accuse Poland directly of mistreating the Germans. In the speech, he also stressed he was not making any demand for a Polish apology, just a recognition of ``the injustice that was also inflicted on innocent Germans.'' ``We Germans are not entitled to such words, and even less must we try to balance accounts in one way or another,'' he said. Earlier this year, Kohl had angered Poles and worried officials in other European countries by refusing to guarantee that a unified Germany would respect Poland's existing borders. Kohl made a forthright pledge last month that Germany would not seek to change the borders. One-third of Poland was German territory before the war, and Warsaw has demanded both German states promise to honor Poland's borders before uniting. Kohl and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher spoke at Cambridge University for the 40th anniversary of the Koenigswinter Conference, set up to foster Anglo-German relations five years after the defeat of Nazi Germany in 1945.

DOC.HEAD: Andrus `Agonizing' Over Abortion Bill As Self-Imposed Deadline Nears
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 6th graf pvs, `Earlier in...', to add background on slim likelihood of override. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Anti-abortion forces...'.
DOC.TEXT: As his self-imposed Saturday deadline approached, Gov. Cecil Andrus expressed reservations about some provisions of what would become the nation's most restrictive state abortion law. But he said his concern will not necessarily translate into the veto abortion rights activists have been demanding under threats of economic retaliation. ``My views being pro-life haven't changed,'' he said Thursday. ``But I am concerned about the bill. I am concerned that this bill may narrow it to the point where a woman who has suffered rape, who has suffered incest or the mother's life is in danger might not be able to receive an abortion. ... ``I'm agonizing over it.'' Another 1,000 abortion rights advocates held their ninth straight candlelight vigil on the steps of the Capitol Thursday night, continuing to press their case for a veto. Earlier in the day a smaller group dumped 10,000 potatoes on the Statehouse steps to show their support for the boycott if the bill becomes law. State lawmakers were expected to adjourn the 1990 session about midday today. If Andrus decided to veto the bill and waited until after the adjournment to do so, the Legislature would not have the chance to even consider an override. Chances for an override, which would take two-thirds majorities in each house, would be slim in any event. When the bill was passed, opponents had seven more votes than needed to block an override in the House and two more than necessary in the Senate. Anti-abortion forces tried to counter a potato boycott by pledging to buy even more Idaho products in what the Concerned Women for America said was a commitment ``to this cause out of respect for the courageous men and women in the Idaho Legislature.'' But with some Idaho businessmen reporting order cancellations because of the abortion vote, the state Commerce Department was developing contingency plans to cope with whatever decision Andrus makes on the bill. It makes abortion illegal except in cases of non-statutory rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is under 18, severe fetal deformity and a threat to the life or physical health of the woman. If signed, it will take effect July 1. Some legal scholars have said it is so restrictive it will be voided by the U.S. Supreme Court. But the National Right to Life Committee helped draft the bill so that a promised court challenge will give the high court the opportunity to reverse its 1973 decision legalizing abortion. Andrus has been consulting with legal scholars, church officials and other experts, but he said there was no consensus on the issue. Brian Johnston of the National Right to Life Committee said the governor expressed doubts on Thursday because ``the only people he had spoken with are those who actually oppose this bill.'' An aide said that later in the day the governor spoke with David Smolin of Samford University in Alabama. Smolin is the constitutional scholar anti-abortion advocates have relied on to counter the constitutional questions. Despite prospects of economic retaliation, Commerce Director James Hawkins remained confident the state, finally in the midst of an economic resurgence after suffering through harsh times during most of the 1980s, would weather any assault. ``We do have political issues in this state, but I don't know about any political streams or political potatoes,'' Hawkins said. ``What I'm worried about is people being divided. We need to bring them back together.''

DOC.HEAD: Rapist, Acquitted in `Asked For It' Case, Convicted in Separate Attack
DOC.TEXT: A rapist who won acquittal in a Florida trial when the jury thought the victim had ``asked for it'' was convicted of attempted rape in Georgia, where he already is serving a life sentence in another case. A Gwinnett County jury deliberated 25 minutes Thursday before convicting Steven Lamar Lord, 26, of Lawrenceville of attempted rape, aggravated assault, robbery and false imprisonment. He was charged with attacking a 20-year-old woman who had stopped at a gas station to use a pay telephone. Lord was acquitted of rape in Fort Lauderdale last year in a case that led to pickets and protests over the jury foreman's published comment that the victim had ``asked for it'' by wearing a lace miniskirt and no underwear. The juror later said he was quoted out of context. Gwinnett Superior Court Judge James A. Henderson sentenced Lord to 50 years in prison to be served after his life term. Lord pleaded guilty to raping a woman in DeKalb County in 1988 when she stopped to use an automatic teller machine.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa Releases Sisulu's Nephew
With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: South Africa released seven black nationalists from prison today, including the nephew of African National Congress leader Walter Sisulu. The releases raised to 42 the number of political prisoners freed from Robben Island prison since the end of an 11-day hunger strike there in early March. The strike ended after a meeting between lawyers of the 346 hunger strikers and government officials. The details of their agreement have never been made public, but the pace of releases has increased since the meeting. The ANC, the leading black anti-apartheid group, has demanded the release of all prisoners convicted of politically motivated crimes as a condition for its participation in formal negotiations on a new constitution. The prisoners freed today included five members of the ANC and two members of the Black Consciousness Movement. Among the prisoners released was Jomguzi Sisulu, 31, who was sentenced in May 1986 to five years for treason. The father of two small children said he was shocked when authorities told him Thursday he would be freed the next day. ``I couldn't believe it, it was so unexpected,'' he said. Sisulu's uncle, Walter, was freed from the same prison in October after serving 25 years of a life term for plotting sabotage to end white rule. President F.W. de Klerk will hold talks April 11 with top ANC leaders, including Nelson Mandela, to work out a framework for constitutional talks.

DOC.HEAD: New University of Maryland Chancellor Named
DOC.TEXT: Donald Langenberg, a physicist and chancellor of the University of Illinois at Chicago, will head the 11-campus University of Maryland system. A former deputy director of the National Science Foundation, Langenberg was named Thursday by the Board of Regents as chancellor of the 130,000-student university system. Langenberg ``recognizes and respects the bond between the academy and the larger community,'' regents Chairman George McGowan said at a meeting at Towson State University. The 58-year-old scholar will replace John S. Toll, also a physicist, who stepped down over disagreements with regents about his vision for the university system, formed in a 1988 reorganization of state higher education. Langenberg, who will be paid $175,000 a year, is a North Dakota native with a doctorate from the University of California at Berkeley. He also has taught at the University of Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says New Drug Can Help Spinal Injuries
DOC.TEXT: Spinal injury patients treated with a new drug recovered significantly more function than untreated patients in a clinical trial, a federal agency reported today. The National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke said that in a clinical trial of 487 patients with acute spinal cord injury, those treated with the drug methylprednisolone within eight hours of the injury recovered more motor and sensory function than those treated with other drugs or with a placebo. The study, started in 1977, was conducted at 10 U.S. medical centers. The report said that 162 patients were treated with methylprednisolone. Another 154 patients received naloxone and 171 patients received placebos. Motor and sensory functions were assessed on admission and again six weeks after treatment and finally six months after injury. The report said patients received methylprednisolone ``showed significant improvement in both muscle function and pin and touch sensation at six weeks and six months after injury,'' the announcement said. The drug must be given within eight hours of injury to be effective, the study said. The announcement said that the dose of methylprednisolone is critical and the successful dose was 30 milligrams for each kilogram of patient weight followed by an infusion of 5.4 milligrams per kilogram of weight per hour for 23 hours. Lower doses of the medication were found not to be effective. About 10,000 Americans each year suffer spinal cord injury with paralysis and the direct cost to the federal government for medical treatment for these injuries exceeds $4 billion annually.

DOC.HEAD: `Cosby Show' Returns for Seventh Season
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with published report saying deal was costliest renewal in TV history, reported value, quotes from Cosby's agent, Picks up 6th graf, `Carsey-Werner Co...'.
DOC.TEXT: ``The Cosby Show'' will return for a seventh season after NBC executives and producers of the hit series reached a deal described as the costliest renewal in TV history. NBC and producers Marcy Carsey and Tom Werner signed a one-year contract calling for 26 new episodes in the 1990-91 season, the network said Thursday. NBC refused to provide financial details of the contract, but the Los Angeles Times today cited unidentified sources as saying the deal was worth about $50 million, or roughly $2 million an episode. The producers initially sought a license fee of $3 million per episode, the Times said. The deal was signed amid widespread reports Carsey and Werner wanted an unprecedented signing bonus of up to $100 million. ``There is no bonus,'' said NBC spokesman Curt Block. ``This is a standard agreement. We're not discussing what went on in the negotiations.'' Since contract talks began in December, the producers reportedly came under pressure from peers to drop the bonus demands because of fears it would further strain relations with the networks, the Times said. ``Everybody's happy,'' said Cosby's agent, Norman Brokaw, who is chief executive of the William Morris Agency. ``The deal has been finalized. Bill Cosby was not prepared to go somewhere else.'' Carsey-Werner Co., which also produces ABC's popular ``Roseanne,'' packs considerable clout with the networks. In last week's Nielsen ratings, three of the top five shows were Carsey-Werner productions. It also produces the highly rated ``Cosby'' spinoff ``A Different World'' on NBC, and the network's new series ``Grand,'' which made its debut to mixed reviews in the winter. The single-year contract left in doubt whether the enormously popular program would extend its run beyond the 90-91 season. The show was No. 1 in last week's Nielsens. ``The Cosby Show,'' starring Bill Cosby as New York obstetrician Cliff Huxtable, was instrumental in NBC's jump from last to first place among the three major networks. Syndicated episodes have earned more than $500 million for Carsey-Werner.

DOC.HEAD: Sources Say Rabta Chemical Plant Not As Damaged As Previously Thought
DOC.TEXT: The Libyan chemical factory at Rabta which caught fire two weeks ago was not damaged as extensively as first believed, administration sources say. ``There is far less damage there than we first thought,'' an administration source said Thursday, speaking on condition of anonymity. U.S. officials have charged that the plant was producing poison gas, but the Libyans said it was making medicine. After reports of the fire became known, U.S. officials said damage to the plant appeared to have been extensive, and White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the plant was ``out of business.'' The administration source declined to specify how the information had been obtained. U.S. intelligence agencies have relied on satellite photographs for such information in the past. Nor did the source offer an estimate on how long it would take to repair the plant and get it back into production. Before the fire, U.S. officials said it appeared that the plant, after a long period of little production, had begun turning out limited quantities of mustard and nerve gases. The plant, about 60 miles southwest of Tripoli, caught fire on March 14. The Libyan ambassador to Italy said last week that the fire had caused great damage and that it had been set by a worker at the plant. The ambassador told reporters several people had been arrested and that the person responsible would be executed. Last week a French company said photographs taken by the European Spot I satellite showed that the plant was not heavily damaged by the fire. The photograph showed some black traces on buildings apparently used for storage about 800 yards from the main plant. ``The principal structures of the Libyan chemical factory at Rabta don't seem to have been touched,'' Christian Barnard, a spokesman for Spot Image, said last week. Libya has accused the United States, Israel and West Germany of being behind the burning of the plant. All three countries have denied it.

DOC.HEAD: Guatemala to Negotiate Peace with Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of Guatemala's guerrilla alliance met with a government-approved commission today and signed an agreement to open negotiations toward ending the nation's 28-year-old civil war. The accord said the guerrillas and the commission agreed to ask the United Nations to monitor the peace process and act as a ``guarantor of the fulfillment of the agreements and commitments.'' The head of the Guatemalan National Revolutionary Unity rebel alliance, Luis Becker Guzman, said the guerrillas had offered a cease-fire during the Easter holiday as part of the agreement. He said the government-approved National Reconciliation Commission said it would forward the offer to Guatemala's government and army. The agreement also calls for a second round of talks, tentatively scheduled for late May, between the rebels and Guatemala's political parties. The delegations also agreed to direct talks among the rebels, the Guatemalan army and the government but gave no date. The accord said negotiations would be held ``with the aim of achieving a political solution to the internal armed conflict.'' The three-day talks in Oslo were sponsored by the World Lutheran Federation. The talks were the third meeting between the leftist rebels and government representatives since a civilian government came to power in Guatemala in 1986 and promised to end the civil fighting. Talks broke off almost immediately when guerrillas met government officials in Madrid in 1986, and peace talks broke down last year in Costa Rica. Government representative Jorge Serrano Elias said today's talks were successful because of a strong national concensus to end the civil fighting that has left an estimated 100,000 people dead. ``Never before in my country has there been such a consensus of wills to support a process of negotiation and dialogue,'' he said. Norway's Foreign Minister Kjell Magne Bondevik, who attended the signing ceremony called the agreement ``a commendable willingness to compromise.'' Guatemalan National Revoluntionary Unity is an umbrella movement including three guerrilla groups: the Rebel Armed Forces, Guerrilla Army of the Poor and the Organization of the People in Arms. U.S. estimates put the movement's fighting force at 1,500.

DOC.HEAD: Duke and Duchess of York Name Baby Princess Eugenie
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS pronouncer to yoo-ZHAY-nee
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON2,8
DOC.TEXT: The Duke and Duchess of York have named their week-old daughter Princess Eugenie Victoria Helena, Buckingham Palace said today. The baby's name was announced shortly after the royal couple stepped from Portland Hospital with the new princess, wrapped in a white blanket. The baby slept quietly through the cheers of the crowd and the click of hundreds of cameras. Princess Eugenie is the sixth grandchild of Queen Elizabeth II and sixth in the line of succession. She is the second daughter born to the duchess and her husband, Prince Andrew. The 30-year-old Duchess of York, the former Sarah Ferguson, gave birth to Princess Eugenie by Caesarian section on March 23. The baby's name surprised Britain. Bookmakers William Hill said they had thousands of bets but not one for Eugenie. It was the name of Queen Victoria's granddaughter, the daughter of Princess Beatrice who was Victoria's fifth daughter and youngest child. The baby's second name _ Victoria _ comes from Queen Victoria herself, and the third name, Helena, comes from the third daughter of Queen Victoria. Eugenie is the French derivative of the ancient Greek word ``Eugenia'' meaning ``nobility'' and ``excellence,'' and was made fashionable in 19th- century France by the Empress Eugenie, wife of Emperor Napoleon III, said David Williamson, co-editor of Debrett's Peerage, a leading reference book on the aristocracy. In its classical form of Eugenia, it was first recorded as a name in England in the 12th century, he said. Prince Andrew's elder brother Prince Charles, 41, is first in line to the throne, followed by Charles' sons, Prince William and Prince Harry. Then comes Andrew, 30, then Beatrice. The queen's unmarried youngest son, Edward, 26, is now seventh in line of succession. Her 39-year-old daughter Anne, the Princess Royal, is eighth and has a son and daughter, Peter and Zara, who are ninth and 10th.

DOC.HEAD: No-Bid Contracts At New Housing Agency Probed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 3 pvs, Mary Brunette, with HUD IG's comments; SUBS graf 5 to addattempts to reach Ms. Bush and her attorney unsuccessful
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Housing and Urban Development's inspector general is investigating three no-bid contracts awarded to close friends by the embattled director of a new agency that controls millions of dollars in housing money. Inspector General Paul A. Adams, in a preliminary report to Secretary Jack Kemp, said the contracts may have been issued in violation of government regulations, a HUD source, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said Thursday night. Adams today declined to discuss any preliminary findings but said he hoped to make a final report to Kemp next week. Adams said he began the investigation of the Federal Housing Finance Board contracting procedures on Monday at Kemp's request and has received full cooperation from the agency. Kemp raised questions about the contracts during a lengthy meeting Thursday with Mary K. Bush, the housing secretary's handpicked choice to head the new agency. The meeting was arranged after behind-the-scenes effort by Kemp aides to exert influence over the independent agency became public. Ms. Bush has asked Peter Wallison, a former Reagan administration attorney now in private practice, to represent her during the investigation, according to her spokesman. She is not related to President Bush. Attempts to reach Ms. Bush and Wallison today were unsuccessful; both were reported to be out of town. Joseph Slye, the spokesman for the housing board, confirmed that Adams had visited the agency earlier this week and taken several contract files. He said Ms. Bush had asked the board's own inspector general to look into the contracts after HUD officials raised questions about them last week. Ms. Bush awarded the three consulting contracts in question to three close friends with whom she had worked in the Reagan administration. The recipients included Wendell Gunn, Kemp's former chief of staff at HUD, and Margery Waxman, who in 1988 represented Charles Keating in his then-successful effort to persuade regulators not to seize a troubled California savings and loan he owned, Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. Both Slye and HUD sources refused to provide details of Kemp's meeting with Ms. Bush. Also unclear was whether Adams got involved in the investigation at Kemp's request, as suggested by the HUD source, or at the request of the finance board's own inspector general. The board oversees the 12 regional Federal Home Loan Banks, which must give up $400 million of their profits each year to help pay for the bailout of the savings and loan industry. Congress also directed the regional banks to put a percentage of their profits each year into affordable housing programs, starting with $78 million this year and rising to $100 million. Control of those subsidies, and the new agency's plum patronage jobs, was the prize in the effort by Kemp aides to gain considerable influence over the Housing Finance Board. Kemp recruited Ms. Bush last year and promised to name her the panel's chairwoman. She agreed to take the title of managing director until her appointment was made and she was confirmed by the Senate. Ms. Bush never received the appointment, however, leaving the agency under the control of Kemp, who as housing secretary is the only permanent board member. Kemp and aides publicly blamed the delay on the bureaucracy and on a debate with Congress over whether the board members should be full time or part time, as HUD aides want. As recently as a week ago Kemp restated his support for Ms. Bush. But HUD sources and an internal memo obtained by The Associated Press and department sources provided evidence that an effort to oust Ms. Bush began some time ago after she reportedly balked at some of the department's ideas for the agency. The memo, written seven weeks ago by HUD Undersecretary Alfred A. DelliBovi, ended with an account of the plans of a Housing Finance Board consultant to end his work there. ``If he goes let's hope he takes Mary,'' was its final statement. Ms. Bush left a vice presidency at the Federal National Mortgage Association to take the Housing Finance Board job. She worked at the Treasury Department during the Reagan administration.

DOC.HEAD: GM Didn't Violate Contract By Closing Plant, Arbitrator Rules
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. didn't breach its contract with the United Auto Workers union by closing an automobile plant in Pontiac, Mich., an arbitrator has ruled. Arbitrator Thomas Roberts of Los Angeles accepted GM's argument that the shutdown of the Fiero plant was permitted by the contract. Thursday's ruling is the latest in a series of setbacks for the UAW and the approximately 1,700 GM employees who were laid off when the plant closed in August 1988 after a sharp sales decline in the two-seat sports car. ``The corporation is pleased, obviously,'' GM spokesman John Maciarz said today. ``It was our position that the idling of the Fiero plant and subsequent layoff of employees of that facility were caused by volume-related market decreases in demand.'' The ruling could raise tensions between the union and the automaker as they prepare for contract negotiations next summer. UAW officials have said they would press to close loopholes in the contract's plant-closing prohibition. ``The decision provides a clear imperative to improve the job security provisions'' in the new contract, said Stephen Yokich, UAW vice president and head of union's GM department.

DOC.HEAD: Riccardo Muti Quitting Philadelphia Orchestra
DOC.TEXT: Riccardo Muti, who kept the Philadelphia Orchestra in the international limelight during a decade as music director, has decided to quit after the 1991-92 season. Muti shocked the orchestra Thursday with the announcement that he will not renew his contract when it expires in 1992. He said his devotion to music has left him too little time for a personal life. Muti, 48, will continue as music director at the opera house La Scala in Milan, Italy, and have the title of laureate conductor in Philadelphia. He will maintain a relationship with the Philadelphia Orchestra through recording contracts and as guest conductor. ``It was very hard for me to say what I said,'' Muti said. ``But I have felt the last year under great pressure and stress.'' He said a career on two continents has left him little time for his personal life and he simply wants more time to ``think and to read _ to have a life.'' ``It reached a point where I felt it was time for me ... to take care of myself. I have sometimes felt like a man without air,'' he said. Muti's decision caught the orchestra by surprise, said Theodore A. Burtis, president of the Philadelphia Orchestra Association. ``We are all in shock, but we do understand,'' Burtis said. The director said he decided to announce his decision now, rather than wait two years, to give the orchestra time to search for a replacement. Muti succeeded Eugene Ormandy, who in 44 years took the orchestra to international prominence. Under Muti, the Philadelphia Orchestra continued that legacy. Since he took over as music director in 1980, the orchestra's subscription concerts have been sold out every year, and tours have taken the musicians around the world. The orchestra also commissioned new works, resumed opera performances and expanded its recording contracts. Muti's first role as as a principal conductor and music director came in 1969 with the Maggio Musicale Fiorentino in Florence, Italy, where he served for 11 years. In 1972, he succeeded Otto Klemperer as principal conductor of the Philharmonia Orchestra of London.

DOC.HEAD: Simpson Urges Republican Colleagues Not to Reject Rostenkowski Plan
DOC.TEXT: The deputy Republican leader in the Senate urged colleagues today not to reject out of hand a deficit-reduction plan by Rep. Dan Rostenkowski that would raise taxes and freeze most government spending. ``Those who stand ready to rip apart and ridicule this proposal must be prepared to offer a thoughtful substitute,'' Sen. Alan Simpson of Wyoming wrote in The Washington Post. Simpson wrote that Rostenkowski, D-Ill., who chairs the House Ways and Means Committee, ``has dared to speak the unspeakable: that our monstrous deficit can be eliminated only with some real discomfort _ for every one of us.'' For that reason, the senator added, ``every element of his plan _ and core of any serious deficit-reduction plan _ is going to be political quicksand to various members of Congress.'' While not endorsing all parts of Rostenkowski's plan, Simpson said, ``we should all endorse and admire the spirit in which it was made and contribute some spirit and energy of our own .... It's flashier to chop a plan to shreds than to create a new one.'' Rostenkowski's plan would eliminate the federal deficit by 1993 by cutting the defense budget more deeply than the Bush amdinistration prefers; freezing most federal programs, including Social Security benefits, for a year; eliminating for one year the automatic inflation adjustments in the income tax; raising income taxes on the richest 600,000 Americans, and boosting taxes on gasoline, cigarettes, beer and wine. President Bush has said the proposal deserves consideration. But he said he has not changed his opposition to increasing taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He Would Like to Visit Australia
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke he would like to visit his country this year but that it may not be possible, a spokesman said today. Bush called Hawke to congratulate him on his victory in becoming the first Labor leader to win four consecutive terms. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Hawke renewed an invitation for a Bush visit. Fitzwater said the president replied that ``he would love to do it but is not sure it will be possible this year.''

DOC.HEAD: Couple Returns to Court to Enforce Payments in Daughter's Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to recast, move up jail sentence. Picks up 7th graf, `Tunell broke ...
DOC.TEXT: A man who killed a young woman in a drunken driving accident eight years ago was ordered jailed for failing to abide by an agreement to pay $1 a week to the victim's parents for 18 years. However, Fairfax County Circuit Court Judge Jack B. Stevens suspended the sentence Thursday to allow Kevin Tunell a chance to appeal. Tunell, then 17, killed Susan Herzog on New Year's morning 1982 while he was driving under the influence. A settlement of a civil lawsuit required him to send a $1 check every Friday because Friday was the night Miss Herzog died. The agreement required that checks be mailed each week for 18 years, as many years as she lived. Patricia and Louis Herzog went back to Fairfax County Circuit Court on Thursday, arguing that Tunell, now 26, was in contempt because he had failed to make the required weekly payments since March 1989. ``We just wanted a remembrance or a reminder,'' said Mrs. Herzog. ``We felt like if he did this for 18 years, he wouldn't forget Susan Herzog. To make a long story short, he kept forgetting.'' Tunell broke into tears on the stand, telling Stevens he was not trying to hurt the Herzogs. Tunell said he is constantly haunted by Susan Herzog's death and tormented by the weekly payments. ``I just don't feel good. It hurts,'' he said. Tunell was convicted in juvenile court of manslaughter and drunken driving, and agreed to make the $1 payments to settle a $1.5 million lawsuit filed by the Herzogs. At $1 a week, the payments for 18 years amount to $936. Tunell's criminal sentence on the manslaughter conviction was to spend a year speaking to groups about the evils of drunken driving. He completed that sentence, he said, and then spent the next six years continuing to speak to groups across the country and made two videos on the subject. Despite those efforts, Tunell testified, he has remained haunted by a vision of Susan Herzog. ``I used to, like, lie in bed and if I heard the house settling or noises I used to think Susan was going to come visit me,'' he said. From the stand Thursday, he offered the Herzogs two boxes of checks that he had pre-written up until 2001 _ a year more than what was required by the agreement. The Herzogs shook their heads. It was the principle, they argued. Although Tunell as of Thursday was up to date on his bill _ the Herzogs had received an envelope of 47 checks of $1 each _ they would accept only weekly payments. ``What we want is to receive that check every week on time,'' Mrs. Herzog said. ``He must understand we are going to pursue this until August of the year 2000. We will go back to court every month if we have to.''

DOC.HEAD: Arabs Strike in Israel and Occupied Lands, Palestinian Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with army breaking up riots, policeman stabbed, 6 police injured in stone-throwing, Israeli Arab rally, CORRECTS that Palestinian teen-ager fatally wounded Thursday night. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Heavily reinforced army and police units broke up several anti-Israeli demonstrations today as Palestinians and Israeli Arabs staged rallies and protest marches to commemorate a bloody 1976 demonstration. A general strike closed shops and schools throughout the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, Arab east Jerusalem and Arab villages in Israel. The protests and strikes marked the 1976 ``Land Day'' riots protesting Israel's confiscation of Arab land in the Galilee. Six Arabs were killed by Israeli police during the disturbances 14 years ago. In a rare clash with Arabs inside Israel, one policeman was stabbed while arresting stone throwers in the town of Taibeh, and six other police were injured by stones, Israel radio said. Police used tear gas to disperse the demonstrators, and at least five Arabs were taken into custody, reporters said. About 10,000 Israeli Arabs attended the main rally in Arraba, the village where two Land Day protesters were killed in 1976. A police helicopter hovered briefly over the crowd, but no police were deployed on the ground. Israeli media reported extra precautions by both police and the army because the protest day fell on the first Friday of the Moslem holy month of Ramadan, a day when anti-Israeli riots are common. Before the four-hour rally, two people were injured when about 100 followers of the nationalist extremist ``Sons of the Village'' waving Palestinian flags battled a group of Communists with sticks. Protest marches also were held in several towns in the occupied West Bank. In the Israeli Arab town of Kafr Kanna north of Nazareth, Parliament member Abdul Wahab Daroushe read a communique from PLO leader Yasser Arafat to several thousand Arabs attending an annual memorial service for a local teen-ager killed in the 1976 clashes. Arafat's message, sent by facsimile from Europe, praised Israeli Arabs ``for igniting the first spark in 1976, which led to the great fire of the uprising.'' It also praised Israelis who support negotiations with Palestinians as ``heroic, democratic Jews willing to make the peace of the courageous, the brave.'' In the West Bank, Jewish settlers set up blue-and-white Israeli flags to emphasize their demand that Israel not give up the land captured in the 1967 Middle East war. The commercial strike in the occupied territories was called by the underground leadership of the uprising and the Islamic fundamentalist Hamas, or Zeal, movement. A solidarity strike was called by Arab leaders in Israel. On Thursday night, army troops fatally wounded 17-year-old Mohammed Rahman Salama during a raid on the village of Kafr Malik, 12 miles north of the West Bank town of Ramallah. Officials at Mukassed Hospital in Jerusalem said Salama had been shot in the chest. The army confirmed the death and said troops opened fire on masked men inciting villagers to violence. He was the 670th Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the 27-month-old uprising against Israel's occupation of the territories. At least 201 other Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most after being accused of collaborating with Israeli authorities. Forty-three Israelis also have been slain in the revolt. In a bid to prevent violence on Land Day, the army declared a curfew on all 700,000 residents of the occupied Gaza Strip and four West Bank towns or villages. About 1 million Palestinians live in the West Bank. One Palestinian youth was wounded in the Gaza Strip's Nusseirat refugee camp when he defied the curfew and ignored soldiers' orders to halt, the army said. Security was especially tight in Jerusalem, where thousands of Moslems often come on Fridays during Ramadan to pray at the Al Aqsa Mosque, one of the holiest sites of Islam. Soldiers set up roadblocks on roads leading into the city and were blocking Palestinian youths from entering. Israeli Arabs comprise the people who stayed within Israel's boundaries when the state was founded in 1948 and number about 810,000. Palestinians are Arabs who fled Israel or were driven out in 1948.

DOC.HEAD: Official King Holiday Wins Final Legislative Approval In Idaho
DOC.TEXT: Legislation declaring the third Monday in January an official state holiday honoring Martin Luther King Jr. won final legislative approval today. Senate passage of the bill establishing the Martin Luther King Jr.-Idaho Human Rights Day removed Idaho from the dwindling list of states still refusing to honor the slain civil rights leader with an official holiday. The bill, clearing the Senate on a 28-11 vote, now goes to Gov. Cecil Andrus, who called for its passage in his State of the State address to open the session last January. ``We've come a long way down the road,'' said Sen. Mary Lou Reed, a Democrat, citing the past four years since the state designated the third Monday in January as a commemorative day for King. Only three other states are now without King holidays _ Montana, New Hampshire and Arizona. The Idaho measure, however, faced a somewhat rocky road in a Legislature that has passed some of the toughest anti-racism laws in the nation, including a criminal malicious harassment law and mandatory hate-crime reporting. After winning initial Senate passage, it was sidetracked in the House until a compromise was agreed to on the formal name. The agreement added Idaho Human Rights Day to the designation. The holiday was pushed by lawmakers and the governor in part to offset the negative image the state has developed because of the presence of white supremacists at the Aryan Nations compound of Richard Butler in northern Idaho. But now with the new holiday and the laws enacted in past sessions, Mrs. Reed said, ``We have the finest package of human rights legislation in the nation. ``Richard Butler and his small band is just a pitiful bunch,'' she said. ``The Aryan Nations people are now moving into the states of Wyoming and Montana.'' The major opposition focused on the potential cost of another day off for government workers, estimated anywhere between $100,000 and $2 million depending on whether payroll is considered, and King's radical political background. Andrus said, however, that ``more than a holiday to honor one man, it will be a day to honor all like him, who believe that no person can truly be free when even one other person is denied liberty.''

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter Parts Shower Suburban Neighborhood
DOC.TEXT: A medical helicopter most likely collided with a bird, scattering metal and fiberglass fragments on a street where youths were playing, authorities said today. No one was injured in the incident at 5 p.m. Thursday in this Pittsburgh suburb and the helicopter returned safely to its base at Allegheny General Hospital in Pittsburgh. Fred Peterson, the hospital's head of trauma and emergency services, said something _ probably a bird _ hit the helicopter, shattering a 2-by-4-foot section of cowling that covers the engine. About a dozen metal and fiberglass fragments of the cowling showered down on the youths. Michael Rosenberger, 17, said he was playing street hockey with five others when the fragments came down ``pretty fast.'' ``It's a miracle none of us were hit,'' he said. One fragment, measuring about a foot by 1{ feet, within a foot of his 9-year-old brother and another playmate, Rosenberger said. The 2-year-old helicopter, one of three Allegheny General uses, was taken out of service for inspection, Peterson said. It was heading to a hospital in Washington, Pa., to pick up a patient, he said. The Federal Aviation Administration and Mount Lebanon police are investigating the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Mental Patient Acquitted By Reason of Insanity in Stabbing Death of Girl
DOC.TEXT: Judges today acquitted a mental patient of murder in the death of a 9-year-old girl he stabbed 34 times at a street fair after escaping from a hospital. The three-member panel of Superior Court judges said David R. Peterson was innocent by reason of insanity. They returned him to Whiting Forensic Institute, the state's maximum-security psychiatric hospital. Peterson, 38, used the insanity plea in the stabbing of Jessica Short of Wallingford. He attacked her at random at a downtown sidewalk sale after walking away from Connecticut Valley Hospital last July 28. The state sought a murder conviction, arguing that Peterson planned the attack, showing he knew what he was doing. Peterson is a chronic paranoid schizophrenic with a history of mental illness and violence dating to his youth. He has spent 15 of his past 20 years in mental institutions. In 1971 and again in 1988, he was found innocent by reason of insanity in stabbing attacks and ordered committed to state hospitals. About two hours before he killed the girl, Peterson had been screaming over the medication he was receiving for pain in his legs and arms, according to testimony. He wanted doctors to change the medication. A psychiatrist hired by the defense said Peterson should have been confined to his ward after the outburst because he had a history of psychotic delusions accompanied by violence. Instead, Peterson was allowed to follow his normal routine, including going outside on the hospital grounds without supervision. He took a bus downtown, bought a hunting knife and attacked the girl. Bystanders and police pulled him away as he was stabbing her. Peterson told police shortly after the slaying that he killed the girl as revenge on his doctors. He told psychiatrists he had pictured himself as a soldier marching into battle. Assistant State's Attorney Timothy Liston said Peterson used the battle scenario to resort to defenses that won him acquittal in the previous stabbings. Peterson chose to be tried by the judges instead of a jury.

DOC.HEAD: Elections Set For June in Bulgaria; New Presidency Created
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Communists and the democratic opposition today set June dates for the country's first free elections since World War II and replaced the governing State Council with a president chosen by Parliament. Also today, the government said it suspended payments on principal for its $10 billion foreign debt but that it will continue paying the interest. The message to creditors on Thursday called the move a temporary measure to give breathing room while Bulgaria implements broad economic reform. The Communists and democratic opposition decided to hold parliamentary elections on June 10th and 17th, the first free elections in Bulgaria in 45 years, said the government news agency BTA. The two sides also agreed to dismantle the State Council, whose president is the nation's leader, and create a presidency chosen by Parliament, BTA said. Petar Mladenov, 53, Bulgaria's current Communist president, will be formally elected to the new post by the current Communist-dominated Parliament and replaced after the June elections, the news agency said. The State Council had been chosen by Parliament. But, as in neighboring Romania and other East European countries, the council ruled in between the infrequent sessions of the countries' parliaments, which rubber-stamped Communist Party policies. It was not immediately clear if the two sides managed to resolve their disagreement over the makeup of a new Parliament and a draft electoral law. Communist Party chief Alexander Lilov said Tuesday the new parliament chosen at June's elections should sit for four years ``because we need a strong government at a time when the country is in crisis,'' Bulgarian state radio reported. Zhelyu Zhelev, the head of the Union of Democratic Forces, the umbrella opposition group, and other opposition leaders want the new Parliament to serve only as a constituent assembly that sits for 18 months to pass a new constitution and other democratic laws. The government sent a letter to its creditors Thursday, suspending its debt payments, the Bulgarian Embassy in London said today. ``The government is compelled to temporarily freeze... the payments,'' said the notification to creditors quoted by the embassy. But the letter added that ``our efforts would continue to regularly pay the interest due on the credits.'' The letter said Bulgaria found it impossible to ``carry out the radical economic and currency reforms in the country and at the same time pay the full amount of the amounts due on the credits.'' Bulgaria hasn't fixed a specific date for resumption of principal payments, said a diplomat at the embassy, who demanded anonymity. Bankers said that the telexed notice, signed by the executive board of the Bulgarian Foreign Trade Bank, offered to meet with the banks. The notice did not, however, outline a timetable and did not indicate whether Bulgaria wants to meet with banks individually or create a bank committee for bilateral discussions.

DOC.HEAD: Endara to Visit Washington
DOC.TEXT: Panamanian President Guillermo Endara will make a three-day visit to Washington for talks with President Bush and other administration leaders April 29 to May 1, the White House said today. Endara was installed as president under U.S. auspices when American forces invaded Panama last year to remove Gen. Antonio Manuel Noriega from power. He will meet with Bush on April 30 during what was termed an official working visit.

DOC.HEAD: Buffalo Transit Commissioners Vote to Shut Down Service
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Savage, who...', to UPDATE with Chicago transit system hiring Savage.
DOC.TEXT: Buffalo's transit agency says it is running out of money and will suspend bus and subway service for its 120,000 daily riders after Saturday night. Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority commissioners voted 8-1 for the suspension Thursday, saying the Erie County Legislature's rejection of a transit tax gave them no choice. ``The community has told us they do not want a transit system,'' Chairman Robert D. Gioia said. ``They do not want to be burdened by $12 a year. The chamber (of commerce) has told us that is too much to ask.'' The tax on public utilities that the county legislature rejected Wednesday would have cost the average family less than $2 a month. It was bitterly opposed by the National Fuel natural-gas company and other business groups. Three hours before the commissioners voted, transit authority executive director Alfred H. Savage said the county legislature's action had persuaded him to resign at the end of April. This morning, the Chicago Transit Authority named Savage its executive director, giving him a three-year contract with a salary of $149,500 a year. Savage, who turned 60 on Thursday, had said he was considering either retiring or accepting the CTA post. Savage informed commissioners before the vote that the agency will have just $89,000 in the bank by Saturday night. Officials said the shutdown will save up to half a million dollars a week, but will cost $1.3 million the first week, mostly because of the final payroll. The money will be siphoned from the authority's profitable Greater Buffalo International Airport operation. Authority officials have said federal law prohibits them from using airport revenues as a continuing transit subsidy. Buffalo, with a population of more than 350,000, is the state's second-largest city, but is the smallest U.S. metropolitan area with a subway, a 5-year-old line. If it abandons the bus and subway system, it will be the biggest U.S. city without any public transit. The crisis occurred when costs rose and federal and state funding did not keep pace. The state insisted the county enact a special tax, but county legislators shot down proposals for sales, property, mortgage and gasoline taxes, as well as the utility tax. The county legislature's chairman, Roger Blackwell, said he would try to get his colleagues to come up with some sort of a tax or combination of taxes that could attract the necessary 12 votes. But he said it probably would not be possible before Saturday night.

DOC.HEAD: Burned Bear and Cub Returned to Mountains
DOC.TEXT: A mother bear and her cub were returned to their mountain home seven months after she suffered a 7,200-volt shock and burns as she fell, drugged by tranquilizer darts, from a utility pole in the city. Scott Brown, spokesman for the state Department of Game and Fish, said the release went off without a hitch Thursday afternoon in the Sandia Mountains east of here. The cub was released first, then his mother. Officers from the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish, U.S. Forest Service and zoo officials assisted in the release. When the mother bear saw them all, ``she just took off,'' Brown said. She stopped after she got about 25 yards away, he said, until the cub caught up with her. ``She looked back at all the people and started wandering up the hill like she should,'' Brown said. ``I guess our last hope is that they are going to mind their business now, stay up there, stay out of trouble,'' said Dr. Bret Snyder, veterinarian at the Rio Grande Zoological Park. Brown said the mother bear was fitted with a radio collar so biologists can monitor her for the next couple of weeks. The mother bear had wandered into Albuquerque's residential Northeast Heights last Aug. 14 and climbed a 25-foot utility pole. When wildlife officials shot her with a tranquilizer gun, she fell, brushing a transformer and causing the shock and burns. Pictures of the dramatic fall was broadcast nationally. The cub had been captured in town the previous day. The bears were taken to the zoo and slowly reintroduced to each other to protect the injured female. She had suffered extensive damage to her skin and muscles on her hind legs. On her right hind leg, the bone was exposed, but it healed over, Snyder said. ``She did maintain enough use of that leg that we really can't tell that she has any disability to speak of,'' he added. The bears were kept in a medical unit at the zoo until mid-December, when they were moved to a quarter-acre fenced area with cottonwood trees and a den. The bears also dug an outside den under some concrete, Snyder said. The mother bear weighed 104{ pounds when brought in for treatment but was up to 188 pounds Thursday, he said. The cub grew from 15 pounds to 108 pounds. ``He's fat, but he's also matured a lot,'' Snyder said. He said zoo crews tried to keep contact with the animals to a minimum. ``When they sensed humans, they went into the dens, so we didn't see them at all for several weeks,'' he said. ``They only came out at night. We thought that was a good sign that they were staying wild.'' Albuquerque was invaded by 19 bears last summer. Drought apparently caused a food shortage in the mountains, sending the bears into the city.

DOC.HEAD: Thieves Pick Wrong Type of Shoes
DOC.TEXT: Thieves who allegedly stole 57 pairs of athletic shoes from a delivery truck were slightly ahead of their time: They chose a type of shoe not yet on sale at area stores. The 57 pairs, worth about $1,300, were taken Wednesday from a truck parked behind the office of the Athlete's Foot store in Lenexa, a city of 18,000 on the perimeter of Kansas City, said police Detective Mike Siebers. The theft was discovered about 15 minutes after a man went into the office to ask for a job, Siebers said. About two hours later, two men walked into an Athlete's Foot store in Kansas City, Kan., and asked to exchange a pair of shoes that didn't fit. Store employees, notified of the Lenexa theft, recognized the shoes. Police found six more pairs of the shoes in a car in the store's parking lot but 50 pairs still are missing. The two men were released pending further investigation.

DOC.HEAD: 100 Fishermen Missing in Storm
DOC.TEXT: At least 100 fishermen were missing and many of them were presumed dead in a storm that tore across southern Bangladesh earlier in the week, police and news reports said Friday. At least 15 people were killed. Police said 20 fishing boats were caught in the Bay of Bengal in Wednesday's storm and have not returned home. On Thursday, police said 10 people had died in the storm, but the confirmed death toll rose to 15 when searchers found more bodies in collapsed houses. Nearly 500 people were injured. The storm uprooted trees, toppled electricity poles and destroyed vast rice paddies in the coastal Noakhali district 75 miles southeast of Bangladesh. More than 50 deaths have been reported in storms during the past two weeks in Bangladesh, which is one of the world's poorest nations and is perennially buffeted by storms and floods.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Upholds Church's Dismissal Of Homosexual
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court Friday ruled that Roman Catholic officials had the right to fire a sexton because he was homosexual, and it overturned an arbitration board's award of damages to the man. The board awarded about $3,500 to the man in 1988, saying he was unfairly fired from his job in a Paris parish. The appeals court quashed this judgment, saying the man's homosexuality constituted an infringement of his contract. The former sexton's name was not released.

DOC.HEAD: Three Die in Explosion at Dynamite Factory
DOC.TEXT: Explosions rocked a dynamite factory Friday, killing three people, leveling many buildings and damaging houses, police said. Three workers were injured, two of them seriously, according to police. About 30 workers were at the sprawling Dynamit Nobel complex when the series of blasts went off in the morning. A police spokesman said more deaths were prevented ``only because of lucky circumstances.'' At the time of the explosions, most workers were on their morning break in another part of the complex. Two Germans and a Turk died in the blasts, which occurred inside a shop that makes gunpowder and fireworks, said police. The explosions leveled a number of workshops at the complex as well as the factory's social club, said police. Nearby homes were also damaged. Bretzfeld is about 25 miles southeast of Heidelberg.

DOC.HEAD: Moslems Mourn Slain Militant Leader, Vow to Continue Secession Fight
DOC.TEXT: A leader of the Moslem separatist movement in Kashmir tried to hurl a grenade into a police bunker Friday but was killed in a volley of police gunfire. Tens of thousands of Moslems gathered later for the funeral. Comrades fired into the air and vowed to carry on the fight for independence from India. Ashfaq Majid Wani, 28, was a leader of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, a leading separatist group. He was the front's area commander in Srinagar. Police said he tried to throw the grenade at a police bunker in downtown Srinagar while riding by on a motor scooter. The grenade went off after officers opened fire with automatic weapons. Three other people died in the melee, the police said. Hours later, thousands of residents gathered near Wani's house in an attempt to hold a funeral procession in defiance of a government curfew. But soldiers and police prevented the procession and took Wani's body to a burial ground in a government ambulance escorted by a police jeep. Women wailed and beat their chest as Wani's body was taken out of the ambulance and placed near the grave. Men shouted: ``Ashfaq's blood will usher independence!'' A group militants fired pistols and automatic rifles in the air. Witnesses estimated the crowd at 40,000. The firing continued intermittently for more than one hour until the body wa interred at 5 p.m. ``We will carry forward Asfaq's mission, which was to gain independence,'' said one militant leader holding a Soviet-designed Kalashnikov rifle. He refused to give his name. The secessionist movement has been alternately simmering and flaring since 1948, when the Hindu ruler of the old princely state of Kashmir, faced with the option of merging either with India or Islamic Pakistan, chose India. The two countries then were one year old, having been partitioned from the British colonial India. India and Pakistan have fought two wars over Kashmir. They left the region split into the Pakistan-held territory called Azad Kashmir, or free Kashmir, and the Indian-controlled Jammu-Kashmir state. Jammu-Kashmir is the only state in India that is dominated by Moslems. Most of India's 880 million people are Hindu. At least 233 people have been killed in Kashmir since Jan. 20 when the government launched a crackdown on increasing violence by Moslem separatists. Official sources said Indian soldiers shot and killed 10 Moslem separatists Friday who were trying to slip into Pakistani-held territory of Kashmir. They said the men were in a group 22 that opened fire on the soldiers. The 12 surviving militants were arrested, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Also Friday, police fatally shot a curfew violated in Srinagar. The body of a suspected police informer was found in Srinagar, and officials said militants claimed responsibility.

DOC.HEAD: Easter Tradition Comes to End, Eggs Pose Threat of Botulism
DOC.TEXT: A group that for 66 years has sold hand-painted Easter eggs is ceasing production on the advice of its lawyers, who fear that children may eat spoiled eggs and contract botulism. The announcement by the Blue Bird Circle, an organization that aids children with neurological disorders, forced the cancellation of orders for 24,000 eggs from Houston country clubs and several retail stores. For years, the eggs were intricately designed with colorful decals, trimmed in gold paint and dyed in many colors. ``We're very disappointed. The Easter eggs have been one of our most fun projects, but we certainly don't want to contribute to a child getting sick,'' said Bonnie McMillian, Easter basket project chairwoman. ``I'm sure we'll find another way to do it with a non-edible product.''

DOC.HEAD: Rallies, Marches Mark Anniversary of Bloody Riots
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Palestinians and Israeli Arabs held rallies and protest marches Friday to mark the 14th anniversary of ``Land Day,'' when bloody riots broke out over Israeli confiscation of Arab land. A general strike closed shops and schools throughout the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, in Arab east Jerusalem, and in Arab villages in Israel. In a rare clash inside Israel, police used tear gas to disperse Arab demonstrators after an hour of stone throwing by youths in the town of Taibeh, reporters said. Israel radio said two firebombs were also thrown. One policeman was stabbed while arresting stone throwers. He was hospitalized in stable condition. Six other officers were injured by stones, the radio said. At least five Arabs were taken into custody. About 10,000 Israeli Arabs attended the main Land Day rally in Arraba, where two people were killed during the 1976 riots. In Jerusalem, Sheik Hamed Bitawi complained that Israeli soldiers and police prevented thousands of Moslems from attending Friday prayer services at the Al Aqsa Mosque, one of Islam's holiest sites. ``We pray to God to avenge this wrong,'' Bitawi told the prayer service. ``The Zionists have committed an injustice against us. Soldiers are here as if it is a battlefield.'' Extra police and soldiers were deployed to prevent unrest surrounding the anniversary. During the 1976 riots, police shot to death six Arabs who were protesting the seizing of Arab land in the Galilee. This year's anniversary also fell on the first Friday _ the Moslem prayer day _ of the holy month of Ramadan, so officials were particularly concerned about unrest. Fewer than 10,000 Moslems attended the Al Aqsa prayers. Before the start of the Palestinian uprising in December 1987, Ramadan services would draw more than 150,000 people. Young Palestinians were turned back at Israeli police and army checkpoints on roads leading to Jerusalem. Troops also turned people away as they tried to enter Jerusalem's old walled city to go to Al Aqsa. An army statement said the soldiers were blocking ``elements likely of endangering the security of the state.'' In protests in the occupied territories and Israel, Arabs stoned cars, held marches and raised Palestinian flags in defiance of Israeli authorities. In the Arab town of Kafr Kanna, Abdel Wahab Daroushe, an Arab member of Israel's Parliament, read a message from PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat to several thousand people at an annual memorial service for a teen-ager killed in 1976. Arafat's message praised Israeli Arabs ``for igniting the first spark in 1976, which led to the great fire of the uprising.'' It also praised Israelis who support negotiations with Palestinians as ``heroic, democratic Jews.'' Palestinian protest marches were reported in the West Bank towns of Jenin, Beit Jala and Yatta. Troops broke up the Yatta demonstration by dropping tear gas from helicopters. Soldiers fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse stone throwers in Beit Jala, Arab reports said. In Jenin, hundreds of women and masked men marched carrying pictures of Arafat, Arab reporters said. On walls in the town, Palestinians painted pictures of donkeys with Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's name written under them. In a counter demonstration, Jewish settlers flew Israeli flags in the West Bank to emphasize their demand that Israel not give up the land captured in the 1967 Middle East war. The flags were placed on a road leading from the Jewish suburb of Gilo on the outskirts of Jerusalem to the Dheishe refugee camp. The camp was established to house Palestinians who fled their homes at the founding of Israel in 1948. Curfews were imposed on all 700,000 residents of the Gaza Strip and on four West Bank towns or villages.

DOC.HEAD: House Child-Care Package Expands Programs, Services; Phases Out Tax Credits
DOC.TEXT: Here are highlights of the child care bill passed by the House on Thursday: _ The package is estimated to cost $27 billion over a five-year phase in period. _ Most of the money, $18.5 billion, would expand the earned income tax credit, which goes to low-income working families. _ It would expand the Head Start program for disadvantaged children to provide child care throughout the calender year during each work day. _ It would provide money for states to give to local school districts to expand, establish or operate child-care programs based in the schools. _ It would provide $2.9 billion to increase the Title XX Social Servies Block Grant program for use by the states in providing child-care services. States would be required to offer low-income families vouchers to pay for child care operated by religious groups. _ It would provide additional money for states to improve the quality of child care and to encourage private businesses to establish child-care programs. _ It would phase out the existing dependent-care tax credit for families earning $70,000 to $90,000, and eliminate it above that level. It would make permanent the 3 percent telephone excise tax.

DOC.HEAD: Spring Forward Sunday
DOC.TEXT: Daylight saving time returns Sunday. The change, moving clocks ahead one hour, is scheduled for 2 a.m. Most folks will switch their clocks before retiring, or they might be an hour late for church or other activities. Daylight time will remain in effect until Oct. 28, when that hour of lost sleep will be returned.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sends Personal Message to Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, with editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he sent a personal message to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to make sure ``the Soviets understand our position'' on Lithuania. ``I do not want to risk misunderstanding by failing to communicate,'' Bush said. The president sent a personal message to the Soviet leader on Thursday night appealing for a peaceful resolution of the crisis in the seccesionist Baltic republic, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Later, speaking with reporters during a picture-taking session, Bush said: ``I want to be sure the Soviets understand our position and understand that we're not trying to make things difficult for Lithuania or the Soviet Uniion or anybody else,'' Bush said. He said he had not yet heard back from Gorbachev but indicated that he expected some form of reply. Bush declined to disclose the contents of his message, calling it confidential. Asked why he decided to contact Gorbachev directly, Bush cited the importance of ``staying in touch and being sure there is no disconnect because of misinformation.'' It was Bush's first effort at direct contact with the Soviet leader since tensions began escalating with the March 11 Lithuanian declaration of independence. In the letter to Gorbachev, Bush ``clearly stated his support and the American support for the aspirations of the Lithuanian people for self-determination,'' Fitzwater said. ``We have expressed our belief and our emphatic view that a resolution of this conflict lies in peaceful dialogue,'' Fitzwater said. ``The president's message to President Gorbachev simply reaffirmed our position as stated many times.'' Fitzwater said. The spokesman said Bush's letter was sent ``via diplomatic channels'' Thursday evening. ``He wanted to be certain our position was understood,'' Fitzwater said. Fitzwater also said that Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., had met with Bush in the White House on Thursday to report on the senator's trip to Moscow and meeting with Gorbachev. Kennedy's half-hour report to Bush on the trip ``was a factor'' in the president's decision to write a letter to Gorbachev, Fitzwater said. Fitzwater said Bush's letter was delivered to officials at the Soviet Embassy in Washington, which relayed it to Moscow. It came a day after Fitzwater said Bush ``simply feels that this is not the time'' for direct contact with the Soviet leader. Today, the spokesman said, ``I was not aware of any intent to do it'' on Thursday morning but that Bush ``decided to do it and just did it.'' ``The president felt that last night was the right time to send a personal, written message that clearly laid out our position,'' Fitzwater said. The Bush administration had treaded carefully on the Lithuanian subject, voicing support for the self-determination rights of citizens of the rebellious Baltic republic while urging restraint on both sides. The United States has never recognized the 1940 forced incorporation of Lithuania into the Soviet Union. But, neither has it extended formal diplomatic recognition to the secessionist state. Fitzwater said that an ``accumulation of information and feedback'' had prompted the president ``to feel that this was the time for a personal message that used his words and that President Gorbachev knew came directly from him.'' Fitzwater said this ``feedback'' included Bush's meeting with Kennedy, his phone call on Wednesday to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and contacts between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and his Soviet counterpart, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Administration officials have repeatedly cautioned that use of force by Moscow in blocking Lithuanian independence would backfire and could damage U.S.-Soviet relations. But Bush has come under pressure from some members of Congress for not being more aggressive in complaining about Soviet actions in the breakaway republic. While acknowledging the criticism, Fitzwater today said, ``We believe our supporters far outnumber our critics on this issue.'' On recent developments in Lithuania, Fitzwater said: ``We have not seen too many episodes the last few days that have been very dramatic. But the problem is not resolved. They're still searching for solutions. And we hope that can be worked out.'' Fitzwater said Bush welcomed Kennedy's firsthand report, even though generally speaking, ``we never feel that great about senators doing their own foreign policy.'' The spokesman said that no attempts had been made to contact directly the rebellious Lithuanian leaders, citing the lack of any formal ties with the Vilnius government. However, he said that contact with Lithuanian leaders by some U.S. citizens and U.S.-Lithuanian groups here had been generally helpful in indirectly getting across U.S. policy views to Lithuanians. ``Our interest is not in making threats and not in doing any damage to the situation, but in being positive and constructive,'' Fitzwater said. ``We want to be helpful in resolving this process. We don't want to do any harm,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister of Nepal Quits Amid Democracy Campaign
DOC.TEXT: The foreign minister of this Himalayan kingdom quit Friday because of differences with the prime minister over the government's handling of a spiraling movement for a multiparty democracy. Shailendra Kumar Upadhyaya, contacted by telephone, said he submitted his resignation Friday morning to Prime Minister Marich Man Singh Shrestha. ``I was not satisfied regarding the prime minister's handling of the present situation,'' he said. It was the first time Upadhyaya had indicated he disagreed with the government crackdown on the fledgling campaign. He has been in office since 1986. State-run radio reported that two pro-democracy protesters were killed by police gunfire Friday in the Katmandu suburb of Patan. The radio said police opened fire when protesters became violent. Three protesters were injured by police gunfire, and 30 policemen were injured in daylong clashes, the report said. Witnesses contacted by telephone said 11 demonstrators were injured. The witnesses, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they were not aware of police casualties. The radio said the demonstrators burned a police van, hurled stones and damaged an ambulance and a bus. They also damaged property in five government buildings, the radio reported. It said 45 people were arrested. At least 14 people have been killed in Nepal since Feb. 18, when the government launched a crackdown on protesters demanding the lifting of a 29-year-old ban on political parties. The movement is led by the Nepali Congress Party, a coalition of left-wing groups. Kesar Bahadur Bista, a National Assembly deputy representing Patan constituency, said violence had increased on both sides in recent weeks. ``Violence from any side is not good. There should be a political dialogue to solve the problem,'' he said. In a protest related to the political unrest, hundreds of women beating spoons on metal dinner plates protested in Katmandu against high prices Friday. Protest leader Mina Pandey blamed the government for the situation. ``Democracy will usher in a new era under which we will be able to express our grievances freely,'' she said. Police arrested about 25 women after the meeting. It was not immediately clear if they were charged. Power in Nepal is shared by the king and the National Assembly. The monarch nominates one-fifth of the Assembly's members, and the rest are elected on a non-party basis. Nepal's two-year experiment with a Western-style democracy ended in 1961, when the present monarch's father, King Mahendra, dismissed the government of the Nepali Congress, accusing it of corruption and mismanagement. The government says the current political system is a working democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Yiddish Book Center Celebrates Decade
DOC.TEXT: Ten years ago this weekend, graduate student Aaron Lansky rented a modest loft, took out corporation papers and launched an ambitious mission: rescuing Yiddish literature from extinction. ``Everybody's best guess was that there were about 75,000 volumes still extant. Here we are a million books later and still going strong,'' he said. ``There was no way to have imagined how prolific Jews were as writers and readers.'' Now, the founder of the National Yiddish Book Center is turning to the business of trying to disseminate the thousands of books written in the language spoken by Eastern European Jews for hundreds of years and nearly erased in the Holocaust. ``Our first 10 years was devoted to collecting and distributing books. Now we'll branch out and begin doing a great more,'' he said. ``Our premise is now we've collected all these books, we've got to open them up and let the world know what's inside of them.'' Lansky, 33, has moved the center to nearby Amherst and established a warehouse about 10 miles away in Holyoke to hold the thousands of books sent in, including some that were rescued from trash bins or plucked from attics. In December, he traveled to the Soviet Union's Baltic states, responding to letters from Jews who hoped President Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms would mean a return for Yiddish. ``It was a pretty grueling experience in many ways,'' he said. ``What we found was that Yiddish was not widely spoken in Russia proper. There is really what amounts to 70 years of assimilation.'' Lansky hopes to work out a system of shipping books to Stockholm and then taking them personally into the Soviet Union. The international venture goes far beyond the hopes he had as a student of Yiddish who wanted to collect fodder for his research. ``Collecting the books was a big undertaking for us. We've collected almost 1 million volumes which no one would have thought possible. Surprisingly enough they're still coming in,'' Lansky said. The non-profit center has a staff of about two dozen and runs educational and cultural programs, including the Yiddish Library Development Program. About 70 libraries are participating, including Yale University, which has a collection of 70,000 Yiddish books from the center. The center celebrated its 10th anniversary quietly, holding a four-day film series in Northampton, where the venture began. Lansky said the decade has seen a resurgence of interest in Yiddish. ``Really what we're doing is picking up the remnants of a shattered past,'' he said. ``We're right at the nexus of two worlds where the last of a Yiddish-speaking generation is passing on. My generation is the last generation whose grandparents spoke Yiddish. There's really a great deal of urgency in all this.''

DOC.HEAD: No-Bid Contracts At New Housing Agency Probed
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Housing and Urban Development's inspector general confirmed Friday he is investigating a new agency whose director gave no-bid contracts to three friends from the Reagan administration. However, Inspector General Paul A. Adams declined comment on an account from a department source who said the preliminary effort found ``contract irregularities'' at the new Federal Housing Finance Board, which controls millions of dollars in federal housing aid. The agency, whose embattled director has been clashing with top aides to HUD Secretary Jack Kemp, is independent of HUD but has remained under Kemp's control for seven months because he is its only named board member. The agency was created as part of the savings and loan bailout plan _ to oversee the 12 regional Federal Home Loan Banks, which must give up $400 million of their profits each year to help pay for the thrift bailout. The regional banks also must put a percentage of their profits each year into affordable housing programs, starting with $78 million this year and rising to $100 million. Kemp spent several hours meeting Thursday with the women he recruited to head the agency, Mary K. Bush, who was a Treasury Department official during the Reagan administration. Among the recipients of the no-bid contracts were: _ Wendell Gunn, who worked for Reagan and also served for several months last year as Kemp's chief of staff at HUD. _ Margery Waxman, an attorney who after leaving Treasury helped Charles Keating try to fend off S&L regulators who wanted to seize his troubled California thrift. Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan later failed at an estimated eventual cost to taxpayers of $2.5 billion.
