The third went to a consulting firm whose partners include another former Treasury official. Kemp aides said Friday that he had not been aware of any of the no-bid contracts until last week or of any financial arrangement between Gunn and the Housing Finance Board. Gunn has said he informed Kemp late last year. And HUD Undersecretary Alfred A. DelliBovi, in a memo to several top Kemp aides last month, listed ``Wendell'' as being among those being paid by the agency. Adams, the inspector general, said he began the investigation at Kemp's request and on Monday took possession of Housing Finance Board records. He said agency officials were cooperating. He declined to answer questions about specifics of his review but said he hoped to issue a final report to Kemp next week. A department source, speaking only on the condition of anonymity, said the preliminary findings showed that all board contract awards followed accepted procedures except the three to Ms. Bush's friends. Ms. Bush was not available for comment. Her spokesman, Joseph Slye, said she had taken the day off and was out of town. She has asked attorney Peter Wallison, a former Reagan administration attorney with whom she worked at Treasury, to represent her in the investigation. Wallison's office said he was out of town and not available for comment. Ms. Bush, through Slye, said last week that she had the power to issue no-bid contracts and did so because the agency was short-staffed and needed to get up and running. Kemp's decision to call in Adams is the latest development in a behind-the-scenes struggle between Ms. Bush and top Kemp deputies. Publicly, Kemp and others at HUD have maintained their support of Ms. Bush but one of the housing secretary's top deputies said nearly two months ago in a memo to other Kemp aides that he hoped she would leave. In his Feb. 5, memo, obtained by The Associated Press, DelliBovi said ``Wendell'' had told a new agency employee he wanted to soon leave the Housing Finance Board. ``If he goes let's hope he takes Mary,'' is how DelliBovi concluded the memo. Among the six Kemp aides to whom it was addressed was Mary Brunette, Kemp's closest adviser. She said Friday she did not recall ever reading the memo. ``To my knowledge the secretary was not aware of any contractual relationship or financial relationship between Wendell Gunn and the Federal Housing Finance Board,'' Ms. Brunette said. ``If I became aware of such a relationship I would have told him.'' But Gunn, in an angry letter to DelliBovi this week said: ``The secretary did in fact know I was being paid for my work and, if you ask, he will tell you so. In fact, in late November, I offered to end the arrangement retroactively, giving up all accrued compensation, if the secretary thought there was even the appearance of a problem.''

DOC.HEAD: 35 Nations Accused of Having Trade Barriers Against U.S. Products
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today accused 35 separate nations of erecting trade barriers against U.S. products, the first stage of a process that could result in retaliation against countries that refuse to open their doors to American goods. The accusations were included in the 1990 edition of the ``National Trade Report on Foreign Trade Barriers.' Japan, which accounts for almost of half of America's $109 billion trade deficit, was singled out for having more barriers than any other country, accounting for 19 pages 216 page report. South Korea was the second worst offender with 10 pages of alleged infractions. Today's report was the first step in drawing up a list of priority countries the administration will target for intensive negotiations aimed at getting the offending trade barriers eliminated. That priority list is due on April 30. The requirement for a target list of countries was the most controversial section of the 1988 trade law. In addition to Japan and South Korea, 33 other nations and two trading blocks were singled out for barriers against U.S. products. The other countries were: Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, China, Colombia, Egypt, West Germany, Finland, France, Greece, India, Indonesia, Israel, Italy, Malaysia, Medico, New Zealand, Nigeria, Norway, Pakistan, the Philippines, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Taiwan, Thailand, Turkey, the United Kingdom, Venezuela and Yugoslavia. The two trading blocs were the 12 nation European Community and the Gulf Cooperation Council, which includes Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.

DOC.HEAD: Orders Bounce Back After Steep January Fall
DOC.TEXT: Orders to factories for manufactured goods bounced back 1.8 percent in February from their steepest dive in 16 years a month earlier, the government said Friday. Still, orders were running below the levels posted late last year. Analysts said the report was more evidence of sluggishness in the industrial sector of the economy, but also found signs indicating improvement ahead. ``Manufacturing is aimlessly drifting along on a plateau,'' Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Co. in Chicago, said of the report. ``The mini-recession in manufacturing is still there.'' Evalina Tainer, senior economist for the First National Bank of Chicago, agreed, but added that the report suggests ``the manufacturing sector has bottomed out and we could be a little bit on the mend.'' The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and non-durable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $231.6 billion after plummeting 5.5 percent in January, the steepest drop since a 7 percent decline in December 1974. January's plunge was even deeper than the 5.4 percent reported last month. But while the February rebound was not back to pre-January levels, Dederick and Ms. Tainer saw signs of optimism in a category often used in measuring future business investment plans. ``Capital goods orders less aircraft are looking a little firmer than they did before,'' Dederick said. ``They're showing some signs of underlying support to the expansion. I'm not saying strength, but weakness is not developing.'' Commerce said non-defense capital goods orders less aircraft rose 2.2 percent in February. Durable goods orders advanced 2.6 percent. Durable goods orders _ expensive items expected to last more than three years _ have been affected most by the Federal Reserve's high-interest policies because they often are financed by loans. The department said durable goods orders were concentrated in transportation equipment, up 10.4 percent to $29.9 billion. Transportation orders had led the overall January decline with a drop of 29.4 percent. Non-durable goods orders rose 0.9 percent to $110.7 billion. The largest increases were in food and printing and publishing. Defense orders, which often are volatile, shot ahead 21.7 percent to $7.9 billion after falling 33.6 percent the previous month. Excluding defense, orders were up 1.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota's Rep. Bill Frenzel Says He Won't Seek Re-election In 1990
DOC.TEXT: Ten-term Rep. Bill Frenzel, the senior member of Minnesota's congressional delegation, announced today that he will not seek re-election this fall. ``Every member of Congress knows when the time has come not to run again,'' Frenzel, 61, told a news conference. ``For me, it is now.'' Frenzel, is the fourth-ranking Republican on the powerful Ways and Means Committee and the senior GOP lawmaker on the Budget committee. ``I have no specific plans for the future,'' he said. ``I expect to be useful in some way, but I am not looking for any more 80-hours-a-week jobs.'' Frenzel was first elected to the U.S. House in 1970 from the 3rd District, which includes western and southern Minneapolis suburbs and some outlying regions. The announcement was unexpected, and the race to succeed Frenzel him could attract a dozen or more candidates. Frenzel himself predicted ``30 or 40 candidates for my seat.'' Party primaries are held in September. ``What a shocker, a total surprise,'' said state Sen. Jim Ramstad, who is expected to be among the first of the IR candidates to enter the congressional race.

DOC.HEAD: Magistrate Says Man Accused in Credit Union Scheme Incompetent for Trial
DOC.TEXT: The former manager of a failed Omaha credit union is mentally incompetent to stand trial on federal charges of conspiracy, fraud and filing false tax returns, a magistrate said today. U.S. Magistrate Richard Kopf said he would recommend that Lawrence E. King Jr. be committed to a federal medical center in Rochester, Minn., for treatment. King was manager-treasurer of the Franklin Community Federal Credit Union, which was created to help north Omaha's poor. Federal regulators closed it in 1988, and officials said $39 million was missing. King, a wealthy black businessman who sang the national anthem at the 1984 Republican National Convention, is accused of diverting the money for his personal use. The prosecution agrees that King, 45, is not competent to stand trial, said assistant U.S. attorney Thomas Thalken. A psychiatrist diagnosed King as having ``probable delusional paranoid disorder _ grandiose type.'' Kopf said that while King understood the nature and consequences of the 40 charges against him, he would be unable to assist in his defense in the complex case. The magistrate said he would recommend to U.S. District Judge William G. Cambridge that doctors who treat King at the hospital report to the court within four months on whether King could face trial in the foreseeable future.

DOC.HEAD: Two Injured in Clashes Between Vietnamese Boat People
DOC.TEXT: About 100 Vietnamese boat people battled each other with homemade weapons at a detention center Friday, and two people were injured, police reported. It was not known what sparked the violence at the Shek Kong detention center, where about 6,000 Vietnamese live. The fighting broke out at 8 p.m. and was brought under control one hour later, police said. They said two Vietnamese were taken to hospitals where they were reported in serious condition. There have been several outbreaks of violence in the squalid and crowded refugee camps in this British colony, where about 44,000 people fleeing their Communist homeland have landed since mid-June 1989. Five people died last year in riots. In December, 51 Vietnamese were repatriated against their will, leading to a marked increase in tension in the camps.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian Makes Fence-Mending Visit to Israeli Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Panama's Vice President Guillermo Ford called at the Israeli Embassy Friday to smooth over differences resulting from Israel's past ties with deposed military leader Gen. Manuel Noriega and to propose joint economic projects. Ford, in the United States to lobby for economic aid to Panama, met with Ambassador Moshe Arad and David Turgeman, head of the Israeli foreign ministry's Latin American bureau, said spokeswoman Ruth Yaron. Ford said his government was determined to ``forgive and move on,'' Yaron said. Ford's comment refers to tensions between the two countries over Israel's close links to Noriega before he was ousted last December by a U.S. invasion force and brought to Miami to stand trial on drug trafficking charges. Israel had trained Noriega's personal bodyguards and its defense industries had several lucrative contracts with Panama. Noriega owned property in Israel and had sent his daughters there several times. One of Noriega's closest advisers was Mike Harari, a former operative of the Mossad intelligence agency who turned to private business in Latin America. The idea of the Israeli meeting with Ford was proposed during talks Turgeman held this week with Undersecretary of State Robert Kimmitt, Yaron said. The Panamanian Embassy confirmed the meeting took place but could not immediately provide details. Panama is anxious to rebuild its economy, shattered by a U.S. boycott of the country under Noriega and by the invasion itself. Ford and the Israeli diplomats agreed that Israel would provide Panama with expertise on agricultural projects and on rebuilding the country's medical system, Yaron said. Since neither Israel nor Panama have money for such projects, the United States may fund them, she said. Ford also was invited to visit Israel, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Slovaks Protest Country's New Name
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Slovaks rallied Friday to protest the country's new name, which does not have a hyphen to distinguish Slovaks from the dominant Czechs. The national Parliament voted Thursday night to drop the ``Socialist'' designation from the country's name and call the nation the Czechoslovak Federative Republic. That set off daylong protests in Bratislava, the capital of the Slovak republic. Parliament agreed to allow the Slovaks to write the new name with a hyphen. But the Slovaks wanted legislators to approve ``Czecho-Slovak Republic'' as the proper name of the country. Tension had been building for weeks between Czechs and Slovaks over the issue. The spontaneous protest Friday began outside the Slovak Parliament building and then moved to a central Bratislava square. Chanting ``Long live Slovakia!'' the crowd applauded speakers who asserted that the Czechs, who make up about two-thirds of Czechoslovakia's 15.5 million people, had ridden roughshod over the interests of the Slovaks. Some even carried banners calling for a sovereign Slovak state. Slovakia's Parliament unanimously passed a resolution demanding talks involving the federal Parliament and the leaderships of the Czech and Slovak republics on the name issue. Civic Forum and Public Against Violence, the movements that led last winter's peaceful revolution against Communism, appealed for an end to the strife. ``It seems the time when we could be proud of what we have achieved ... has ended,'' said Jan Urban, leader of Civic Forum. The row developed after President Vaclav Havel, a Czech, suggested in January that Czechoslovakia follow Poland and Hungary and drop the designation ``Socialist'' from its formal title of Czechoslovak Socialist Republic. The Slovaks suggested a hyphen be inserted in the new name to set them apart from the Czechs. But the hyphen suggestion was firmly rejected by the dominant Czech deputies, and by some Slovaks, when the federal Parliament voted Thursday. Slovakia became a republic in 1969. The division into Czech and Slovak republics meant that Slovakia got one-half of most federal resources. Slovak television and Czech radio both broadcast the rally for awhile. Slovak television abruptly halted the transmission after a few minutes. Czech radio broadcast remarks by an unidentified speaker but then cut off the transmission, saying it could not support separatist tendencies voiced in the speech.

DOC.HEAD: Report: More Research Needed on Mopping Up Oil Spills
DOC.TEXT: Technology for cleaning up a spill the size of the one caused by the Exxon Valdez was marginal to begin with and hasn't improved in the year since the accident, says a government report released Friday. Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, said the study shows that the government should create more incentives to study how to clean up oil. ``This report will be used to urge more investment in research and development,'' said Stevens as he released the study from Congress' Office of Technology Assessment. He suggested tax law changes to give industry more incentive to do the research. He also said pending legislation authorizes $28 million annually for national research into spill cleanup and $23 million over a 10-year period for the Prince William Sound oil spill institute. The Prince William Sound research would include a decade-long study of the impact of Exxon's nearly 11 million gallon crude oil spill last year on Alaska's natural environment. However, both industry and government should be focusing first on prevention, said Stevens. ``Short of eliminating oil transportation at sea, no perfect solution to the problem of offshore oil spills exists,'' said the OTA. ``Oil spills will occur again and the catastrophic ones will never be cleaned up satisfactorily. The proverbial ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.'' Stevens said legislation passed by both the House and Senate and now in conference has safety provisions designed to reduce the number of spills. The senator said he is certain a bill will be passed this year, but it's currently stalled in the conference committee because of differences between the Senate and the House over certain provisions, including whether tankers should be required to have double hulls and bottoms.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Stop Work in Homage to Colleague Killed By Terrorists
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of doctors and nurses went on strike nationwide Friday to pay homage to a colleague, who was allegedly slain for helping force terrorists on a hunger strike to eat. An estimated 3,000 doctors and nurses in this northern city took part in a 24-hour strike and silently marched from a hospital to the doctor's residence, where they left hundreds of white flowers. A two-hour work stoppage at health facilities was observed across the country. A woman shot and killed Dr. Ramon Munoz y Fernandez in his office Tuesday in this northern city, police said. No group has claimed responsibility. Officials blame the leftist group known as GRAPO, which had threatened doctors who fed jailed GRAPO hunger strikers. Munoz fed two convicted GRAPO terrorists during a recent hunger strike aimed at pressuring the government to stop dispersing jailed terrorists to numerous prisons.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors In State Hospitals Stage Nationwide Strike
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of government doctors around the country staged a 24-hour strike for more pay Friday, leaving most hospital patients in the provinces without medical care. The stoppage was the third this month by hospital doctors demanding better wages and protesting the possible closure of provincial hospitals. The government doctors say low staff levels in the provinces mean some hospitals would have to close down or cut back on services unless doctors are willing to work overtime for no extra pay. Doctors' salaries are indexed to rise automatically with inflation, currently at 15 percent. But Kyriakos Eleftheriadis, president of the Athens and Piraeus Hospital Doctors Union, said doctors have had no real pay increase since 1983. Georgios Sepirgiotis, vice president of the government doctors' union, said the average monthly pay for a senior hospital doctor is $660.

DOC.HEAD: President Gets Licenses to Fish
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, an avid fisherman, received fishing licenses Friday from the District of Columbia and adjacent Virginia and Maryland. ``There's a good possibility of fishing trips in the local area,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater after officials of the three jurisdictions gave Bush the licenses at a White House presentation. Since he's been in the White House, Bush has fished extensively in Maine _ both from his powerboat in the Atlantic off his vacation home in Kennebunkport and for freshwater fish in the nearby Kennebunk River. The president fished in Wyoming last year during a visit to Grand Teton National Park and in the Gulf of Mexico off the Texas coast near Corpus Christi during a year-end vacation. He plans to go fishing in the Florida Keys next month after a meeting at Key Largo with French President Francois Mitterrand. Presenting Bush with the fishing licenses were Elizabeth Haskell, Virginia Secretary of Natural Resources; Torrey Brown, Maryland Department of Natural Resources; and Ben Williams, manager of fishing licenses for the District of Columbia. White House aides said Bush hopes to fish in the Potomac River, the border between Maryland and Virginia, as well in some of the trout streams near Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Prisoners Execute Inmate to Protest Overcrowding
DOC.TEXT: Prisoners in a southeastern jail held a ``death lottery'' and executed the loser to protest overcrowding and poor living conditions, police said Friday. Police inspector Rosemarie Goncalves de Freitas said prisoners killed 27-year-old Marcelo de Pietro, who was serving a 31-year sentence for rape and murder. ``His fellow inmates strangled him with a nylon cord used to sew soccer balls. The execution was a way to protest overcrowded conditions,'' she said by telephone. The killing took place Thursday in the central jail of Santo Andre, an industrial suburb of Sao Paulo. Nearly 400 inmates were locked up in the Santo Andre jail. It was built to hold 96 prisoners. In de Pietro's cell, 47 inmates were kept in a space intended for six. Ms. Freitas said De Pietro was chosen by lottery but did not give details. Press reports said only rapists and murderers were included in the drawing. On Friday, 36 inmates were transferred to other prisons to prevent further executions, Ms. Freitas said.

DOC.HEAD: Airbus Rejects India's Accusations of Corruption
DOC.TEXT: Airbus Industrie on Friday rejected accusations by India's top investigative agency that its directors bribed former Indian government officials to win a $1.47 billion airplane contract. The European aircraft-manufacturing consortium threatened legal action against the unidentified sources of the charges made Thursday by the Central Bureau of Investigation in New Delhi. In a press statement, Airbus declared its ``astonishment by these fantasy-like accusations.'' The charges are the latest in the dispute between India and Airbus since the Feb. 14 crash of an Indian Airlines Airbus A320. The accident killed 92 of the 146 people aboard. Indian officials have said the crash was due to a computer malfunction. Airbus officials have blamed errors by the crew. The Central Bureau of Investigation on Thursday filed preliminary charges in the bribery scandal against officials from Airbus Industrie; International Aero Engines, which manufactured the aircraft's engines; and four former Indian aviation officials. In India, preliminary charges are registered when enough evidence exits to launch an investigation. Final charges are filed when an investigation is completed. The charges said Indian officials accepted kickbacks to reverse a decision to purchase U.S.-made Boeing 757 jetliners and instead buy 38 Airbus A320s in a deal concluded in June. The charges did not say how much money was allegedly involved. The government has grounded all Indian Airlines A320s pending an investigation of the crash. Further deliveries of the plane have been halted. Airbus Industrie is a consortium composed of British Aerospace, Aerospaciale of France, Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm Gmbh of West Germany and Aeronauticas Naccionales of Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Parents Say $1 a Week Not Too Much for Daughter's Memory
DOC.TEXT: For the drunken driver and the parents of the teen-age girl he killed, $1 a week is the price for getting on with the rest of their lives. ``I told the kid face-to-face, if you want to get on with your life and never see me again, just put a dollar in the mail every Friday,'' said Louis Herzog. Susan Herzog was 18 when she was killed on New Year's Day 1982. Kevin Tunell was 17, so his case went to Juvenile Court where he was convicted of manslaughter and drunken driving. Louis and Patricia Herzog filed a $1.5 million suit against Tunell, but settled for $936, to be paid $1 at a time to remind Tunell what he had done to their daughter. Tunell, now 26, keeps missing his payments. The Herzogs keep taking him to court. He was sentenced Thursday in Fairfax County Circuit Court to 30 days in jail for contempt because he has not lived up to his agreement to make the weekly payments. Circuit Judge Jack B. Stevens allowed him 30 days to appeal. Testifying Thursday, Tunell said he is haunted by Susan Herzog's death and tormented by the payments. ``It's like I'm not purposely not writing them because I want to defy the court and I'm trying to hurt the Herzogs. I just don't feel good. It hurts,'' he said, weeping. This was the fourth time in eight years that the Herzogs, both active in Mothers Against Drunk Driving, have been to court trying to enforce the dollar-a-week agreement. As his criminal sentence, Tunell was ordered to spend a year talking to groups about the evils of drunken driving. He completed that sentence, he said, and continued to campaign against drunken driving for the next six years. Tunell declined Friday to talk about the case. ``I think it's pretty evident what's going on. I think people will understand why I don't want to talk,'' Tunell said by telephone from his parents' home in Fairfax. ``I just want to get on with my life.'' Tunnel's lawyer, Stan Klein, also declined to answer questions but read a statement. ``Kevin and his family hope that this tragedy of over eight years ago can be left to the families that have suffered as a result of it, as they will have to continue to live with it for the rest of their lives,'' the statement said. The $1 payments are due each Friday because Susan died on a Friday. They began in 1982 and will end in 2000 _ one year for every year Susan lived. The agreement specifies that payments are to be made by check made out to Susan Herzog. Her parents deposit the money in a scholarship fund at Virginia Tech, earmarked for students from Robinson High School, where their daughter was a senior. From the witness stand Thursday, Tunell offered the Herzogs two boxes of checks covering payments until 2001, one year more than required. They refused. ``What we want is to receive that check every week on time,'' Mrs. Herzog said. ``He must understand we are going to pursue this until August of the year 2000. We will go back to court every month if we have to.'' The couple say they have no sympathy for drunken drivers. A second daughter, Deborah, was hit by a drunken driver in 1987. The Florida accident crushed Deborah Herzog's legs and she now walks with a permanent limp. Judge Stevens, while ruling Tunell in contempt, questioned the parents' persistence. ``It's been said, `To err is human. But to forgive is divine,''' Stevens said. ``I suppose to forgive is divine, but unfortunately Lou Herzog is just an average guy,'' Herzog said Friday. ``We're always asked why are we doing this, why are we trying to ruin this boy's life,'' he said. ``We're not vindictive. We're not trying to destroy this young man. All we want is what we agreed to. We're getting on with our lives and we want him to get on with his.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Gaining Allies in Effort To Repeal U.N. Resolution
DOC.TEXT: The United States is working to repeal the 1975 U.N. resolution equating Zionism with racism but will not call for a vote in the General Assembly unless success is guaranteed, a State Department official said Friday. ``We are taking action and will intensify our efforts during the 1990 session of the General Assembly,'' John R. Bolton, assistant secretary of state for international organization affairs, told a congressional hearing. ``We must be most careful, nonetheless, to ensure that our efforts are not subverted by those hostile to Israel and to the Middle East peace process.'' The Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Near Eastern and South Asian affairs is considering a joint resolution calling on all U.N. members to repeal General Assembly Resolution 3379. Zionism, the movement to support the Jewish national state of Israel, is opposed by Israel's Arab neighbors and their allies. The United States has been consulting with countries that originally voted for Resolution 3379 ``but which have subsequently acquired new governments and new thinking,'' Bolton told the subcommittee. ``Our consultations are far from over but we have seen substantial evidence of shifts of opinion,'' he said, citing indications from Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Mexico. The United States is also talking with Arab countries and with nations that abstained or were absent for the 1975 vote or which joined the United Nations after that, Bolton said. Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., the chairman of the subcommittee, asked Bolton to produce a list of countries that voted for Resolution 3379 and that also receive direct U.S. aid. ``Have we ever told one country _ just one country _ that you're getting American money but you're not going to get any more unless you change your mind?'' Moynihan asked. Bolton said he did not know.

DOC.HEAD: Natori Heads from Lingerie to Luxury Fashion
DOC.TEXT: Josie Cruz Natori, once a Wall Street investment banker, is heading back to New York as avant-garde designer trying to bring underwear out of the closet and into the fashion spotlight. Her first full-scale show opens in Manhattan on Wednesday, and she admits to some nervousness. ``You never know how critics will react,'' said the diminutive Philippine-born American. Mrs. Natori, 43, has been building a solid business and reputation in the lingerie field for 10 years and now feels it's time to go big-time. ``I don't want my fashion to be categorized. I almost hate the word `lingerie' to describe it,'' she said, escorting a model wearing a luxurious gold charmeuse satin sheath and embroidered velvet cape out of her Paris bedroom. Her career has gone from boardroom to bedroom and now to ballroom. She entered the investment banking business in 1968 and in 1976 became the first woman vice president of Merrill Lynch. ``I simply wanted to build my own business and fell into the design field almost by accident,'' said Mrs. Natori, who grew up in Manila. ``I was researching a business I could start based on Filipino artisans' skills. So in 1977 a friend sent me some Filipino-embroidered blouses.'' A buyer at Bloomingdales saw a blouse and told Mrs. Natori, ``Make it into a nightshirt.'' ``I ddn't even know what a nightshirt was,'' said Mrs. Natori. But she was soon enthusiastically turning out nightshirts _ not to mention sexy merry widows, bedjackets. She later expanded into embroidered ``mules,'' ballerina slippers and appliqued bathroom linens, plus a line of toiletries. From an initial outlay of $10,000, her company has grown into a $25 million business. Her husband of 17 years, Ken Natori, recently quit his Wall Street job with a six-figure salary to help manage the operation. ``I couldn't have done this without my family's support, though they thought I was crazy to leave a good financial job,'' said Mrs. Natori. She credits her father's acumen for her business flair and her mother's artistic eye for her design talents. ``But women in the Philippines are strong managers, too,'' added Mrs. Natori. ``My grandmother was nicknamed `Supreme Commander' and my mother was `Commander in Chief.' '' Mrs. Natori was educated at a Catholic school in Manila, then attended Manhattanville College in New York. Her first job at Bache and Co. in 1968 took her right back to the Philippines to open a new office. Returning to New York, she was just into a new job with Merrill Lynch in 1971 when she met her future husband. The Natoris now have a 14-year-old son and what Mrs. Natori calls ``a rare work-and-home relationship.'' ``Paris is the `soul' side of me,'' said Mrs. Natori, who manufactures both in the United States and the Philippines but gravitates to the French capital. She opened her first free-standing shop at the prestigious Place Vendome in Paris two years ago. ``And I come back for fashion stimulation and relaxation whenever I can,'' she said. But she takes fashion with a grain of salt. ``There is too much emphasis on categories, like sportswear, office wear, lingerie,'' she said. ``I'm primarily interested in making a good product that people will buy, something that's different, that you can wear to dress up at home or go out in,'' she said. ``That's the philosophy of my clothes that have grown out of underwear.'' She feels many high-style clothes are overpriced. Her recent gold-embroidered velvet cape retails for about $1,200. She says her first fashion show will be modest, featuring just 60 select models, though she regularly turns out five lines a year of about 350 pieces each. Can she draw? ``Yes, but I have seven assistants as well, and our total staff is about 700.'' Mrs. Natori is an accomplished pianist and on request, sat down to execute a Chopin Nocturne on her Paris concert Steinway. Later at a party for fashion people, she played musical comedy songs by ear as her guests sang along. Her professional passion is business, not fashion, she said. ``I can't take it too seriously. I design what I'd like to wear myself, and hope it flies.''

DOC.HEAD: Baldness, Multiple Motherhood May Be Linked to Coronary Risk
DOC.TEXT: Baldheaded men and mothers who bear five or more children develop blood cholesterol patterns that might raise their risk of heart disease, according to studies released Friday. In a study of 872 electronics factory workers in Italy, Dr. Maurizio Trevisan found blood cholesterol and blood pressure levels rose with age among the 278 men with ``male-pattern baldness.'' They defined that as a receding hairline and a bald spot on the crown of the head. The small but significant increases weren't found among the 321 men with full heads of hair or the 273 with receding hairlines but not a balding crown, said Trevisan, an epidemiologist at the State University of New York at Buffalo. The study, released at an American Heart Association meeting, is ``reason to lose one more hair,'' John Capps, founder of Baldheaded Men of America, said by phone from Morehead City, N.C. ``Maybe we need to put our heads together on it and work out a solution.'' Trevisan and colleagues at the University of Naples plan research on whether elevated cholesterol and blood pressure levels actually make bald men more prone to heart attack and stroke. ``If these data are confirmed, they could be at higher risk,'' he said. ``Right now, I have no idea. ... These (elevated levels) are not numbers that place these men in a very high-risk category for developing coronary heart disease. But this may change as the men age.'' If elevated blood pressure and cholesterol also are found in other populations, Trevisan's study would be considered ``a breakthrough observation,'' said Dr. Elizabeth Barrett-Connor, chairwoman of community and family medicine at the University of California, San Diego. Barrett-Connor co-authored the study of multiple pregnancies. In her study of 1,275 women in Rancho Bernardo, near San Diego, she found that the women who had at least five pregnancies had a nearly 8 percent drop in levels of high-density lipoprotein, which is believed to protect against heart disease. There was no drop in the so-called ``good'' cholesterol among women with fewer children. ``Pregnancy may be another risk for heart disease, but it does not show up until five or more,'' said Barrett-Connor's colleague Donna Kritz-Silverstein. Like the bald men, the women with five or more kids haven't been followed long enough to know if they actually will develop higher heart disease rates. They were studied for 10 years since their most recent pregnancies. ``I'm not going to recommend women do family planning based on this'' single study, said Barrett-Connor. ``I would tell a woman who had five or more kids her HDL is the least of her troubles.'' Kritz-Silverstein said, ``Several, but not all studies have reported an increased risk of cardiovascular disease among women who have been pregnant,'' and decreased high-density lipoprotein levels may be one explanation. Also Friday, University of Iowa scientists said they found sixth- through eighth-grade children had significantly lower ``good'' cholesterol levels if one or both parents smoked at home daily or if the child chewed tobacco weekly or smoked cigarettes monthly. Aside from lung disease, the possible heart disease link ``is another reason for parents who smoke to think seriously about the toxic effect their habit has on their children,'' said Dr. Paul Pomrehn, the study's author. High-density lipoprotein, or HDL, hooks onto cholesterol in blood, carrying the fatty substance to the liver for disposal so it won't clog arteries and cause heart attacks and strokes. In the baldness study, all the men had similar cholesterol and blood pressure levels when the research started in 1975, but those with male-pattern baldness developed high levels as they grew older and lost hair. By 1987, they averaged blood cholesterol levels of 214 milligrams per deciliter, compared with 208 for non-bald men and men with only receding hairlines. Trevisan and Barrett-Connor speculated hormone changes accompanying balding and pregnancy might cause the cholesterol patterns they found. Those patterns existed even after accounting for individual differences in age, weight and obesity, and cigarette and alcohol consumption.

DOC.HEAD: Gunshots Fired From Ground Injure Military Helicopter Passenger
DOC.TEXT: Gunshots fired from the ground struck a military helicopter on a medical flight today, injuring a doctor aboard and prompting the craft to make an emergency landing, authorities said. Three shots were fired about 11:30 a.m. at the Vermont Air National Guard helicopter, which was on an emergency medical mission to Massena, N.Y., said Lt. Lloyd Goodrow, National Guard spokesman. There were five people on board, three military personnel and two civilians, Goodrow said. The doctor was accompanying a patient being taken from Massena Memorial Hospital to Vermont Medical Center, said National Guard spokesman Jim Banks. The injured man, a medical resident from Vermont Medical Center in Burlington, Vt., was shot in the neck and shoulder but his injuries were not life-threatening, said Bart Hayes, emergency department manager at Champlain Valley Physicians Hospital in Plattsburgh. The helicopter landed along state Route 190 in the Clinton County town of Altona, about 150 miles north of Albany, according to state police. Massena is about 55 miles west of the crash site. The helicopter crew realized something was wrong with the craft when an oil light went on, Goodrow said. The pilots, not immediately realizing someone in the back of the copter had been shot, decided to land as a precaution after seeing the oil pressure fall. ``Obviously, somebody shot at a low-flying helicopter,'' said Gen. Don Edwards of the Vermont Army National Guard. ``That's a federal offense and the FBI will be investigating.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Soviet Soldiers Occupy Lithuanian Government Building
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Prosecutor's office reportedly taken over by Soviet troops. TRIMS to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet troops occupied Lithuania's Prosecutor's Office today after its staff members refused to take orders from a new chief prosecutor appointed by Moscow, Lithuanian officials said. If the report is confirmed, it would be the first time Soviet soldiers have taken control of a Lithuanian government building since the Baltic republic defied Moscow and declared its independence on March 11. The report came several hours after the White House announced that President Bush had called for a peaceful resolution of the Lithuanian crisis. The trouble began at the Prosecutor's Office earlier today when Moscow officials fired Lithuania's chief prosecutor in a bid to make the republic adhere to Soviet law, then tried to intall new prosecutor of their choosing. The move failed when the office's employees said they would remain loyal to their former boss. The dispute became a standoff, with both chief prosecutors trying to run the office at the same time. Several hours later, soldiers of the Soviet Interior Ministry took over the building with the help of one employee, Egidius Bickauskas, a Lithuanian legislator, said on the republic's television. He did not elaborate. He accused the Soviet Union of violating the republic's sovereignty. A Lithuanian Interior Ministry spokesman confirmed that Soviet soldiers were inside the Prosecutor's Office. He also said the soldiers had moved into the Institute of Party History. A foreign journalist who rushed to the scene said he saw a truckload of Soviet Interior Ministry soldiers enter the building. Soldiers previously had occupied a handful of Communist Party buildings in Lithuania, but today was the first time they reportedly occupied a Lithuanian government building. Also today, the KGB pledged to protect Lithuanian citizens who cooperate with it in enforcing Soviet law. The statement, distributed by the Tass news agency, called illegal a resolution passed Tuesday by Lithuania's legislature saying KGB ``informers'' risk being punished and having their names published. Before today's reported occupation, Moscow's tactics had included shows of military force, the arrest of army deserters and orders for foreigners to leave and for residents to turn in their guns. In response to a Kremlin demand for a referendum, Lithuania on Thursday offered to hold a public vote on whether to rejoin the Soviet Union. The White House said today that President Bush sent a letter to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev calling for a peaceful resolution in Lithuania. The letter, sent via diplomatic channels on Thursday, stated Bush's ``suppot and the American support for the aspirations of the Lithuanian people for self-determination,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. ``We have expressed our belief and our emphatic view that a resolution of this conflict lies in peaceful dialogue,'' Fitzwater said of the letter. On Thursday, the Lithuanian Prosecutor's Office ordered police not to carry out Gorbachev's order to confiscate firearms that citizens had not surrendered. Lithuanian police had already refused. The standoff began at the office when Moscow officials tried to replace Arturis Paulauskas, the prosecutor appointed by the Lithuanian government on March 22. Soviet Deputy Prosecutor Alexei Vasiliev told more than 100 members of the Lithuanian prosecutor's staff to execute Soviet law. He brought with him an ethnic Lithuanian, Antanas Petrauskas, to replace Paulauskas. Tass later carried a statement from Soviet Prosecutor General Alexander Sukharev firing Paulauskas and officially naming Petrauskas as his successor. Staff members reacted during the meeting with angry questions. ``Do you know our government was elected legally?'' one employee shouted. Bickauskas, the Lithuanian legislator, told the staff: ``I hope you will consider your place is in your offices under the leadership of Mr. Paulauskas.'' Nearly everyone applauded as they rose to leave the room and returned to their their desks. ``You must obey the orders of the general prosecutor of the U.S.S.R.,'' Vasiliev said in a raised voice as people left. But his appeal had little effect until the building was taken over later. Vasiliev told a handful of reporters after he was ignored that his 11-member team from Moscow is ``not an instrument of force,'' and that his next step in the struggle would be a legal one. He would not elaborate. Paulauskas, back in his office, said: ``I am the prosecutor of Lithuania, and I will stay here until force is used against me.'' Foreign reporters attended the meeting, although the press corps in Vilnius has dwindled since Soviet authorities barred foreigners from Lithuania and refused to extend permission to stay for correspondents already there. Foreign journalists in the Soviet Union are all based in Moscow and must get permission to travel outside the capital and state the length of their stay. As their departure dates arrive, reporters have been leaving Vilnius. Lithuania wants back the independence it enjoyed before being crushed by the Soviet Union in 1940 along with the two other Baltic republics of Estonia and Latvia. A Stalin-Hitler pact gave the Soviets control over the republics.

DOC.HEAD: Train Derails, Collapses Viaduct; Motorists Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with detail, quotes. No pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A train derailed and rammed the supports of an aging viaduct today, causing part of the span to collapse and injuring three people driving on a roadway over it, authorities said. One of the injured, an unidentified 39-year-old woman, was in fair condition with a chest injury, while the other two were treated and released, said a St. Joseph's Hospital spokeswoman who declined to give her name. Union Pacific spokesman John Bromley said two switching engines were pulling nine cars when the third car, a covered grain hopper, apparently derailed and struck the support of the Locust Street bridge. At least one adjoining rail car also derailed. Locust Street is a two-lane street that goes mainly through an industrial area. The accident occurred shortly before 11 a.m. about two miles southwest of Eppley Airfield, the area's principal commercial airport. About 250 feet of the bridge collapsed. Afterward, two railroad cars were lying at an angle under the metal, concrete and aged white wood of the bridge. Perry Soule, manager of Troll Auto Parts along the tracks, said he heard a noise and ran outside, adding, ``It sounded like thunder.'' He said he helped put out a fire in one of the three cars on the debris of the bridge. Rescue workers had to pry open the door of one motorist's car, witnesses said. The accident occurred while during switching operations in northern Omaha, said Alex Tice, a Union Pacific Railroad spokesman. It was unclear what caused the derailment. ``We've got people out there right now,'' Tice said. ``None of the train people are injured.'' Lou Lamberty, Omaha public works director, said he thought the bridge was built in 1916. It was last inspected in February 1989, and discussions were under way to have it torn down and replaced by a grade crossing.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: If it weren't for skin color, Little Richard says, he _ not Elvis Presley _ could have reigned as the king of rock 'n' roll. ``If I was white, do you know how huge I'd be?'' Little Richard asks in the April 19 issue of Rolling Stone. ``I think Elvis was more acceptable being white in that period. I believe if Elvis had been black, he wouldn't have been as big as he was.'' The rock pioneer, who recorded classics such as ``Tutti Frutti'' and ``Lucille,'' says he can recall being upstaged only once during his flamboyant 43-year performing career. The man who did it: the late Jimi Hendrix. ``He was my guitar player, and you know, we didn't know he could play with his mouth. One night I heard this screaming and hollering, and they were screaming and hollering for him!'' says Richard. ``I thought they were screaming for me. But he was back there playing the guitar with his mouth.''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON8
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Name pronounced yoo-ZHAY-nee
DOC.TEXT: The newest member of British royalty, week-old Princess Eugenie Victoria Helena, slept through the crowd's cheers and clattering cameras Friday as she went home with her parents, the Duke and Duchess of York. Buckingham Palace announced Princess Eugenie's name shortly after the royal couple stepped from Portland Hospital with their new princess, wrapped in a white blanket. Princess Eugenie is the sixth grandchild of Queen Elizabeth II and sixth in the line of succession. She is the second daughter born to the duchess and her husband, Prince Andrew. The 30-year-old Duchess of York, the former Sarah Ferguson, gave birth to Princess Eugenie by Caesarean section on March 23. The baby's name surprised Britain. Bookmakers said they had thousands of bets but not one for Eugenie. It was the name of Queen Victoria's granddaughter, the daughter of Princess Beatrice who was Victoria's fifth daughter and youngest child. The baby's second name _ Victoria _ comes from Queen Victoria herself, and the third name, Helena, comes from the third daughter of Queen Victoria. Eugenie is the French derivative of the ancient Greek word ``Eugenia'' meaning ``nobility'' and ``excellence,'' and was made fashionable in 19th- century France by the Empress Eugenie, wife of Emperor Napoleon III, said David Williamson, co-editor of Debrett's Peerage, a leading reference book on the aristocracy.

Rhythm & Blues singer Regina Belle says adopting a newborn girl four months ago has thrown her headlong into the war against drugs. Ms. Belle said having a child in her life made her realize that other children needed someone to help them learn to say no to drugs. When she is not touring, Ms. Belle, 26, helps with a fund-raising project in Harlem called the Children's Storefront Program, which sends underprivileged children to college. ``I think the biggest problem in America today is not drugs; it's misguidance, no guidance and illiteracy,'' said Ms. Belle, whose current single ``Make It Like It Was'' is getting video play on cable television.

Americans could get smarter by watching nothing but the Public Broadcasting Service on television, but viewers prefer less intellectual programming, says entertainer Steve Allen. In an interview published Friday to promote a performance in Nashville, Allen said ``you'd have a more literate, intelligent populace'' if television viewers tuned in only to PBS. But he said that most people ``when given a choice between true quality and garbage ... are likely to head for the garbage.'' He discussed television while commenting on his new book, ``Dumbth,'' which concerns what he calls the ineptitude of the American citizen. Allen, 68, is a musician, comedian, songwriter, author and former host of the ``Tonight'' show on NBC.

Michael Eisner, the entertainment wizard who's turned around the Walt Disney Co., should feel like a man on top of the Matterhorn. Eisner didn't sound sky-high during a speech Thursday night at the St. Mary's College 33rd annual Executives Symposium. ``How do I feel about all this good fortune?'' Eisner asked. ``In a word, panic.'' In an interview published in Friday's Contra Costa Times, Eisner, 48, said he rarely rests easy. ``We always think the sky is falling, that our last movie hit is really going to be our last hit, period,'' said Eisner. ``I tend to run scared. I always like to think that there are two outs in the last of the ninth inning and we're three runs down.'' Disney has to stay on its toes, Eisner said, because ``ours is an unpredictable and often irrational business that generally defies logic. ``There is no sure-fire formula for success in the entertainment industry. But there are any number of interesting ways to fail,'' said Eisner, who became one of the highest-paid U.S. executives when he became Disney's chairman in 1984. In the next decade, Disney intends to build second theme parks in Southern California and Tokyo, expanding Disneyland in Anaheim and Disney World in Florida and building a Euro Disneyland near Paris. When the company's first European theme park is complete in 1992, Eisner said, a Disney ride will be operating somewhere in the world every minute of every day. Other projects include a new record company, 15 network TV pilots and a restaurant chain called Mickey's Kitchen. ``As I think of all these developments, I get very excited,'' Eisner said. ``Just before the panic sets in.''

DOC.HEAD: Woman Toting Rifle Holes Up in Actress' Home Before Surrendering
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Ms. Penn gave...', to CORRECT police captain's first name to Dan sted Don. SUBS 6th graf, `She was...', to add that weapon was loaded.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY26
DOC.TEXT: An obsessed fan who once threatened to kill herself in front of actress Sharon Gless holed up in the ``Cagney and Lacey'' star's home with a rifle for seven hours today before surrendering, authorities said. Joni Leigh Penn, 30, who had been under court order to stay away from Miss Gless, was led from the house shortly after 10 a.m. and placed in a police car. The actress was not at home at the time of the incident. Ms. Penn gave herself up, police Capt. Dan Watson said, adding, ``She was tired. She was just kind of worn down.'' He said a special weapons team went inside the house and officers talked to the woman through the door of a bathroom in which she barricaded herself. She was coherent throughout the standoff and no shots were fired, Watson said. Ms. Penn had threatened to kill herself, but it was unclear whether she also intended to harm the 46-year-old actress, Watson said. She was being booked for investigation of felony burglary, Watson said. The woman had been carrying a weapon resembling an assault rifle, but Watson said the weapon recovered was an AT-22, a .22-caliber rifle. He said the weapon was loaded. In November 1988, a judge ordered Ms. Penn to stay away from Miss Gless, her homes and relatives. The previous month, Ms. Penn reportedly went to Miss Gless' home and told the actress' secretary she had a gun. She threatened to shoot herself in front of the actress, according to a letter submitted to the Superior Court by Ms. Penn's psychiatrist, Hubert Nestor. During 1988, Miss Gless received 20 letters from Ms. Penn. Obsessed fans have stalked many celebrities, including Johnny Carson, David Letterman, Olivia Newton-John, Michael Landon and Michael J. Fox. In the most serious Hollywood incidents, ``My Sister Sam'' star Rebecca Schaeffer was shot to death last year and actress Theresa Saldana was injured in a knifing eight years ago. Miss Gless, who won a best actress Emmy in 1987 for her role as the tough police detective Christine Cagney, has a single-story stucco house on a tree-lined cul-de-sac in Studio City. Homes in the area about 15 miles north of downtown Los Angeles are valued at about $300,000. Ten neighboring homes were evacuated as a precaution, but some residents were allowed to return after police entered the Gless house, officers said. Neighbor Sam Snider said the Gless home is protected by a sliding gate but it would be easy to get inside anyway. ``Sharon's always so friendly. I don't know what difficulties she would be having with this woman,'' said Snider. CBS on Wednesday announced that Miss Gless would reunite with ``Cagney and Lacey'' executive producer Barney Rosenzweig to create a new dramatic series for the 1990-91 season tentatively titled ``Renewal.'' The show is to deal with a woman in her early 40s who has been through a difficult divorce and re-enters the work force.

DOC.HEAD: Guilty Plea Entered in Pentagan Case
DOC.TEXT: A former Unisys Corp. employee under investigation in the Pentagon procurement scandal of the 1980s pleaded guilty Friday to a felony count of filing a false income tax return. Frederick J. Carville of New Hartford, N.Y., entered the plea in the Operation Ill Wind case before U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton in Alexandria, Va. He could be sentenced to up to three years in prison and fined $100,000. The plea resulted from negotiations between the U.S. attorney's office and Carville's attorney, said Michael Costello, who heads the Washington field office of the Defense Department's criminal investigative service. Operation Ill Wind concerned allegations that defense contractors and consultants bribed Pentagon officials to obtain inside information that would give them a competitive advantage in obtaining multimillion dollar contracts. The investigation began in the summer of 1986 but was not revealed until June 1988 when federal agents executed dozens of search warrants nationwide. Numerous companies and individuals have pleaded guilty or have been convicted in the probe. Carville, a Unisys marketing representative, was responsible for getting business for the company at the Rome Air Development Center at Rome, N.Y., a government facility that does electronics research, primarily for the Air Force. Costello said Carville and two other Unisys employees _ Charles F. Gardner and Steven Monas _ ``came up with this sceme to try to get contracts from the Rome Air Development Center. He (Carville) was supposed to ingratiate himself with the employees at that facility, so they gave him money'' to spend on entertainment for the employees. ``He formed this company to funnel the money through so it wouldn't be traceable to him,'' Costello said. The company was called Consul-Tech Inc., and Carville and his wife were the sole shareholders and officers, according to Costello. Carville also created BPD Enterprises, a partnership consisting of his wife and three daughters. In a 1983 income tax return for Consul-Tech, Carville claimed false deductions for consulting services provided by BPD and falsely deducted expenses realted to a Jaguar automobile bought for Monas, Costello said. Gardner, considered by prosecutors to be a major figure in the Ill Wind investigation, was a Unisys vice president at its Great Neck, N.Y., facility. He pleaded guilty a year ago to charges of bribing Pentagon officials for inside information on contract bids and setting up a slush fund to pay bribes and make illegal campaign contributions. Gardner was sentenced in September to 32 months in prison and was fined $40,000. Costello would not say whether Monas, the Air Force marketing director for Unisys' Great Neck facility, was under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Study Says New Drug Treatment Can Reduce Paralysis
DOC.TEXT: Massive doses of a steroid drug given within hours of a spinal cord injury can significantly reduce paralysis for patients who previously had seemed beyond help, a government study reported Friday. The study, conducted at 10 centers around the United States, proved that the drug methylprednisolone was able to restore some feeling and movement in virtually all spinal cord injury patients, marking the first time that an effective treatment for such paralyzing injuries has been found, federal officials said. ``We now know that paralysis after spinal cord injury can be reduced by early treatment,'' said Michael B. Bracken, a professor at the Yale University School of Medicine who directed the study. ``We were never certain about that before this study.'' Clinical trials of the drug involved 487 spinal injury patients. The study compared the results of 162 treated with methylprednisolone with 154 treated with naloxone and 171 who received a placebo. The results, said, Bracken, show that methylprednisolone is ``an effective treatment for reducing some of the neurological damage of a spinal injury.'' Officials who monitored the study said its results could have an important effect on the lives of some 10,000 Americans annually who suffer acute spinal cord injury. Automobile accidents are the most common source of such injuries. Most such injuries occur in men under the age of 30 and most such patients will spend their lives permanently disabled. Methylprednisolone has been used for years to treat shock, to prevent swelling of the brain from injury or stroke and to stabilize membranes after injury. For the spinal injury study, researchers at the clinical centers gave patients 10 to 100 times the normal dosage within a 23-hour period. The result, said Bracken, is that virtually all patients receiving the drug improved to some degree. The improvement was significantly greater than for patients with similar injuries who received other treatment. Bracken said the study results have been evaluated by reviewers and will be published in May in the New England Journal of Medicine. He said the announcement was made in advance of publication in hopes that patients can benefit immediately. Federal officials said doctors may obtain information about treatment with the drug by calling 301-496-5751 during working hours. Weekends, the number to call is 800-633-3425. The drug works only if it is given within eight hours after a spinal cord injury. About 95 percent of all spinal cord patients are admitted to hospitals within eight hours, which means that most can benefit from this therapy, Bracken said. Some patients in the study reported remarkable and unexpected recovery from serious spinal injuries. In Phoenix, doctors credit the drug with saving Denise Shoblom, owner of several Arizona broadcast outlets, from possible paralysis. Ms. Shoblom was taken to Kingman Regional Medical Center in August 1989, following an auto accident. Doctors there injected methylprednisolone on the recommendation of doctors at Barrow Neurological Institute, one of the centers taking part in the federal study. Just after the accident, Ms. Shoblom had no feeling in her limbs, but she is now walking on her own and hopes to make a complete recovery. ``Because this medication was given to her within eight hours of her injury, she was able to recover much of her motor function,'' said Dr. Volker Sonntag of Barrow. ``If it hadn't been for this medication, she might be completely paralyzed today.'' Much of the improvement seen among patients receiving the medication was much more subtle, Bracken said. Among quadriplegics, he said, the improvement might mean that a patient would be able to use a hand that without the drug would have been paralyzed. For those who might have had paralyzed legs, said Bracken, the improvement could mean that they would be able to transfer themselves from wheelchair to car, or that they would be able to walk with crutches. Some, he said, were able to leave wheelchairs permanently. Precisely how the drug works is still not clear. Dr. William F. Collins, chairman of the surgery department at Yale, said that medical science has long believed that the paralyzing effects of spinal injuries actually occur only as an indirect result of the trauma itself. He said it is believed that injured nerve cells release a substance that damages adjacent cells and nerve fiber, causing paralysis to set in. ``It's sort of a cascade that continues for several hours after the injury,'' said Collins. Massive doses of methylprednisolone ``alters that cascade ... and then protects those adjacent cells and fibers.'' The study was supported by the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, one of the National Institutes of Health. The clinical centers taking part in the study were Yale University School of Medicine, New Haven, Conn.; Medical University of South Carolina, Charleston; New York University Bellevue Medical Center, New York; University of Texas Medical Branch, Galveston; Baylor University College of Medicine, Houston; Barrow Neurological Institute, Phoenix; University of California, San Diego; Harborview Medical Center, Seattle; University of California, Davis, and Allegheny General Hospital, Pittsburgh.

DOC.HEAD: Bad Grammar No Grounds for Appeal, Maine Supreme Court Says
DOC.TEXT: It don't make no difference if prosecutors go after criminals with indictments that use bad grammar, the state's highest court said in a ruling that may help perpetuate generations of language abuse by lawyers. Convicted arsonist Leon Corson Sr. said he should have been cleared because the indictment against him was so poorly written and ambiguous that it made no sense. The indictment returned by grand jurors in Piscataquis County contained a 180-word sentence that takes up 14 lines on the page. It said in part, that ``with the intent that conduct be performed which, in fact, would constitute a crime or crimes,'' the fire in question was set. The Maine Supreme Judicial Court's five justices did not buy Corson's arguments, saying the indictment, ``even though grammatically incorrect, adequately informs the defendant of the nature of the charge against him.'' This week's ruling came as no surprise to scholars of English, who said Friday that lawyers are among the worst language offenders. ``A 180-word sentence should be taken out and be shot,'' said Richard Lederer, a columnist and language author from Concord, N.H. ``It is disgraceful. They're trying to protect somebody's rights and it's very tough to do with a 180-word sentence, even if it's 180 simple words.'' At the University of Southern Maine, assistant professor of English Willard Rusch said most lawyers should plead guilty to using ``fossilized phrases in English that people don't use.'' ``Sentences of that type are written according to outdated rules of grammar, and they're difficult for people to understand,'' Rusch said. ``Possibly, the person has a real good complaint.'' The justices didn't see it that way, although they pointed out that Maine law insists an indictment ``shall be a plain, concise and definite written statement of the essential facts constituting the offense charged.'' That may well be too much to ask of lawyers. They often use complex sentences decorated with such phrases as ``to wit,'' ``whereas,'' and ``aforementioned,'' as well as numerous bits of Latin, in an attempt to show they are a special, educated class of people, scholars say. ``They won't call a spade a spade,'' Lederer said. ``They call it an excavation device. It sometimes sounds more important.'' Anyone who winds up being indicted with such confusing language can always get it translated into regular English, but the translation will come from yet another lawyer, he said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Legalese
DOC.TEXT: Here is the sentence that was cited in a ruling by the Maine Supreme Court upholding the use of bad grammar in indictments: ``That on or about the eighth day of September, 1987, in the County of Piscataquis and State of Maine, Leon Stan Corson, Sr., Randall Quimby, Marsha Quimby and Shane A. Cote did with the intent that conduct be performed which, in fact, would constitute a crime or crimes, Leon Stan Corson, Sr., Randall Quimby, Marsha Quimby and Shane A. Cote agreed with one or more others to engage in or cause the performance of said conduct, to wit, the said Leon Stan Corson, Sr., Randall Quimby, Marsha Quimby and Shane A. Cote did agree with one or more others to commit the crime of arson, to wit, to start, cause or maintain a fire or explosion on the property of Anthony and Evelyn Fernandes, d.b.a., Bucksworth II, with the intent to damage or destroy property thereon, the said Leon Stan Corson Sr., Randall Quimby, Marsha Quimby and Shane A. Cote or another with whom they conspired, took a substantial step toward the commission of the crime of arson, by setting fire to a structure owned by Anthony and Evelyn Fernandes.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Labor Leader Dies at Age 88
DOC.TEXT: Union leader Harry Bridges, who helped set the stage for the modern labor movement, died today. He was 88. Bridges died of emphysema at his San Francisco home, said Danny Beagle, spokesman for the Longshoremen's Union. Bridges led the Longshoremen's Union on the West Coast from 1934 through 1977. He first came to prominence in the dock workers' walkout that led to a bloody general strike in San Francisco in July 1934. He was the subject of numerous deportation attempts by the federal government.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Calls Evidence Against Poindexter Overwhelming
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 3rd graf with case expected to go to jury next week; addl material on Reagan in grafs 12-14.
DOC.TEXT: The prosecutor at John Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial said today in closing arguments that evidence against the former national security adviser is overwhelming and that Poindexter directed Oliver North to lie to Congress. But Poindexter's defense attorney told the jury that Poindexter was a victim caught in a ``political battle'' between Congress and the White House and was not part of a coverup conspiracy. Poindexter is accused of concealing from Congress North's secret military assistance to the Contras and the U.S. role in a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. His case is expected to go to the jury next week, after four weeks of testimony. In his closing arguments today, prosecutor Dan Webb said the jury must convict Poindexter ``because the boss can't escape legal responsibility just because he didn't get his hands dirty.'' Webb said Poindexter ``generally instructed'' North to go to a meeting with congressmen and lie by denying he was assisting the Contras militarily. North ``was there because the defendant on trial in this case, his commander, sent him there to do that,'' said Webb. But Poindexter's attorney, Richard Beckler, told the jurors that ``the only real victim as a result of this political battle is Admiral John Poindexter.'' Poindexter did ``his ever-loving best to give as much information as he could tell'' to Congress, said the lawyer. Poindexter was not part of ``some grimy little conspiracy'' as the prosecution ``would have you believe,'' said Beckler. ``He was working for the president of the United States.'' Webb said that if the jurors sat in 1,000 cases, they would ``never find evidence more powerful and more convincing. ... It is overwhelming.'' The defense witnesses included former President Reagan, who Webb said ``didn't have the slightest clue whether John Poindexter did or did not participate'' in the crimes he is accused of committing. A presidential document which Poindexter tore up ``is the one document that puts the lie'' to a speech Reagan gave on Nov. 13, 1986, Webb said. In it, Reagan asserted that ``we did not ... trade weapons ... for hostages.'' ``You don't lie to the American public,'' Webb said of Reagan. The prosecutor at one point tore up a copy of the document in front of the jury to dramatize what Poindexter had done. Poindexter destroyed the document hours after telling Congress on Nov. 21, 1986, that the president hadn't approved a shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran in November 1986. The document signed by Reagan, called a finding, depicted a swap of arms for hostages. In two days of videotaped testimony, Reagan was questioned by defense attorney Beckler about his various meetings with foreign leaders in support of the Nicaraguan Contras. ``For the life of me I could not understand what that had to do with the issues in this case,'' said Webb. Webb said he became ``a little bit angry'' when Reagan winked at Poindexter during his testimony, as if to say ``did that last answer help you John?'' ``I would have expected more of a former president,'' said Webb. Webb said the defense had engaged in a ``scatter gun, let's throw mud against the wall, let's see what happens'' approach. ``That type of defense insults your intelligence,'' Webb told the jury. When the defense rested Tuesday after calling 15 witnesses, Webb called no rebuttal witnesses for the government. ``There was nothing to rebut,'' said Webb. North, whose 3{ days of testimony was the centerpiece of the case against Poindexter, ``was right in the middle of it,'' said the prosecutor. Granted immunity from prosecution, North ``had to go on the witness stand whether he wanted to or not,'' said Webb. North testified reluctantly against the former national security adviser. He said he watched his boss tear up the presidential document that ratified the Hawks shipment to Iran.

DOC.HEAD: Indictments Cloud New England Mob Picture
DOC.TEXT: The time is ripe for would-be mobsters to think about succeeding New England's reputed crime boss, the jailed Raymond J. ``Junior'' Patriarca, law enforcement officials say. A humiliating roundup began Monday with the arrests of Patriarca and 14 other mob figures in Rhode Island, Connecticut and Massachusetts. By Thursday, 21 organized crime figures were in custody in connection with the case. Law enforcement officials sayd any and all organized crime is evil, but most agree that mob activity in New England is penny-ante compared to families elsewhere on the East Coast. ``At the risk of being labeled a New Yorker, New York is the center of the Cosa Nostra. There are five (families) here,'' said Ron Goldstock, director of the New York State Organized Crime Commission. ``The Boston family tends to be way behind the New York families as far as the size, scope of criminal activities and sophistication,'' he said. ``My understanding is that it's a much smaller scale operation but it's still lucrative,'' said Michael Davitt of the Organized Crime Strike Force assigned to the U.S. Attorney's office in Providence. FBI agents held the roundup with 113-count indictments, with charges that included murder, racketeering, kidnapping, gambling, drug trafficking, obstruction of justice and witness intimidation. ``If those convictions (hold up), they will have decimated the Cosa Nostra family in the New England area,'' said Goldstock, who also teaches law at Cornell Law School. The Providence-based crime family used to wield power under Raymond L.S. Patriarca, Junior's father, and that power diminished after the elder Patriarca's death in 1984, authorities said. ``I think Ray Senior acted as sort of a mob diplomat and resolved disputes in Connecticut,'' Davitt said. ``In doing so (New England organized crime) gained more of a national reputation.'' Even if someone from New York City moved in _ reputed Gambino crime family boss John Gotti has been mentioned _ gaining a foothold in New England still wouldn't carry the same weight as having a resident family, Goldstock said. ``It will certainly reduce ... the capability of the family to inflict harm on society,'' he said. The contenders in Patriarca's family include Edward ``Mulligan'' Romano, William ``Billy Blackjack'' Delsanto, and Luigi ``Baby Shanks'' Manocchio, authorities said. All have been with the family since the elder Patriarca's regime: _Manocchio, whose 1968 murder convictions in the gangland slayings of Rudolph Marfeo and Anthony Melei were overturned by the state Supreme Court, seems to be factored out because of his low profile, authorities said. _Delsanto, a former Providence city worker who was accused of accepting paychecks as a no-show worker; the charges were dropped because the state took too long to bring him to trial. _Romano, reputedly the only capo, or captain, in the Patriarca family to escape indictment. ``They're the over-the-hill gang,'' said John Partington, Providence's public safety commissioner, who helped set up the original federal witness protection program to assist mob investigations when he worked for the U.S. Marshal's Service in the mid-1960s. South Kingstown Police Chief Vincent Vespia, a principal mob investigator during 22 years in the state police, said law enforcement officials will have to watch the streets to determine what is going on with the Patriarca family. ``Traditionally, when mob bosses went to jail ... they get pretty well reorganized. You can't put a gag on them,'' Vespia said. ``I question whether Raymond, with the embarrassment here, can operate very strongly from prison.'' Partington said if the younger Patriarca's legal problems persist, bosses in New York would want to install their own man, but nothing will happen immediately. He said the New York crime families are tied closely to New England. ``Out of due respect for his father, Junior is going to stay until something happens in court,'' he said. ``I'm sure there are meetings in New York about what's going to happen in Rhode Island and New England.''

DOC.HEAD: Nationally Known Black Nun Dead At Age 52
DOC.TEXT: Sister Thea Bowman, a nun who battled cancer to continue her lifelong devotion to educating and evangelizing blacks and promoting the cause of women in the Roman Catholic church, died Friday. She was 52. She died at her Canton home after lapsing into a coma Thursday, a church spokesman said. She was diagnosed with breast cancer in 1985 and had to use a wheelchair after the disease spread to her bones. The granddaughter of a slave, Sister Bowman was a lecturer, evangelist, poet and singer. The only black member of the Franciscan Sisters of Perpetual Adoration, Sister Bowman served as director of intercultural awareness of the Jackson Diocese and was on the faculty of the Institute of Black Catholic Studies at Xavier University in New Orleans. ``She was an outstanding woman,'' said Bishop Joseph Houck of the Diocese of Jackson. ``She was proud of her heritage and totally dedicated to the vision of Jesus Christ for love and growth of all people.'' Houck said that despite pain and cancer treatments, Sister Bowman maintained a taxing schedule of rallies, lectures, workshops and singing engagements. Sister Bowman was to receive the Laetare Medal, the oldest and most prestigious award given to U.S. Catholics, at Notre Dame's commencement exercises May 20. She will receive the award posthumously, the university said Friday. She received numerous honors for her pioneering work in encouraging black Catholics to express their cultural roots inside the church. Her 1988 album ``Sister Thea: Songs of My People'' was 15 black spirituals that made her popular at conventions across the country. Last year, the Sister Thea Bowman Black Catholic Educational Foundation was established to provide financial support for black students in Catholic primary and elementary schools and Catholic colleges and universities. A funeral Mass is scheduled for Tuesday at St. Mary Catholic Church in Jackson with burial at Elmwood Cemetery in Memphis, Tenn.

DOC.HEAD: Whistleblower Fired from Army Arsenal Ordered Reinstated
DOC.TEXT: A judge has ordered reinstatement of a government whistleblower who was fired after he revealed unsafe practices at the Army's Rock Island Arsenal. Charles ``Curt'' McRae, a pilot fired two years after he turned in his supervisors, also will receive back pay under the order filed Thursday by Administrative Law Judge Phillip N. Miller. Miller said McRae's appeal to the Merit System Protection Board had supported his allegation that his firing was in reprisal for activity protected under a federal law that protects whistleblowers. The decision by Miller will become final on May 3 unless a party to the matter appeals to the merit board, or the board decides to reopen the case. ``I am very happy, I mean very happy, that the judge looked at all the facts and ruled in our favor,'' McRae said in a telephone interview Friday from his home. McRae said he had at times doubted he would be vindicated in the battle with his superiors at the northern Illinois base. ``This will kind of reaffirm that if you're willing to wait and be persistent, the system will work, yes,'' McRae said. McRae, who has been looking for other work, said he wants to go back to his military job, but would report violations again if he saw them. Al Schwartz, an Army spokesman at the arsenal, said there was no immediate decision on how the agency would proceed. ``We have received Judge Miller's decision and at this time we are reviewing it in detail. Once we have completed our review we will determine what our action will be,'' Schwartz said. McRae's reinstatement is retroactive to Nov. 29, 1989, the date he appealed his firing. At hearings held two weeks ago in Rock Island, McRae said he complained and went over aviation chief Neil Pobanz's head after Pobanz repeatedly ignored pilots' complaints about poor aircraft maintenance and unsafe practices. McRae was hired as a pilot for the arsenal in 1982. He was fired Nov. 17, 1989, more than two years after he reported mishandling of dangerous chemicals and explosives, among other flight-safety violations. A month after he made his complaints in September 1987, McRae was grounded by Pobanz. Acting on McRae's tip, Army investigators found assorted violations, including failure to report aircraft mishaps, transportation of unauthorized personnel, failure to notify the airport of hazardous cargo and falsification of officials documents.

DOC.HEAD: High School Student Caught Living in Secret Auditorium Apartment
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age Phantom of the Opera lived for six months above the stage of his high school auditorium in a secret apartment equipped with a television, videocassette recorder and microwave oven, police said. Police discovered Robert Davis' living arrangements on Monday when they saw someone using a key sneak into the auditorium at John H.
