Francis Polytechnic High School in suburban Sun Valley. ``Maybe he was like `The Phantom of the Opera' _ hiding here, hiding there,'' Detective Oscar Carballo said, adding he'd lived there about six months. ``I just don't understand how he could be living there without anyone knowing it.'' Officers found Davis, 18, a student at the school, and three visiting students inside the living area equipped with a bed, refrigerator, telephone and heater, police said. Davis fled but was arrested the next day. The other three youths were captured inside the school, officials said. All were booked for investigation of burglary, Carballo said. Many items furnishing the apartment apparently had been taken from the school, police said. Principal Virginia A. Holt said staff members knew someone with a key was entering rooms and taking things, such as the microwave oven, but they did not know about the apartment. She refused to release further information about the boy. Sun Valley is a San Fernando Valley community about 20 miles northwest of downtown.

DOC.HEAD: Simpson Blasts `Shoddy and Confounding' Report on Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: A Senate conservative on Friday attacked as ``shoddy'' a report that hiring discrimination has become ``widespread'' as a result of a 4-year-old immigration law while liberal lawmakers defended that assessment. ``You can fancy dan this baby all over the place, you can double speak like you did in your conclusions, (but) you really can't get away with that,'' Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., told officials of the General Accounting Office. Simpson's remark that the accounting office did ``a shoddy and confounding job of analysis here'' came at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing at which the accounting office officials reported on their finding of widespread hiring discrimination caused by the 1986 Immigration Control and Reform Act. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said it appeared that the report was correct. ``The GAO report confirms exactly what many of us in Congress feared when employer sanctions were enacted in 1986 _ that sanctions would be discriminatory against Hispanic-American citizens, Asian-American citizens and other ethnic minorities ...'' ``The GAO report must be immediately addressed by Congress,'' Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., told the committee. ``... This report documents some of the most serious levels of discrimination. Some of our worst fears have been realized.'' Both sides in the dispute said that any discrimination in hiring is wrong and added that changes are needed in the nation's immigration laws, although they were not in agreement on precisely what should be done. Perhaps 10 percent of 4.6 million employers projected statistically by the report are engaging in discrimination against ``foreign looking'' or ``foreign sounding'' job applicants, according to the GAO, a congressional investigative arm. The report said the bias is being practiced by employers who are confused about the law, which provides for civil and criminal penalties for those who knowingly hire foreign workers who are in this country illegally. The law was designed to curb the flow of illegal aliens over the southern border in search of American jobs. At the time it was passed, a number of lawmakers expressed fear that the employer penalties, or ``sanctions,'' would lead to discrimination against eligible workers. Critics inserted in the law a requirement calling on the GAO to study that question and report back to Congress. The report was made public on Thursday. The 10 percent estimate was used in the report to justify the use of ``widespread'' to describe the amount of discrimination caused by the law. That finding in turn could lead to repeal of the employer sanctions provision. Simpson and GAO officials led by Comptroller General Charles Bowsher became snarled in a battle of statistics, with the senator saying the report itself showed only 6.6 percent of employers discriminating. The GAO said the correct number should be 10 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: The years of separation never drove Larry Hyre's 1967 Corvette Stingray from his heart. Still, he never expected to see it again after it was stolen in 1971. Hyre, an Atlanta attorney who grew up in Parkersburg, was astounded recently to learn that police had found the car earlier this month. ``It's like an old friend you haven't seen in 19 years,'' he said. Hyre, now 42, bought the car in 1969 with money he earned from summer jobs. It was stolen two years later, while he was attending law school at West Virginia University. Sheriff's deputies in Henry County, Ohio, found the blue Stingray while helping with the foreclosure of an investment company that specialized in old Corvettes, Sheriff John Nye said Thursday. Police tracked down Hyre's parents, Ruth and Kermit, who still held the car's insurance and registration papers. Hyre drives a Mercedes these days, but he wouldn't consider giving up the Corvette again. ``It's got too many memories. It went to all the Pitt and Penn State away games,'' Hyre said. ``It was quite a car for a college student to have, especially in those days.''

It was just going to be a beheading. But looking at the potbellied, sculpted figure of the previous champion weight loser, Guinness officials said Friday the whole body would probably have to go. Michael Hebranko, 35, of Brooklyn _ who now holds that title _ heaved a sigh of relief. ``I hate that T-shirt and that underwear,'' he said. Hebranko recently wrested the World's Champion Slimmer title from William J. ``Happy Humphrey'' Cobb of Georgia by losing 687 pounds in 24 months. Cobb lost 582 pounds in 32 months. Guinness Book of World Record officials like to keep things exact, so they planned on replacing Cobb's sculpted head at their Empire State Building museum with one of Hebranko. The rest of the body _ that of a potbellied man wearing a green sleeveless T-shirt and polka-dot boxer shorts _ was going to stay. But that's just not Hebranko. What would he like his monument to look like? ``Patrick Swayze,'' he said. Failing that, Hebranko said, ``I hope they at least change the underwear.'' Hebranko lost the weight under the supervision of diet guru Richard Simmons and medical doctors from St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital. His former 115-inch waist is now a svelte 38. His weight has dropped from 905 and now hovers between 212 and 220.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Fine for Jews to Live in East Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James Baker III, addressing supporters of Israel in Congress, said Jews have the right to live both in East and West Jerusalem. Writing to Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., Baker sought to lay to rest a flap prompted by President Bush's comments earlier this month. At a news conference in Palm Springs, Calif., Bush said the United States does not believe there should be new Jewish settlements in the Israeli-occupied West Bank or in East Jerusalem. The eastern section of the city was captured by Israel from Jordan in the 1967 Mideast war and then annexed to the western part of the holy city. The United States and most countries refuse to recognize the united city as the Israeli capital, saying Jerusalem should remain undivided but the question of its sovereignty must be determined in Arab-Israeli negotiations. In his letter, parts of which were made available to The Associated Press, Baker said he was ``very aware of the great significance which Jerusalem has for the Jewish people as well as for people of all religions.'' ``Clearly, Jews and others can live where they want _ East or West _ and the city must remain undivided,'' Baker said. Israel supporters hailed his comments as heralding a softening of the U.S. position on the touchy issue. ``We are heartened by this important clarification,'' said the World Jewish Congress. State Department officials said there was no change in the U.S. position. Still, previous statements, the most recent one issued by the White House on March 9, have spoken about the right of Jews to live in all parts of Jerusalem ``in the context of a negotiated settlement.'' Baker's letter dropped that condition. Bush's unprecedented statement, equating Jewish settlement in the West Bank with that in East Jerusalem, helped set off a political crisis in Israel that led to the fall of the government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. It also generated a host of letters to Baker from members of Congress, including Levine, concerned that U.S. support for Israel might be eroding. In more than two decades of U.S. diplomacy, Jerusalem and the West Bank have been approached as separate issues. Jerusalem is touchier, and American presidents and secretaries of state have tried to keep their distance from the issue.

DOC.HEAD: US to Pursue Dialogue on International Cooperation in Space Exploration
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday the United States will explore the possibility of broad international cooperation in the exploration of space. A White House statement said Bush had decided that Europe, Canada, Japan and the Soviet Union, as well as other nations, would be engaged in ``an exploratory dialogue'' about participating in U.S. space initiatives. Bush has set long-range goals for completion of a manned space station, returning permanently to the Moon and sending a manned expedition to Mars. The statement said the dialogue with other countries will be based on guidelines to be developed soon by the National Space Council, led by Vice President Dan Quayle. ``The exploratory dialogue will focus solely on conceptual possibilities for cooperation,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Breaks National Pyramid Scheme
DOC.TEXT: More than 28,000 people in 21 states and Canada were bilked in a pyramid scheme that offered to turn a $105 investment into a $46,700 profit, the FBI said Friday. Four people have been arrested on fraud and other charges lodged in a 13-count indictment issued by a federal grand jury. The indictment, handed up March 21, was unsealed after all four were arrested. The victims of the 3{-year scheme ``were just ordinary people,'' said FBI agent Ron Halter. The investment scheme, run out of Charlotte, N.C., used the names The Circles of Light Church, the Woman Man God Program, Winner's Marketing Group, Creative Solutions and the WMG Program, the indictment said. The investigation began after victims notified the Pennsylvania Attorney General's Office and the Bureau of Consumer Protection, said FBI spokesman John Kundts. Arrested this week were Robert E. Graven, 49, of Knoxville, Tenn.; James F. Foley Jr., 28, of Warren, Ohio; Gregory A. Long, 32, and Cherie S. Long, 20, both of Raleigh, N.C. The four were held without bail in federal prisons on charges of mail fraud, wire fraud, interstate transportation of stolen property, conspiracy and money laundering both nationally and internationally, authorities said. The proceeds of the alleged scheme, totaling $1.4 million, could be forfeited to the federal government if the four are convicted, the indictment says. The defendants are accused of operating a fraudulent scheme between October 1986 and March 21, mostly in the eastern United States, requiring participants to pay $105 in hopes of making $46,720. Each participant was required to recruit two others, and the expanding base of investors was supposed to provide the payoff for people who joined earlier. They are accused of laundering money through the First American Bank in Plymouth, Montserrat, in the British West Indies, to the First Community Bank in Columbus, Ohio, and then to other banks in the country. If convicted, each of the four could receive sentences up to 105 years in prison and fined $3.75 million. In April 1989, the state Consumer Protection agency successfully sued the Circles of Light Church to stop the group from operating in Pennsylvania. The FBI and the U.S. Postal Inspection Service began an investigation, which was later joined by Britain's New Scotland Yard. The FBI has identified victims in Alabama, Arizona, California, Colorado, Florida, Idaho, Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, Michigan, New Mexico, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Virginia, Washington, West Virginia and Wisconsin. Others have been found in the Canadian provinces of British Columbia, Ontario and Quebec.

DOC.HEAD: Kime To Head Coast Guard
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT name to J. William Kime, sted William J. Kime. SUBS 3rd graf to CLARIFY that Boston City College is a high school
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday he will nominate Rear Adm. J. William Kime to be commandant of the Coast Guard. Kime is commander of the Eleventh Coast Guard District, with headquarters in Long Beach, Calif. A graduate of the Coast Guard Academy, Kime attended high school at Baltimore City College and graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. If confirmed by the Senate, Kime would succeed Adm. Paul Yost, who is retiring.

DOC.HEAD: Corn Farmers Intend to Boost Plantings 4 Percent This Spring
DOC.TEXT: Farmers say they intend to boost corn plantings to 74.8 million acres this spring, up 4 percent from last year and the most since 1986, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Soybean plantings are expected to drop 2 percent to 59.4 million acres, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said. Except for last year, 1990 soybean plantings still would be the largest since 1986. Total wheat plantings for the 1990 harvest, including winter wheat planted last fall and spring-planted varieties, were forecast at about 77.6 million acres, up 1 percent from last year. According to USDA records, the all-wheat acreage would be the largest since 79.2 million acres were planted for the 1989 harvest. The 1990 winter wheat crop was reported planted on 57.2 million acres, up 4 percent from a year ago. But durum wheat planted this spring was indicated at 3.35 million acres, down 12 percent. Other types of spring wheat were estimated at 17 million acres, down 4 percent from last year. Farmers have been encouraged by relatively strong corn and wheat prices, as well as an easing of acreage requirements under federal commodity programs. In the case of soybeans, however, record world oilseed production has reduced prices from last season. The 1990 planting figures were based on an annual March survey of approximately 75,000 farmers to help determine how much land may be used for crops this year. No production estimates were provided in the report. The department's first estimate of winter wheat production will be issued May 10, and the first all-wheat figures July 12. The first corn and soybean production estimates will be released Aug. 9. The acreage report also indicated that farmers will plant more cotton, rice, peanuts, tobacco and dry edible beans. Declines were reported for sorghum, barley, oats and hay. Officials cautioned that the actual crop acreages planted by farmers this year ``may vary from intentions because of the effects of weather, availability of production inputs, changes in market conditions prior to planting'' and the impact of the report itself. Other crops included in the survey report were: _Cotton plantings, 12.4 million acres, up 17 percent from 1989. _Sorghum, 11.5 million acres, down 9 percent. _Barley, 8.89 million acres, down 3 percent. _Oats, 11 million acres, down 9 percent. _Hay, 62 million acres for harvest, down 2 percent. _Rice, 2.9 million acres, up 6 percent. _Peanuts, 1.71 million acres, up 3 percent. _Tobacco, 731,000 acres, up 6 percent. _Dry edible beans, 2.07 million acres, up 11 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Army Chief Postpones Soviet Trip
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Carl Vuono, the Army chief of staff, has postponed a week-long trip to the Soviet Union that was scheduled to begin next week, a Pentagon spokeswoman said on Friday. ``It just was felt that it isn't a good time to go,'' said spokeswoman Maj. Kathy Wood, in an apparent reference to the difficulties that have arisen in recent weeks between the Soviet Union and Lithuania. The Baltic republic declared independence from Moscow on March 11. The four-star general had been slated to leave Saturday for Helsinki, Finland, and travel on Monday to Moscow. Visits to Kiev and Leningrad were also on the schedule, Wood said. The decision to put off the trip was made by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Secretary of State James Baker and Vuono, Wood said. ``His trip has been postponed. It hasn't been cancelled. We hope that he'll eventually go,'' Wood said. The visit was part of the ongoing military exchanges that were started under the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. William Crowe.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Urging China Not to Sell Missiles to Mideast
DOC.TEXT: The State Department has urged Chinese authorities not to export medium-range missiles, but a spokesman said Friday he was unable to offer firm assurances that China has not engaged in such transactions. Deputy spokesman Richard Boucher refused to characterize the Chinese position other than to note that China has pledged to pursue a ``prudent and responsible attitude.'' ``You are all well aware of the importance we attach to stopping missile proliferation. Our dialogue with Beijing on missile proliferation continues,'' he said. The New York Times reported in Friday's editions that Under Secretary of State Reginald Bartholomew was unable to elicit assurances from China's ambassador during a meeting last month that the country will not sell medium-range missiles to the Middle East. Boucher said administration officials have placed particular emphasis on the risks involved in missile sales to the Middle East and on missiles with a range of at least 300 kilometers and with a payload of at least 500 kilograms. ``Beijing has said that it will follow a prudent and responsible attitude and we will look for actions consistent with that statement,'' Boucher said. He said the administration had been unable to confirm media reports suggesting that China has resumed missile sales to the Middle East. The most recent reports said Western diplomats believe China is selling missiles to a Middle East country but that those missiles have a shorter range than those about which the administration has expressed concern. China has dismissed the report as a rumor.

DOC.HEAD: Train Derails, Collapses Viaduct; Motorists Injured
LaserPhoto AH2
DOC.TEXT: A 250-foot section of a bridge collapsed Friday after it was struck by a derailed Union Pacific train, spilling three cars from the viaduct and injuring three people, authorities said. A man and two women were treated for injuries. One of the women, age 46, was extricated from her car and admitted to St. Joseph Hospital in fair condition with chest injuries after the 10:55 a.m. collapse of the Locust Street bridge, authorities said. Identities of the three people injured were withheld pending notification of relatives, said police Investigator Milo Mally. Two switching engines were pulling nine cars on the freight train when the third car, a covered grain hopper, apparently derailed and struck a pillar that supported the 74-year-old viaduct, said John Bromley, a Union Pacific spokesman. None of the train crew was injured, authorities said . The bridge, which crosses about 40 feet above the tracks in an industrial area, held three cars when it collapsed, authorities said. Two cars landed upright on debris atop two derailed freight cars; the third was upright near the end of the collapsed section. Bromley said the train was going 8 mph when it struck the bridge. He said railroad officials were trying to determine what caused the derailment. The railroad had been discussing removing the bridge with the city, Bromley said. The bridge had been cited for structural deficiencies in 1974 and was closed for three months for repairs in 1977, the Omaha World-Herald reported.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Prosecutor's Office: Caught Between Moscow, Vilnius
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's chief prosecutor sat in the conference hall, his cheeks flush with anger, as the Soviet Union's deputy prosecutor informed the staff that from now on Moscow's man was their boss. Sandy-haired Arturis Paulauskas, 37, appointed a week earlier by the Lithuanian government, listened silently to Friday's statement by Soviet deputy prosecutor Alexei Vasiliev. The incident was the first attempt by Soviet officials to take direct control of a Lithuanian government agency since the Baltic republic's parliament declared independence on March 11. After Vasiliev read his statement, the employees began shouting and arguing with him. One employee stood up and declared that the Soviet Constitution ``says every republic has the right to sovereignty.'' The rest of the staff broke into loud applause. ``Questions of that kind must be solved in a constitutional way,'' Vasiliev countered. But another Lithuanian employee took the argument one step further with a reference to the Soviet annexation of Lithuania in 1940. ``Do you think 1940 was solved in a constitutional way?'' he shouted. Vasiliev maintained that ``the general prosecutor of the U.S.S.R. has the right to name any prosecutor he wants.'' Vasiliev named Antanas Petrauskas, an ethnic Lithuanian, to replace Paulauskas. He also ordered the legal staff of almost 100 to carry out Soviet law. Staff members reacted to the replacement with angry questions. ``Do you know our government was elected legally?'' one told Vasiliev. Another staffer stood up and asked: ``What will the prosecutor of the U.S.S.R. do if 90 percent of the prosecutorial staff leaves their jobs?'' ``I would not like to guess,'' Vasiliev said. Lithuanian legislator Egidius Bickauskas coldly told Vasiliev he should remember he was currently on the sovereign territory of Lithuania, and not in the U.S.S.R. ``You can occupy this building with the help of paratroopers, but that occupation will be different from the occupation of party buildings,'' he said, referring to the occupation by Soviet paratroopers of at least five Communist party buildings this week. ``I can't ask him (Vasiliev) to leave this room,'' Bickauskas went on, addressing the workers. ``But I hope you will consider your place is in your offices, under the leadership of Mr. Paulauskas.'' At that, almost everyone in the room applauded, got up and left. ``You must obey the orders of the general prosecutor of the U.S.S.R.,'' Vasiliev said in a raised voice as people left. Vasiliev told several reporters afterward that his 11-member team from Moscow is ``not an instrument of force.'' He said his next step in the dispute would be a legal one, but he would not elaborate. Paulauskas, back in his office, said: ``I am the prosecutor of Lithuania, and I will stay here until force is used against me.'' He said he had looked up the relevant Soviet law and figured his defiance to Moscow could only be punished by a maximum of three years in prison. He said he considered it likely he would be barred from the building on Monday and implied he might move the office's operations to a different site. When the prosecutor's secretary, Henrika Pocei, was asked who she worked she paused and said, ``I think I have to go home.'' But she added: ``It'll be really interesting on Monday _ payday.''

DOC.HEAD: West Coast Dock Union Leader Dies At Age 88
LaserPhoto FX2
DOC.TEXT: Legendary labor leader Harry Bridges, whose battle to found the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union set the stage for unionization of West Coast docks, died Friday of emphysema. He was 88. Bridges died at his San Francisco home, said union spokesman Danny Beagle. The crusty union leader, who first came to prominence when a dockworkers' walkout led to a bloody general strike in San Francisco in 1934, was once labeled a communist by the federal government. Authorities tried repeatedly to throw him out of the country for alleged communist activities, and he once was jailed for 20 days as a communist conspirator. The son of a prosperous Australian real estate man, Bridges led the ILWU from 1934 to 1977, pushing it to a position of supremacy on West Coast docks. The union's success in the 1934 strike inspired formation of dockworkers' unions from San Diego to Seattle, and it now extends nationwide. ``He was really the guy who set in motion the whole reorganzation of labor in the 1930s in the West Coast,'' said Beagle. ``He was a very interesting, powerful person.'' On July 5, 1934, two dock workers were killed and 100 wounded when 1,000 police officers clashed with 5,000 dock workers and sympathizers in San Francisco. The California National Guard was called out, and the lean, hawk-faced Bridges plunged San Francisco into a general strike 11 days later. The strike ended after three days with an agreement on a contract that established a union-operated rather than employer-run hiring hall on the docks.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Rebel Organization Agrees to Disarm
DOC.TEXT: The Indian rebel group Yatama has agreed to disarm and demobilize before Nicaragua's new government takes office next month, the office of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro said Friday. Yatama, an organization of Atlantic coast Indians, claims to have 2,000 armed combatants in Nicaragua and in camps on the Honduran coast. Defense Ministry sources put Yatama's strength at 500 in Honduras and 100 in Nicaragua. Yatama, by signing the Rio Coco agreement, ``commits itself to beginning the process of general demobilization of its armed forces, beginning with disarmament of those still in Honduras,'' Mrs. Chamorro's office said in a brief communique issued late Thursday. The agreement sets a deadline for demobilization of April 20, five days before Mrs. Chamorro takes office and replaces Sandinista President Daniel Ortega. The accord also asks for cooperation from the U.N. observer force and a commission monitoring the Central American peace process. The pact is similar to that signed March 23 by the Nicaraguan Resistance, umbrella for most of the U.S.-backed Contra rebels fighting the leftist Sandinista government. Rebel leaders, international observers and reporters say most of the 12,000 Contras in Honduran base camps have returned to Nicaragua, where under the agreement with the new government they are to gather in security zones. That accord sets an April 20 deadline for disarming and leaving the Honduran camps, but fixes no date for demobilization from the security zones. The Sandinistas, in power since 1979, agreed this week to cede control of the army and police but stressed that demobilization of the rebels is essential to a peaceful transition of power.

DOC.HEAD: Low Turnout in Zimbabwe Elections as Polls Close
DOC.TEXT: Polls closed Friday in Zimbabwe's three-day national elections, which could result in the ruling party being unchallenged in Parliament. President Robert Mugabe, 66, has vowed that if his ruling Zimbabwe African National Union sweeps all of Parliament's contested seats, he will change the constitution and institute a Marxist one-party state. There are currently two opposition legislators in the 150-member Parliament and a unanimous vote is required to change the constitution. Observers said only the Zimbabwe Unity Movement, led by oposition legislator Edgar Tekere, had a chance of capturing a seat and blocking Mugabe's dream of one-party rule. Interest in the elections appeared low. Election officials said only 45.3 percent of the nation's 4.8 million registered voters had cast their ballots as of Thursday. They did not expect heavy voting Friday. Balloting had been set to end Thursday, but it was extended through Friday in hopes more people would turn out. Election officials said heavy rain Wednesday and problems at some polling booths kept turnout low the first day. The head of the electoral supervisory committee, Walter Kamba, told reporters some polling stations received no voters at all Friday. Counting was scheduled to begin early Saturday, and first results were expected a few hours later, he said. Some observers said the low turnout was the result of voter dissatisfaction with Mugabe's policies and uncertainty over whether Tekere could solve the nation's record unemployment and spiraling inflation.

DOC.HEAD: Sewer-Dwelling, Pizza-Eating Turtles Are Heroes on the Halfshell
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The choice is simple. You can go see ``My Left Foot.'' Or you can watch a quartet of man-size, goggle-wearing turtles eat pizza. Like it or not, the ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' are now at a theater near you. And this weekend's opening will test the unproven theory that a hit toy can forge a profitable trail for a blockbuster movie. The Turtles were born six years ago in a $1,200 comic book partially funded by a tax refund. The Turtles now star in a smash animated television series and have become one of the hottest childrens' products since Cabbage Patch Kids. Playmates Toys Inc. sold $115 million in Turtle-related merchandise last year. Some 175 manufacturers are pushing about 600 Turtle items, including Turtle pizzas, a musical talking Turtle toothbrush, Turtle underwear, cereal, pork rinds, yogurt, cookies and sleepwear. ``It's definitely our most popular line,'' said Richard Sallis, Playmates' senior vice president for marketing. ``I've never seen anything like this before.'' The Turtles are the nation's third best-selling toy, behind Nintendo and Barbie. The question, though, is whether bed sheets can translate to box-office. Like never before, Hollywood has become obsessed in adapting trends for the screen _ the lambada prompted two movies and beach volleyball is the focus of the new film ``Side Out.'' The makers of ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' are betting that the live-action $15 million film will be as strong in theaters as the Turtles are in toy stores. The movie is playing in 1,900 movie houses, a spectacularly wide release. ``This movie had an extraordinary awareness level before we did anything,'' said Sondra Ruch, marketing president for the movie's distributor, New Line Cinema. ``Kids find these turtles irresistible.'' Alex Lee, 5, is one such fan. ``I like them because they are so cool basically. They wear masks all the time and, you know, they do cool stuff,'' Lee said. ``They have Japanese weapons, they are Ninjas, they don't wear too much clothes and they eat pizza.'' The challenge for New Line is to distinguish the movie from the animated series, and thus create a broader audience. Sneak previews on college campuses played to packed houses, New Line reports, and the film fared well late Thursday night to mostly adult viewers. ``We had to differentiate between the cartoon and the movie,'' Ruch said. ``And the line we've been using in our campaign is, `Hey dude! This is no cartoon!''' It may not be a cartoon, but the PG-rated movie is filled with comicbook-style violence. ``It's violence, while not graphic, is much more abundant than the rating might lead parents to believe,'' a review in The New York Times said. The movie, developed before the toys became so coveted, focuses on the adventures of the four turtles _ Leonardo, Michaelangelo, Raphael and Donatello _ who try to foil teen-age hoods on the loose in New York City. It is directed by Steve Barron and written by Bobby Herbeck; Muppet creator Jim Henson designed the Turtle outfits for the film. Other filmmakers have attempted to capitalize on well-liked toys with mixed results. In 1987, Cannon released ``Masters of the Universe,'' a live-action film based on a then-popular toy and animated television series. Starring Dolph Lundgren, the movie was a critical and commercial flop. Reviews of the Turtle movie have been mixed, but this might be a review-proof film. USA Today gave it three stars out of a possible four, saying ``If you think the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles are awesome in cartoon and toy form, wait till you see them in live action.'' The New York Times review called the film ``a mutant of sorts, a contentious, unsightly hybrid of martial-arts exploitation film and live-action cartoon.'' Mark Freedman, who supervises licensing and entertainment marketing for the Turtles, says the characters do not exploit audiences the way other animated figures have in the past. The hook, he said, is not clever merchandising but three-dimensional characters and a creative plot. ``You can't fool kids. They wouldn't want to go see the movie if it was just a long cartoon. '' He said the Turtles are popular because they reject most of the conventions of animated programming. ``All the traditional super heroes are either the mightiest or the fastest,'' he said. ``The Turtles are neither. They're funny.''

DOC.HEAD: Relatives of Slain Activists Push for Prosecution of Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of activists killed by the government demonstrated outside the presidential palace Friday demanding the prosecution of military officers responsible for the slayings. Hundreds of people held up a huge red and white banner reading ``Truth and Justice in Chile. No to impunity.'' Mimes dressed as ghosts moved through a mock cemetery. The demonstration was the first of its kind since the military gave way to an elected civilian leadership March 11. Organizers vowed to hold similar protests outside the presidential palace on the last Friday of each month. Most of the demonstrators were women, who planted posters of dead or missing husbands, sons or other relatives in an empty garden patch outside the palace. They placed red carnations around the posters, while mimes in black writhed between the posters, imitating ghosts. A squad of national police stood nearby with a tear-gas truck and a water cannon. At one point they tried to push the demonstrators away, but later they backed off and waited for the protest to break up on its own. The government of former military ruler Augusto Pinochet, who has retained command of the 60,000-man army, was repeatedly accused of systematic abuses by international human rights organizations. After seizing power in 1973, Pinochet launched a massive crackdown on leftists in which hundreds were killed and thousands jailed, tortured or deported. President Patricio Aylwin has said he will let the courts act independently in cases of abuses. But he has also said that to achieve national reconciliation, the country must be prepared to forgive past offenses.

DOC.HEAD: East German Leaders Examine Files the Secret Police Kept on Them
DOC.TEXT: East German leaders tried to defuse a political crisis Friday by inspecting dossiers the secret police kept on them, and the official news service ADN said they were cleared of links to the notorious ``Stasi.'' On Thursday, nationwide demonstrations were held demanding an investigation of allegations that some victors in East Germany's first free elections were informants for the despised security apparatus of the former Stalinist regime. ADN said officals overseeing the disbanding of the secret police let the nation's most influential politicians, or their representatives, study the confidential files on Friday. It said the leaders of the three major political factions were given access to the files. The politicians were accompanied by citzens' representatives and officials overseeing dismantling of the secret police, the agency reported. It said Manfred Stolpe, senior administrator of East Berlin's Lutheran Church, looked at the files of Christian Democratic leader Lothar de Maiziere and found no evidence connecting him with the secret police. ADN said de Maiziere asked Stolpe and Communist Party chief Gregor Gysi to look at the files for him. The agency said Stolpe also found no evidence that Gysi, head of the new, reform-oriented Communist Party, had secret police ties. ADN said Gysi looked at his files with Stolpe. Social Democratic Chairman Ibrahim Boehme looked at his records himself and told reporters he also was cleared. De Maiziere's conservative political alliance finished with the most votes in March 18 elections, the Social Democrats finished a distant second and the Communists third. Boehme said last week he was temporarily stepping down as party chairman amid allegations he was a secret police informant. On Friday, he said he was resuming his duties because inspection of the files proved his innocence. The allegations of secret police involvement have clouded talks on forming East Germany's freely elected government. De Maziere has been trying to forge a coalition with the left-leaning Social Democrats to ensure a majority in the new Parliament so it will adopt a plan for swift unification with West Germany. After more than five hours of checking ``between 200 and 300 pages,'' of records kept at the now disbanded Stasi headquarters in East Berlin, a smiling Boehme told reporters waiting outside the building, ``Everything is fine.'' Two lawyers went with him to the headquarters. The Social Democrats have expressed concern about working with the ultraconservative element of de Maiziere's alliance, the German Social Union. But the Social Democrats and Christian Democrats said on Thursday that they had agreed on basic points of forming a majority coalition. The office of the interim East German president, Manfred Gerlach, meanwhile announced Friday that the new, 400-member Parliament will convene on April 5, ADN said. Since hard-line Communist Erich Honecker was toppled on Oct. 18, a pro-reform interim government dominated by the Communists has run the country. East Germany, essentially leaderless since the revolt, has been beset by mass emigration and economic problems as it awaits eventual reunification with wealthy West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Hog Farmers Cutting Back
DOC.TEXT: Hog farmers are cutting back further on the number of animals they will send to market and will keep for future production, a report by the Agriculture Department indicated Friday. As of March 1, the U.S. inventory of hogs and pigs totaled an estimated 51.7 million head, down 2 percent from a year ago, the report said. The breeding herd was put at 6.81 million head, down 4 percent from a year earlier. Market hogs, at 44.9 million head, were down 2 percent. Inventories in the 10 top pork states were reported at 40.5 million head, down 3 percent from a year ago. Hog producers nationally expect to have 3.19 million sows farrow this spring, down 3 percent from farrowing during March, April and May of last year. Farrowing intentions for June, July and August were estimated at 2.91 million, also down 3 percent from a year-earlier. The following list shows the March 1 inventory in the 10 major states, which account for 78 percent of the U.S. total. The first number, in thousands, is the total number of hogs in the state, the second is the March 1 figure's percentage of a year earlier.
Georgia 1,220 104 Illinois 5,200 99 Indiana 4,200 102 Iowa 13,000 96 Kansas 1,370 91 Minnesota 4,250 96 Missouri 2,550 91 Nebraska 4,150 102 North Carolina 2,600 96 Ohio 1,930 94

DOC.HEAD: State Files Contempt Charges in Fernald Cleanup
DOC.TEXT: Contempt of court charges were filed Friday against the U.S. Department of Energy and the operator of the Fernald uranium processing plant for allegedly violating a cleanup agreement. State Attorney General Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr. accused the federal government and Westinghouse Materials Co. of Ohio Inc. of mishandling hazardous waste containers, failing to properly analyze some 40,000 drums of radioactive material and failing to develop a written inspection schedule. Westinghouse operates the Fernald plant. ``The performance since 1988 has not been all bad, ... but it's my experience that only after we hit them with a club, that they start compliance,'' Celebrezze said. Under a December 1988 consent decree, the plant must comply with state and federal hazardous waste laws and pollution standards. Celebrezze said the consent decree gave the state clear authority to regulate disposal and treatment of hazardous waste. The decree did not cover radioactive waste, he said. Celebrezze asked U.S. District Judge S. Arthur Spiegel to force the government to make proper environmental reports, use safe containers for hazardous waste, and guarantee that waste water does not spill on the ground. Celebrezze also is seeking proper sampling of the hazardous waste. The attorney general said the state would leave the amount of any possible fine up to Spiegel. Celebrezze said Westinghouse did not sign the consent decree but is subject to its terms because the Energy Department signed on behalf of all contractors, including Westinghouse. There was no immediate response from the Energy Department or Westinghouse. The Fernald plant, 18 miles northwest of Cincinnati, began processing uranium in 1951 for use in nuclear reactors and weapons. The contractor operating the 1,050-acre plant, Westinghouse Materials Corp. of Ohio, suspended production last year to concentrate on cleanup efforts. A lawsuit on behalf of 14,000 people living or working within five miles of the plant led to an unprecedented $78 million settlement last summer by the DOE. The government made its first $16 million payment on the settlement last month. The Reagan administration called for closing the plant by the mid-1990s, but the current administration hasn't endorsed the plan. The cleanup cost has been estimated at $1 billion to $5 billion. The federal government entered into an agreement with Ohio that gives the state court-enforceable regulatory authority over the cleanup of hazardous wastes, not including nuclear waste. Stored at the plant in waste pits, two concrete silos and thousands of 55-gallon drums are more than 500,000 metric tons of radioactive wastes dating from current plant operations to the World War II-era Manhattan Project to develop the atomic bomb. The Energy Department in 1985 admitted that the plant had released about 300,000 pounds of uranium oxide dust into the atmosphere over the years through faulty exhaust-filter systems.

DOC.HEAD: Murder Defendants from Polynesian Atoll Describe Witch Hunt
DOC.TEXT: Two dozen islanders accused of torturing to death six people have told a court they were possessed by the devil or seized by religious fervor during a hunt for evil spirits in 1987. All week the jury has been considering the case, which focuses on two days of terror on the remote atoll of Faaite after a visit by three women who claimed to represent a charismatic movement founded in the United States. Psychiatric experts testified that the charismatic movement, mixed with ancient Polynesian beliefs in the supernatural, produced a dangerous mix on an isolated island lacking institutional authority. The three women, whom investigators ruled never ordered the killings, are not on trial. But witnesses say the violence had its roots in a visit that August by the three women from Tahiti, about 310 miles west. ``I had a spirit under the spell of the devil,'' one of the islanders from Faaite told Judge Marcel Bihl of the Papeete Tribunal on Thursday. ``I lost my head, but I believed I was on the holy path, shunning the evil fighting within me.'' Other defendants, clad in bright tropical shirts and white trousers, said they lost self-control during the search for demons and sorcerers. The 24 defendants are charged with murder, inciting violence and other offenses. The women claimed to represent the Charismatic Renewal, a movement founded in 1967 and affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church. However, church authorities said they had no connection with the women. At the time, the movement already had a strong following on Faaite, an atoll studded with white sand beaches and about 180 residents. The women, regarded as priestesses by the islanders, took over the tiny whitewashed church and, by force of personality, replaced the lay preacher as the religious authority on the atoll, witnesses said. The trio's leader, Alexandra Silvia, conducted services in a trance and told frightened islanders of her visions that God would abandon Faaite, the defendants said. She suggested demons were in their midst, and the population began viewing with suspicion fellow islanders who failed to attend her daily services. In late August that year, the trio left Faaite and gave roses to seven islanders, designating them as disciples to continue their work. On Sept. 2, Ioane Harris, the assistant mayor, publicly denounced what was happening. One defendant told the court he looked into Harris' eyes and believed him possessed. Maddened villagers tightened a cord around Harris' neck, held a crucifix before his face, and beat him senseless. They then drowned Harris during a ritual in the lagoon and threw his body on a bonfire built under palm trees in front of the church. ``It was necessary to purify him,'' one of the defendants calmly told the court. ``It was necessary to purify the village.'' Five more people were killed over the next two days. One, a mentally handicapped young man who claimed to be Jesus Christ, was burned alive. Informed of the killings, the mayor arrived on Sept. 4 with a Catholic priest and a squadron of police in time to stop further violence. The jury was expected reach a verdict after two weeks' testimony.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Conservative Parties to Run in Alliance
DOC.TEXT: The Hungarian Democratic Forum, strongest party in last Sunday's free elections, agreed on Friday to form an alliance with two smaller conservative parties in the runoff elections April 8. The state news agency MTI said the Forum agreed with the Independent Smallholders' party and the Christian Democrats to have voters cast ballots for whichever candidate of the three parties is strongest in their districts. It could be a preliminary step to forming a conservative coalition to head Hungary's first democratic government in more than 40 years. A split vote and complex electoral system meant that only five of the 386 contested parliamentary seats were decided in last Sunday's first round of elections. Eight additional seats will be distributed to ethnic minorities for a total of 394 seats in Parliament. The Democratic Forum won 24.71 percent of the vote Sunday and its chief rival, the liberal League of Free Democrats, won 21.38 percent. The Independent Smallholders' were third with 11.76 percent and the Christian Democrats sixth with 6.46 percent. In the runoff, the League of Free Democrats is likely to team up with the leftist Young Democrats, who took 8.94 percent of the votes Sunday. The governing Socialists, formed from the Communist reformers who led Hungary peacefully toward democracy, came fourth with 10.89 percent. The Socialists are still associated in voters' minds with the excesses of Stalinism, however, and both the Forum and Free Democrats reject any coalition which includes them. Both the Democratic Forum and Free Democrats agree on one issue: the need for a market economy.

DOC.HEAD: Says Global Trend Toward Democracy Reaches Gale-Force Proportions
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4 grafs after pvs 5th graf bgng ``The speech...'' to add comments made after speech
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III urged Americans on Friday to support a U.S. foreign policy based on ``idealism plus realism'' and not to withdraw from the foreign field now that communism is in retreat. ``The time of sweeping away the old dictators is passing fast,'' Baker said. ``The time of building up the new democracies has arrived.'' Baker spoke to the World Affairs Council in Dallas. Texts were distributed at the State Department where U.S. officials said one of Baker's aims was to combat ``neo-isolationism'' in America. ``Now that the adversaries of democracy are weaker, some say we should retire, mission accomplished, to tend our problems at home,'' Baker said in his prepared remarks. ``I am not among them. In the new world struggling to be born, like the old world now rapidly passing away, there is no substitute for American leadership.'' The speech was largely philosophical. There was no mention in it of Lithuania, where secessionists are seeking stronger support from the Bush administration. Afterward, Baker said the United States was continuing to call for a resolution of the dispute through dialogue and independence. ``We've never recognized the incorporation of Lithuania into the Soviet Union in 1940,'' Baker said. ``We support Lithuanians in their desire to achieve self-determination. ``The real issue is how do we best get there?'' Baker also praised the Soviet leadership for a commitment to reform that, he said, has brought about ``remarkable changes'' in Eastern Europe and other areas of the world. The U.S. officials, who briefed reporters under condition of anonymity, said Baker preferred focusing on broader foreign policy issues. One of his central themes was the surprisingly rapid trend toward democracy around the world. When President Bush took office in January 1989 there was ``a new breeze blowing for freedom,'' Baker said. Now, 14 months later, he said, ``that breeze has become a gale-force wind.'' Baker cited Nicaragua and developments in Central and Eastern Europe. But, he stressed, ``as we enter a new era of democracy, the old arguments of idealism versus realism must be replaced by idealism plus realism.'' On the one hand, he said, Americans will not support a U.S. foreign policy that lacks support for humane values. And yet, Baker said, ``I am equally convinced that Americans will reject a policy based primarily on moral exhortation which ignores our power to act.''

DOC.HEAD: Factional Fighting Continues, ANC Cancels Peace Rally
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS four grafs for 9-12 bgng `It was...' to CORRECT that Mandela did not sign cancellation announcement and that positive publicity feared for Buthelezi, sted King Goodwill; pickup 13th `Mandela appeared...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DUR1
DOC.TEXT: Zulu fighters supporting rival black factions clashed with guns and knives Friday in Natal Province, and the African National Congress persuaded Nelson Mandela to cancel a peace rally in the region. The sudden cancellation angered the leader of Inkatha, whose followers are pitted in the battles against supporters of the ANC-supported United Democratic Front. The fighting this week has left at least 37 dead, sent thousands fleeing their villages and prompted the white-minority government to threaten a crackdown. It also has kept Mandela from forging black unity before preliminary talks with the government on dismantling apartheid. Those talks are scheduled April 11. Mandela had planned to join Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi in a rally Monday in the war-torn Edendale Valley of Natal. Inkatha favors a Zulu-based state in Natal, while the United Democratic Front favors a united South Africa under democratic majority rule. Both groups have been fighting for control of black townships since 1983. ``The atmosphere is not yet ideal for a joint rally in Natal,'' the ANC's cancellation announcement said. It did not elaborate. The statement said, however, that Mandela will go to Natal on Monday and Tuesday to visit the affected areas and that arrangements were being made for a private meeting with Buthelezi. It was issued after a five-hour meeting of Mandela and ANC officials at Mandela's Soweto home. Mandela and other ANC leaders were unavailable for comment later. Buthelezi said Mandela told him in a telephone conversation that ANC and United Democratic Front leaders thought the situation in Natal was too tense for the rally. But Buthelezi said, ``People are going to die while they delay. It was his initiative, his suggestion, and he saw it as a matter of urgency that we address a joint peace meeting either on Monday or Tuesday.'' Some ANC and UDF leaders in Natal opposed a Mandela-Buthelezi meeting on grounds it might give positive publicity to Buthelezi. Mandela appeared to put aside such considerations Thursday night, when he said of the planned rally: ``This is not time for people with political differences to stand on ceremony. We must unite now in our commitment to end the violence in Natal and work out a strategy we are all united behind.'' A joint rally by the two was seen as an important step in efforts to stop the revenge slaughter that has escalated beyond the original political differences. It has now been complicated by criminal gangs and personal disputes. Police said at least 37 people had been killed since Tuesday in clashes between Zulu bands in the rugged hill country near Edendale. ``It's impossible to say how many people have been hurt. It's in the hundreds,'' police Maj. Piet Kitching said. Rival war bands were battling Friday in rural areas, but the situation was quieter, police said. ``It's very tense. It could erupt again at any time. It's a terrible situation,'' Kitching said. Nearly 4,000 have died in the past four years in the feuding. President F.W. de Klerk said Friday the unrest was becoming a threat to stability and the government would use force to restore order. ``Demonstrators openly espousing violence or preaching class and racial hatred are playing with fire. Fanning these flames may easily lead to a catastrophic intergroup conflagration,'' he told the Cape Town Press Club. De Klerk gave no details but said he would make a statement to parliament on Monday on measures to stop the violence. It is the worst to sweep the country since the national state of emergency was declared June 12, 1986. Also Friday, the government freed seven more black nationalists from prison, including the nephew of African National Congress leader Walter Sisulu. The ANC, the leading black anti-apartheid group, has demanded the release of all political prisoners as a condition for talking with the government. The government lifted bans on Mandela's autobiography ``The Struggle Is My Life'' and the anti-apartheid movie ``A Dry White Season.''

DOC.HEAD: Mental Patient Who Killed Young Girl Innocent By Reason Of Insanity
DOC.TEXT: A mental patient who walked away from a state hospital and randomly stabbed a 9-year-old girl to death at a street fair was found innocent by reason of insanity Friday. David R. Peterson, 38, lacked the capacity to conform his conduct to the requirements of the law, a three-judge Superior Court panel unanimously concluded in acquitting him of murder and escape charges. However, Dr. Donald R. Grayson, a state-commissioned psychiatrist who examined Peterson, said it would be ``a dreadful mistake in judgment'' ever to release him from a high-security psychiatric facility. At Peterson's arraignment last summer, an angry crowd yelled ``Kill him, kill him!'' when he was brought to court. But there were no such demonstrations Friday. The girl's parents, Catherine and Robert Short, and a handful of their closest friends were present for the brief reading of the verdict. They showed no emotion as the decision was announced, and declined to comment when they left the courthouse. The Shorts are planning to sue the state. Peterson walked off the grounds of Connecticut Valley Hospital last July 28. He took a bus three miles downtown, bought a hunting knife at a Main Street sporting goods shop and walked only about 100 yards before pouncing on 9-year-old Jessica Short. He picked his victim at random from a crowd of hundreds attending a sidewalk sale and fair. He stabbed her 34 times before stunned and horrified bystanders and police could pull him away. Judges James Higgins, Barry Schaller and Salvatore Arena, who began deliberations Wednesday afternoon, ordered Peterson committed to the custody of the state mental health commissioner for evaluation. He will be held at the Whiting Forensic Institute, the state's only maximum-security institution, at least until another court hearing to determine whether he should be confined or released. His attorney, public defender Christopher James, said Peterson is happy to be at Whiting because he feels safer there. Psychiatrists hired by both the prosecution and the defense testified during the trial that Peterson represents a chronic danger to society and is as dangerous as a mentally ill person can be to others. Peterson, a chronic paranoid schizophrenic with a history of mental illness and violence, has spent 15 of his past 20 years in mental institutions. In 1971 and again in 1988, he was found innocent by reason of insanity in stabbing attacks and ordered committed to state hospitals. In 1988, he was moved from Whiting to Connecticut Valley Hospital after doctors at both places said they believed he could be adequately supervised in a minimum-security setting, said the state Psychiatric Security Review Board. Peterson's attorney said the case shows that the board, which by law has the primary duty of protecting society, should seek the recommendations of outside experts rather than relying solely on information coming from the hospitals. About two hours before he killed the girl, Peterson had been screaming about pain in his legs and arms that he blamed on the medication he was taking. The psychiatrist hired by the defense said the patient should have been confined to his ward after the outburst because he had a history of psychotic delusions being accompanied by violence. Instead, Peterson was allowed to follow his normal routine and go out onto the hospital grounds without supervison, according to court testimony. Peterson told police he killed Miss Short to take revenge on his doctors because they wouldn't change his medication. He told psychiatrists he went downtown to take revenge on his ``enemies'' _ whites of European descent _ and had pictured himself as a soldier marching into battle.

DOC.HEAD: Government Lifts Bans on Mandela's Autobiography
DOC.TEXT: The government Friday removed the ban on Nelson Mandela's autobiography, saying it is now ``part of the accepted political rhetoric'' in South Africa. The government censorship board also lifted the ban on ``A Dry White Season,'' an anti-apartheid movie starring Donald Sutherland and Marlon Brando, made in the United States and based on a novel by South African Andre Brink. The Publication Appeals Board banned Mandela's autobiography, ``The Struggle Is My Life,'' three years ago. Mandela was released Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison for his role in launching the bombing and sabotage campaign of the African National Congress. He continues to support the ANC's armed struggle, although it has been largely dormant the past year. ``As far as the principle of armed violence is concerned, (Mandela's) standpoint is so well known that it is unlikely it will change the outlook of the reader toward political violence,'' the Appeals Board said in its judgment. Other books about Mandela and the ANC have been available in South Africa for several years. Speaking about ``A Dry White Season,'' the panel said in a statement: ``The board believes this film is a serious one which addresses the sensitive relations between white and black in South Africa. ``In the board's opinion, it attempts to improve these relations: sadly it often loses its effect by falling into propaganda.'' The film was screened at a South African film festival last year but was banned from general circulation. It concerns a series of injustices suffered by a black family at the hands of white authorities. A white teacher, played by Sutherland, becomes involved and unsuccessfully seeks redress through the courts. Another anti-apartheid film, ``Cry Freedom,'' is scheduled to reopen in South Africa on April 27. The board approved the film in July 1988, but police used their powers under the national state of emergency to confiscate it from theaters the day it opened, saying it posed a threat to public safety. The distributors said police returned the copies of the film recently. ``Cry Freedom'' is about black activist Steve Biko, who died in police custody in 1977, and Donald Woods, a white newspaper editor who had befriended him.

DOC.HEAD: Armed Fan Surrenders to Police After Standoff at Actress' Home
LaserPhotos LA4, NY26
DOC.TEXT: A rifle-toting woman who allegedly harassed actress Sharon Gless for years surrendered peacefully Friday after a seven-hour standoff with police inside the ``Cagney and Lacey'' star's home. Joni Leigh Penn, 30, who in the past had threatened to kill herself in front of the actress, put down a loaded .22-caliber semiautomatic rifle and surrendered to officers inside Miss Gless' Studio City home at 10 a.m., said police Capt. Dan Watson. Miss Gless was not home at the time. ``She surrendered voluntarily. She was tired. She was just kind of worn down,'' said Watson, who described Ms. Penn as an obsessed fan of Miss Gless. A policewoman was instrumental in convincing the woman to surrender, but her name was not immediately available, officers said. ``I don't know what she said to her,'' Watson added. Ms. Penn was quickly handcuffed and led outside to a police car while dozens of reporters and neighbors watched. She walked out with her head down. She looked somber and did not speak. She was taken to the Police Department's North Hollywood station, where Watson said she would be booked for investigation of armed burglary, a felony. An hour earlier, Watson told reporters gathered outside the actress' home on a tree-lined cul-de-sac that Ms. Penn had threatened to kill herself. Another police spokesman, Officer C.K. Witkamp, said Ms. Penn had pointed the weapon to her head when officers arrived. Miss Gless, who was in touch with police throughout the ordeal, issued a statement shortly afterward in which she said Ms. Penn had harassed her for several years. ``These are horrendous times that we live in, especially when disturbed people have such easy access to weapons that can be used indiscriminately,'' she said. ``This has been going on for several years now, and I think has to be dealt with by the authorities.'' Obsessed fans have stalked many Hollywood celebrities in recent years. Actress Theresa Saldana was stabbed and nearly killed outside her home by an obsessed fan eight years ago and ``My Sister Sam'' star Rebecca Schaeffer was shot to death in the doorway of her apartment building last year. Johnny Carson, David Letterman, Olivia Newton-John, Michael Landon and Michael J. Fox have also been targets of obsessive fans. Police said Ms. Penn barricaded herself inside a bathroom at Miss Gless' home. Officers answering a silent burglar alarm found her inside shortly after 3 a.m. She remained in the bathroom for nearly seven hours while a Police Department psychologist and several officers talked to her from the other side of the door. Miss Gless was staying at another home she owns in Los Angeles. No one was in the Studio City house, about 15 miles north of downtown, Watson said. He said Ms. Penn was also a suspect in an attempted burglary at the Gless home Monday night. Police said Miss Gless obtained a court order in November 1988 requiring Ms. Penn to keep away from her. It appeared that until this week Ms. Penn had complied with the order, Watson said. Miss Gless, 46, played the tough police detective Christine Cagney on the ``Cagney and Lacey'' TV series. She won a best actress Emmy in 1987. CBS on Wednesday announced that Miss Gless would reunite with ``Cagney and Lacey'' executive producer Barney Rosenzweig to create a new dramatic series for the 1990-91 season tentatively titled ``Renewal.''

DOC.HEAD: Cease-Fire Collapses; 38 Dead in War Between Christian Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with eight grafs to UPDATE with fighting continuing past midnight, death toll reaching 38 Friday. Pickup 9th, `Thunderous blasts...
DOC.TEXT: After weeks of sporadic clashes, a cease-fire between rival Christian forces collapsed Friday in thunderous battles that killed at least 38 people and left Beirut and the surrounding hills in flames. The fighting began at daybreak and continued without letup past midnight. Residents of the Metn region overlooking Beirut reported heavy shelling. The residents, reached by telephone from Cyprus, said they had been in bomb shelters since dawn. ``It's all-out war again,'' said a police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations. A cease-fire had been in effect since March 3 between Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and the rival Lebanese Forces militia. It had been violated repeatedly, raising fears of renewed warfare, but none of the previous fighting was as serious as that Friday. The Christian forces have been battling since Jan. 30 for control of the Christian enclave. Aoun began the warfare in January by moving to crush Samir Geagea's militia, the main challenger to Aoun's authority in the Christian region. Police said at least 38 people were killed and 65 wounded in savage combat Friday in the central sector of Christian east Beirut and in the mountains of Kesrouan province, 20 miles northeast of the capital. Since Jan. 30, at least 814 people have died in the battles. Most have been civilians. Thunderous blasts reverberated across Beirut. Schools, churches, apartments and shops were set ablaze in the city and across Kesrouan, and flames lit the night sky over Beirut. Police said scores of houses collapsed on their tenants. Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, spiritual head of the Maronite Catholic community of which Aoun and Geagea are members, threatened both men with excommunication if fighting did not stop. ``This horrific, destructive shelling which the army and the Lebanese Forces blame on each other ... has forced people to flee their homes and take shelter in forests,'' Sfeir said. ``How dare they claim they are defending Christian land while they are turning it into scorched earth?'' he said. The statement was broadcast on Beirut radio stations. Sfeir also issued an excommunication threat March 2, a day before the cease-fire. Geagea responded to Sfeir's latest appeal by saying he would stop shooting if Aoun reciprocated. There was no immediate response from Aoun. Aoun's force of 19,000 army troops and Geagea's 6,000-man militia accused each other of destroying the truce. Aoun's command said Geagea forces tried to attack army positions at Badaro, next to the Geagea stronghold of Ashrafieh in east Beirut. ``The attackers suffered heavy losses in lives and equipment,'' a communique said. The Lebanese Forces issued their own communique. It said Aoun's troops attacked the mountain village of Kleiat in an attempt to clear a path way for Aoun's troops to capture Kesrouan province. ``The Lebanese Forces prevented Aoun's units from accomplishing their objectives ... and succeeded in pushing them (Aoun's units) almost completely out of Kleiat in a counterattack,'' the Lebanese Forces' chief spokesman, George Abdul-Massih, told The Associated Press. Before the new outbreak of fighting, Aoun's army held a quarter of Kleiat. The rest was under Lebanese Forces control. On Thursday, Maronite leaders met in Bkirki, seat of the Maronite patriarchate, and empowered a mediation committee to reopen talks with Geagea and Aoun for a political solution. Aoun boycotted the meeting. Geagea attended and said he will press for a resolution urging Aoun and himself to discuss with President Elias Hrawi an overall settlement of the Lebanese crisis. Aoun, Geagea and Hrawi are all Maronites, the 900,000-strong Catholic sect that has dominated government since Lebanon's independence from France in 1943. The Syrian-backed Hrawi was elected president by Parliament in November and given the task of implementing political reforms designed to end 15 years of sectarian civil war. The reforms and election were part of an Arab League-brokered peace treaty endorsed the previous month. Aoun rejects that accord because it does not guarantee the withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops, deployed in Lebanon since 1976 to quell civil war fighting. He refuses to recognize Hrawi, who dismissed Aoun as army commander and interim prime minister in November. The general has refused to step down. Geagea recognizes the presidency. He has not declared his support for the accord, which would give the Moslems more of a say in governing Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Unveils Rescue Plan but Shutdown Still on Track
DOC.TEXT: Buffalo's subway and bus system hurtled toward a shutdown as a last-minute rescue plan announced Friday by Mayor James D. Griffin ran into opposition. Erie County officials, who earlier rejected a utility tax to fund mass transit, criticized Griffin's new proposal to use county sales taxes and an advance on county operating subsidies to keep the system afloat. County leaders said they saw no way to avoid a Saturday night shutdown of the bus and subway system, which carries 120,000 riders a day in New York's second-largest city. If the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority's buses and subways stop running, 9,700 students who normally take public buses to school will be on their own, Buffalo school officials said. Hospital administrators said they would handle the shutdown as if it were a blizzard, encouraging workers to stagger their hours and form car pools, and would look into renting private buses if necessary. Griffin said the city might relax parking restrictions. Riders lamented the political logjam. ``It's terrible,'' said Pat Gustine of suburban Williamsville. ``I'm in favor of them upping the fare or doing whatever they have to do.'' In another development, the transit agency's executive director, Alfred H. Savage, accepted a $149,500-a-year post as head of the Chicago Transit Authority. Savage resigned from the transportation authority Thursday, saying he was fed up with the county's unwillingness to support public transit. The system has been squeezed between rising costs and declining federal subsidies since 1985, when it opened its subway line. The bus and subway system cost $52 million to operate in the year ending March 31, and ran a deficit of $19.5 million. Farebox revenues pay about 40 percent of the operating cost; most of the rest comes from shrinking federal, state and county grants. The crisis point was reached Wednesday when the county legislature rejected a proposed tax on public utilities that would have raised $9 million for transit. A day later, transportation authority commissioners voted 8-1 to suspend operations, saying the legislature's action showed community leaders don't want a transit system. Transportation authority Comptroller Michael J. Neumeister said the agency will have just $89,000 in the bank Saturday night and will have to borrow from its profitable Greater Buffalo International Airport operation to meet the shutdown expense of $1.3 million. Expenses include final payroll and unemployment insurance payments. The plan announced by the mayor on Friday would take $9 million from an expected increase in local sales tax collections. He said the city, which faces a $30 million deficit, can't afford to give up its share of that money but can't afford to give up the transit system either. ``Shutting down affects those people who don't appear to have any voice,'' Griffin said. ``If we close down this system, shame on all of us.'' But such a change would need the approval of the county legislature, the elected county executive and the mayors of two other Erie County cities. And officials said Friday that approval was unlikely to be granted. County Executive Dennis Gorski said he opposes the sales tax transfer _ and the mayor's proposal that the county advance the system $2.1 million in subsidies that would normally be paid in August. ``He leaves out the part where property and school taxes across Erie County will have to be raised to make up the difference,'' Gorski said. On Thursday, Gorski said he would refuse an advance unless his own proposal for sweeping service cuts and reorganization of the transportation authority is adopted. Leonard R. Lenihan, the county legislature's majority leader, said he didn't think the sales tax proposal would win much support in that body.

DOC.HEAD: Eight SS-23 Missiles in Bulgaria, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Bulgaria has 72 short-range missiles, eight of them Soviet-made SS-23s with a maximum range of 312 miles, a Foreign Ministry official said Friday. The official BTA news agency quoted the unidentified official as saying, ``The eight missiles were bought and received in 1986, they are Bulgaria's property and are under exclusive Bulgarian control.'' He said there ``have never been and there are not at the moment any missiles in Bulgaria which should be declared and destroyed on the strength of the INF (intermediate nuclear forces) treaty signed by the Soviet Union and the United States in 1987.'' BTA said the SS-23s ``have never had nor has there been any intention to supply them with nuclear warheads.''

DOC.HEAD: Nearly Everyone's Talking HDTV at Broadcasters' Convention
LaserPhoto AX3
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of screens offering crystal clear, larger-than-life images of rock concerts, boxing matches and surreal animation greeted broadcasters as the industry's annual convention began Friday. One term was on nearly everyone's lips: HDTV. High Definition Television commanded center stage at the Advanced Technology Exhibit, which launched the National Association of Broadcasters' five-day convention. Dozens of HDTV screens offering sharp images flashed beside displays of high definition lenses, fiber-optic cameras and special effects gizmos aimed at changing the way TV is made and watched. HDTV would give viewers a picture far sharper than current broadcast standards by more than doubling the number of lines that make up a TV image. A major issue overhanging the exhibits is how the disparate technology can be standardized and sold in a way that won't make obsolete the millions of television sets now in use. Convention organizers say HDTV probably won't be available to U.S. homes until at least the middle of this decade. ``The issues are not so much what is technically possible,'' said Michael C. Rau, the association's senior vice president for science and technology. ``Rather, the issues are what kind of HDTV actually can be achieved, what technologies and standards can be agreed upon, what technologies have consensus.'' Displays at the convention suggest that technologically speaking, a great deal is possible. For example, the towering Pioneer CUBE system that greeted visitors Friday with an ultra-sharp broadcast of a rock concert made it clear that TV can look a lot better than what most people see in their homes. CUBE used a bank of 12 40-inch HDTV screens, each one showing a part of the larger picture and together presenting an image that was remarkably clear for a large-screen display. Drawing a small crowd nearby was an exhibit by the Broadcasting Technology Association of Tokyo of ``ghost reducer'' equipment designed to eliminate the multiple images that have bothered viewers since television's infancy. The problem occurs when television signals are reflected off mountains, tall buildings or other structures, officials said. The new technology eliminates the problem by adding an extra signal at the transmitter, which is picked up by a device on the TV set and used to filter out the distorted signal. The system was standardized in Japan in 1989 and is used by more than 100 TV stations there. Several U.S. companies are working on similar technology, but reducers are not expected to be available here for several years. ``It's not yet a consumer product because the demand will not justify the investment or the cost,'' said Amihai Miron, video department head for Philips Laboratories in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., one of the U.S. companies that have developed ghost reducer prototypes. Miron said it would cost up to $1,200, under current conditions, to equip a television set to use the system. Hundreds of additional exhibitors and dozens of panels and workshops are scheduled when the general sessions of the convention, expected to draw more than 50,000 people, begin Saturday. President Bush is scheduled to address the gathering Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Idaho Legislature Approves King Holiday
DOC.TEXT: A holiday honoring Martin Luther King Jr. won final approval in the Legislature on Friday, making Idaho the 47th state agreeing to adopt the federal holiday. Senate passage of the measure on a 28-11 vote assured it of becoming law with Gov. Cecil Andrus' promised approval. The vote was one of the Legislature's last acts before adjourning for the year, and came four years after the state designated the third Monday in January as a commemorative day but not an official holiday for King. Arizona, New Hampshire and Montana also have refused to designate a holiday. ``We've come a long way down the road,'' Sen. Mary Lou Reed said. ``We have the finest package of human rights legislation in the nation.'' The Legislature has passed some of the toughest laws in the nation against racial harassment and discrimination. But the King holiday, after winning initial Senate passage, was sidetracked in the House. Final passage came when the Senate agreed to a House amendment to call the holiday Martin Luther King Jr.-Idaho Human Rights Day. A black community leader, the Rev. Ellis Robinson of St. Paul Baptist Church in Boise, said the action extended the holiday beyond King to ``anyone who's ever struggled and worked for the rights of others.'' ``We're not looking at this as a victory for black people,'' Robinson said. ``We're looking at it as a victory for all people.'' The King holiday was pushed by lawmakers and the governor in part to offset the negative image the state has developed because of the presence of white supremacists at the Aryan Nations compound of Richard Butler in the state's panhandle. The major opposition focused on the potential cost of another day off for government workers, estimated anywhere between $100,000 and $2 million, depending on whether payroll is considered.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Leaves Southeast Texas, Snow in Northeast, Northern New Mexico
DOC.TEXT: Rainshowers dotted much of the eastern half of the nation Friday, turning to snow in northern and higher locations but changing back to rain later in the day. Colorado Springs, Colo., had a two-inch cover of new snow at daybreak, and the recent storm left as much as 6 inches of snow in the mountains near Flagstaff, Ariz. Snow advisories were posted for the north central mountains, the northeast highlands, the northeast Plains, the central highlands and the Sandia-Manzano mountains of New Mexico, changing to rain with thundershowers in the lower elevations of New Mexico. A flood watch was posted through for southeast Texas, where thunderstorms have produced locally heavy rain during the past two days. Thunderstorms continued across southeast Texas overnight and during the morning, with half-inch hail at Cotulla and La Salle. Morning snowfall across eastern New York and central New England generally turned to slush, but accumulations included 3 inches at Litchfield, Mass., and North Canaan, Conn., and 1 inch in the Massachusetts Berkshires. At noon, snowshowers were scattered over central and southern New England into northwest New York. Rain extended from the remainder of the eastern half of New York across Maryland and Delaware. Showers and thunderstorms dotted coastal Georgia, the southern coast of South Carolina, the Florida Panhandle and northern Florida, southwest Georgia, southeast Louisiana, and the upper Texas Gulf Coast. Rain extended from the western portion of the Carolinas across northern Georgia, northern Mississippi, Tennessee, Kentucky, southern Indiana, southern Illinois, southeast and southern Missouri, northern Arkansas, eastern and southern Kansas and southwest Nebraska. Rain over north central Colorado changed to snow, or became mixed with snow over much of the remainder of the state. Snow was also falling over southwest New Mexico.
