Heavier rainfall during the 6 hours ending at noon EST included almost 1{ inches at Panama City, Fla., 1 1-3 inches at Valparaiso, Fla., and almost an inch at Palacious, Texas. The low temperature for the nation Friday morning was 2 degrees below zero at Houlton, Maine. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 29 degrees at Worcester, Mass., to 87 degrees at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Company Denies Involvement in Alleged Iraqi Smuggling Ring
DOC.TEXT: A management company denied on Friday, two days after a search by customs officers, that the company had supplied sensitive equipment to Iraq without notifying with the government. Officers investigating an alleged Iraqi smuggling operation seized documents in the raid Wednesday at Global Technical and Management Services International, based in Deeside, Wales. An unidentified company in Edinburgh, Scotland, also was raided. The British news agency Press Association said officials were looking for information on alleged smuggling to Iraq of acoustic detonators for sea mines that can distinguish between friendly and enemy ships. Documents seized Wednesday reportedly contained proof that at least one acoustic detonator already had been smuggled to Iraq. Global issued a statement Friday saying it recently completed a contract with Iraq to clear offshore waterways of mines and debris to make shipping lanes safe. ``The project involved the supply to Iraq of equipment and personnel to carry out the ... work and also to train Iraqi Navy personnel,'' it said. But the company said it ``would not provide any service to Iraq or any other foreign country that was not accepted or sanctioned by the British authorities.'' British authorities say they want to question some Global executives when they return from abroad. The Anglo-American probe into the alleged illegal export of naval equipment sprang from an 18-month investigation by U.S. and British police and customs that culminated Wednesday in the seizure at London's Heathrow Airport of nuclear components about to be put on an Iraqi Airways flight to Baghdad. Three people were charged Thursday with trying to export 40 capacitors, essential components in detonating nuclear bombs, in violation of the Export of Prohibited Goods Control Act. Iraqi Omar Latif, who said he was an official with state-owned Iraqi Airways, was arrested Wednesday and will be deported as soon as possible, Home Office officials said Friday. Iraq denied it bought nuclear triggers and threatened retaliatory action if Latif is expelled.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Gorbachev: `Not Trying to Be Difficult' on Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS two grafs after 2nd graf pvs, White House, to update with Army visit postponed and SUBS 3rd graf pvs, In contrast, for transition; INSERTS one graf after 9th graf pvs, He cited, to add Bush comment at golf course
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday he had sent a confidential letter to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on the crisis in Lithuania, assuring him ``we're not trying to make things difficult'' for either side. White House officials indicated Gorbachev was under intense pressure to take a tough line toward the breakaway republic, and the administration continued trying to take a low-key approach. Yet, in a sign of displeasure, Gen. Carl E. Vuono, the U.S. Army chief of staff, postponed a courtesy visit he had been scheduled to make to the Soviet Union. Two U.S. officials, demanding anonymity, said Vuono's host would have been the Soviet military commander in Lithuania, and it would have been inappropriate for them to meet now. Meanwhile, Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., warned that ``all bets are off'' if Gorbachev resorts to force. ``The Soviets will be in real trouble here _ no trade agreements, no trade preferences and no more of the kind of relations the Kremlin is desperately seeking from Washington,'' Dole said. ``It would be a severe blow to U.S.-Soviet relations.'' The White House said Bush's message, sent through diplomatic channels Thursday night, emphasized U.S. hopes for resolving the conflict by peaceful dialogue. Bush declined to divulge exactly what the letter said, calling it confidential. ``I do not want to risk misunderstanding by failing to communicate,'' Bush said. It was Bush's first contact with Gorbachev since tensions began escalating with Lithuania's March 11 declaration to secede from the Soviet Union. ``I want to be sure that the Soviets understand our position and understand that we're not trying to make things difficult for Lithuania or the Soviet Union or anybody else,'' the president said, talking with reporters at a picture-taking ceremony He cited the importance of ``staying in touch and being sure there is no disconnect because of misinformation.'' Later, while playing golf, Bush was asked if Gorbachev had replied to his letter. ``What I said doesn't ... require any answer,'' he replied. The United States has repeatedly voiced support for Lithuania's right to self determination. At the same time, the Bush administration does not want the dispute to lead to the removal of Gorbachev, who has championed reforms in the Soviet Union and paved the way for the flowering of democratic governments in Eastern Europe. A senior administration official said Gorbachev appears to be under ``considerable domestic pressure'' because of the Lithuanian crisis. Lithuania's secession, by itself, would not be a critical episode for Moscow, the official said, ``but if that then becomes the symbol for a whole bunch of areas around the periphery of the Soviet Union, that would be very difficult.'' The official, who commented on condition of anonymity, said, ``It isn't in anybody's interest to have this thing blow up.'' The White House has alternated between tough rhetoric and near silence about Moscow's response to Lithuania, first warning that use of force would backfire and disrupt superpower relations and then refusing to pass judgment on Soviet actions. Maintaining that low-key approach, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We have not seen any _ too many episodes in the last few days that have been very dramatic. ``But the problem is not resolved,'' he said. ``They're still searching for solutions and we're hopeful that can be worked out.'' Bush has been criticized by some members of Congress for not being more aggressive in complaining about Soviet actions in Lithuania. While acknowledging the criticism, Fitzwater said, ``We believe our supporters far outnumber our critics on this issue.'' In a display of solidarity with Lithuania, staged before news cameras, three conservative senators telephoned President Vytautas Landsbergis with words of encouragement for his struggle against Moscow. Afterward, Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., said ``Our role is to demand (independence) today, even though it may not be possible for a month. It is to be outspoken. I think we can be a useful tool (for Bush) and I don't mind lending ourselves for that purpose.'' The other senators were Republicans Frank Murkowski of Alaska and Connie Mack of Florida. On Thursday, Fitzwater ruled out any direct contact by Bush with Gorbachev, saying the president ``simply feels that this is not the time to make a direct contact.'' Asked about the sudden reversal, Fitzwater said Bush was moved by, among other things, a telephone conversation Wednesday with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and a meeting Thursday with Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. Kennedy met with Gorbachev in Moscow on Monday. Mrs. Thatcher spoke with the Soviet leader by telephone this week. Kennedy said Gorbachev told him his efforts at reform were being undermined by Western criticism of his actions in Lithuania. Fitzwater said that Bush felt ``this was a time for a personal message that used his words and that President Gorbachev knew came directly from him in expressing our position.'' He said Bush ``clearly stated his support and the American support for the aspirations of the Lithuanian people for self-determination. ``We have expressed our belief and our emphatic view that a resolution of this conflict lies in peaceful dialogue,'' Fitzwater said. ``The president's message to President Gorbachev simply reaffirmed our position as stated many times.''

DOC.HEAD: Officials Will Seal Mass Grave Near World War II-Era Camp
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people will remain buried near a prison camp first used by the Nazis and then by the Soviets because the dead ``should rest in peace,'' an official said Friday. Local officials in Oranienburg discovered the remains at the site this week after a resident said he saw Soviet soldiers gun down hundreds of German prisoners there after World War II. The Nazis ran the prison camp near the town during World War II and the Soviets later used it to intern German prisoners after the war. ``Mass Grave of Unknown Victims _ Entry Forbidden,'' said the sign posted after authorities unearthed dozens more remains on Friday. Skeletal parts from 200 to 1,000 people, some of them children, have been unearthed, officials said. They said that after more than four decades, identification of the victims would be ``extremely difficult'' and that it would be better not to further disturb the remains. Oranienburg authorities have now decided to seal off the mass grave, said Heinz Erdmann, deputy Oranienburg district leader. ``The dead should rest in peace, they will not be transplanted,'' Erdmann said. ``The site will be turned into a memorial,'' Erdmann said. The camp, about 30 miles north of Berlin, is one of several Nazi camps later used by the Soviets to hold German prisoners. East German soldiers digging in the wooded area near the site of a former camp uncovered the skeletal remains of dozens more people Friday. The remains, including skulls and nearly intact skeletons, turned brown apparently from the soil in the region after more than 40 years under ground. Some of the skeletons apparently were stacked upon each other, while others were found alone over an area of about 300 square yards in the Schmachtenhagener woods outside the town. Few clothes or other belongings were found in the area, but rusted and illegible military-type ``dog-tag'' identification chains were found among the skeletons, soldiers working at the site said. Also found were empty shell casings. The official news agency ADN reported this week that officials ordered the excavation after a local resident said that in the years after 1945, he witnessed naked prisoners being driven to the site on trucks. According to the ADN report, the prisoners were forced to dig their own graves before they were shot and buried. ``They were piled on each other like sardines'' in the graves, the report said. ADN said the local prosecutor's office in Oranienburg has recommended that a special government commission be set up to investigate the mass burial site. Last weekend, East German officials reported that a mass grave had been uncovered at Fuenfeichen near Neubrandenburg, another of a total of 11 Nazi internment camps taken over by the Soviets in what is now East Germany. The existence of the graves had long been suspected but little evidence had surfaced until recently, after the old Communist regime was toppled last fall. But it was unclear from whether the remains were from the post-war Soviet era, the period of Nazi rule, or both. A West German official said 65,000 to 70,000 German prisoners may have died at the post-war Soviet camps. During the Nazi era, 6 million Jews and hundreds of thousands of gypsies, Poles and others were killed.

DOC.HEAD: New Charges Filed Against Cult Members
DOC.TEXT: A couple indicted in the suspected cult slayings of five family members pleaded innocent Friday to new charges that they also were involved in another murder plot. A grand jury returned the new indictment Thursday, charging Dennis S. Patrick, 35, and his wife, Tonya, 33, both of Independence, Mo., with one count each of complicity to commit aggravated murder. The indictment says the couple conspired to kill people in connection with a takeover of the Kirtland Temple of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, a splinter group of the Mormon Church. Judge James Jackson kept bond at $50,000 each on the new charges. The pair were then led in handcuffs back to the Lake County Jail, pending April trials. Lake County Prosecutor Steven LaTourette said additional charges are expected against two other people. The Patricks and 11 others have been charged in the shooting deaths last April of Dennis Avery, his wife, and their three daughters. The Averys and the 13 people charged in their deaths were in a cult group of former members of the Reorganized Church. LaTourette alleged that the victims were led one by one into a barn, bound at the hands and feet with tape and shot to death. The bodies of Avery, 49, his wife, Cheryl, 42, and their children _ Trina, 15, Rebecca, 13, and Karen, 7 _ were exhumed in early January. Authorities have said the cult was led by Jeffrey Lundgren, a former lay minister of the Reorganized Church who conducted tours of the temple until he began preaching a radical theology and was asked to leave the church. Ray Luffman, the pastor at the Kirtland Reorganized Church, has said Lundgren told his followers Jesus Christ would return to the temple and anyone not inside the building would perish. Former members who left the cult before the Avery killings have told authorities cult members trained with guns as part of the plot to take over the Kirtland temple. Luffman said he understood he was among those targeted for death. The temple was built by Mormons in the 19th century on their trek to Salt Lake City. Members of the Church of Jesus Christ Latter-day Saints, known as the Mormons, have common roots but aren't connected to the Reorganized Church. The Patricks pleaded innocent Jan. 16 to five counts each of conspiracy to commit aggravated murder in the deaths of the Averys. Dennis Patrick's attorney, James Koerner, said he expects the charges in the Avery killings to be dropped. He said the Patricks hope to return to Missouri, where their 10-year-old daughter lives. All the suspects in the killings have been arrested. Nine have been returned here to face charges, but four _ Jeffrey Lundgren, 39; his son, Damon, 19; Daniel Kraft, 25; and Kathryn Johnson, 36 _ have been jailed in San Diego since January.

DOC.HEAD: Cholesterol Poses Risk for the Elderly After All
DOC.TEXT: Old people suffer more heart disease if their blood cholesterol is high and they might benefit by eating less fat, exercising and losing weight, a government study has concluded. The findings contradict earlier research which made some doctors reluctant to advise elderly people to reduce their serum cholesterol, said Dr. Dwayne Reed of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute. The study of 3,440 middle-aged and 1,419 elderly men in Hawaii showed that a high level of cholesterol in the bloodstream increased the risk of future heart disease among 65- to 74-year-olds just as it did for those age 50 to 59. The 20 percent of men with the highest cholesterol levels were 1.7 times more likely to develop heart disease within 12 years than the 20 percent of men with the lowest levels, regardless of whether they were middle-aged or elderly when the study started in 1977. That means people with high cholesterol _ levels above 240 milligrams of cholesterol per deciliter of blood _ ``should be treated the same no matter what age they are,'' he added. Reed, an epidemiologist and physician who directs the government's Honolulu Heart Program, presented the findings Thursday during an American Heart Association conference. He said the results contradict some earlier findings of a famed study that started in 1948 and linked high blood cholesterol, high blood pressure and cigarette smoking to increased heart disease among residents of Framingham, Mass. For years, the study found no significant link between heart disease and cholesterol among people 65 and older. ``Previous to 1985-86, we would say it looks like cholesterol is weak or non-existent as a risk factor in the elderly,'' said Dr. Peter Wilson, laboratory director for the Framingham study. That's because there were too few elderly people in the study until recent years, and their health hadn't been followed long enough to reveal the cholesterol hazard, he added. Recent analyses of Framingham data confirm the Hawaii findings linking high blood cholesterol and heart disease risk among people 65 and older, but ``there's been a lag in terms of communication to the public,'' Wilson said. Wilson said the new study only demonstrates that cholesterol raises heart disease risk in elderly people. It will be a few years before studies determine if their risk can be reduced with cholesterol-lowering drugs or by cutting dietary fat, losing weight and increasing exercise. A majority of cholesterol experts believe all adults should ``know your cholesterol level and bring it down'' if it's above 240, first by dieting for a year, then by trying medications shown to be safe, Wilson said. People with levels over 300 often need medication immediately, he said. He noted that elderly heart disease patients already under a doctor's care are the most likely targets for such treatment. Those who should be checked for high cholesterol include seniors with other coronary risk factors such as high blood pressure, cigarette smoking or family history of heart disease. Experts are debating whether cholesterol testing would be worth the cost for all senior citizens. Seniors with high cholesterol should see a doctor who doesn't simply try to reduce total cholesterol, but tries to raise so-called ``good'' cholesterol, or HDL, while reducing ``bad'' cholesterol, or LDL, Wilson said. He urged people to get their cholesterol tested through a doctor who draws blood from a vein and has the blood tested by sophisticated equipment. Experts have disputed the accuracy of portable testing units that use blood from a finger stick. Such units often are seen in shopping malls. Reed said some doctors still don't urge old people to quit cigarettes because of earlier Framingham data that found no increase in heart disease risk in elderly smokers. But Wilson said most doctors and patients ``have gotten the message on smoking.'' The men in the Hawaii study are of Japanese ancestry and have lower heart disease death rates than white Americans. Reed said research has shown that regardless of race, ``the biological causes of heart disease are the same. ... And there is no reason to believe their biological effect would change as people get older.''

DOC.HEAD: Jennifer Casolo's Childhood Home Broken Into
DOC.TEXT: Intruders ransacked the home Jennifer Casolo returned to after her release from prison in El Salvador, dumping files and papers onto her bedroom floor, but apparently took nothing, police said. The intruders, who broke a window in the front door to get inside Casolo's mother's apartment, also rifled a night table in her mother's room and splashed fruit punch on the wall, police said. Casolo was a church worker in El Salvador when she was arrested in November on charges of storing munitions in her back yard for leftist Salvadoran rebels. Authorities released her for lack of evidence and expelled her from the country. The break-in, discovered by Casolo's mother, Audrey Casolo, when she returned home from work March 9, was similar to more than 100 others at homes and offices of people who oppose U.S. policy in Central America, according to a New York-based civil rights organization. Burglaries at the homes of opponents of U.S. military aid to El Salvador and the Nicaraguan Contras were the subject of congressional hearings in 1987, when the break-ins numbered 58. In most of the cases, intruders ignored cameras, stereos, computers and office equipment, and zeroed in on files, particularly membership, donor and mailing lists. The Center for Constitutional Rights, an organization of New York lawyers, says it has documented 108 intrusions since 1983. Since returning home to Thomaston, Casolo has toured the United States, speaking about her experiences and calling for an end to military aid to El Salvador.

DOC.HEAD: Beijing Mayor Denies Restrictions on Tiananmen Strolls
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of Beijing on Friday denied authorities have warned citizens to stay away from Tiananmen Square, site of last spring's bloody suppression of the pro-democracy movement, to prevent ``protest strolls.'' ``This is the first time I have heard such news,'' the mayor, Chen Xitong, said when asked at a news conference about the reported warnings. ``Everyone is allowed to take a walk anywhere.'' Overseas-based Chinese dissident groups have called on students and others to stroll through Tiananmen on April 1 and April 5 in a silent protest against the crackdown of the student-led pro-democracy movement last spring. The groups have suggested casual walks through the square, the focal point of last year's movement, because of the certainty that police would quickly break up any organized demonstration and arrest participants. Chinese sources have reported work units and schools throughout the city are telling workers and students to stay away from the square on the two designated days. April 5 is ``Qingming'' or Gravesweeping Day, the annual day when Chinese honor their dead. It has been suggested students might use the occasion to honor Hu Yaobang, the reformist former party chief whose death last April 15 touched off the student campaign for democratic reform. In 1976, thousands of people streamed to Tiananmen on Qingming to lay wreathes and flowers honoring Chou En-lai, the beloved premier who had died in January. The violent suppression of that spontaneous movement set the stage for the arrests of the ultra-leftist ``Gang of Four'' and the end of the Cultural Revolution later that year. Beijing students have received intensive political indoctrination and have been under tight surveillance since the democracy movement was crushed by military force last June 4. In private, many continue to condemn the repression and corruption of the government, but say open opposition is unlikely under the current harsh political climate. Mayor Chen asserted students are ``studying hard and behaving very well.'' He said people who think students are troublemakers have the wrong idea. The overwhelming majority, he said, support the Communist Party and the socialist system.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Says Nyet to Soviet Consul
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet reaction to the unrest in Lithuania prompted the U.S. State Department to cancel a Soviet diplomat's speech at a small college here, school officials said Friday. Soviet General Consul Gennady Zolotov was scheduled to speak Friday evening on changing conditions in his country and improved relations with the United States, said Roz Parry, a spokeswoman for Sierra Nevada College. Late Thursday, however, Parry said the State Department, which must approve any trip of more than 25 miles from the diplomat's San Francisco base, told Zolotov to stay home. The order came after the Soviets refused to give an American consular official in Leningrad a travel permit to visit Lithuania. Kim Lamberty of the State Department's Soviet section said the policy between the two countries remains one of strict reciprocity: If one nation denies the request of another for an official visit, the rebuff draws an immediate rejection by the other, Parry said. Zolotov was next on the list of Soviets scheduled for an appearance in the U.S., Parry said. ``It's so terminally silly it's almost difficult to take it seriously,'' said Mark Hurtubise, dean of the 165-student liberal arts college near Lake Tahoe. ``I would have liked to think that we (Americans) would be able to set an example for them in situations like this,'' he said. ``We should be playing the role model here, not just showing them that we can be as silly as they are.'' Evgueni Fokine, Soviet vice consul in San Francisco, was philosophical about the denial. ``It's a matter of reciprocity,'' he said. ``It happens. ``Travel in Lithuania is being restricted because of the turmoil there,'' he said. ``Foreign diplomats have been ordered out because of the danger. Is there turmoil and danger in Incline Village?''

DOC.HEAD: First Anniversary of K mart Bombing Approaches
DOC.TEXT: A woman whose young daughter was maimed by a pipe bomb planted on a store shelf wishes whoever is responsible for the attack could see the lasting effects of the cruel act. Erin Bower, 6, has been fitted with an artificial left hand and is attending school. Next month she undergoes a cornea transplant for her left eye, which also was damaged in the April 17, 1989, blast at a K mart store. The person who put the bomb on the K mart shelf remains at large. ``We're so lucky that internally she's fine and mentally she's fine. She's such a happy child. She really is,'' said Erin's mother, Maureen Bower. ``I don't get down as frequently as I used to, but when we had to make the decision on the cornea transplant, it rehashed all the garbage again,'' the mother said. ``That's when I started frequently wishing that this person would see what he has done. I got real upset with that person, and I usually don't think about that person at all. But when you have to relive all this again, it's tough,'' she said. Erin was shopping with her family at the K mart in Castleton when she picked up a tube of toothpaste. The tube exploded. Federal agents remain optimistic they will crack the case eventually. ``We believe we've finally turned the corner, and we're very hopeful at this point,'' said Charles A. Petersen, agent in charge of the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in Indianapolis. He declined to elaborate. Ed Verkin, an agent in the agency's Louisville, Ky., bureau, says a laboratory examining fragments of the pipe bomb has found some new evidence in the case, but he, too, declined to elaborate. Rewards totaling about $50,000 remain posted in the case. ``She's doing great,'' Mrs. Bower said. ``Emotionally, there is no problem, which is an absolute miracle.'' ``She hasn't missed a beat,'' said her father, Kevin. ``She'd doing real well, getting very good grades. She's becoming more of a little bit of a leader in her class. ``The kids have been great. They'll ask questions (about her artificial hand) and look, but as soon as that period is over, they don't even think about it,'' Bower said. ``They think Erin's like everybody else.'' As April 17 nears, the Bowers sense it will be a difficult day but not an impossible one. ``It's hard to believe a year is coming up,'' Mrs. Bower said. ``I think that day will be kind of hard. I'm sure I'll think about it an awful lot. I already think about it. But it's over with. There's nothing we can do about it now. I think we're beyond it.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Soldiers Occupy Lithuanian Government Building
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with newspaper plant invaded, premier's report. Picks up 6th, `Lithuanian legislator...' with minor editing to trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos VIL2,VIL3,WX17
DOC.TEXT: Soviet troops took over the building housing the Lithuanian chief prosecutor's office late Friday after staff members refused to work with a Moscow loyalist named as new chief prosecutor by the Kremlin. The takeover was the first occupation of a government building in Vilnius since Lithuania declared its independence on March 11, and came as an abrupt reversal by the Soviets after initial steps by both sides toward a compromise. Soldiers previously had occupied a few Communist Party buildings. Uniformed men early Saturday also moved into Lithuania's central newspaper printing plant. They refused to identify themselves and said only that they were protecting the building. Witnesses said they saw at least seven men, armed with nightsticks. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said on television the decision to take over the prosecutor's office ``brings shame on the Soviet Union.'' ``They are trying to destroy the legal system. We have had these challenges before. We have stood against them, and we will do it again,'' he said. Premier Kazimiera Prunskiene told reporters after an emergency session of the Presidium of the Lithuania parliament that the government told employees of the prosecutor's office to try to work in the building under the Lithuanian official rather than Moscow's choice. Lithuanian legislator Egidius Bickauskas said earlier on TV that the Soviet troops occupied the building with the help of an employee. He did not elaborate. A foreign journalist rushed to the scene and said he saw a truckload of Interior Ministry soldiers enter the building. Moscow earlier tried to force Lithuania to adhere to Soviet law by firing Lithuania's chief prosecutor, Arturis Paulauskas, and announcing he would be replaced by Antanas Petrauskas. The chief prosecutor is basically a republic-wide district attorney. Soviet deputy prosecutor Alexei Vasiliev made the announcement in a conference hall of the prosecutor's building in Vilnius. He ordered the 100 staff members to enforce Soviet law. Staffers began arguing and shouting at Vasiliev and then walked out. Hours later, the Soviet soldiers moved in. A duty officer at the Lithuanian Interior Ministry said soldiers also had arrived at a Communist Party building, the Institute of Party History. Other buildings under military control are the Institute of Marxism-Leninism, the Higher Party School and Communist Party headquarters. All are Communist Party buildings. Deputy Premier Kazimieras Motieka, speaking to reporters, accused Vasiliev of bargaining in bad faith when he met with Lithuanian officials earlier. Motieka attended that meeting. Vasiliev spoke politely of compromise with the Lithuanians when ``there's no question at that moment they already had this planned,'' Motieka charged. He said soldiers told Lithuanian Interior Minister Marijonas Misiukonis they were ``taking it (the buiding) over to enforce security at the request of Vasiliev.'' In other developments Friday: _Byelorussia, the republic just south of Lithuania, demanded the return of territory given to Lithuania when the republic was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. _The republic of Estonia, also annexed by the Kremlin in 1940, pledged to achieve full independence. _The KGB said it would enforce Soviet law in Lithuania and protect Lithuanian citizens who cooperate with it. _The Council of the Federation, a new body of leaders in President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's government, directed Gorbachev to tell Lithuania that before any talks on secession begin, the republic must rescind laws contradicting the Soviet Constitution. The White House said President Bush sent a letter to Gorbachev emphasizing U.S. hopes the conflict could be resolved peacefully. Bush said the letter assured Gorbachev ``we're not trying to make things difficult'' for either side. The United States has repeatedly voiced support for Lithuania's right to self-determination. At the same time, the United States _ like other Western nations _ does not want the dispute to lead to the removal of Gorbachev, whose reforms have paved the way for democratic governments across Eastern Europe. Byelorussia, known for its conservative leadership, said Lithuania was given ``historically Byelorussian territory'' in a half-dozen border regions when Soviet officials incorporated Lithuania and set its borders 50 years ago. If Lithuania secedes, ``we will be forced to insist on the return to the Byelorussian Soviet Socialist republic of Byelorussian land,'' said the statement. The Estonian parliament did not set a date for full independence from Moscow. For the past two days, both sides in the Lithuanian dispute had taken steps toward compromise. The Defense Ministry on Thursday said it would not punish the hundreds of Lithuanian deserters if they voluntarily returned to their units. On Wednesday, the Lithuanian government said it was halting plans to establish a border guard, and it advised citizens not to resist if Soviet authorities came to seize their weapons. Chief Military Prosecutor Alexander Katusev said in an interview on Soviet TV Friday that the Defense Ministry had been out of line in offering amnesty. He said criminal cases had begun against all deserters. People inciting deserters to leave the armed forces also will be prosecuted, he said. The KGB, in a statement distributed by the Tass news agency, said officers in Lithuania would continue to enforce Soviet law and guard the border. It said a resolution passed Tuesday by Lithuania's legislature demanding citizens stop cooperating with it was illegal. In Moscow, the Council of the Federation charged that Lithuania is ``stubbornly ignoring'' Soviet law. It said Gorbachev should demand Lithuanian laws contradicting Soviet law be withdrawn before any talks can begin. Soviet Foreign Ministry officials told most of the few foreign journalists remaining in Lithuania on Friday they would have to leave by Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Philip Warns Population Growth Poses Ecological Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Prince Philip said Friday population growth has created an environmental crisis that could be ``more devastating than any nuclear holocaust'' if unchecked. In a speech at the United Nations, Prince Philip said the problem was caused by ``human scientific and technological genius'' that led to rampant population growth. ``It seems to me that it is about time that these same people, the leaders in thought, in politics and in administration, began to face the facts and started to make serious efforts to find ways of solving the crisis,'' he said. ``The fuse of the population bomb has already been ignited and the consequences of the explosion for the future of the world will be a great deal more devastating than any nuclear holocaust,'' he said in the speech sponsored by the U.N. Population Fund. Prince Philip, president of the Worldwide Fund for Nature, said the ecological problems resulting from population growth are compounded because the countries facing the most dire circumstances are generally the poorest. The prince recommended more international support for aid agencies so they can stabilize world population and avert conditions threatening many plant and animal species. The U.N. Population Fund estimates the current world population is nearly 5.3 billion people. But it projects the figure will be 14 billion by the year 2100. Prince Philip said that while increasing numbers of people is the main problem for many poor countries, the increasing rate of consumption in richer countries also is causing serious trouble. ``This leads to the inescapable conclusion that we are eating into our capital assets, to the detriment of future generations,'' he said. ``As the forests shrink, as the marshes are drained, as the rivers are polluted, as the dams, highways, railroads, factories and houses are built, so the wildlife loses its habitat and, unable to find any food and nowhere to breed, it just dies out.'' Prince Philip also stressed the need to control hunting and fishing to prevent the exploitation of animals. ``There can be no doubt that such practices should come under some sort of international control, but the perpetrators claim that the starving millions need the food and that they need the jobs,'' he said. ``It should not be very difficult to imagine the consequences of the indiscriminate exploitation of a dwindling resource in order to meet a rising demand.''

DOC.HEAD: Hillary Warns Against Ecological Destruction of Himalayas
DOC.TEXT: Mountain climber Sir Edmund Hillary, who made history in 1953 by conquering Mount Everest, said Friday that tourist development since then has destroyed much of the beauty of the Himalayas. Hillary and other speakers warned of widespread deforestation of the mountains in speeches at the opening session of the two-day First International Conference on Environmental Protection of the Himalayas. The 70-year-old New Zealander recalled the remote valleys and foothills he traveled before he and Sherpa guide Tenzing Norgay became the first to reach the top of Mount Everest on May 29, 1953. ``In 1951, the people lived a simple, hardy existence. Few of them had ever seen a railroad train or a bus. Tourism was unknown,'' Hillary said. ``Nowadays, tens of thousands are walking the hills tracks, floating down the rivers, landing in tiny airstrips in remote valleys. ... The living standards are increasing, but the beautiful tracks and valleys have been littered and the forests destroyed.'' The conference is sponsored by the Himalayan Adventure Trust, which Hillary helped found two years ago, and by the Indian Mountaineering Foundation. Hillary said tourism in the Himalayas must be spread more thinly and visitors must take their trash with them when they leave. ``Tourist agents must be pressured to make sure their customers leave the hills and valleys beautiful,'' he said. He said huge population increases have sent more farmers into the Himalayas in search of survival. ``The local people are forced higher and higher to cut trees and make terraces for their crops. When will it ever stop?'' he asked. Maneka Gandhi, India's minister of state for environment and forests, warned that deforestation and pollution would have disastrous results reaching far beyond the Himalayan highlands. ``Today the Himalayas are crumbling,'' said Mrs. Gandhi, sister-in-law of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. ``The disappearance of the Himalayas will mean the desertification of India and neighboring areas. We have to preserve the Himalayas or we perish.'' She said the new government of Prime Minister V.P. Singh was considering a $175 million plan ``to re-green the Himalayas.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Check `Foreign Object' in Oil Rig Machinery
DOC.TEXT: Occidental Petroleum Corp. said Friday it discovered a ``potential malicious act'' that could have imperiled 350 men on a North Sea rig. Police said they were investigating. Occidental said a ``foreign object'' was found in non-operating machinery on the Claymore rig _ sister platform to the Piper Alpha, which exploded and burned July 6, 1988, killing 167 men 120 miles off east Scotland. Claymore was shut down after the disaster, but resumed partial production in August 1989. Occidental said the object was found in the gas compression system, which was due to go back into operation in April. It did not identify the object. Neither Occidental nor police would say if the act was being viewed as a possible sabotage attempt. Claymore's 350 staff live and work on the installation _ 260 on the platform, the rest on the adjoining support vessel Tharos. Occidental said, ``This appears to be a stupid and irresponsible act which suggests the presence of someone on board the platform who has no respect for the safety of his fellow workers. We will not tolerate this behavior.'' It said it summoned police and also notified the Department of Energy. The company said it was withholding further information at police request. Grampian Police said: ``We were advised by Occidental of an incident on the Claymore platform and we are making inquiries into it.'' A spokesman declined to comment further.

DOC.HEAD: United States Returns $2 Million to Panama
DOC.TEXT: The United States has returned to Panama more than $2 million confiscated by American troops during the December invasion, Panamanian justice officials said Friday. During the invasion that began Dec. 20, U.S. troops raided homes and offices of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's ousted strongman. U.S. soldiers also went through homes and offices of Noriega associates, seizing documents, weapons, money and other items. Marcos Ostrander, chief of U.S. International and Operational Law, said in a letter accompanying the funds that authorities do not know who the money belongs to. He said private funds should go back to their owners but it was up to the Panamanians to decide how to distribute the money. It was returned to Panamanian officials ``due to the form and circumstances in which it was confiscated,'' said Elquilia Santos, a Panamanian attorney general's office spokeswoman. The check for $2,015,750.21 was sent to the Panamanian comptroller's office to determine how the funds will be used.

DOC.HEAD: Keillor Says Artists Should Be Provocative
DOC.TEXT: Garrison Keillor, the soft-spoken humorist known for his fond pokes at small-town America, told a Senate panel Thursday that government-funded artists should be more provocative. ``I wish there were more of the controversial projects,'' Keillor told the Senate Labor and Human Resources subcommittee on education, arts and humanities. The subcommittee is studying the renewal of the NEA, which has been at the center of a controversy because of taxpayer-funded exhibits of works judged by some to be pornographic and insulting to religion. Speaking of his early struggles as a writer, Keillor said, ``I remember very well when nobody else was but my mother and the National Endowment was interested.'' Defenders say only 20 projects out of 85,000 receiving NEA funding in the last quarter century have been controversial. ``I think that that small number out of 85,000 is a remarkable testament to how timid and self-repressed'' artists have become, he said. He warned lawmakers against tying strings to funding, saying: ``If Congress doesn't do something about obscene art, we'll have to build galleries twice as big to hold the people who want to go see it. And if Congress does do something about obscene art, the galleries will need to be even bigger than that.''

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher: She, Kohl Agree Nuclear Weapons Must Stay in United Germany
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Friday she has agreed with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany that nuclear weapons must remain in Europe after the Germanys are unified. But Kohl refused to commit himself to her insistence that West German-based NATO nuclear missiles, aimed at East Germany, should remain after unification. ``We both agreed that the presence of nuclear weapons on European soil _ and I think German soil is the preferred soil for American nuclear weapons _ is vital,'' Mrs. Thatcher said, sitting next to Kohl at a news conference winding up his two-day visit to Britain. Kohl said: ``I think in the future, too, we need full protection of NATO for the territory of Germany.'' But he did not say outright that he wanted NATO nuclear weapons to stay on German soil after unification, and Mrs. Thatcher acknowledged her talks with Kohl were held in a ``rapidly changing situation.'' ``We have not in fact got down to the details ... that will be negotiated through NATO,'' she said. While insisting that Germany wanted to map out its future in close cooperation with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and its European Community partners, Kohl gave no clearcut reply when asked if nuclear weapons should stay in Germany. ``I think the world has changed and within NATO we will have to draw the consequences in reasonable discussions,'' he said. Kohl said Germany sought no special status or treatment within NATO and did not want to be neutral or demilitarized. But he said that in negotiations to reduce conventional, chemical and short-range nuclear weapons, ``I think that we can now achieve enormous progress, progress that would have been unthinkable one or two years ago.'' Kohl reiterated that his goal was political unification of Europe, something Mrs. Thatcher opposes. He said he was not angered by those who say European unity is vital to ``control'' the might of a united Germany. ``We don't mind this argument, even if it is not very flattering, because it's the goal that counts,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Rep. Bill Frenzel Retiring From Congress After 20 Years
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Bill Frenzel, a leading Republican spokesman on budget and tax issues, announced Friday he would retire from Congress after representing Minnesota for 20 years. ``I have done this for a long time and it is now time for someone else to do it,'' Frenzel, 61, said in announcing he won't seek re-election this year. ``Every member of Congress knows when the time has come not to run again,'' Frenzel told a news conference. ``For me, it is now.'' Frenzel, the top Republican on the House Budget Committee and a senior member of the Ways and Means Committee, is one of the most respected fiscal conservatives in Washington and one of Minnesota's most popular politicians. Frenzel has mixed economic conservatism with social liberalism ever since he first won the 3rd District seat in 1970, in a close race with a TV personality. He has won re-election by wide margins ever since. He has represented the House GOP in virtually every important budget conclave in recent years, including White House-congressional summits and the National Economic Commission. House Minority Leader Robert H. Michel, R-Ill., said he was devastated to hear of Frenzel's retirement. ``He's been the GOP's most eloquent and intelligent spokesman on budget and tax issues for many years,'' Michel said. Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the Budget Committee and a frequent Frenzel battler, on Friday praised his erstwhle foe as ``one of the giants of this institution.'' Even when unpopular to do so, Frenzel has taken the House floor to point out the costs of legislation before the chamber. For example, just this week he pointed out that since the House had not figured out how to pay for its $27 billion child day-care legislation, those same children will find a big debt waiting for them when they grow up. ``What a weird, tortured way of taking care of children _ by giving them an IOU for $30 billion,'' he said. Frenzel said he has not decided if he will stay in Washington or return to Minnesota to live. Although a friend of President Bush, Frenzel said he has not received an offer for a post in the Bush administration. ``I think there will be something out there,'' he said. ``It is not that I am forced by some event to do this. It's just that I think it is time to do it.'' Frenzel won re-election in 1988 by more than a 2-1 margin. His district is considered a Republican stronghold and includes portions of Carver, Dakota, Hennepin, Scott and a tiny portion of Goodhue County. Rick Stafford, communications director of the state Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party, said Frenzel was more popular than the Republican Party. ``I think we really feel we have a good shot at taking that seat with Frenzel not running again,'' he said, He described Frenzel as ``pro-choice, very moderate Republican; moderate to liberal, matter of fact.'' ``Frenzel was very popular with Democrats and Republicans'' he said. ``He was liberal on a lot of social issues; the old-time Republican that you don't see around much any more.''

DOC.HEAD: Gonzalez Indicted in Fire That Killed 87 People
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with prosecutor saying defendant could be convicted of two murder counts for each victim, lawsuits filed; CORRECT that defendant wasn't present when indictment returned but was in court earlier on another matter. Pick up 13th graf pvs, `Berne said...' SUBS 20th graf pvs, `Six victims...,' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Red Cross charter flight to return bodies to Honduras, Honduras withdrawing request for National Guard help.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SJ1
DOC.TEXT: The man accused of killing 87 people by torching an illegal social club in a jealous rage was indicted on 178 counts of murder, arson and other charges Friday. A state grand jury indicted Julio Gonzalez on one count of second-degree murder and one count of murder in the commission of a felony for each person killed inside the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx. He also was indicted on two counts of arson and single counts of attempted murder and assault. The defendant wasn't present when the indictment was returned. Gonzalez, 36, who is due back in court April 12, could face a sentence of 25 years to life if convicted on all counts in the case, said Assistant District Attorney Eric Warner. If a judge made the sentences run consecutively, he could receive a 2,000-year term. ``No case is open and shut,'' Warner said. ``We have a very good case. The evidence is strong.'' Bronx District Attorney Robert Johnson said it is ``conceivable'' that Gonzalez could be convicted of two murder counts for each victim, but he said a jury ``probably would have to choose between the two.'' Gonzalez, a Cuban immigrant, opted against testifying before the panel, said his court-appointed attorney, Richard W. Berne. While the grand jury considered the charges, authorities released records indicating that one of the club's landlords was contacted by a fire lieutenant eight months before the blaze and told a vacate order was in effect against the building. Morris Jaffe, a partner in Little Peach Realty, responded that the problem ``would be taken care of,'' according to a July 28, 1989, Fire Department document. Jaffe and Jay Weiss, the husband of actress Kathleen Turner, are partners in Little Peach. Jaffe didn't return telephone messages left at his office Friday seeking comment on the report. Weiss, Jaffe and their company were named in two more multimillion-dollar negligence lawsuits filed Friday on behalf of the families of fire victims. Also named were the club itself; the building's owner of record, Alex DiLorenzo; and the City of New York. One lawsuit asks for $100 million in damages; the second asks for $57 million. Both were filed in Manhattan's federal court. The day before, a $510 million lawsuit was filed by the mother of another victim. Friday was the deadline for an indictment of Gonzalez, who has been held on murder and arson charges since Sunday. He had not entered a plea in the case because he hadn't been indicted. Gonzalez, brought to court earlier in the day on another matter, was returned to Bellevue Hospital, where he was under 24-hour watch. A shotgun-wielding correction officer accompanied the suspect back and forth from the court, and no other prisoners are permitted within 20 feet of him at Bellevue, his lawyer said. Berne said he hoped to arrange a psychiatric examination for Gonzalez soon. ``Obviously, one potential avenue of defense is psychiatric,'' said Berne. ``It's always a possible defense. Now I'm looking through doors, and I will (decide) ... which door I want to walk through.'' Berne said Gonzalez was exhausted when they met Thursday night. ``Imagine what he's been through. He's very tired,'' Berne told reporters at state court in the Bronx. Gonzalez, enraged by a girlfriend's rejection, spilled gasoline in the entrance to the Happy Land social club early Sunday and set it ablaze, authorities said. Eighty-seven patrons died inside the cramped club, which catered largely to immigrants from Honduras. His attorney said he was going into the case without any preconceptions. ``All you hear at this stage is the worst of everything. I wouldn't be a very good lawyer if I rendered a decision on what I've read in the newspapers,'' Berne said. The Red Cross was preparing a charter flight to carry more than 40 bodies back to Honduras Saturday. In Albany, the New York National Guard said the Honduran government had withdrawn a request for its help in transporting victims' bodies. Six victims were buried Friday at St. Raymond's Cemetery in the Bronx, and dozens of mourners attended a wake Friday evening for three others. One of the few patrons to survive the fire, meanwhile, was interviewed about the scene at Happy Land when the fire broke out. Felipe Figueroa said the club's disc jockey, Ruben Valladares, was playing a Jamaican reggae song when the club doorman rushed up the deadly narrow staircase yelling, ``Fuego! fuego!'' or fire, fire. ``Right away, people went crazy,'' he said in the interview with The New York Times. ``Everybody was running around.'' He said he made his way down a narrow staircase and out the door, and then saw Valladares, who was a friend of his, come out in flames. The disc jockey remains hospitalized with burns over 40 percent of his body. ``My mind can't stop,'' Figueroa said. ``All the screams, all the noise, and the moment when my friend came out of there screaming. I can't forget that.'' Authorities are unsure how many people survived but most accounts put the number at five or six.

DOC.BYLINE: Court is Asked to Curb US Trade with Labor Rights Violators ^By CARL HARTMAN
DOC.TEXT: Organizations led by former Labor Secretary Ray Marshall asked a court on Thursday to make President Bush deny trade privileges to countries that violate their citizens' labor rights. The lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. It did not name countries, but a press statement said the organizations have documents to show violations in Guatemala, El Salvador, Malaysia, Haiti, the Philippines, Thailand, Turkey and Indonesia, among others. About 140 areas are privileged to ship some of their products to the United States duty-free, or at reduced duties, under what is called the Generalized System of Preferences. The reduced duties allow the products to be sold in this country at lower prices than similar goods from other countries. The system is designed to help the Third World countries develop their industries. The law setting up the system limits the benefits to countries that respect internationally recognized worker rights. These include a ban on child labor, special provisions for women, the right to form labor unions and others. Under this provision, U.S. authorities have banned Nicaragua, Romania and Burma from the program and suspended Paraguay, Chile and the Central African Republic. Marshall and the other complainants consider that inadequate. ``The Bush administration's refusal to enforce the law gives large, multinational firms a windfall at the expense of both American and foreign workers,'' Marshall said in a statement. ``Businesses can earn great profits in developing countries relatively free from labor regulation, export their products duty-free to the U.S. market, displace American workers, and take advantage of unprotected foreign workers.'' The complaint was filed by the AFL-CIO and 22 other labor unions and private groups, including Marshall's own International Labor Rights Education and Research Fund, an advocacy group. It asked the court to interpret the law and to order Bush and his administration to review the rights of labor in all the countries that benefit from it. The office of U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said the action had been signalled in advance but it had no comment. Bush and six members of his Cabinet named as defendants, including Ms. Hills, have 60 days to reply.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Legislators Appeal for Clemency for Robert Harris
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to UPDATE with execution blocked. Picks up 2nd, `The petition...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Harris Execution
DOC.TEXT: Italian parliamentarians have signed a petition urging the governor of California to stop the scheduled April 3 execution of Robert Alton Harris, convicted of killing two teen-agers in 1978. Late Friday in San Francisco, a federal appeals court blocked the scheduled execution, saying Harris may not have received competent psychiatric help at the time of his trial. The petition drive was organized by ``Non Uccidere,'' or ``Thou Shall Not Kill,'' a group that campaigns against the death penalty. It was addressed to Gov. George Deukmejian and signed by 200 legislators from across the political spectrum. ``The death penalty is against the value of human life in every case. It would be even more hideous if applied to Robert Harris, whose life has been marked by pain and suffering,'' it said. The petition described Harris' personal story as ``terrifying,'' noting that he was born prematurely after his father kicked his alcoholic mother, and that he was beaten as a young child. It urged Deukmejian to ``leave inactive your state's gas chamber to give the world an example of civility, to affirm the coherence of the choice of democracy, to respect the international treaties on human rights.'' Harris, 37, was convicted of abducting and killing two 16-year-old San Diego boys 12 years ago. He would become the first person executed in California since 1967.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Prosecutor Tells Jury to Ignore `Biased' Reagan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS additional remarks in one graf after 22nd graf, pvs bgng ``Beckler argued,'' and one graf after 27th graf, pvs bgng: ``The prosecutor.''
DOC.TEXT: The prosecutor at John Poindexter's trial asked jurors in final arguments Friday to ignore former President Reagan's ``biased'' testimony and convict his national security adviser of Iran-Contra coverup charges. But Poindexter's attorney said the defendant had merely gotten caught in a political battle between Congress and the White House and had done ``his ever-loving best to give as much information as he could tell'' rather than conspiring to hide the affair. Poindexter had done his job for Reagan, ``the driving engine behind his actions,'' said defense lawyer Richard Beckler. Prosecutor Dan K. Webb said in his summation that there was ``overwhelming evidence'' that Poindexter lied to Congress and destroyed documents to cover up the diversion of Iran arms sale profits to help the Nicaraguan Contra rebels when aid was banned by Congress. Webb ridiculed the defense's decision to call Reagan as its ``star witness,'' calling it an attempt to persuade jurors to ignore the facts. Reagan ``didn't have the slightest clue'' whether Poindexter participated in the crimes charged in the indictment, Webb said. The defense hoped that ``just because the president testified you ought to acquit John Poindexter,'' Webb said. ``That defense is an insult to your intelligence.'' Poindexter's attorney told jurors that Reagan resisted testifying and did not come ``as a friendly witness.'' He defended the former president's value as a witness, saying: ``the fact he forgot some things does not mean his testimony was not relevant.'' The eight hours of Reagan's videotaped testimony, taken in February in Los Angeles, was played for the jury last week by the defense, which rested its case Wednesday without calling Poindexter to the stand. The case, which began with jury selection March 5, is expected to go to the jury Monday after the judge gives his final instructions. Beckler told jurors Friday that Poindexter, a retired Navy rear admiral, should not have to pay for the misdeeds of his former aide, Oliver L. North, who was convicted of charges last year. ``If Oliver North did something wrong, that is Oliver North's responsibility. That is not Admiral Poindexter's responsibility,'' said Beckler, who tried to paint North as a renegade operator in the Iran-Contra affair. ``There were absolutely many things that Admiral Poindexter didn't know Oliver North was doing,'' Beckler said. Poindexter was not a member of ``some grimy little conspiracy that the prosecution would have you believe,'' Beckler said. ``He is a victim of a concerted action by Congress, working hand-in-hand with the independent counsel's office to try to do something with this political battle'' between Congress and the White House, Beckler said. Through much of Beckler's 2{-hour summation, Poindexter's wife Linda sat in the front row of the spectator's gallery holding 4-year-old grandson Zachary on her lap. Prosecutor Webb attacked Reagan's testimony, saying ``Ronald Reagan didn't seem to remember anything in this case'' and demonstrated bias at one point by turning and winking at Poindexter. ``When people come into court we expect them to give fair and truthful testimony,'' Webb said. ``But when a person is so biased he turns to wink at someone as if to say `Did that last answer help you, John?' _ I would have expected more from a former president than that,'' Webb said. Webb ridiculed Reagan's defense of three letters Poindexter sent to Congress in July, 1986, which the prosecution charges falsely deny that the National Security Council staff was secretly orchestrating arms shipments to the Contras. The prosecutor recalled that when Reagan was shown one of the letters, the former president said he agreed with its contents and added ```I would have added in a profanity.''' ``He gave that testimony because he hoped it would help John Poindexter,'' Webb said. ``He hadn't the foggiest idea those were false letters sent to obstruct Congress.'' Beckler argued the letters were, in fact, truthful. He said Reagan mentioned including profanity in the response because the lawmaker's request for information as ``nothing more than an attempt by Congress to take a shot at the administration's position on Contra support.'' Webb reminded jurors that on cross-examination, Reagan said he never authorized Poindexter to lie or destroy documents. Webb, a former U.S. attorney in Chicago appointed by Reagan, argued that Poindexter tore up a document authorizing U.S. involvement in Iranian arms sales to protect Reagan from political embarrassment. ``This is the one document in the world that puts the lie to what Ronald Reagan told the American people'' when he denied in a Nov. 13, 1986, speech that he had sold arms to Iran to try to free American hostages, Webb said. The document, an intelligence ``finding'' signed by Reagan in December 1985, authorized the CIA's involvement a month earlier in the shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. It described the transaction as an effort to free U.S. hostages. Webb said that Poindexter, after lying to two congressional committees on Nov. 21, 1986, about U.S.-Iran arms sales, returned to his office and ``he tore up the original finding signed by the president of the United States.'' The prosecutor, ripping up a copy of the document to dramatize his point, said, ``The act of tearing up that finding is strong evidence'' Poindexter ``intended to obstruct Congress.'' Webb said it ``was not a coincidence'' that both Poindexter and then-CIA Director William Casey, who died in 1987, lied to Congress that day about the 1985 Hawk shipment. ``That was an obstruction of Congress by two of the highest ranking people in the government of our nation,'' the prosecutor said. Poindexter, who served as Reagan's national security adviser from late 1985 until his resignation on Nov. 25, 1986, is also accused of deceiving Congress about White House involvement in covert assistant to the Nicaraguan rebels. Webb recounted North's testimony that he was ``generally instructed'' by Poindexter to lie to lawmakers about the secret aid network. North ``was there because the defendant on trial in this case, his commander, sent him there to do that,'' Webb said. ``The boss can't escape legal responsibility just because he didn't get his hands dirty.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Stays First California Execution in 23 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with attorney general to appeal to U.S. Supreme Court, quotes from him, relative of victim. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Noonan, a...' INSERTS 1 graf after 13th, `It takes...,' to add background on appeal.
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals judge on Friday blocked next Tuesday's scheduled execution of convicted double murderer Robert Alton Harris, who would have become the first inmate executed in California in 23 years. Harris, convicted of shooting two teen-age boys to death in 1978 to use their car in a robbery, may not have had competent psychiatric help at the time of his trial, said Judge John Noonan of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. ``It is reasonably arguable, and we cannot determine from this record, whether Harris received competent psychiatric assistance,'' said Noonan. His order, issued after a 50-minute hearing, would spare Harris the gas chamber to allow arguments before a three-judge panel of the court on whether the convict should get an evidentiary hearing. That process normally takes several months. In Sacramento, Attorney General John Van de Kamp said he would ask the U.S. Supreme Court to lift the stay. ``It's potentially possible to get it lifted before Tuesday,'' said Chief Assistant Attorney General Richard Iglehart. ``We would argue that it's impossible for psychiatrists to go back and review what other psychiatrists did years ago,'' said Van de Kamp. ``(The decision) creates a brand-new legal right for accused murderers like Robert Harris _ the right to challenge the competency of psychiatric experts years after the fact. We believe this reading of the law is in error.'' Michael McCabe, one of Harris' lawyers, said, ``We're very happy that our client's life has been spared. We're pleased that Judge Noonan ... was not stampeded by the wave of public attention generated here.'' Harris, 37, would be the first person executed in California since 1967. He came within four days of execution once before, in 1982. ``This stuns me. How many times does this guy have to be turned down?'' said William Stalder, uncle of John Mayeski, one of Harris' victims. ``This just keeps the wound open. It keeps us waiting and waiting.'' Noonan, a conservative appointee of former President Ronald Reagan, said his order was ``a vindication of the state and federal interest that no one be put to death without due process of law.'' He said U.S. District Judge William Enright of San Diego, who turned down Harris' last-ditch appeal Wednesday, should have held a fact-finding hearing on new psychiatric evidence submitted by the defense. That evidence includes reports by psychologists who concluded that the psychiatric consultants who assisted Harris' trial lawyer acted incompetently by failing to test for brain damage or other serious mental disorders. Enright had rejected those conclusions without an evidentiary hearing. He said the dispute amounted to a mere disagreement among experts, wasn't the fault of the state and wouldn't have affected the jury's decision. It takes two votes on the three-member appellate panel to return the case to Enright for an evidentiary hearing. Noonan's order, if it stands, would block the execution and allow further written arguments and a hearing before the full panel to decide on an evidentiary hearing. Harris' current appeal, filed after the U.S. Supreme Court turned him down for the fourth time this January, is based largely on examinations that concluded he had organic brain damage and other mental disorders that affected his ability to control his impulses. Harris was convicted in 1979 of killing John Mayeski and Michael Baker, both 16, in San Diego in July 1978. He had abducted the boys at gunpoint from a drive-in restaurant as they sat in their parked cars. He forced them to drive to a remote area where he shot them so he could use their car in a bank robbery. In last week's appeal, Harris' lawyers challenged the evaluation of a state mental health expert who characterized the defendant as a sociopath incapable of remorse or rehabilitation. They also claimed that abuse in childhood and his mother's heavy drinking during her pregnancy with him exacerbated Harris' mental disorders.

DOC.HEAD: Magistrate Rules Former Credit Manager Incompetent to Stand Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE that defendant's wife also charged, grand jury investigating allegations of child abuse at parties given by credit union officials. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `The magistrate...
DOC.TEXT: The former manager of a failed credit union is mentally incompetent to stand trial on federal charges stemming from allegations he diverted money for his own use, a magistrate said Friday. Lawrence E. King Jr. understands the nature and consequences of the charges against him, but would be unable to help in his defense in what is expected to be a long trial, U.S. Magistrate Richard Kopf said. King, 45, a prominent businessman who sang the national anthem at the 1984 Republican National Convention, is charged with conspiracy, fraud and filing false tax returns in the failure of Franklin Community Federal Credit Union. Kopf said he would recommend that King be kept in federal custody and taken to the U.S. Medical Center for Federal Prisoners at Rochester, Minn., for treatment. The magistrate based his decision on a report prepared by Dr. Dorsey Dysart, chief psychiatrist at the U.S. Medical Center in Springfield, Mo., who has diagnosed King as suffering from ``probable delusional paranoid disorder _ grandiose type.'' A patient with such a disorder believes he has great powers to do things other people can't. Kopf said the psychiatrist noted that ``the intellectual system of grandiosity leads to disorganization of thought processes which gravely impairs the ability of Mr. King to withstand a lengthy trial.'' King faces 40 counts in from the failure of the Franklin Community Federal Union. Officials said $39 million was missing from the credit union, which had been established to help north Omaha's poor, when it was closed on Nov. 4, 1988. King's wife, Alice, also faces charges stemming from the credit union's failure. Soon after it failed, stories began surfacing of alleged sexual abuse at parties thrown by credit union officials. Authorities who first investigated didn't file any such charges, but the allegations were aired in a legislative investigation and the matter was taken up by a county grand jury. King hasn't been charged with any such offense. The magistrate said he would recommend to U.S. District Judge William G. Cambridge that King be committed to a hospital for treatment, generally consisting of anti-psychotic medication and psychotherapy. In addition, Kopf will ask that a report be given to the court within four months on whether King could face trial in the foreseeable future. Kopf also set a Monday deadline for any objections to the order. Alan Stoler, who represented King in the competency proceedings, said he does not expect to appeal the magistrate's findings. Two other court-appointed attorneys defending King against the criminal charges, Steven Achelpohl and Marilyn Abbott, said they will not appeal the ruling. U.S. Attorney Ron Lahners said the prosecution agrees that King is not competent to stand trial, and he expects Cambridge to sign the order soon. ``It's in the best interest of the defendant to get back into treatment,'' Lahners said. King, however, believes he is competent to stand trial, Kopf said.

DOC.HEAD: Andrus Vetoes Idaho Abortion Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 21-22, Bgn `The debate...,' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Right to Life spokesman unsure where to turn for test, background on other abortion laws. Picks up 23rd graf pvs, `Ms. Michelman...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BD1, BD2
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Cecil Andrus, confronted with thousands of pleas and a threatened potato boycott by opponents of Idaho's abortion bill, on Friday vetoed what would have been the most restrictive state abortion law. The veto ended the hopes of anti-abortion groups who wanted to use an Idaho law to challenge the U.S. Supreme Court's commitment to legalized abortion, embodied in its 1973 Roe v. Wade decision. Andrus, an anti-abortion governor who said he agonized over provisions of the legislation, explained his decision by saying the bill does not provide a woman and her family any flexibility in cases of rape and incest. ``The bill is drawn so narrowly that it would punitively and without compassion further harm an Idaho woman who may find herself in the horrible, unthinkable position of confronting a pregnancy that resulted from rape or incest,'' he said in a written statement read at a 5 p.m. news conference. The veto effectively killed the bill, since state legislators had conceded they did not have enough votes to gain the two-thirds majority needed to override the veto. In addition, the Legislature adjourned its session at 4:32 p.m. Friday, and can be called back only by the governor. But Republican Rep. Gary Montgomery, one of the bill's main architects, said anti-abortion lawmakers would refine the legislation and press it again in the 1991 session. The veto ``is the most significant demonstration to date of the power, depth and intensity of the pro-choice movement,'' said Kate Michelman, executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League in Washington, D.C. But she warned that the abortion-rights movement remains vulnerable. ``Despite our victories, it only takes one anti-choice legislature to pass one anti-choice, test-case bill that is signed into law by one anti-choice governor for the right to choose to be stripped from every American woman,'' Ms. Michelman said. ``It will only take one case to challenge Roe in the U.S. Supreme Court.'' John Willke, president of the National Right to Life Committee, said: ``Gov. Andrus today abandoned thousands of unborn children who will continue to die needlessly in Idaho. He has bowed to the hollow threats and pressure tactics of pro-abortion extremists who insist abortion be available as a method of birth control.'' Willke said the veto ``is not only unprincipled, but politically unwise. This veto will galvanize the pro-life majority in Idaho and nationwide.'' Andrus, who is running for an unprecedented fourth term, said he had consulted with legal scholars of both political parties who said there was not the ``remotest chance'' of the Supreme Court upholding such a law. He also said the financial burden for the state to defend the bill in court would have been excessive, with estimates running as high as $1.5 million. The bill called for outlawing abortion except in cases of non-statutory rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is under 18, severe fetal deformity or a threat to the life or health of the woman. The governor had said Thursday he was concerned that other women who have been raped, victimized by incest or faced a threat to their own lives might not be able to obtain a justified abortion. On Friday, Andrus said many of his own reservations about the bill, which would have banned more than 90 percent of the 1,500 abortions performed in Idaho each year, were known to lawmakers as they considered it. ``But all were shunted aside in the frenzy to pass a bill that, by the sponsors' own admission, was conceived outside of our state for the sole purpose of getting this issue back before the Supreme Court,'' he said. ``I believe, and I am confident the people of Idaho believe, that we can make our own judgments on this terribly important issue without outside pressure and outside influence or threats,'' Andrus said. The governor has repeatedly reaffirmed his opposition to abortion except in cases of rape, incest and to save the woman's life. Right to Life spokesman Douglas Johnson said his group was not sure where it would now turn to test Roe v. Wade, with many state legislatures declining to take on the issue despite a Supreme Court ruling last year that allowed them to impose some restrictions. A new law in the U.S. territory of Guam prohibits abortions except when a pregnancy endangers a woman's life, and is currently the target of a class-action lawsuit. In Pennsylvania, sections of a tough law restricting abortions have been stayed by a judge because of challenges from abortion-rights groups. The debate over the Idaho bill promised to spill over into coming gubernatorial campaign. Johnson said anti-abortion forces would support an anti-abortion opponent if the three-way Republican primary yields one. Two of the three challengers oppose abortion. Ms. Michelman, of the national abortion-rights group, said the organization would back Andrus in his campaign, despite his continued opposition to abortion. ``We will be there to support him, and the people of Idaho will support him because a majority of the people of Idaho disagreed with what the Legislature did,'' Ms. Michelman said. Before the veto was announced, Andrus remained closeted in his inner office as staff members handled a tide of phone messages, which were running 2-to-1 for a veto of the bill. ``There are only so many lines,'' receptionist Jean Jewell said. ``We couldn't handle any more.'' Since the bill banning abortion as a method of birth control cleared its first major legislative hurdle in the House three weeks ago, more than 21,000 telephone calls, letters and petitions came into the office. Since Wednesday morning, the staff had begun counting out-of-state calls separately; they were running about three times greater than those from Idahoans. Abortion-rights groups, led by the National Organization for Women, had called for a boycott of Idaho products if Andrus signed the measure. The focus of the boycott would have been Idaho's potato crop, a mainstay of the state's economy. In response, anti-abortion activists began mailing potatoes to NOW. In a separate development, a Nebraska legislator who favors abortion-rights began a filibuster Friday after anti-abortion forces tried to bring up a bill requiring a minor to notify her parents before getting an abortion. Anti-abortion groups had hoped the Idaho bill could give the U.S. Supreme Court the opportunity to reverse Roe vs. Wade, its 1973 decision legalizing abortion. Since the night before final legislative approval last week, abortion-rights forces have staged candlelight vigils on the Capitol steps urging a veto.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Decision May Help Fire Plaintiffs
With AM-Social Club Fire
DOC.TEXT: A state appeals court issued a decision three days before a Bronx social club fire that probably strengthens the victims' families' chances of successfully suing the owner or landlord of the fire site. One victim's mother has already sued the owners, lessees and proprietors of the club for $510 million, her lawyer said Thursday. Many other relatives of the 87 people who died already have contacted lawyers. But their success seems to depend on their ability to collect from the only potential defendants with substantial assets or insurance _ the building's owner, Alex DiLorenzo, and its landlords, Jay Weiss and Morris Jaffe. The families' case appears to have been buttressed by a March 22 ruling by a state appeals court. In a 3-2 decision, the panel ruled that an owner of real estate who allows it to be used for an unlawful purpose can be liable for damages caused by the illegal activity to innocent people who are not tenants. The case involved 9-year-old Miguel Muniz, who was blinded by stray gunfire from a Harlem building that had been a center of drug dealing. The appellate panel reversed a judge who had ruled that the landlord could not be held liable for damages. Aaron Broder, the lawyer who represented the boy and is advising plaintiffs' lawyers in the social club case, said courts have tended to rule that unless harm to an innocent third party flowed from a building defect over which a landlord had direct control, the landlord could not be held liable. The social club was the scene of arrests for illegal alcohol sales and was repeatedly cited for building and safety code violations, including the lack of fire alarms, sprinklers and emergency exits. The city's Buildings Department finally ordered it closed. A copy of the order was tacked to the club's front door, and at least one copy was supposed to have been sent to Dilorenzo or Weiss and Jaffe. The chain of control begins with DiLorenzo, who owns the building and gave a 30-year lease to Weiss and Jaffe. They, in turn, leased the premises to Elias Colon, who operated the social club.
