Since Colon died in the fire _ and is not thought to have had substantial assets or insurance _ plaintiffs' attorneys will focus on the owner and the landlord, arguing that they were aware, or should have been aware, of the illegal uses of the premises and should have done something. The Muniz case is particularly relevant because, as in the case of the social club, the landlord already had gone to court seeking the tenant's eviction for non-payment of rent, not for breaking any law or regulation. ``The court (in Muniz) held that if a landlord has sought to evict a tenant for non-payment and does not choose to seek eviction for other reasons, it's evidence of his potential negligence,'' Broder said. ``The landlord demonstrated he was capable of using the courts, but only when it was profitable to him.'' But a real estate lawyer, Flora Schnall, said the fact Weiss and Jaffe were trying to evict Colon was more important than why. Non-payment of rent, she said, ``is the easiest thing to evict someone for. It's very difficult to evict someone for illegal uses.''

House Democrats are tempting a presidential veto by rejecting the White House version of a child-care bill in favor of their own more costly and ambitious plan. The House approved the measure, estimated to cost at least $27 billion over its first five years, just hours after a spokesman for President Bush issued a fresh veto threat Thursday. ``Rather than waving his veto pen, our president should match his warm words with good deeds and agree to sign our child-care bill,'' House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said after the vote. The bill still must go to a House-Senate conference to resolve differences with the Senate. But Democrats hoped the ultimate version would mirror the House bill and that election-year pressures would make Bush back down from his threat.

The Senate appears on track to approving a sweeping air pollution control bill next week after narrowly rejecting $500 million in aid to coal miners who could lose their jobs because of tougher environmental standards. By a 50-49 vote Thursday, senators defeated a proposal that Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., called only a matter of ``fairness ... and justice'' because thousands of miners will be thrown out of work. The majority heeded warnings from Senate leaders that the amendment would prompt a presidential veto of the overall bill. The three-year, $500 million assistance program was considered to be the last major obstacle to Senate passage of the clean air bill. A vote on the legislation is scheduled for next Tuesday. A House version is in committee.

Life expectancy in the United States has never been higher, but disparities remain between whites and blacks, federal researchers say. Overall U.S. life expectancy rose to 75 years, according to 1987 data, the Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. That was up 0.2 years _ about 73 days _ from 1986, said Ken Kochanek, a statistician with the CDC's National Center for Health Statistics in Hyattsville, Md. The life-expectancy concept means that someone born in 1987 would live, on the average, 75 years. Women, on average, outlive men by 6.9 years.

The Food and Drug Administration is hoping for a consensus among health experts and food companies on how to make sure consumers striving for health and fitness aren't fooled by product labels and advertising. Executives from some of the country's largest food corporations met Thursday with federal officials at a conference prompted by FDA proposals to tighten regulation of food health claims. ``We're trying to define boundaries so consumers can believe what's on that label,'' said Fred Shank, the agency's director for food safety and applied nutrition. At the heart of the debate: a conflict over what diet and health messages should be allowed on food packaging and who should set the standards.

The president of a U.S. defense contractor says he cooperated with a sting that averted shipment of 40 nuclear detonators to Iraq because he feared nuclear weapons in the hands of ``irresponsible'' countries. The sting came as part of an 18-month investigation by U.S. and British customs agents that culminated in a federal indictment against five people and two British companies. Jerold Kowalsky, an engineer and president of CSI Technologies Inc., said he alerted U.S. agents in 1988 to inquiries from alleged representatives of Iraq into his company, which makes electronic triggers to military specifications. He said Thursday that the possibility of the devices falling into the hands of the Iraqi government disturbed him.

Lawmakers have approved a new way to finance and run Kentucky's public schools, abolishing a system the state Supreme Court said shortchanged poor districts and dragged down test scores. The House voted 58-42 Thursday to approve the overhaul _ which includes a $1.26 billion tax increase and decentralization of control over day-to-day operation of the 570,000-student system _ and sent it to Gov. Wallace Wilkinson. The Senate passed the measure 30-8 on Wednesday. The governor has hailed the plan as ``history in the making.'' ``It's the first time that any state has scrapped its existing system and started over again,'' said Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States, a federally supported research organization.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Trying to Make Japan a Space Leader
DOC.TEXT: At a small center with a single launch pad in the hills of Uchinoura, scientists are trying to make Japan a leader in space. Private Japanese companies count on them to succeed, and have elaborate plans ranging from mines on the moon to a doughnut-shaped orbiting hotel that would make its own gravity. The government is known for targeting new technologies with well-financed research programs, but Uchinoura's budget is small. Scientists stretch it by doing the work of technicians, even checking the rockets. Staff members shiver during winter liftoffs because building heaters are shut down so the limited electrical supply can power the launch equipment. Despite years of trailing the United States and Soviet Union in both glamor and spending, the Japanese space industry has built a respected technical foundation and is aiming toward its own manned space program. Scientists at Uchinoura's Institute of Space and Astronautical Science put a satellite into lunar orbit March 19, using a small M3S-2 rocket. That made Japan only the third nation to probe the moon. Japan's other government-financed space organization, the National Space Development Agency, test-fired a sophisticated engine March 7 for the H-2 rocket, which will compete with U.S., Soviet and European rockets in payload capacity. So far, Japanese aerospace companies usually have been subcontractors for overseas firms or have manufactured products under foreign licenses. ``In the past, other nations took the initiative in space and Japan participated passively, but in the future Japan will take the lead more often,'' said Tomifumi Godai, director of the Space Development Agency. As with many earlier industrial successes, Japan has avoided expensive space failures by licensing proven technology and gradually improving on it. ``It's the same old story,'' says Keisuke Kasagi, a senior analyst in Tokyo for W.I. Carr securities. ``Japan developed everything from foreign technology, and then went on to develop its own domestic technology.'' The workhorse H-1 rocket uses 25-year-old U.S. Delta technology developed by McDonnell Douglas, with Japanese improvements that include a new second-stage engine. McDonnell Douglas recently asked Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, chief contractor on the H-1, to supply it with the new engines for U.S. rockets, according to Japanese space officials. ``When I attend international meetings these days, I'm often asked by other countries whether we will sell them technology,'' Godai told reporters. An important gauge of that technology will be whether Japan can complete development of the H-2 rocket independently. The engine caught fire in two tests last year, delaying the first flight until at least March 1993. Having its own rockets would free Japan from a 1969 agreement under which the United States can veto launching of satellites for third countries. Support for more independence may grow following discord over joint development plans with the United States for the FSX fighter plane, discovery of design problems in a U.S.-led international space station project, and the explosion Feb. 22 of a European Ariane rocket carrying two Japanese communications satellites worth about $600 million. Both satellites on the Ariane were made in the United States. American trade officials have threatened penalty tariffs on Japanese products unless Japan agrees to buy more U.S. satellites instead of supporting development of the domestic satellite industry. ``It's hard to believe this great nation, which produces so many goods so well, has to protect an infant industry'' like satellites, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher said on a recent visit to Japan. Some analysts question whether Japan will become competitive in commercial launches. Its two small space centers, at Uchinoura and nearby Tanegashima, are far from the equator. That increases launching costs for geostationary satellites, which must be placed in orbits over the equator. ``Already there are well-established commercially viable launch programs in the United States, Europe, the Soviet Union and China,'' said Stephen Marvin, an analyst for Jardine Fleming Securities. ``Japan won't have the economies of scale to make it cost-effective.'' Whatever the analysts say, Japanese space space plans are ambitious. Over the next 10 years, the government program calls for creating a small space shuttle, probes of the moon and Venus to prepare for manned missions and building a $2 billion module for the space station. Most experiments in the module will involve processing materials in space, as will many of the 34 experiments to be conducted by a Japanese astronaut next year on the U.S. space shuttle Atlantis. A group of 20 companies led by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries plans to build a moon base by 2010 where humans can live for a few weeks. By 2030, the group hopes to station more than 100 people there on a long-term basis to begin extracting helium-3 as a source of power for nuclear fusion reactors, which it said would mean ``no energy shortage on Earth ever.'' Shimizu Corp. plans a doughnut-shaped space hotel with 64 rooms that would orbit Earth at an altitude of about 280 miles. It would rotate three times a minute to create artificial gravity in the guest rooms, and weightless ``space games'' could be played in the center of the ring. Japan is alloting $1.02 billion for space this year, less than one-tenth the $12.3 billion budgeted for the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Analysts in the Tokyo office of Baring Securities said spending probably would grow by 17 percent to 20 percent a year to an annual $6.9 billion by the end of the decade.

DOC.HEAD: Creeping Racism In Japan-Bashing Becoming Less Subtle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on vacation.
DOC.TEXT: You can feel it in Lee Iacocca's vow to peel off their Teflon kimonos. It's there in the hearty applause for Johnny Carson's monologues about their voracious appetite for American real estate and Jay Leno'scracks about their proposed takeover of 7-Eleven. Those are only among the most visible signs. There's nothing new about Japan-bashing, which has been around since well before Pearl Harbor. But racially charged hostility toward the once-subdued Japanese and their postwar economic might seems less subtle and more fear-laden now. Some would argue it's becoming bold and belligerent. Ironically, the anti-Japanese jibes have been accompanied and even overshadowed by a growing sophistication and respect for Japan in many parts of the country. American companies often strive to copy Japanese models for success. Japanese companies are building factories and opening offices in the United States, contributing to charities and striving to be responsible corporate citizens. Japanese language study has grown enormously popular. From cinema to sports to sushi bars, Japanese culture is integrating into the American mainstream and embellishing its diversity. One of Japan's star athletes, ice skater Midori Ito, is a darling of the American sports press. On Monday night, an honorary Oscar was awarded to Japan's Akira Kurosawa, considered one of the greatest living film directors. At the same time, however, the tone and nature of Japan-bashing has changed, tapping into some deeply ingrained prejudices held by an older generation of Americans who never really thought of the Japanese as friends. This change is not an isolated event. It comes against a background of seemingly intractable disputes between the United States and Japan over a number of crucial economic issues that have redefined our postwar relationship. The United States long has wanted Japan to open its market to foreign goods and help alleviate a growing trade deficit Washington claims is undermining the productivity and competitiveness of domestic industries. But Japan is becoming less patient with this argument. It wants Americans to stop spending beyond their means and clean up social malignancies that range from illiteracy to drug abuse. This response seems only to have further inflamed the ire of the Japan-bashers. True, you don't often hear the wartime epithet ``Jap,'' at least in public. But you do read and hear cultural slights against the Japanese, which if applied to some other ethnic group would be construed as racial slurs. Perhaps the most obvious example is an advertising campaign by Iacocca, the Chrysler Corp. boss who is seeking to stimulate the car company's sales with a tribal us-vs.-them pitch that paints the Japanese as devious, crafty copycats. ``A lot of Americans think if it's made in Japan, it's terrific, if it's made in America, it's lousy,'' he rails on television and print ads. ``It's time to peel off the Teflon kimono.'' Iacocca _ whose company, by the way, imports and sells many Japanese cars under its own nameplates _ has denied that his remarks are anti-Japanese, much less racially inspired. On the contrary, Iacocca claims he's one of Japan's greatest fans. But the timing of his publicity drive and the almost bellicose nature of his language suggests he's pandering to prejudices about Japan as though they were a threat to apple pie America. Other prominent Americans, from congressmen to governors to talk-show hosts, have engaged in the same sort of rhetoric, spicing it up with gratuitous and uncomplimentary references to the Japanese way of life. Even the press has chimed in. When a Japanese company agreed earlier this month to acquire debt-laden Southland Corp.'s 7-Eleven stores, for example, some news reports focused more on who the buyer was than why the seller was desperate for a financial rescue and sought a Japanese savior. One newspaper account began with the line, ``Sushi Slurpees, anyone?''

DOC.HEAD: Inspiration From TV Music
LaserPhoto NY312 of March 30
DOC.TEXT: Last winter, Ryuichi Sakamoto turned on the TV in his Los Angeles hotel room and heard some familiar music. Fascinating, he thought _ the orchestration, the instrumentation, how the French horns used high octave violin phrases. It was the theme from ``Bonanza.'' ``I'm always looking for something which can inspire me,'' said Sakamoto, who composed the Academy Award-winning soundtrack to the ``The Last Emperor'' and has released a new album, ``Beauty.'' ``When I listen to any music, I automatically see musical notes and instruments. In films, just one tone, a sound could mean a lot,'' he said. ``Bonanza'' inspired Sakamoto to purchase a compilation of themes from westerns, which played softly in the background during a recent interview at a Manhattan hotel. He came to New York well prepared for any unexpected musical adventure. On the dresser by his bed sat a compact disc player, a digital audio tape machine and tapes of everything from reggae to jazz. Nicknamed ``Professor'' in college, Sakamoto is like a sonic Henry Higgins, able to tell the difference between Hong Kong and Moscow by the pitch of car horns. Born in Tokyo in 1952, he was just 10 when he began studying music composition at the University of Art of Tokyo. But Sakamoto is a proudly self-trained listener, recalling his daily commutes to high school. ``I paid attention to every noise on the train and counted every different noise. Spins, boxes crashing, people talking, cable wires,'' said Sakamto, who identified each sound with an uncanny imitation. ``Echoes of cities are different. The first time I went to London, I was kind of surprised. I flew from Tokyo to London and the echoes the cities had were very different,'' said the composer, whose debut album, ``Thousand Knives,'' was released in 1978. ``In London, the buildings were made out of stones. The steps sounded very different to me, very hypnotic.'' Sakamoto admits, however, that keeping his ears pinned to grindstone left him tone-deaf to people. Soft-spoken and shy, he simply preferred listening to talking, sounds over words. The turning point, he said, came in 1987 when he worked with director Bernardo Bertolucci on ``The Last Emperor.'' ``It was quite tricky, because my music's kind of depressed and flat on the surface. Bertolucci forced me to write more and more emotional music. He kept saying, `More emotional.' It was very difficult,'' Sakamoto said. ``Before `The Last Emperor,' I was kind of afraid to let people into my music. I could hardly communicate with people. But after the experience of `The Last Emperor,' I easily could communicate with people. I was surprised. So Sakamoto calls ``Beauty'' his most idealistic record, a former loner's attempt to embrace the world to the beat of world music, the composer's own mixture of dance rhythms and Japanese folk. ``Each day, I would say, `I need an African percussion player. I need an African guitarist. I need a Korean guitar player. I need a Chinese musician.' I had so many different nusicians from all over the world, and communication was so important for recording with them. Maybe three years ago I couldn't do that.'' Sakamoto has also worked with rock 'n' rollers. He appeared in the 1983 film, ``Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence,'' which starred David Bowie, and two years later collaborated with Thomas Dolby on the album ``Field Work.'' On ``Beauty,'' he applies his personal touch to the Rolling Stones' ``We Love You.'' The original was released in 1967, right after Mick Jagger and Keith Richards had been jailed briefly on drug charges. With John Lennon and Paul McCartney singing backup, the song was a cynical take on the Summer of Love, complete with the sound of cell doors slamming. But ``We Love You'' was no joke to Sakamoto, who in 1967 was politically active and listening to the experimental music of John Cage. The composer got rid of the studio effects and turned the song into a friendly handshake _ offered, of course, via state-of-the-art technology. ``I wanted to have a song which was for people who I have never met,'' he said. ``I wanted to introduce myself to people who were not just music fans, but all young people. Like ordinary people in the United States, people in Romania. I want them to listen to my music.''

DOC.HEAD: Words and Music
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A lyric sheet is not included with Galaxie 500's album, ``On Fire.'' Bandleader Dean Wareham wants it that way. ``I don't like writing down lyrics that much,'' said the guitarist-singer-songwriter, a native of New Zealand. ``On paper, I think, lyrics are something completely different. All they are are words that go along with the music.'' So listen carefully if you want to sing along, though Wareham doesn't think it's worth the trouble. He's not telling stories or sending messages. Words about weather, cars and the environment are only words, he says, nothing, literally, worth writing about. ``It's not like folk music, it just helps us set the mood. `Blue Thunder' is about my car, not about the weather. `Snowstorm' is about the weather but just as much about TV. People say I'm into nature because of `Decomposing Trees' and `Leave the Planet,' and that's not true: too many bugs.'' The real story can be heard from Wareham's own brand of white noise: a guitar that churns out chords as easy as A-B-C and a wobbly tenor that breaks occasionally into an even wobblier falsetto. ``Start simple and build'' is the motto. These songs, quiet but never peaceful, usually open with Wareham strumming guitar and gradually intensify, threatening to explode at any time. ``I think we do have a distinctive sound. That's a criticism: Everything sounds the same. It just means you have a sound you can call your own. You can hear the influences. ``We had some German kids coming to us in Frankfurt and they said, `How did you get this sound?' And then after we played they said, `We couldn't believe how easy it was.' It was distortion and sustained compression.'' The members of Galaxie 500 met in high school in New York, but only started playing together 2{ years ago. Bassist Naomi Yang and drummer Damon Krukowski were in Boston and Wareham was still in New York when he quit his old band. ``I quit after the first time on stage when I saw what they were like. He was a cross between Freddie Mercury and David Lee Roth. He was dancing all over the stage and the stuff he was doing was really corny and annoying. I had loaned somebody in the band $300 and when he paid me back, I quit.'' He needed that money. Few people, including Galaxie 500, own a copy of the group's first album. Aurora Records released it, but Aurora Records consisted of one man operating from his home in Boston. ``He did our single and he did our LP and he did another single, Wareham said. ``What's frustrating for us at this point is when the first album gets reviewed in the Village Voice and you couldn't get it in New York.'' Though their first record was called ``Today,'' the band proudly takes its name and music from the past. Galaxie 500 is a 1960s car that a friend of Wareham's owned, and the sound is vintage 1967: part psychedelic Beatles, part Velvet Underground. ``On Fire'' was distributed by Rough Trade records and features nine originals plus a cover of ``Isn't It a Pity'' off George Harrison's ``All Things Must Pass'' album. Harrison and Bob Dylan wrote it, and Eric Clapton played lead guitar, but Wareham was unimpressed, applying the faithful ``start simple and build'' treatment. ``My roommate had the record,'' Wareham said. ``I'm not really a fan of Eric Clapton, who's all over that record. It was a longshot in the studio. We said, `Let's just give this a try.''' Galaxie 500 is still a cult band, even for Galaxie 500. Wareham puts in time as a temp around Manhattan, Yang has been studying architecture and Krukowski teaches. For now, Wareham says, their only goal is to sell enough records to make music a full-time job. ``Yeah, we'd like to do that, but I don't think any of us see doing it in 10 years. We just sort of stumbled into it. We just played for fun and all of a sudden sounded a little better than it did before. ``I think our audience really has just got a sense of us. Things have changed a lot. It used to that 50 people came to see us in Boston and now we're selling out shows. It's no longer just critics and hipsters.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PM Thurs April 5

DOC.HEAD: New Paper Targets Capital Insiders
DOC.TEXT: Not hearing enough about the federal government? Roger Kranz hopes so and he's prepared to fill the gap with gossip, news and opinion pieces about the capital's major industry. Kranz is launching the Washington Reporter, a new daily newspaper, to remedy what he sees as a dearth of details about government and politics. It will be distributed free to 30,000 lawyers, lobbyists, journalists, consultants, members of Congress and senior government officials. ``They must read many, many publications to really find out what's going on in Washington,'' said Kranz, who quit his job as group vice president of the National Journal to publish the new paper. He plans to deliver the inside skinny, starting Oct. 1, in one 16-page package easily digested after his readers finish with The Washington Post, The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal or whatever else they read. Kranz said the Washington Reporter will have more details than those papers on what happens day-to-day inside the Beltway, and will be more timely than weekly magazines that might carry similar stories or think pieces. ``I won't have to wait a week to tell you what you already know,'' he said. ``It's a cliche to say information is power, but in Washington, D.C., having information before anybody else makes you powerful.'' Are the town's movers and shakers ready to add yet another publication to their daily diet? ``It's too much,'' says Jim Glassman, editor of Roll Call, a twice-weekly newspaper about Congress. ``People are overwhelmed with paper. And this, if it ever gets published, is going to overwhelm them even more. ... We brought up the idea (of going daily) with our readers, and were told, `God, no, I've got enough stuff on my desk.''' On the other hand, there can never be enough news for some people. ``I feel like I'm getting too much, but at the same time I don't mind getting more,'' says Michael Kinsley, a syndicated columnist and senior editor of The New Republic. There is some skepticism not only about the need for the paper but also about whether Kranz can raise the $12.45 million he says he needs for the paper's first year. ``I am continuing to negotiate for full financing. I am on schedule to be publishing in October,'' Kranz said. He refused to name investors or say how much money is committed so far. A prototype of the new paper shows a good grasp of what appeals to status-conscious Washingtonians, including a politics page, several gossip columns and a Page 2 ``People'' index of everyone mentioned in the entire paper. ``I guarantee you it will be the best-read section of the newspaper. ... It's a very egotistical town,'' Kranz said of the index. In the prototype it includes such inside-the-Beltway luminaries as GOP consultant Roger Ailes and hairdresser Robin Weir as well as the usual lawmakers, media types and public officials. The front page of the prototype features articles about the Federal Election Commission, the Department of Housing and Urban Development, a sensitive high-tech telephone deal with the Soviet Union, the House since Jim Wright's departure, a sex survey and President Bush's capital gains tax cut proposal. The back pages contain people, media and gossip columns, stories about the television networks, a profile of a Senate staff aide, an excerpt from former CBS reporter Fred Graham's book and an article on where the powerful like to lunch. Five writers offer their views on the peace dividend in a two-page commentary section. Don Graham, publisher of the Post, said the success of newsletters covering narrow slices of federal activity bodes reasonably well for the Washington Reporter. ``There are many, many daily newspapers covering aspects of the work of the federal government, but if you look at evidence of the last few years, there seems to be room for more,'' Graham said. ``There are continually many new publications starting up, some of which are quite successful.'' One example of that trend is Roll Call. According to Glassman, the chatty, tabloid-size paper was an eight-page weekly with a circulation of 4,000 when he and a partner bought it four years ago. Now, he said, it comes out twice a week with 30 pages in each issue and has a circulation of more than 17,000. ``We certainly have shown that advertisers are interested in reaching the public policy market and there certainly are readers there,'' he said. But he added a word of advice to Kranz: ``It's got to be real, real good.''
DOC.NOTE: End Advance for Monday PMs April 2

DOC.HEAD: Ted Koppel Studies Romanian Revolution
DOC.TEXT: We tend to think of the lowly home video camera as a goof-dispenser for ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' But it increasingly is used to record serious things, too, such as history. That's graphically illustrated tonight in Ted Koppel's ABC News special, ``Death of a Dictator,'' about the bloody December revolt in Romania that led to the Christmas Day executions of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife, Elena. While ambiguous in spots, it's first-rate in the way it chronicles the revolution by weaving together often-chilling footage shot by Western TV crews and by unidentified Romanians armed only with home video cameras. The latter footage is grainy, often shot at odd angles. But it's riveting stuff, even an early, almost farcical headquarters scene in which the Romanian army's chief of staff is frustrated by language problems when the battle still is in doubt. The same footage shows the head of the hated Securitate secret police, who, incredibly, is allowed to join the new regime-in-progress (its officials belatedly suspect him of helping their foes and arrest him). The headquarters farce constrasts sharply with shots of deadly combat at the Bucharest airport between army troops and the secret police, where there are visible sparks as bullets strike concrete and metal. Some interviews are remarkable, particuarly one with an army major, Mihai Lupoi, an eyewitness to the execution of the Ceausescus shortly after a quick military trial that was only a formality. The couple, captured on Dec. 22 while trying to flee their country, were found guilty of genocide and other grave crimes. ``We took them out, took them to the wall, and asked to the people, `Who wants to shoot?''' says Lupoi, who occasionally gives a short, eerie chuckle as he speaks in English. ``Everybody wanted (to shoot). ``So they selected three people. And they didn't wait for the command to shoot ... three guns, 90 bullets. I don't know if all of them were in the body. ... Nobody counted.'' Koppel reports that while still alive, Ceausescu wore a tiny radio transmitter he hoped would aid his escape after capture. But the show leaves unanswered some questions about his attempted getaway. One is why the helicopter pilot who flew the Ceausescus from Bucharest helped in their capture by setting down in a field not far from the city. Details of the capture also were missing from a review copy of the program, although an ABC spokeswoman said that will be added tonight. Despite its title, ``Death of a Dictator'' actually is a two-part report. The first is a step-by-step account of the Romanian revolt that was sparked by reports of a December massacre in the border town of Timisoara. The second examines those reports and how many people actually died in Romania duuring the revolt, the dictator's long stay in power and Washington's apparent willingness to ignore his tyranny, and whether the revolution really has changed anything in Romania, whether one dictatorship eventually will be replaced with another. The show's broad scope seems too much for an hour, despite the skill of Koppel and his staff. It would have been better to make the report a 90-minute special or even two separate programs. But it's worth watching, if only for its examples of television as a force in modern history _ including the dramatic moment Ceausescu starts to speak to what he thinks is the usual tame crowd. You won't forget the startled look on his stern face when he's greeted with unexpected jeers and whistling. Although perhaps forgetting TV's coverage of last year's bloody, unsuccessful uprising in Beijing, Romanian TV anchorman Nicolae Melinescu is right in speaking of television's impact on his country last December. Interviewed in English for ABC's special, his grammar is tangled but his meaning is clear when he says: ``I think it was the first time when one can watch on TV a revolution _ live.'' __ Elsewhere in television ... ART FOR THE SAKE OF CABLE: King World Productions, which syndicates such uplifting fare as ``Wheel of Fortune,'' has teamed with cable TV's Arts & Entertainment Network on a new Friday night series on the various arts, including theater, dance, literature and even television. To premiere on May 4, the new venture is called ``Arts & Entertainment Revue.'' Av Westin, for many years an ABC News executive, is in charge of the show. If the series needs some traveling music, no problem. The series' senior producer, Susan Lester, another ABC News graduate, is a jazz pianist.

DOC.HEAD: Undersea Tunnel Has Two Safety Stations
DOC.TEXT: Tappi station's waiting room is huge, but no one starts a trip there. It provides a way out if something goes wrong under the Tsugaru Straits, in the world's longest tunnel. Five trains stop at Tappi each day and let hundreds of people off for a look, by guided tour, at conditions 450 feet beneath the surface. The passengers then board the next train to finish the journey between Hokkaido, Japan's northernmost main island, and the central island of Honshu. The purpose of Tappi and Yoshioka, a similar station near the other end of the Seikan Tunnel, is to provide shelter or an exit in case of earthquakes or other trouble. At 50 mph, a train takes 40 minutes to complete the trip through the tunnel, an $8.5 billion tube 34 miles long that runs under the Tsugaru Straits for nearly 15 miles. ``Down that way, you can walk to the other side,'' a guide said, pointing down a side tunnel. ``It would take about six hours.'' Before the Seikan opened in March 1988, rail passengers tranferred to a ferry for a four-hour voyage across the straits between Aomori, on Honshu, and Hakodate, on Hokkaido. Sometimes the service was halted by storms. A typhoon sank a ferry in 1954, killing more than 1,100 people, and support for a tunnel grew. Guides from Japan Railways show visitors to Tappi and Yoshioka some of the ways of coping with emergencies. Each station is under land. The tunnel does not emerge from the ground for 8{ miles beyond Tappi, and 10{ past Yoshioka, but stranded passengers can take a cable car or stairway to the surface. It is 1,316 steps to the top from Tappi, about a 20-minute climb. Both stations are in the service tunnels, which are big enough for a truck to drive through and run along both sides of the 36-foot-wide main railway tube. Air pressure in the service tunnels is higher than in the main tunnel so smoke from a fire cannot enter them. The main tunnel has sprinkler and drainage systems. Tappi and Yoshioka have rest rooms, first aid stations and benches for hundreds of people. Sensors and television cameras monitor conditions inside the tunnel. A television monitor in Tappi, using remote-controlled cameras, gives a sweeping view of conditions on the surface similar to that of a submarine periscope. When there is no emergency, passengers can stop at Tappi to walk in the service tunnels, buy soft drinks from a machine or purchase a small souvenir tunnel ``passport'' whose price of 1,000 yen ($6.70) includes a card good for that value in travel on Japan Railways. At its center, the tunnel is 785 feet below the water's surface and 330 feet under the seabed. To keep water from seeping in under high pressure, the earth around the tunnel has been reinforced for a distance of up to 65 feet. Excavation began in 1971, with the cost estimated at about one-third the final total. The tunnel required 13.8 million man-days of work and took the lives of 34 workers. Four serious cases of flooding delayed construction. Techniques developed in the project are expected to help in construction of the 31-mile tunnel under the English Channel that will link England and France. Seikan completes the ground linkage of Japan's four main islands. The 2.3-mile Kanmon Tunnel betwen Honshu and the southern island of Kyushu was completed in 1942, and in April 1988 the 7.7-mile Seto Ohashi Bridge opened between Honshu and Shikoku, east of Kyushu.

DOC.HEAD: East Has Its First Private Channel, in a Makeshift Studio
DOC.TEXT: Eight entreprenuers with a handmade transmitter, satellite dish and broom-closet studio have broken the government monopoly on television broadcasts in what used to be the Soviet bloc. Marek Mlynarczyk smiled and said: ``You might say we've made a little mess.'' He is general manager of ECHO-TV, the first private commercial television station in Eastern Europe. ECHO has broadcast six hours a night since Feb. 6, mostly music videos and movies pirated, more or less, from satellite transmissions. ``Nobody believed we would do it,'' said Mlynarczyk, who thinks that's the only reason he and his seven co-owners got permission from the authorities. ``They decided, `Oh, if you want permission, just take it. We don't believe you will do something with it','' he said. ``The result is that, now, no other permissions are being given.'' In decades of Communist control, Poland's two government-run television channels offered a dull diet of propaganda presented as news, cheap-to-make interview programs, and cheap-to-buy American reruns and Brazilian soap operas. Occasionally, a Polish film spiced up the schedule. Poles are hooked on the tube nonetheless, and Mlynarczyk said the response to ECHO-TV was ``something of a shock at first.'' There is no ratings system in Poland, but estimates put the number of viewers at 200,000 for the station, which can be picked up within about 18 miles of Wroclaw, an industrial city 200 miles southwest of Warsaw. Some viewers need a special antenna. Demand was so great that stores sold out and the ECHO-TV office was mobbed when an advertising misprint implied the antennas were being sold there. Most people can receive ECHO without special equipment or set adjustments. The station goes on the air at 6 p.m. from two tiny rooms atop a student dormitory where, says one of the 16 staff technicians, ``we could use a window.'' Virtually all the equipment fits on a table in one corner: three televisions, two video cassette recorders, a personal computer and a special effects mixer. Another corner three steps away serves as the set for the five-minute news program. The foot-square logo backdrop is cut from paper. Andrzej Zygmunt, the technical manager, cobbled together a transmitter slightly bigger than a bread box. A cable strung through an air vent takes the signal to the roof. The eight shareholders invested the equivalent of about $50,000 in what they call ``semi-professional'' equipment to start the station and an affiliated video company. So far, they have more orders for one-minute, computer-generated advertising messages than they can accommodate. The rate is $5 per commercial. ``We're not dreaming of big money,'' Mlynarczyk said. ``We just want to show we can maintain this. ``This is the beginning. We are making something new.'' There are many plans afoot for original programming, but for now most of the programs come from MTV, the U.S. music video channel, and other stations carried by satellite. Mlynarczyk said he had a ``verbal agreement'' with the satellite distributor, but was uncomfortable with the informal arrangement. ``We're the first,'' he said. ``We have to be careful or someone could come here and close us down.'' He said ECHO's owners want to offer television that is ``more fun.'' Mlynarczyk described Polish television as ``too serious .. . a lot of guys sitting in arm chairs telling something, blah, blah, blah.'' Marek Hamera, the program coordinator, said: ``It should be closer to life ... everything state-owned TV doesn't do.'' After the Solidarity-led government assumed power last fall, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki was under intense public pressure to reform state television, which one member of Parliament called ``the medium that lied the most.'' The evening news program was changed and some announcers most closely identified with the former Communist regime were replaced. There was criticism when the new director of the state broadcasting committee heeded Mazowiecki's recommendation against a wholesale purge. One-third of the directors have been replaced and a law on control of the airwaves is being drafted. ECHO-TV's owners said they applied for the station two weeks after the new head of the state committee was appointed. ``When we got the permission, we worked nonstop to put the station on the air because we were afraid someone would take it away,'' Zygmunt said. A permit for a second station in Lublin, southeast of Warsaw, is on hold. Efforts to break the government monopoly on non-satellite television also are under way elsewhere in Eastern Europe, especially in Hungary. MTI, the Hungarian news agency, reported that 80 applications for private broadcast stations had been filed, but the Hungarian government has said there should be only three televison channels. The state already controls two.

DOC.HEAD: With BC-EARTH-Adirondacks
DOC.TEXT: Here are some statistics on the Adirondack Park: _At about 6 million acres, the Adirondack Park is the largest public park in the lower 48 states. It is 2{ times the size of Yellowstone National Park. About 2.3 million acres are a forest preserve protected under the state constitution as ``forever wild.'' About 2 million acres are logged. New York state owns about 37 percent of the park. _Lake Placid, in the heart of the park, was the site of the Winter Olympics in 1932 and 1980. _The park is home to 130,000 year-round residents. There are 110,000 seasonal residents. _Nine million people visit the park each year. _The park has 2,000 miles of hiking trails and more than 100 peaks at least 3,000 feet high. It encompasses more than 6,000 miles of streams and 2,853 lakes and ponds; more than 260 of its lakes are considered ``dead'' because of acid rain. _Two-hundred-eighteen species of birds have been observed in the park, along with 55 kinds of mammals, 35 kinds of reptiles and 86 varieties of fish. _The lynx, peregrine falcon and bald eagle have been reintroduced to the Adirondack Park, and officials may attempt to bring back the moose. The park is the only area in the eastern United States being considered for reintroduction of the wolf and cougar.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, April 1

DOC.TEXT: Unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines, exasperated at the carrier's mounting losses and its new plan to reduce debt payments, are considering seeking the liquidation of the airline, sources said. A source close to the creditors' committee said Thursday there is a ``50-50 chance'' the group will request the bankruptcy court to appoint a special trustee to oversee a liquidation of Eastern. Such a move would be a radical shift by the creditors. They have been supportive of Eastern since it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization on March 9, 1989, five days after it was struck by Machinists, pilots and flight attendants.

Lockheed Corp. Chairman Daniel Tellep promised major concessions to big shareholders but predicted victory in his battle with Texas investor Harold Simmons over control of the company. ``I'm expecting a clear majority in every category of shareholder, except of course, Mr. Simmons,'' Tellep said at a news conference Thursday after the aerospace company's annual meeting. Simmons, who owns 19 percent of Lockheed, and his chief strategist, J. Landis Martin, said they believed the contest was too close to call, although Martin later seemed to acknowledge they had lost.

Norton Co.'s board of directors rejected a $1.6 billion buyout offer from the British conglomerate BTR PLC and said it might buy back some of its stock to thwart a takeover. But analysts said Thursday that Norton apparently was trying to raise the BTR bid, and they expected the company eventually would accept a deal.

Hanson PLC said it would take full control of the United States' biggest coal producer by buying Newmont Mining Corp.'s 55 percent stake in Peabody Holding Co. for $715 million. The British conglomerate bought a 45 percent stake in Peabody for $504 million last month. Newmont, which is 49 percent owned by Hanson, said Thurasday the sale would yield about $600 million after taxes and expenses and help it to reduce its debt.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. Ltd. has agreed to sell Star magazine for $400 million in cash and stock to the publisher of its saucy rival, The National Enquirer. The would-be buyer, G.P. Group Inc., said Thursday it plans to ``maintain the Star's editorial independence'' and would continue to publish it from the magazine's current location in Tarrytown.

Polaroid Corp., which has been reorganizing since fending off a hostile takeover effort two years ago, said it would take additional steps to restructure itself to boost sales and respond better to market demands. Polaroid officials said Thursday's announcement caps a company-wide restructuring Polaroid undertook in 1988 while fighting a hostile takeover attempt by Shamrock Holdings.

The regulation of stocks and stock index futures by two separate government agencies has not increased sharp price swings in the stock markets, Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan said. Greenspan also said Thursday that while some regulatory fine tuning may be needed, the Fed doesn't think creating one, super regulator is the answer to jurisdictional disputes.

Growth in consumer spending slowed to 0.4 percent in February from increases of 1 percent in December and January, the government said. Analysts blamed weak car sales for the slowdown, and some said buying momentum was building in other areas of the economy. The Commerce Department said Thursday that personal consumption totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.63 trillion, the smallest increase since a 0.3 percent gain in October.

Prices farmers get for raw products increased 1.3 percent from February to March, raising the overall commodity index 2.7 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said. Overall, the department said Thursday its ``prices received'' index matched the record level set in January. The index declined in February then rose again to the January level.

Stock prices posted their first loss of the week Thursday in light selling as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 15.99 to 2,727.70. The dollar plunged against the Japanese yen and lost ground against other key currencies. Bond prices tumbled. Cocoa futures prices surged to seven-month highs; livestock and meat futures mostly were lower; grains and soybeans advanced; precious metals rose; and energy futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Approves Eastern's Sale of Latin American Routes
DOC.TEXT: Unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines, exasperated at the carrier's mounting losses and its new plan to reduce debt payments, are considering seeking the liquidation of the airline, sources said. A source close to the creditors' committee said Thursday there is a ``50-50 chance'' the group will request the bankruptcy court to appoint a special trustee to oversee a liquidation of Eastern. Such a move would be a radical shift by the creditors. They have been supportive of Eastern since it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization on March 9, 1989, five days after it was struck by Machinists, pilots and flight attendants. The naming of a trustee, who would take control of the airline from Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp., has long been advocated by the airline's unions but rejected by both the company and its creditors. A move for liquidation also could imperil Eastern's agreement to sell its prized Latin American routes to American Airlines for $349 million. Proceeds from that sale are central to Eastern's plan to rebuild. On Tuesday, Miami-based Eastern sharply scaled back its business prospects, forecasting a bigger loss for this year and a delay in this summer's planned emergence from bankruptcy reorganization. Eastern said difficulties in rebuilding its strike-battered business also meant it would be unable to fulfill a tentative agreement to pay unsecured creditors 50 cents on the dollar. Under that accord the unsecured creditors, who are owed $980 million, would receive about $490 million in cash and notes. The creditors' committee privately passed a resolution late Tuesday authorizing its attorneys to seek the appointment of a trustee and to propose a plan of liquidation, said sources close to the committee, who requested anonymity. The creditors' attorneys would take such action if Texas Air refused to cover Eastern's future operating losses, according to the resolution. Currently, the losses are funded out of escrow accounts held for the creditors, which contain the proceeds of sales of Eastern assets. ``In the event (Texas Air) refuses to fund such losses ... the committee hereby authorizes counsel to prepare and file either a motion seeking the appointment of a trustee to consummate the sale to American Airlines and then to effectuate an orderly liquidation of Eastern Airlines, or a liquidating plan and a contemporaneous motion for the appointment of a trustee,'' the resolution read. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland on Thursday approved Eastern's proposed sale of the Latin American routes and related assets. That sale forms the core of a $471 million deal that also includes a $102.5 million settlement of litigation between American and Continental Airlines, Eastern's sister Texas Air subsidiary. The proposed transaction still must be approved by the Transportation Department. A department attorney said at the hearing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court that a decision on the sale probably would be made by April 6. If approved, the transfer would cap a string of more than $800 million in assets sold by Eastern. The sale also would greatly extend the international reach of American, the nation's largest airline. Completion of the sale is a necessary condition for final approval of a reorganization agreement between Eastern and the unsecured creditors, which include aircraft and engine manufacturers such as Boeing Co., Airbus Industrie and General Electric Co. One source close to the situation said Robert Ferguson, a vice president of Texas Air, suggested to creditors during a conference call Thursday that they ``pretend'' to negotiate a reorganization of Eastern until the Transportation Department approves the sale. Houston-based Texas Air was concerned that if the department thought Eastern was being liquidated, it would bar the sale, this source said. The airline's suggestion ``is designed to pull the wool over the eyes of the Department of Transportation,'' the source said. ``That's at the very least unethical, if not unlawful.'' Eastern spokesman Robin Matell in Miami declined any comment on the issue. ``Eastern and Texas Air will discuss with the responsible parties the manner in which to structure a final agreement,'' he said. Lawyers for the Air Line Pilots Association and the Machinists union opposed the Latin American sale at the hearing, as they have done with Eastern's previous asset transfers. Adam Harris, an attorney representing Eastern's unsecured creditors, said they didn't object to the transaction. The committee did not express in court its displeasure with Eastern's latest reorganization proposals. Early this month, the Justice Department said it did not object to the sale of the Latin American routes. Eastern bought the Latin American routes from Braniff Inc. in 1982 for around $30 million.

DOC.HEAD: Murdoch Sells Star Magazine to Rival National Enquirer Publisher
DOC.TEXT: ``Shocker! National Enquirer Publisher Poised to Devour Star!'' That's how the Star might scream it from its rack near the checkout counter. Under an agreement announced Thursday, Rupert Murdoch's News Corp Ltd. is selling the Star for at least $400 million in cash and stock to the company that publishes its tabloid rival. The news came as a surprise to Star staffers. ``We're in shock,'' said Barry Levine, the Star's Hollywood bureau chief. ``Up until this moment, we and the Enquirer have been bitter enemies.'' But the would-be buyer, G.P. Group Inc. of Lantana, Fla., said it plans to ``maintain the Star's editorial independence'' and would continue to publish it from the magazine's current location in Tarrytown, N.Y. ``They will still compete with each other,'' said Iain Calder, editor and president of the Enquirer, from his office in Florida. The agreement comes nearly a year after G.P. Group itself was acquired by a partnership led by principals of the romance magazine publisher Macfadden Holdings Inc. and the media investment firm Boston Ventures for $412.5 million. Macfadden's titles include True Story, True Confessions and Modern Romance, The purchase would solidify G.P. Group's franchise in the grocery checkout lines. It also publishes the sensationalist Weekly World News. The Star has an average weekly circulation of 3.6 million, according to News Corp. The National Enquirer's average weekly circulation is 4.1 million and Weekly World News is at 950,000, according to G.P. Group. Under terms of the proposed sale, News Corp. would receive about $200 million in cash and the balance in preferred stock in G.P. Group. The sale is expected to be completed before June 30, the companies said in a news release. It is subject to government waivers or approvals and other conditions. News Corp. was expected to use proceeds from the sale to reduce debt incurred in several recent acquisitions, including the $3 billion purchase of the publisher of TV Guide in 1988 and the $407 million purchase of book publisher Scott Foresman and Co. last fall. Star was among the first major successes for Murdoch in the United States. ``We created Star magazine 16 years ago and developed it into one of America's most popular periodicals,'' said Martin Singerman, president of News America Publishing Inc., the News Corp. subsidiary that publishes the magazine. Michael Boylan, vice chairman and chief operating officer, said G.P. Group was interested because the Star ``is a great publication'' and newsstand distribution is ``a business we understand.'' Since taking over the Enquirer and the Weekly World News, G.P. Group's new owners reportedly have more than tripled the company's annual cash flow to about $60 million, partly by trimming a 400-person staff by about 10 percent and partly by making paper and printing operations more efficient. Some of the biggest names in the publishing business were believed to have been bidders for G.P. Group when it was up for sale last year, including Britain's Maxwell Communications Corp., France's Hachette SA and the West German publisher Heinrich Bauer. It could not be determined if there were any other bidders for the Star. News Corp. officials were said to be unavailable for comment. Australian-based News Corp. is a diversified international media company with interests in newspapers, magazines, book publishing, motion picture and television production and commercial printing. In addition to its debt from acquisitions, the company has been preparing to expand its weekly lineup of shows for its Fox Television Network, which is mounting a challenge to the ABC, NBC and CBS networks.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher, Restaurant Group Launches Magazine with a Menu
DOC.TEXT: Theater goers get the cast names in a playbook. Sports fans can look up the players' numbers in a program. And now diners at more than 60 New York restaurants are getting their menu in a magazine. The magazine is called Knife & Fork, and it is being produced by a joint venture involving a specialty publishing concern and a company that owns restaurants. Instead of the usual menus, customers at selected restaurants are getting the general interest magazine with its menu stapled inside. They can read while they eat or take it home. It is being billed as just the ticket for advertisers trying to reach young go-getters who often don't spend much time watching TV. If it is successful in New York, its owners say they may expand it nationally. But critics said the magazine could be an unwelcome conversation stopper. And some advertising executives said they failed to detect a clear sense of editorial mission, something they say is critical to a magazine's success. Knife & Fork is the latest in a growing trend which has seen the creation of media vehicles aimed at helping advertisers reach specific audiences more efficiently than through mass magazines or broadcast outlets. Some recent examples include advertiser-supported magazines for women at the beauty parlor or the doctor's office. Critics say people may grow weary of finding themselves targeted for advertising in unexpected locations. They question whether these media vehicles are reaching as many people as projected. Knife & Fork is a creation of a 50-50 joint venture between the publishing company Performance Network Inc. of Lindenhurst, N.Y., and The Riese Organization, a privately-held company that owns more than 300 restaurants in the New York area and owns stakes in more than 100 others nationwide. Performance Network previously has published boxing programs for Madison Square Garden events and sells advertising in the sports programs distributed at New York Mets baseball games, according to Chairman Richard Neste. Neste and Murray Riese, a partner in The Riese Organization, each declined to say how much they were investing in the new magazine project. The March-April issue is being distributed at about 65 to 70 Riese-owned restaurants in Manhattan. The restaurants are known by 22 different brand names, including Houlihan's, Charlie O's, TGI Friday's and Lindy's. Not counting the menu, the magazine was 32 pages and included a feature on personal ads, a story on what your underwear says about you and tips on how to buy a man's suit. Some articles were reprints from other magazines. Advertisers were told more than 1 million copies of the magazine will be distributed every two months based on customer counts at the restaurants. Among the brands advertised in the first issue were Parliament Lights cigarettes, Miller beer, V8 vegetable juice and Sony televisions. Advertising executives compared the magazine to theater playbills, which have a few pages devoted to the specific production surrounded by stories on theater in general. Neste, who is publisher and editor in chief, said Knife & Fork is different because customers have to look at it to order. But will people go back to the magazine later? ``The key issue is how many of them will look at it,'' said Joseph Ostrow, worldwide media director for Foote Cone & Belding Communications. He said he expects the magazine will provide research to address that.

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Says It Won Proxy War; Simmons Takes Credit for Big Concessions
DOC.TEXT: Dallas billionaire Harold Simmons may have lost his proxy war for control of Lockheed Corp.'s board, but he claimed all the credit for the company's sudden fondness for its major shareholders. At Lockheed's annual meeting Thursday, Chairman Daniel Tellep made major concessions to the pension funds and other large investors who hold 60 percent of its stock. The biggest was an offer to give shareholders up to three new seats on the board. Simmons, who controls 19 percent of the military contractor's common stock, originally asked for six board seats. When denied, the investor nominated his own full slate of candidates and urged shareholders to vote for them. Official results of the vote for the board and for several shareholder rights planks won't be know until next week at the earliest, but Tellep claimed victory. ``I'm expecting a clear majority in every category of shareholder, except of course, Mr. Simmons,'' Tellep said at a news conference after the meeting. At a separate news conference, Simmons and Martin at first said the contest was too close to call. But later they seemed to acknowledge defeat. ``It's like a political campaign,'' Martin said. ``Sometimes you just have to come back again the next time.'' Tellep, who took the helm of Lockheed last year, said he courted 70 institutional investors during the past few weeks of the proxy battle. He said he considered the wooing of shareholders a valuable education and his ``baptism by fire'' in their desire to have a say in the company's affairs. Replied Simmons: ``There's no question but it was our campaign that caused him to get religion.'' Added Simmons' chief lieutenant, J. Landis Martin: ``Mr. Simmons was baptized a long time ago.'' The battle, waged in newspaper advertisements as well as formal mailings to shareholders, was expensive. Lockheed spent about $8 million and Simmons spent about $6 million. Asked about his efforts to portray himself as a builder of companies rather than a corporate raider, Simmons said, ``We weren't entirely successful, no.'' He complained that he had not had enough time to wage his campaign because Tellep had moved up the date of the meeting. Tellep acknowledged Thursday that he turned down a last-minute compromise proposal in which Simmons promised to drop his campaign to replace the board in return for three board seats. Simmons began his campaign as a battle for the entire board and that is the way Lockheed fought it, Tellep said. He also said Simmons never personally presented a formal settlement offer. Instead, the offer was forwarded Tuesday by Thomas Flanigan, the chief investment officer of the California teachers pension fund, which wound up supporting Simmons. The annual meeting was held in a vast hangar beside the Burbank Airport, not far from where Lockheed built the stealth fighter in the super-secret ``skunk works.'' In addition to up to three new board seats, Tellep promised to heed the results of a ``shareholder rights'' proposal urging the company to opt out of strict anti-takeover provisions of the law in Delaware, where Lockheed is incorporated. Tellep said even if the proposal got only a ``significant'' minority vote he would recommend that the board support an amendment at the next meeting to have Lockheed opt out. He also offered to meet regularly with representatives of Simmons' NL Industries Inc. to discuss the future of Lockheed. And he reiterated a promise made earlier, to recommend to the board that shareholders be allowed to vote confidentially from now on. Martin and Simmons objected to the way in which a small portion of the shares belonging to an employees stock ownership plan had been voted. They said the trustee of the plan, which holds 19 percent of Lockheed stock, had wrongly voted all the shares even though some employees abstained from voting. Those shares were voted proportionally with the rest of the plan's votes, which went by more than 90 percent to Lockheed's board. Martin suggested that if his side lost by a narrow margin, it might challenge the result on those grounds. Tellep said he would look into whether the employees could get one of the new board seats, but stopped short of promising they would. Simmons had urged Lockheed, with a recent history of sagging earnings and cost overruns, to improve profits at its non-core technology services and electronics businesses or sell them off. The company said Simmons had no experience in military contracting and no business running Lockheed, which had 1989 sales of $9.9 billion. Tellep also claimed the company was poised for a rebound after a major restructuring last year and a decision to take $500 million in writeoffs. Simmons has lost $100 million on his $530 million investment in Lockheed because of a slumping share price. Lockheed stock fell 25 cents Thursday to $36.62{ on the New York Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Doesn't Think Split Markets Regulation Causes Volatility
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve Board believes regulation of stocks and stock index futures by two separate government agencies has not worsened price swings in the stock markets, Chairman Alan Greenspan says. Greenspan told a Senate panel Thursday that while some fine tuning is in order, the Fed doesn't think creating one super regulator is the answer to jurisdictional disputes. ``The board does not believe that the existing division of regulatory authority has increased volatility in the securities markets,'' he said. The head of the nation's top economic policy-making body was among several key government officials to testify on the turf battle between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Greenspan told the securities subcommittee of the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee that he ``marginally'' favored giving jurisdiction over stock index futures to the SEC. But he quickly said he was speaking only for himself on that point, and that several Fed governors disagreed with that position. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission oversees stock index futures, which let investors bet on the rise and fall of a basket of stocks without having to buy the underlying securities. But critics claim the wide disparity between margins _ the downpayment investors must make to buy securities on credit _ required in futures markets and the securities markets leads to sharp rises and drops in prices. And that volatility, they say, has spooked small investors out of the stock market. The Federal Reserve sets margin requirements for stocks and other securities but margins for futures contracts are set by the exchange's themselves, usually at a fraction of the amount the Fed requires. Greenspan said the Fed ``does not see a clear basis for choosing between CFTC and SEC oversight of stock index futures margins.'' He added, however, that the board ``feels strongly'' about giving up the margin authority it has already and putting the SEC and the exchanges in charge of setting margins for stocks and stock options. Other witnesses included SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden, CFTC Chairman Wendy L. Gramm and Treasury Undersecretary Robert R. Glauber. While those three agencies have delivered opinions on who should regulate so-called ``hybrid'' financial products that contain aspects of both a security and a futures contract, Greenspan previously had kept mum. Last year, a federal appeals court in Chicago ruled that financial products with any properties of a futures contract belong under CFTC oversight. The Fed, Treasury, SEC and CFTC make up the President's Working Group on Financial Markets, a panel set up in the wake of the 1987 stock market crash. They have yet to reach an agreement on the thorny matter of jurisdiction for hybrid instruments like stock index futures. Breeden said he favored either merging control of securities and futures under one agency or _ at the least _ giving the SEC control over stock index futures as well as stocks. Glauber said Treasury favors giving the SEC authority over stocks, stock options and stock index futures. Gramm, however, opposes ``any shift in CFTC jurisdiction,'' claiming it hasn't been proven that such a change would benefit the markets. The subcommittee, chaired by Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., is looking specifically at the question of margins. ``This hearing is not to debate the issue of `turf,''' Dodd said at the hearing's start. But the topic quickly strayed to the long-simmering dispute between the SEC and the CFTC. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, said the jurisdictional debate was holding up much-needed reform in the commodities futures markets. In testimony before Dodd's subcommittee he accused the SEC of launching ``a hostile takeover'' of the CFTC's responsibilities. ``I am convinced that simply shifting jurisdiction for stock index futures from the CFTC to the SEC will not strengthen regulation, end volatility in the stock market or restore investor confidence in Wall Street.'' He called for passage of legislation to make the CFTC a tougher regulator and then someday combine the CFTC and SEC. ``But realistically, the merger solution is far off,'' said Leahy.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Offers Socially Conscious Savings Plan
DOC.TEXT: A Chicago bank renowned for revitalizing its impoverished neighborhood is hoping to find a market for a novel instrument: certificates of deposit for socially conscious investors. For investors willing to forsake big yields, the new CDs from the South Shore Bank of Chicago promise to give a boost to the city's South Shore neighborhood and provide aid for groups such as Vietnamese refugees, bank officials said Thursday. ``I think it's going to appeal to that universe of social investors who want to do something good with their money,'' said Katherine Gross, director of the revolving loan fund of the Industrial Cooperative Association of Somerville, Mass., the bank's partner in the effort. A normal certificate of deposit might pay a 7 percent return. But investors who buy a South Shore CD can choose to keep 1 percent to 4 percent of the interest and give the rest to the ICA. A $100,000 CD yielding 7 percent annually would return $7,000 to an investor. But if the South Shore investor chose to earn only 1 percent interest, or $1,000, the other $6,000 in interest would be donated to the ICA. The non-profit group invests such funds in locally-owned companies and community organizations around the country, Gross said. Prospective clients include an Indian tribe in North Dakota that wants to start a gas station and a group of Vietnamese refugees who want to start a fishing cooperative, she said. The new CD serves a two-fold purpose. The interest goes to the non-profit group while the principal is reinvested in the South Shore neighborhood. ``For someone who would like to promote social objectives, this is a terrific investment,'' said Jan Piercy, vice president of Shore Bank Corp., the group's holding company. ``But anyone who is interested in profit maximization is not going to be interested in this.'' The bank has earned a national reputation for its efforts to revitalize the neighborhood. Like many other urban areas, South Shore suffered from the white flight to the suburbs. The neighborhood went from nearly all-white in the 1950s to 98 percent black by the early 1970s. Many banks and businesses fled during that time. South Shore's previous owner even asked the Federal Reserve Board for permission to move the bank to the Loop, Chicago's downtown business district. But the community revolted, and the Fed denied permission, Piercy said. The owner decided to sell, and a group of investors, including several philanthropic foundations, formed the holding company to buy the bank for $3.2 million in 1973. The new owners decided to use the bank's money to help the community and targeted socially conscious investors nationwide to increase its deposits. During the last 15 years, the bank has provided loans to renovate more than 22 percent of the neighborhood's rental units. ``All of the funds which South Shore gets from its depositors are targeted back into the community, not into investments in junk bonds or oil,'' said Alan Walker, the bank's administrator for development deposits. That approach has won praise from some, and the bank is the subject of a book called ``Community Capitalism'' by a University of Chicago professor. ``Because of the bank's efforts, property values have steadily improved, and the neighborhood is a better place to live than it was 10 or 15 years ago,'' said Dr. Richard Taub, a social science professor and author of the book.

DOC.HEAD: Kidder Selling Bridge Loans, Junk Bonds to Parent
DOC.TEXT: Kidder, Peabody Group Inc. is selling its portfolio of risky junk bonds and bridge loans to its parent's credit arm for about $750 million, making it the latest Wall Street house to turn to its parent for capital. Analysts said the sale of the apparently illiquid investments to GE Capital Corp. would increase Kidder's capital base and reduce its exposure to the dormant high-yield bond market. ``It's going to make our balance sheet very much stronger and very much more liquid that it was prior to the deal,'' Kidder chief operating officer Dick O'Donnell said. The deal follows closely on the heels of efforts by American Express Co. to bolster its ailing brokerage division. In recent months, American Express has announced plans to take over Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and inject about $1.35 billion in new capital. Kidder is a wholly owned subsidiary of General Electric Co. ``It looks like we're starting to see the beginning of a trend here,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder, an industry analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``It strengthens the balance sheet of these companies.'' Like other Wall Street firms, Kidder has been hurt by a downturn in the individual investing, merger activity and securities underwriting. The firm is shifting its retail operation to focus on wealthy clients and small companies rather than all investors. Kidder also has cut its work force to 5,600 employees from a peak of 7,500. Kidder's $750 million portfolio is being sold at current market value, but officials refused to reveal the face value of the investments. The New York Times reported that Kidder would post an operating loss of less than $25 million for the first quarter to reflect the reduced value of the portfolio under the transaction. About half the package is junk bonds and a third outstanding bridge loans _ credits made by Kidder that were intended to be temporary but for which the firm failed to raise permanent financing. The remaining one-sixth is in equity investments in companies made by Kidder's merchant banking department. Kidder refused to say when the junk bonds were issued and bridge loans were made, or to what companies. It said three bridge loans had a total value of under $250 million. The bonds came from the firm's merchant banking division and were not part of its daily trading portfolio. O'Donnell said the firm was not getting out of the high-yield bond business and would continue to maintain a trading inventory. He also said Kidder still would provide merchant banking services, in which an investment firm takes an equity stake in its clients. Kidder officials sought to play down the comparison with Shearson. Chairman and chief executive Michael A. Carpenter said in a statement that GE Capital is ``better positioned to realize the future value'' of the portfolio because it manages longer-term loans. ``This is not a bailout whatsoever,'' O'Donnell said. ``They are buying $750 million worth of investments for cash. This is an inventory which will be part of a much larger portfolio they manage.'' He said the move will increase the net capital of Kidder's broker-dealer unit by about $100 million _ the value of its illiquid junk bond holdings. That will push the regulated entity's capital to about $250 million above New York Stock Exchange requirements, he said. Kidder lost $23 million last year, compared with a $46 million profit in 1988. GE, the electrical products, broadcasting and financial services company based in Fairchild, Conn., paid $600 million to acquire an 80 percent stake in Kidder in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge More Than 3 Percent as Dollar Rebounds
DOC.TEXT: Renewed weakness in the yen sent stock prices diving again Friday, with the Nikkei index suffering its seventh-worst daily loss and plunging below the 30,000-point mark. A decline in stock index futures and heavy index-linked programmed selling accelerated the market's fall, dealers said. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which shed 237.41 points Thursday, lost 1,045.71 points, or 3.37 percent, to end the week at 29,981.45. It was the seventh-worst daily loss both in point and percentage terms. The dollar, which fell sharply on world markets Thursday, rebounded to close at 157.65 yen, up 1.00 yen from Thursday's Tokyo close. After opening at 156.80 yen, the currency ranged between 156.75 yen and 157.95 yen. The yen's renewed slide and an overnight decline on Wall Street triggered broad selling of stocks, dealers said. ``Declining futures, coupled with index-linked selling, contributed to an overall decline,'' said Miyako Sekine, a dealer with Nikko Securities. Nomura Securities analyst Yoshiro Inoue said many market players ``still suffer from pessimism and uncertainties.'' The yen's decline also hammered bond prices, driving interest rates up sharply. The yield on the benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bond surged to 7.36 percent from 7.20 percent Thursday. Friday's decline capped another volatile week for the stock market. After a steep plunge last week, the Nikkei rebounded more than 500 points last Friday and then started this week with its second-biggest single-day gain ever, a surge of 1,468.33 points on Monday. Pessimism about the yen and its impact on interest rates has continued to haunt the market, though. The index fell 562 points on Wednesday and a further 237 points on Thursday. The dollar traded in an unusually broad range of more than 1 yen on Friday. ``The dollar fluctuated sharply in the face of dollar-buying by corporations at the end of the financial year and dollar-selling by others for profit-taking,'' said Kozo Yoshida, a dealer with Mitsui Bank. Many Japanese companies settle their annual accounts at the end of March. Yoshida said there were no specific political or economic factors affecting the exchange market Friday. The dollar has been advancing against the yen for several weeks as Japanese corporations bought the currency amid general pessimism about the yen and to help bolster their balance sheets at the close of their fiscal year.
