DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower Against Most Currencies, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most currencies in quiet European trading this morning. Gold prices were mixed in light trading. Foreign exchange dealers said they did not expect the dollar to pick up any significant new trend until after the April 7 meeting in Paris of finance ministers from the seven major industrialized nations. They saw no major new initiatives emerging from the meeting but anticipated a statement aimed at helping Japan support the yen, which has dropped against the dollar in recent weeks. ``I already think the yen is a bit undervalued at its current level,'' a trader at a U.S. bank in Frankfurt said on condition of anonymity. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 1 yen to a closing 157.65 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 157.40 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.6941 West German marks, down from 1.6960; 1.4979 Swiss francs, down from 1.5005; 5.6988 French francs, down from 5.7070; 1.9085 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9083; 1,249.00 Italian lire, up from 1,248.75; and 1.1712 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1742. In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6423, compared with $1.635 late Thursday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $371.30 a troy ounce, down from $372.25 bid late Thursday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $372.20. In Zurich, the bid price was $371.75, up from $371.70 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.18 to close at a bid $373.11. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $4.96 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $4.97.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer, Wholesale Prices Up, Current Account, Unemployment Fall
DOC.TEXT: Japan's consumer price index climbed a steep 3.6 percent in February from a year ago as a snap of cold weather pushed up food prices, while a weak yen caused a rise in wholesale prices, the government said Friday. The Management and Coordination Agency said February's year-to-year gain was the largest since November 1981, when consumer prices rose 3.8 percent. Compared with the previous month, consumer prices were up 0.3 percent. Higher vegetable prices resulting from heavy snow and cold weather were largely responsible for last month's increase, said an agency official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Vegetable prices jumped 17.3 percent in February, while prices for fresh vegetable prices surged 24.9 percent, the agency said. Fruit prices increased by 14.7 percent, and dairy products rose 10.8 percent. Recreation expenses registered a 5.1 percent increase, the agency said. In the Tokyo area, consumer prices were up 0.4 percent in March from the previous month and were 3.5 percent higher than a year earlier, the government said. Tokyo-area prices are seen as an early indicator of price movements for the rest of Japan. For the fiscal year ending Saturday, consumer prices in the Tokyo-area were up 3.2 percent from the previous fiscal year. Separately, the Bank of Japan reported wholesale prices edged up 0.2 percent in the second 10 days of March from the previous 10-day period and were up 3.8 percent from a year earlier. The central bank attributed the increase partly to the weak Japanese yen. Wholesale prices have been rising gradually in recent months as the yen's steady decline made imports more expensive. Meanwhile, Japan posted a $4.907 billion current account surplus in February, down 32.4 percent from a year ago, the Finance Ministry reported. This marked the 12th consecutive decline in the current account surplus from year-earlier levels, the ministry said. Japan's trade surplus registered $5.491 billion in February, down 35.6 percent drop a year ago. Exports totaled $21.5 billion, down $500 million, or 2.2 percent from a year ago, while imports climbed $2.6 billion, or 18.9 percent, to $16.1 billion. Separately, the government said the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate fell to 2.1 percent in February as the job market continued to tighten. February's jobless rate, down 0.1 percentage point from January's 2.2 percent, matched the lowest level Japan has maintained since last June. Japan's jobless rate would be higher if calculated by U.S. or European methods. In Japan, members of the armed forces and people working more than one hour in the last week of the month are considered employed.

DOC.HEAD: Hooker Chairman to Stand Trial on Bribe Charges
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of Australia's Hooker Corp., which had U.S. retail and development interests before going into provisional liquidation last year, was ordered Friday to stand trial on corruption charges. A magistrate in the northern state of Queensland ruled that George Herscu, chairman and former chief executive of Hooker explain payments allegedly made to Russell Hinze, a former state minister, in 1983. It was alleged that Herscu paid the money so that Hinze would intervene in a dispute between the Brisbane City Council and a shopping center development company associated with Herscu. During the preliminary hearing Herscu claimed the money was a loan, to be used by Hinze to buy racehorses in New Zealand on Herscu's behalf. But the hearing was told that no horses were ever purchased with the money, which was repaid to Herscu after allegations about the payments were made public in 1988. Herscu has not made any plea to the charges. The trial is expected to start in June. Hooker Corp., a property development and retail company, entered provisional liquidation in July 1989 with bank debts of about $1 billion. Its U.S. subsidiary, L.J. Hooker Corp., filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors under U.S. bankruptcy law around the same time. Since entering bankruptcy proceedings, L.J. Hooker has sold assets including its Parisian Inc. department store chain based in Birmingham, Ala., and its Merksamer Jewelers chain based in Sacramento, Calif. It also has liquidated the New York-based B. Altman & Co. department store chain. An agreement recently was announced to sell portions of L.J. Hooker's Bonwit Teller specialty department store company based in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Government Postpones Decision on NTT Breakup
DOC.TEXT: The government said Friday it would wait five years before deciding whether to break up Japan's major telecommunications company, whose recent stock slump has been linked in part to investor worries about a breakup. The government still is the major shareholder in Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp., which was converted into a private company in 1985. ``For the time being, we are going to promote rationalization of the company without breaking it up,'' said Minister of Posts and Telecommunications Takashi Fukaya. ``And if it is deemed necessary (to break up the company), we will take up the matter again in 1995 and make the final conclusion.'' A government advisory council suggested earlier this month that NTT should be broken into three separate companies offering local, long-distance and mobile telephone services. After two years of study, the council concluded that NTT's virtual monopoly on telephone service has hindered free competition in Japan's telecommunications market and led to inefficient management of NTT. A final government decision had been expected at the end of March, when the government was required to review the state of the telecommunications market under the law that made NTT a private company five years ago. But the Finance Ministry, in charge of offering NTT stock to the public, has strongly opposed a breakup, claiming it will hurt NTT shareholders. Hundreds of shareholders have complained to the ministry that the price of NTT stock has slumped to about 1.1 million yen, or $7,050, a share from 3.18 million yen, or $20,385, in April 1987, shortly after its listing on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Company officials have attributed recent declines to a general stock market slump as well as worries about a breakup, which NTT opposes on grounds it would lead to duplication of effort by the long-distance and local service companies. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said the government's decision to postpone a conclusion on breaking up NTT ``reflects the government's understanding about the concern of shareholders.'' Hashimoto also hinted that the ban on foreign investors holding NTT shares is likely to be removed soon.

The stock market gave ground today in a carryover of selling from Thursday's session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 7.43 to 2,720.27 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 361 up, 481 down and 542 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 18.86 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said enthusiasm for stocks was restrained by continuing doubts about the outlook for interest rates. Rates rose slightly in the government bond market today. Traders also reacted warily to renewed selling in the Tokyo stock market, where prices fell 3.37 percent in the last session of Japan's fiscal year. In recent weeks U.S. stock prices have been holding steady while the Japanese market has suffered a sharp setback. But some observers still worry that ripple effects from the drop in Tokyo could soon start to spread more generally to other financial centers around the world. Among actively traded blue chips, International Business Machines rose \ to 106\; General Electric gained [ to 64|, and Philip Morris was unchanged at 40. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .50 to 186.67. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .37 at 359.86. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 15.99 to 2,727.70. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 3 to 2 on the NYSE, with 576 up, 858 down and 511 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 132.19 million shares, against 142.30 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Overland Park Publisher Says He Plans New Afternoon Paper
DOC.TEXT: A suburban Kansas City publisher says he's confident of success for the new afternoon tabloid newspaper he will launch May 14. Stephen F. Rose, president and co-publisher of Sun Publications Inc., announced plans Thursday for a five-day paper called The Evening News. He said the paper will fill a void created when The Kansas City Star Co. closed its afternoon paper on March 1 and merged it with the morning Times. ``We certainly felt it left a vacuum,'' Rose said. According to Rose, the Monday-through-Friday publication will start with a daily press run of 25,000. It will be sold on the street for 50 cents but won't be distributed to homes. ``We expect it to appeal to busy people who want more information, people who don't want to wait 24 hours to find out what happened today,'' Rose said. Rose, 42, is the sole investor in the new paper. The family-owned company currently publishes 18 twice-weekly papers in the affluent Johnson County suburbs, plus two weeklies, the College Boulevard News and The Kansas City Jewish Chronicle. Jack Lovelace, editor of the Sun Newspapers, will assume additional duties as managing editor of the new paper. Rose declined to say how much it would cost to run the paper, but said he's saving money by using Sun Publications' printing press, other equipment and some employees. The paper will buy additional composing equipment and writing terminals. Between 30 and 35 additional full- and part-time employees will be hired. The paper's editorial staff will consist of 12 to 17 full- and part-time employees. The Evening News will have 24 to 28 pages each day and will be sold at newsstands, convenience stores and newspaper racks.

DOC.HEAD: Arbitrator Says GM Didn't Breach Contract
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. did not violate its contract with the United Auto Workers union by idling the Fiero assembly plant in Pontiac, Mich., an arbitrator ruled. The ruling by arbitrator Thomas Roberts of Los Angeles upheld GM's contention that the plant, which shut down in August 1988 after a sharp decline in sales of the two-seat sports car, is indefinitely idled rather than closed. About 1,700 workers were laid off. ``We're obviously pleased with the arbitrator's ruling that GM did not violate the terms of the national agreement,'' the company said in a statement Thursday. ``From the outset of this disagreement, it was our position that ... these actions were caused by volume-related market decreases and demand for the product and therefore justifiable,'' a GM spokesman said. The ruling could raise tensions between the union and the automaker as they prepare for contract negotiations next summer. ``The decision provides a clear imperative to improve the job security provisions of our contract in the new agreement,'' said Stephen Yokich, the UAW's vice president in charge of the union's GM department. UAW officials have vowed they would press to close loopholes in the existing three-year contract's plant closing prohibition. Despite the prohibition, the automaker has laid off 10 percent of its UAW work force since 1987. GM plants in Leeds, Mo. and Framingham, Mass. have been idled, and a third facility in Lakewood, Ga. is to halt production this summer. GM began building Fiero cars at the Pontiac plant in 1984 and showcased the facility as a model of labor-management cooperation. The UAW agreed to set aside a number of longstanding work rules that limited management flexibility in running the plant. But Fiero sales plunged in 1987 partly because of defect problems, and GM ordered a massive recall late in the year to correct problems causing engine fires in 1984 models. When GM announced in 1988 that the plant would close, Yokich's predecessor, Donald Ephlin, came under fire from UAW dissidents for championing cooperative labor-management relations. Yokich replaced Ephlin as head of the union's 300,000-member GM department nine months ago.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound, Union Agree To Resume Negotiations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Scarpino said...', to CORRECT that bus en route to New York from Tulsa sted other way around. Version moved on business wires.
DOC.TEXT: Despite a top executive's contention that a 4-week-old strike is losing its impact, Greyhound Lines Inc. and its bus drivers' union say they will return to the negotiating table next week. Greyhound broke off talks with the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions on March 18, citing continued violence since the drivers walked out March 2. Although the company says the violence is continuing daily, with more than 200 incidents overall, it has agreed to resume negotiations Monday in Tucson, Ariz. Greyhound spokesman Steve Scarpino said a shot was fired at a Greyhound bus about two miles east of Tulsa, Okla., early today. No one was hurt, he said. in Oklahoma, Rogers County Sheriff's Office dispatcher Lance Beard said officers were investigating the shooting on Interstate 44. Scarpino said the bus was en route to New York from Tulsa with 26 passengers aboard when what appeared to be pellets struck the windshield of the bus. The windshield was damaged, he said. The union has condemned the violence and says its officials are not involved. Bernard DeLury, head of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, said Thursday that two mediators will participate in the negotiations. Union spokesman Jeff Nelson said, ``We assume that if they have agreed to go back to the table, we hope that they would be interested in negotiating.'' Previous negotiations have ended with the two sides at odds on wage and job security issues. The company says it can afford no more than the $63 million, three-year pact it is offering. However, the union and Greyhound differ over the value of the union's proposal, with Greyhound saying the last offer would cost $180 million and the union putting the value at about $40 million. Greyhound, operating with crossovers and permanent replacements, said Thursday it will expand service Sunday putting it at 54.1 percent of its total pre-strike miles. The company is adding 112 round trips that will increase service to some cities and add 50 destinations. President Frank Schmieder said Greyhound would like to end the ``open warfare'' with the union, but contended ``we're beginning to have plenty of drivers. ... In certain areas, yes, it's over.'' ``Essentially through the Southeast and Southwest, I think it's over,'' Schmieder said in an interview Wednesday. ``Chicago, Minneapolis, it's over,'' although ``it's still tight'' in the Northeast and West, he said. ``If the company were being as successful as it's claimed to be, I think you would have seen some kind of rush back to work,'' the union's Nelson said. ``That has not happened, and that has not happened, number one, because the company is not up and running.'' Nelson claimed the company is operating only 20 percent of pre-strike routes. While Greyhound says it has been increasing the number of routes it is serving during the strike, Schmieder said Greyhound has no near-term plans to restore service to about 32 percent of the total Greyhound system that is unprofitable. The decision could leave numerous areas without any intercity bus transportation, but Greyhound spokeswoman Elizabeth Hale said Thursday the company would attempt to subcontract some of the routes. ``In no way are we abandoning that 32 percent forever,'' she said. Greyhound is the only nationwide bus company, serving about 9,500 pre-strike destinations. In about 9,000 of those areas, the company provides the only intercity transportation.

DOC.HEAD: NASD Proposes Ending Trading in Penny Stocks
DOC.TEXT: The National Association of Securities Dealers has proposed eliminating penny stocks from its over-the-counter trading system, partly in response to a crackdown on fraud in the low-cost securities. The self-regulatory agency said Thursday it would seek government approval to effectively double the standards companies must meet to be listed on the NASDAQ stock system. NASDAQ stands for the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations system, a computerized stock price quotation system owned and operated by the NASD. The move is expected to eliminate about 500 low-cost, high-risk securities _ known as penny stocks because they usually trade for less than a dollar _ from the NASDAQ system. About 5,000 stocks currently trade on NASDAQ. The new standards will not affect about 2,700 stocks traded on the NASDAQ National Market, which already has a higher standard. The new standards, adopted by the NASD's board of governors earlier this month, would require companies issuing stock for the first time to have a minimum of $4 million in total assets and $2 million in capital and surplus, compared to the present requirements of $2 million and $1 million. In addition to the currently required 100,000 shares of public float for an issue, the float would have to have a market value of $1 million. Float is the term used to describe the number of public shares circulating in the market. Stocks would have to have a minimum bid price of $3 per share. There is no minimum required now. Maintaining a stock listing on NASDAQ under the new rule would require a company to have $2 million in assets, instead of the $750,000 in effect now. Also, $1 million in capital surplus, up from $375,000 would be required. The float would have to have a market value of $200,000 and the stock would be required to have a $1 minimum bid price. The changes, if approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission, would not go into effect until next January, to give already listed companies time to meet the new rule. NASD Executive Vice President John T. Wall said the changes reflected the effects of inflation since the requirements were last amended in 1981. Also prompting the changes was a Jan. 10 letter from the SEC expressing concern that unscrupulous promoters might seek to circumvent tougher rules for selling penny stocks by acquiring a listing on NASDAQ Stock Market. Such a listing would exempt them from the SEC rule requiring a client's written consent to buy stocks not listed by NASDAQ or a stock exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed Ahead Of Plantings Report
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade as players staked out their positions ahead of two Agriculture Department reports. The USDA's quarterly grain stocks report and annual spring planting intentions report were scheduled for release after the close of trading this afternoon. Of the two reports, the prospective plantings were of greater interest to traders. That report is expected to show that U.S. farmers intend to increase corn acreage this year by 4 percent to 75.2 million acres, partly as a result of changes in government programs designed to encourage corn planting. Analysts expect soybean acreage to drop by 3.6 percent to 58.5 million acres, while spring wheat plantings were estimated by private analysts at 17.5 million acres, a very slight decline from 1989. DOC.HEAD: Gillette Reaches Sale Agreement for European Toiletries
DOC.TEXT: Gillette Co. said Friday it had agreed to sell its European skin and hair care operations to Nobel Consumer Goods AB of Sweden for about $107 million. Gillette also will collect an additional $30 million from accounts in those businesses, the company said. The brands to be sold include Silkience hair care products, Aapri skin care items, Antica Erobristeria herbal toiletries in Italy and La Toja toiletry products in Spain. Gillette said last year it planned to sell the businesses as part of a realignment to make the company more efficient. Officials said the European operations being sold were not as successful as the company had hoped. Gillette spokesman David Fausch said the businesses being bought by Nobel had about $132 million in sales last year. That compares with Gillette's worldwide toiletry sales of about $1 billion. The proceeds from the sale will offset the costs of the realignment, Fausch said. Gillette's European deodorants, antiperspirants and shaving creams are not part of the transaction. Nobel is a division of Nobel Industries.

DOC.HEAD: Passage of Pollution Bill Appears on Track
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTs graf 6, The nine cities, to provide cities.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate appears on track to approving a sweeping air pollution control bill next week after narrowly rejecting $500 million in aid to coal miners who could lose their jobs because of tougher environmental standards. By a 50-49 vote Thursday, senators defeated a proposal that Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., called only a matter of ``fairness ... and justice'' because thousands of miners will be thrown out of work. The majority heeded warnings from Senate leaders that the amendment would prompt a presidential veto of the overall bill. The three-year, $500 million assistance program was considered to be the last major obstacle to Senate passage of the clean air bill. A vote on the legislation is scheduled for next Tuesday. A House version is in committee. Working into the evening Thursday, the Senate agreed to a provision that would require the increased sale of a cleaner blend of gasoline by 1993 in cities facing the worst smog problems. The measure was approved by voice vote after attempts to reject it failed, 69-30. The nine cities that would fall under the new clean fuels requirement are Los Angeles, Houston, New York City, Milwaukee, Baltimore, Philadelphia, Hartford, Conn., San Diego and Chicago. Meanwhile, the House Energy and Commerce Committee late Thursday adopted a proposal in its clean air bill that also would require the use of a cleaner blend of gasoline by 1995 in the same cities, although rejecting a plan to broaden the requirement from nine to as many as 40 cities. Thursday's vote on the Byrd amendment was as dramatic as the final tally would indicate. Senators were subject to intense pressure from both sides. Byrd, who wields considerable power and respect as a former Democratic leader and now chairman of the Appropriations Committee, had visited dozens of senators to plead for support. He thought he had enough votes to win as the count began, although a number of senators had not yet made firm commitments to either side. Sen. Spark Matsunaga, D-Hawaii, a staunch Byrd ally who suffers from cancer, arrived for the vote in a wheelchair. But the pressure was just as intense from the other side. The White House unleashed a final round of telephone calls to key senators, including some calls as the vote already was under way. The Senate leaders of both parties _ George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Bob Dole, R-Kan. _ used every means of persuasion to line their senators up against the amendment. And the White House passed the word that President Bush would veto the bill if it contained the miner aid provision. ``I know how hard it is to say no to the president of the United States,'' Byrd said later. ``Three of my votes took wings,'' he lamented, alluding to three senators who changed votes in the final minutes. The administration had strongly opposed the coal miner aid package, arguing that it was too expensive and singled out one industry while workers in other fields also might lose their jobs but not have special benefits. Senate leaders also had feared that if the measure were approved other senators would seek similar financial aid for workers in other industries. Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, promised to do just that. Mitchell said thousands of workers in other industries, including steel and petrochemicals, also could suffer job losses and would not have such benefits. But Byrd urged colleagues to ``hear the cries of people'' and maintained that helping the miners was no different that the federal assistance given to victims of a hurricane or earthquake, who suffer because of no fault of their own. ``We're not asking for welfare,'' he declared. The government estimates as many as 5,000 miners of high-sulfur coal, primarily in Appalachia and parts of the Midwest, will lose their jobs because of new controls on sulfur dioxide emissions required by Midwest electric power plants. The utilities are likely to shift from using high-sulfur coal to a cleaner fuel such as low-sulfur Western coal or natural gas, causing some Eastern mines to close. Under Byrd's proposal, miners of high-sulfur coal, who lose their jobs because utilities switched fuels, would have received up to 70 percent of their salaries for three years and additional funds if they participated in a retraining program. The benefits would have been available as long as the miner was unemployed during the three years.

DOC.HEAD: Banking Committee Narrowly Endorses S&L Regulator
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Banking Committee today narrowly endorsed President Bush's nominee for top savings and loan regulator. The panel voted 11-10 to recommend T. Timothy Ryan Jr. to be director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. The matter now goes to the full Senate. Two Democrats joined all nine Republicans on the panel in backing Ryan. The vote came after Democrats spent 90 minutes complaining that Ryan, a former senior Labor Department official, lacked experience for the job. Sen. Donald W. Riegle, Jr., D-Mich., said Ryan's qualifications were ``woefully short of the quality necessary to do this job.'' Riegle had said earlier that the panel probably would vote against Ryan's nomination. Republicans argued that someone with more experience in the savings and loan industry probably would be disqualified by virtue of conflicts of interest. They argued that rejecting Ryan would only serve to derail Bush's savings and loan bailout and increase costs to the taxpayer. Democrats voting for Ryan were Sens. Richard C. Shelby of Alabama and Terry Sanford of North Carolina. Sanford told reporters he was a personal friend of Ryan while Shelby said he believed it was important to fill the position quickly and that the full Senate should vote on the nomination. The administration has had difficulty finding a nominee since M. Danny Wall announced in early December that he would resign. It has been under pressure to find a replacement because at least five thrifts are challenging the thrift office's constitutional authority to seize troubled S&Ls. Last summer's S&L legislation automatically gave the director's job to Wall, chairman of the thrift office's predecessor agency, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. He was not nominated and confirmed for the director's job. In the latest challenge, U.S. District Court Judge Charles A. Legge in San Francisco on Thursday denied a temporary restraining order that would have removed government agents from the helm of Pacific Coast Savings and Loan Assocation, a a San Francisco-based institution with $1.04 billion in assets. Ryan, a former senior Labor Department official nominated last week, met skepticism from committee Democrats during a hearing on his nomination Wednesday. Lawmakers questioned his lack of direct experience in banking and raised concerns about possible conflicts of interest in his work as a private attorney after leaving government in 1983. As solicitor of the Labor Department, he helped hire former Attorney General William B. Saxbe as independent counsel overseeing the Teamsters Union Central States Pension Fund. After Ryan left the government, Saxbe joined Ryan's firm, bringing with him hundreds of thousands of dollars in fees from the fund. The administration has portrayed Ryan as an experienced manager who supervised 600 attorneys at the Labor Department and a tough enforcer who helped clean up corruption in the Teamsters pension fund.

DOC.TEXT: First Chicago Corp., the Midwest's largest banking company, said it expects to show a 50 percent decline in first-quarter profits largely due to bad commercial real estate loans. DOC.HEAD: Airbus Rejects India's Accusations of Corrurning and winking at Poindexter.
DOC.TEXT: ``When people come into court we expect them to give fair and truthful testimony,'' Webb said. ``But when a person is so biased he turns to wink at someone as if to say `Did that last answer help you, John?' _ I would have expected more from a former president than that,'' Webb said. Webb ridiculed Reagan's defense of three letters Poindexter sent to Congress in July, 1986, which falsely denied that the National Security Council staff was secretly orchestrating arms shipments to the Contras. The prosecutor recalled that when Reagan was shown one of the letters, the former president said he agreed with its contents and added ```I would have added in a profanity.''' ``He gave that testimony because he hoped it would help John Poindexter,'' Webb said. ``He hadn't the foggiest idea those were false letters sent to obstruct Congress.'' Webb, a former U.S. attorney in Chicago appointed by Reagan, argued that Poindexter tore up a document authorizing U.S. involvement in Iranian arms sales to protect Reagan from political embarrassment. ``This is the one document in the world it puts the lie to what Ronald Reagan told the American people'' when he denied in a Nov. 13, 1986, speech that he had sold arms to Iran to try to free American hostages, Webb said. The document, an intelligence ``finding'' signed by Reagan in December 1985, authorized the CIA's involvement a month earlier in the shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. It described the transaction as an effort to free U.S. hostages. Reagan's speech marked ``a rather sad day in America,'' Webb said, because even though the decision to trade arms for hostages might be defensible ``you don't lie to the American public.'' Webb said that Poindexter, after lying to two congressional committees on Nov. 21, 1986, about U.S.-Iran arms sales, returned to his office and ``he tore up the original finding signed by the president of the United States.'' The prosecutor, ripping up a copy of the document to dramatize his point, said, ``The act of tearing up that finding is strong evidence'' Poindexter ``intended to obstruct Congress.'' Poindexter, who served as Reagan's national security adviser from late 1985 until his resignation on Nov. 25, 1986, is also accused of deceiving Congress about White House involvement in covert assistant to the Nicaraguan rebels. Webb recounted testimony by former National Security Council aide Oliver L. North that he was ``generally instructed'' by Poindexter to lie to lawmakers about the secret aid network. North ``was there because the defendant on trial in this case, his commander, sent him there to do that,'' Webb said. ``The boss can't escape legal responsibility just because he didn't get his hands dirty.''

DOC.HEAD: Political and Economic Trends Derail ``Sure Thing'' Market
DOC.TEXT: Political and economic trends have overtaken Japan's financial markets, painfully ending an era during which investing in the Tokyo Stock Exchange seemed to be a sure thing, analysts say. From the beginning of 1990 through Friday's close of trading, the market that once was the world's richest had lost 23 percent of its value. The Japanese yen also has weakened, dropping more than 9 percent to about 158 yen to the U.S. dollar after ending last year at 143.45 yen. And the dollar's rise to a three-year high against the yen has occurred despite heavy dollar-selling by Japan's central bank. Market analysts say these trends could continue during the next few months as the yen and inflated stock prices readjust to political developments and economic realities that have overtaken Japan's monetary authorities and major brokerages. Japan's ``Big Four'' securities firms _ Nomura Securities, Daiwa Securities, Nikko Securities and Yamaichi _ account for about half of the Tokyo market's total turnover. Their market activity and advice often are credited with pulling the market out of slumps, such as the Oct. 20, 1987, crash that followed the ``Black Monday'' plunge on Wall Street, and with instilling the confidence that pushed the key Nikkei average up almost 20,000 points between early 1987 and the end of last year, when it peaked at 38,915.87. ``There's little doubt the major brokers accounted for lots of the market activity in the latter half of last year,'' when the market surged by about 4,000 points, says economist David Pike at UBS Phillips and Drew International Ltd. But the late 1989 surge contradicted economic fundamentals by reacting to speculation that interest rates were peaking, he said. Rather than peaking, domestic interest rates have continued rising as monetary authorities fight inflationary pressures stemming from wage hikes, a 3 percent sales tax and the weaker yen, which raises the cost of fuel and other imports. Japan's central bank has raised its discount rate, the interest it charges on loans to commercial banks, four times since last May to fight inflation, which economists expect to be in the 2 percent-2.5 percent range this year. The discount rate, which has a strong impact on other interest rates, was raised to 5.25 percent on March 20. It was at a historic low of 2.5 percent before the series of increases. Higher interest rates tend to discourage investment in the stock market because higher yields can be found in other investments. Analysts see higher rates as the single biggest factor behind the stock market's prolonged decline. The yen's decline also has pushed stock prices lower. Higher interest rates generally make a country's currency more attractive to investors. By reducing the outflow of capital from Japan in the long run, the discount rate hike could reduce demand for dollars and relieve downward selling pressure on the yen. But the Bank of Japan was ``backed into a corner,'' because boosting rates was certain to further hurt the stock market, says Peter Morgan, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Japan Ltd. Moreover, currency dealers had anticipated the latest rate increase, which so far has failed to help _ in fact the dollar by late Friday had risen to 157.65 yen from 152.70 yen on March 20. The yen also has suffered due to political developments in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, which have strengthened the U.S. dollar, seen as safest in times of uncertainty. Furthermore, Western Europe has become ``sexy'' due to expectations of German reunification and the formation of the European Common Market in 1992, luring Japanese investors away from home markets, Morgan said. Many analysts say they expect the market to continue declining in the short term as it adjusts to factors beyond the control of brokerages or monetary authorities. ``Market sentiment is still deteriorating, so we certainly can't expect a sharp recovery,'' says Susumu Kato, senior economist at Goldman Sachs Japan. This year, higher borrowing costs will depress capital investment and the weaker yen will increase the cost of imports, cutting into corporate earnings, says Lawrence S. Prager, chief analyst and strategist at Nikko Securities Co. But in the long run, Japan's powerhouse economy will take the adjustments in stride, analysts say. ``These are not caused by major economic problems, but are a matter of sentiment,'' says Kermit L. Schoenholtz, senior economist at Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd. ``The economy is extraordinarily competitive and the weaker yen will further boost its export competitiveness.

DOC.HEAD: Campeau Not Paying Interest Due
DOC.NOTE: Eds: The $260 million bond issue is in U.S. dollars.
DOC.TEXT: Campeau Corp. on Friday said it will not pay interest due Saturday on two debts and wants to defer the payments while the retailing and real estate company develops a long-term business plan. The Canadian company said it owes the semi-annual payments on two of its outstanding bond issues. One of the issues, worth 184 million Canadian dollars, is publicly traded and the other, worth $260 million, is owned by Olympia & York Developments Ltd., a big Toronto-based property company. Richard W. Wertheim, a Campeau spokesman, said the interest due on the publicly owned bonds is 6.9 million Canadian dollars and the amount due on the Olympia & York bonds is slightly less than $13 million. Campeau said in a news release that it could be in default on the two issues if it doesn't pay the interest by April 30. However, it said it intends to pursue discussions on deferring the payments. Wertheim said Campeau is fairly confident that the creditors will agree to temporarily waive the interest payments. He also said the company is encouraged by the progress it has made in discussions with its various creditors on a long-term business plan. He declined to specify what the plan might entail but said it will address running the business in the future and will deal with Campeau's debt situtation in some way. ``We're rather optimistic that we can work our way through this,'' he said. Analysts have speculated that Campeau's business plan could include a restructuring of debt and major asset sales. Some outside observers have questioned whether Campeau will be able to survive in its existing form or stay in business at all. Campeau, based in Toronto, owns commercial real estate, including office buildings and shopping centers. Its properties mainly are in the Canadian cities of Toronto, Montreal and Ottawa. The current debt woes facing Campeau are related to, but separate from, the problems of its two U.S. retailing units, Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc., which are in bankruptcy proceedings. Campeau's acquisition of Allied and Federated in 1986 and 1988 saddled the two department store operators with heavy debts. Allied and Federated listed debts totaling $7.7 billion when they filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Act in January.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Surge, Grains Close Mixed Before USDA Report
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices surged in late trading Friday to close strongly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade, while grain futures finished mixed ahead of two eagerly awaited government reports. Trading had been quiet for much of the session as players staked out positions ahead of the Agriculture Department's quarterly grain stocks report and annual report on spring planting intentions. Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago, attributed the late buying of soybean futures to talk that the prospective corn plantings number would be higher and the soybean number lower than the markets had earlier anticipated. Analysts had expected the report to show that U.S. farmers intend to increase corn acreage this year by 4 percent to 75.2 million acres from 72.3 million acres, decrease soybean acreage by 3.6 percent to 58.5 million acres from 60.7 million, and decrease spring wheat acreage by about 1 percent to 17.5 million acres from 17.7 million. The report, which was released after the close, showed plans for a 3.5 percent increase in corn to 74.8 million acres, a 2.1 percent decline in soybeans to 59.4 million acres, and a 4 percent decline in spring wheat acreage to 17 million acres. Wheat futures settled 1\ cents lower to \ cent higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.51} a bushel; corn futures were } cent to 1\ cents higher with May at $2.61\ a bushel; oats were 3 cents to 3\ cents higher with May at $1.50 a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 7\ cents higher with May at $5.95 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Hallmark Sweetens Offer for Univision Debt Buyback
DOC.TEXT: Hallmark Cards Inc. on Friday sweetened the terms of its proposed buyback of $270 million in junk bonds issued by its Univision Holdings Inc. subsidiary after its first offer received a very chilly response. Under the revised offer, Hallmark would pay about 49 cents on the dollar for the two series of securities, up from about 39 cents on the dollar under the initial offer that was to have expired early Friday. But the greeting card company warned that if the tender offers are unsuccessful, Univision will file for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code. The Hallmark board approved that course of action at a meeting earlier this week, the Kansas City, Mo.-based company said. A financial advisor to the bondholders called the revised offers ``constructive'' and indicated the bondholders intended to review them over the weekend and discuss them among themselves on Monday. Univision owns eight television stations and operates the nation's biggest Spanish-language television network which reaches 92 percent of the Hispanic households in the country. In announcing the revised offer for the bond debt, Hallmark and Univision also said they had reached an agreement in principle with Univision's bank lending group on a plan that reschedules payments on $315 million owed to banks and increases the availability of funds to Univision. Hallmark also said it had agreed with the banks that if the restructuring of Univision's debt is completed, Hallmark will defer interest payments on the securities tendered for seven years rather than the five years earlier proposed. Company executives say that while Univision's business is growing, the company has run into stiffer than expected competition and has been unable to meet the terms of its current financial structure. Univision missed $10 million in interest payments that were due Feb. 1 to its bank lenders and bondholders, citing insufficient cash flow. Several days later, Hallmark launched a plan to rescue Univision that included paying $105.75 million for its $270 million in bond debt. But Hallmark said that with one day left under its once-extended tender offers that were to have expired at 12:01 a.m. Friday, only 8 percent of one issue and 4 percent of the other had been tendered. Hallmark wanted at least 95 percent of the bonds tendered under the initial offers. The revised tender offers are scheduled to expire at 12:01 a.m. Friday, April 13, and Hallmark lowered the minimum acceptable amount to 90 percent. Hallmark paid about $600 million to acquire the Univision network and TV stations over three years ended in 1988. It owns a 63.5 percent stake in Univision, while First Chicago Investment Corp. holds 21.5 percent and a private trust owns the remainder. Wilbur Ross, senior managing director at Rothschild Inc. which is serving as financial advisor to holders of a majority of the Univision bonds, said the first Hallmark offer had been ``pretty much rejected out of hand.'' But he said the new offers, which Hallmark valued at $131 million, were about 25 percent higher than the first ones valued at $106 million. ``We regard this as a very constructive development. It is a good faith offer. No decision has yet been made but people are taking this offer quite seriously,'' Ross said. Among the issues which will be studied, he said, are the sufficiency of the offers and how they allocate values between the two debt issues. Hallmark said that under the revised offer it would pay: _$553 per $1,000 principal amount for the $165 million in senior subordinated discount notes, up from $450 per $1,000 principal amount. _$379 per $1,000 in principal amount for the $105 million in 13] percent subordinated debentures, up from $300 per $1,000 principal amount.

DOC.HEAD: BC-Tight Ship, Adv 01,0928
DOC.NOTE: $adv01
For release Sunday April 1
DOC.HEAD: UPS: Striving to Stay Ahead in a Highly Competitive Industry
LaserPhoto; Graphic in AP Access under DELIVERY
DOC.TEXT: For a company that claims to run the tightest ship in the shipping business, the place looks pretty loose. There's a duck pond, women pushing strollers and executives in shirt sleeves taking afternoon walks. But rivals aren't fooled by the serene headquarters of United Parcel Service, the package-delivery giant known for its distinctive brown vans. UPS is pushing hard to make itself the carrier of choice around the world. In the last decade, UPS has substantially increased its fleet of vans and planes, expanded delivery to 180 countries and territories, and is working on advancements like computerized mapping to help drivers figure out the fastest way to travel a route. Such improvements are considered vital in a business that's become fiercely competitive in recent years. UPS, Federal Express Corp. and overseas firms like TNT Ltd. and DHL Worldwide Express have all been expanding and improving operations to capture a bigger share of the worldwide air delivery industry. UPS still leads the pack, with 230,000 employees and 2.8 billion deliveries last year for a record $12.4 billion in revenues _ about $7 billion more than its nearest rival, Federal Express. The company that proclaims in advertisements ``We run the tightest ship in the shipping business'' started as a messenger service in Seattle in 1907, then quickly got into the package business by delivering packages for department stores to their customers. The next 70 years were spent expanding ground service to all corners of the country, a task it essentially accomplished in 1978. Air delivery was started on a limited basis in 1929 but was terminated a few years later in the midst of the Depression. UPS restarted it in 1953 and expanded it nationwide in 1980. Going head to head with the Postal Service, UPS also strove to be the fastest and least expensive carrier, hiring engineers to poke around and find places to save a dime here or a moment there. The seats on the trucks were designed so drivers can slip off easily. Plexiglas skylights were installed in vans to eliminate overhead lights. Drivers are taught to toot their horns before deliveries so the customer comes to the door. Even the pockets of their pants are designed to make it easy to make change for customers. But while UPS was becoming more efficient on the ground, other players snuck into the game and soared above them in the air freight business. Federal Express, which began in 1973, reported $1 billion in annual revenues by 1983. DHL, based in Brussels, became the first worldwide shipper to serve the Soviet Union, in 1985, and China, in 1988. Suddenly UPS had to play catchup. ``Our customers began telling us they needed a next-day air service,'' says John Alden, group manager of business development, forcing UPS into overnight air delivery. UPS responded quickly. It bought 20 planes in 1981-82, began overnight delivery and expanded to 88 percent of the country in a single year. It bought 52 more planes through 1985 and by the end of the year had overnight service in every state but Alaska. It also launched international service in 1985, starting with six European countries, expanding to 16 countries in 1986, 163 countries by April 1989 and 175 countries by August. UPS entered Eastern Europe last December, expanding its scope to more than 180 countries. This year UPS began flying its own planes to Hong Kong and South Korea, which meant the company was able to end a contract with Flying Tiger International Inc. Federal Express bought Flying Tiger last year, which had put UPS in the uncomfortable position of having the competition carry its packages. Analysts believe more than one carrier can flourish in the delivery business, partly because of an enormous growth in the number of international businesses and the need for speedily moving goods between countries. ``The shippers I come in contact with always find ways to keep two guys in business,'' said Tony Robertson, a securities analyst at the Alex Brown & Sons Inc. brokerage of Baltimore. That way, they ward off heavy price increases. UPS, for its part, plans to add more planes and expand service overseas. It's also adopting new high-technology efficiencies for home and abroad, like a computer system that will provide drivers with the fastest way to work their routes, or determine the closest driver when someone calls for a pickup. Another innovation is an automated sorting system that will route a package by reading a code the size of a postage stamp. UPS also is developing a system to alert Customs officials about package contents, costs and addresses before parcels arrive on a foreign front, cutting down the time it takes to inspect and bill each package. ``You reach a point where you can't save any more'' on standard efficiencies, Alden said. ``Now you ask, what else can you do? And that's where we hope technology can truly help us.'' UPS officials have predicted the company won't make a profit until 1993 from international operations. They also have acknowledged that the competition is working just as hard on the kinds of expansions and improvements UPS is banking on. ``The next 10 years are going to be tremendous challenges, but tremendous opportunities,'' Alden said. ``International is just beginning, and there's going to be tremendous expansion in our service around the world.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday April 1

DOC.HEAD: Carrier Blasts Liquidation `Rumors'
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines on Friday blasted rumors that the carrier faces liquidation as it tries to overcome growing skepticism about its ability to survive. Eastern, which last year promised to repay creditors 100 percent then slashed that by half, this week said it wanted to cut the 50 cents-per-dollar payback plan even further. Immediately afterward, unsecured creditors discussed a potential call for Eastern's liquidation. Eastern took the unusual step of releasing a statement in which President Phil Bakes denounced ``the latest wild rumors.'' ``Liquidation is not in the best interests of any group involved in the bankruptcy,'' spokesman Robin Matell said. ``The unsecured creditors would wind up with little at best and maybe nothing in liquidation. ``We think the creditors' stance is a negotiating position ... If it ws in their best interests, they would have advocated it long ago. Eventually, reason is going to take hold and prevail,'' Matell said, adding that negotiations were continuing with the creditors. Frank Ortis, local president of the striking Machinists union, said the union was delighted with the unsecured creditors' discussion, which he said ``moves us closer to what we've wanted all along _ to buy the airline.'' Eastern charged in its statement that the liquidation speculation is being orchestrated by ``bitter unions who nearly destroyed Eastern a year ago and are trying to do it through vicious rumors and leaks at the early stages of confidential committee deliberations.'' Some reports this week indicated the parent Texas Air Corp. was encouraging creditors to hold off on liquidation talk until final approval of the sale of Eastern's Latin American routes to American Airlines. Approved Thursday by Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland, the sale needs approval from the U.S. Department of Transportation and foreign governments involved. Matell said the sale could be approved as early as April 6, clearing the way for bringing $349 million directly to Eastern in a three-way deal that also will give Texas Air some of the proceeds. Eastern is in a strong cash position with some $800 million already, Matell said, and the carrier reported good response to a new ``Y-Not'' promotion that courts business travellers with first-class fares 15 percent below standard coach fares. However, Eastern has consistently fallen short of revenues projections, mainly because frequent business fliers, the strongest revenue base for most airlines, are leery of Eastern. The carrier was hit March 4, 1989, by a paralyzing strike, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization five days later, and has slowly rebuilt while repeatedly missing bankruptcy deadlines and revenue projections. Bakes' statement said Eastern is going ahead with plans to add seven daily roundtrip flights this Sunday, between Atlanta and the cities of New Orleans, Norfolk, Va., Richmond, Va., Greenville-Spartanburg, S.C., and the Florida cities of Fort Myers, Pensacola, and Sarasota. Eastern has about 800 daily flights, compared to 1,080 before the strike. It had just 100 a day in the first weeks of the strike. ``Eastern is running better than ever,'' Bakes said. ``Our domestic load factor this month is 68 percent and we're operating 99 percent of our scheduled flights.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Drops Lincoln Thrift Owner's Case Against Regulators
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Friday dismissed the suit American Continental Corp. filed against federal regulators, which accused them of hurting the survival chances of its Lincoln Savings and Loan Association subsidiary by leaking confidential information. U.S. District Judge Richard M. Bilby agreed to dismiss the case without prejudice, meaning it may be refiled or reopened. But Bilby added that unless American Continental took action by July 1, the claim would be dismissed with prejudice. Bilby precipitated a March 7 motion by American Continental to dismiss the suit when he barred the company from continuing to pay lawyers to pursue the case. He cited the fear that attorneys' fees would use up the equity in American Continental. The company's legal bill had been reaching $1 million a month. In other action during the session, Bilby approved American Continental's plan to raise $700,000 through the sale of stock and agreed to give Los Angeles County District Attorney Ira Reiner access to the voluminous documents in the case. Reiner said two weeks ago that his office planned to prosecute the ``decision-makers'' responsible for selling junk bonds through Irvine, Calif.-based Lincoln. More than 23,000 investors claim they were not warned of the risks in buying the uninsured bonds and lost more than $200 million when the thrift failed. American Continental filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 last April 13, and the government seized Lincoln the next day. American Continental filed suit against the regulators last spring.Bilby combined the bankruptcy case and the suit early this year. The suit claimed regulators caused it more than $100 million in losses through ``repeated, unlawful disclosures'' to the press. The defendants named in the suit included M. Danny Wall, director of the Office of Thrift Supervision; Darrel W. Dochow, the acting principal supervisory agent for Lincoln; and William K. Black, general counsel of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in San Francisco. American Continental added Edwin J. Gray, former chairman of the FHLBB, to the suit in January, but Bilby later severed Gray from trial with the others. He was included in Bilby's blanket dismissal. The suit alleged that Rosemary Stewart, the top enforcement attorney for the Office of Thrift Supervision, acknowledged in congressional testimony that Gray and Black were engaged in a vendetta against Lincoln. Ann Timmer, who represented Black, argued for dismissal with prejudice. ``My client doesn't want to have a cloud hanging over his head that says the only reason this case is dismissed is a lack of money'' for lawyer's fees, she said. David G. Fiske, representing Dochow, said his client should not be included among the defendants because the alleged vendetta dated back to 1984, and Dochow, the former director of the home loan bank board's Office of Regulatory Affairs, didn't enter the scene until 1987. Attorney Robert Milligan countered for American Continental that Dochow was at least as culpable as the others for ``getting on the horn with the Orange County (Calif.) Register'' and telling a reporter that Lincoln had to be sold immediately, or the government would seize it. ``That article had an adverse effect on Lincoln. There were huge runs (by investors),'' Milligan said. ``It had the effect of causing people who might be interested in financing the purchase of Lincoln from ACC to say, `I'm not going to get involved,''' he added. The government has estimated the Lincoln failure may cost taxpayers $2 billion, the most expensive S&L bailout yet. Milligan argued that press coverage was slanted against the corporation and Charles H Keating Jr., founder and chairman of the Phoenix-based development company. Keating, members of his family and other insiders are accused in a $1.1 billion Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. civil suit of plundering Lincoln to support Keating's $3.7 million-a-year salary and lavish development schemes. The case acquired more notoriety with reports that Keating contributed more than $1.3 million to the campaign treasuries five U.S. senators who met with federal regulators on his behalf in 1987.
Stock prices fell today in a subdued windup to the first quarter of 1990. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 21.17 at 2,706.53.

DOC.HEAD: AARP Closing Credit Union Due to Slow Growth
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-7 pvs, `If members ... Bank One,'' to clarify that credit card and CD transfer to Bank One will occur regardless of vote on credit union. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The American Association of Retired Persons said Friday it plans to close its 2-year-old credit union because of a lack of interest from its members. AARP, the nation's largest organization for older Americans, said all savings would be protected in the phase-out, which still must be approved by the credit union's 90,000 members. The credit union's board of directors voted Thursday to recommend that it be closed by June 30. AARP spokesman Bob DeFillippo said the credit union offered its members three services _ credit cards, certificates of deposits and savings accounts _ of which only the credit card attracted much interest. ``The other two just weren't that popular,'' DeFillippo said. ``There was a lack of participation.'' Overall, the credit union had $150 million in assets, he said. Under the AARP's plan, Bank One in Columbus, Ohio, will issue an AARP-sponsored VISA credit card that will be available to all AARP members. People who now have credit cards from the credit union will automatically become card holders through Bank One and be able to continue to use their existing cards, AARP said. In addition, members will get a check for the amount in their savings accounts, and certificates of deposit will be transferred to Bank One. DeFillippo said the credit union's credit card, which was tailored toward older Americans, was more popular than expected. Applicants could use total assets, in addition to income, as a qualification for acceptance. The new AARP credit card issued by Bank One also will take assets into account when determining applicants' eligiblity for credit, AARP said.

Stock prices fell for the second straight session today, finishing the first quarter of 1990 on a downbeat note. Analysts said enthusiasm for stocks was restrained by continuing doubts about the outlook for interest rates. Rates rose in the government bond market today. Prices of long-term Treasury bonds dropped nearly $5 for each $1,000 in face value, putting their yields in the 8.62 percent-8.67 percent range. Traders also reacted warily to renewed selling in the Tokyo stock market, where prices fell 3.37 percent in the last activity of Japan's fiscal year. In recent weeks U.S. stock prices have been holding steady while the Japanese market has suffered a sharp setback. But some observers still worry that ripple effects from the drop in Tokyo could soon start to spread more generally to other financial centers around the world.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. News Executive Moves to Newsweek
DOC.TEXT: Newsweek said Friday that Walter Buchleitner, an executive at rival newsweekly U.S. News & World Report, will join Newsweek magazine as associate publisher and advertising sales director for the domestic edition. Buchleitner, 47, replaces Arthur Karlan, who retired in 1989 after 27 years at Newsweek. He will also be a vice president at Newsweek Inc. Howard W. Smith, Newsweek's worldwide publisher, who plans to step down himself at the end of 1990, said Buchleitner is ``a proven performer with extensive magazine sales experience.'' Buchleitner joined U.S. News in 1985 and was vice president and director of advertising sales. He had previously been associate sales director and national sales account manager at Business Week. He began his publishing career in 1964 as a sales representative for the Chicago Tribune and also worked in sales capacities at Readers Digest and Time.
