DOC.HEAD: A Chronology of United Parcel Service's Growth in the Air
With BC-Tight Ship
DOC.TEXT: Here is a rundown of key events in the growth of United Parcel Service's air-delivery operations, as provided by the company: Aug. 28, 1907 _ United Parcel Service was founded as a messenger business in Seattle and quickly expanded to delivery of packages, mostly from department stores to their customers. Feb. 15, 1929 _ UPS began a limited flying delivery service, known as United Air Express, serving key Pacific coast points, three Arizona cities and El Paso, Texas. April 13, 1931 _ United Air Express was terminated in the midst of the Great Depression. Jan. 22, 1953 _ UPS restarted an air package transportation service. July 6, 1953 _ UPS-AIR began two-day service eastbound-only from Los Angeles and San Francisco to New Yor, Philadelphia, Chicago, Portland and Seattle. Service was later extended to westbound and included more cities. July 28, 1956 _ UPS-AIR added a special ``Long Distance'' transcontinental air service with delivery in four to five days for a reduced rate. April 30, 1959 _ UPS-AIR was changed to ``Blue Label'' air. Aug. 28, 1961 _ ``Long Distance'' service name was changed to ``Brown Label.'' Nov. 6, 1967 _ All air service was converted to two-day delivery under the ``Blue Label'' name. March 1, 1971 _ Air service was expanded to 31 states. Jan. 5, 1976 _ Air service was expanded to 49 states. Feb. 28, 1977 _ Air service was expanded to 50 states. Late 1981-early 1982 _ UPS purchased 20 727-100 aircraft for package delivery use. Aug. 23, 1982 _ UPS inaugurated Next Day Air service between Los Angeles and San Francisco. Sept. 20, 1982 _ Next Day Air was extended to 24 metropolitan areas, and later that year included 37 states plus Washington. Oct. 3, 1983 _ Next Day Air was extended to 44 states plus Washington. Aug. 6, 1984 _ Thirteen cargo jets were purchased for $208 million, bringing total aircraft fleet size to 53. June 3, 1985 _ Next Day Air was extended to all 48 contiguous states, Puerto Rico and Hawaii, and the Next Day Air letter was introduced. Oct. 7, 1985 _ International air service began between the Northeast and six European countries. Sept. 15, 1986 _ International air service expanded to 16 nations. Oct. 3, 1988 _ International air service expanded to 41 nations. Aug. 24, 1989 _ Worldwide air express package and document delivery service began, expanding network to 175 nations and territories. Dec. 6, 1989 _ Air service extended to Eastern Europe. Jan. 3, 1990 _ First scheduled flight by UPS-owned aircraft to Asia.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday April 1.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Grants Stay in High-Tech Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Friday granted Motorola Inc.'s request for a stay following his ruling that the company violated a key computer chip patent and order to stop selling one of its microprocessors. The stay was granted pending an appeal to the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans, according to the U.S. District Court clerk's office in Austin. Motorola spokesman Dan Rogers said the company sought the stay of the court's injunction against domestic marketing and sale of its 68030 microprocessor and ``is studying other legal remedies.'' James A. Norling, president and general manager of Motorola's semi-conductor products sector, said: ``We're disappointed by the judge's decision. We are taking steps to ensure an uninterrupted product supply to our 68030 customers.'' The 68030 microprocessor is the centerpiece of a family of Motorola products that are the electronic heart of millions of personal computers and other electronic devices. A lawsuit between Motorola and Tokyo-based Hitachi Ltd. resulted in each giant computer company receiving an award and a lecture on Thursday from U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton not to waste the court's time. In a said 45-page opinion, Bunoted said the parties ``would have saved time, money, feelings, and relations had they curbed their emotions and sat down to settle their difference out of court.'' Under Bunton's order, Hitachi will pay $1.9 million to Motorola for patent infringements, and Motorola will pay $500,000 to Hitachi for a patent infringement. The order prohibits the companies, allies since 1975 in sharing technological and manufacturing advances, from marketing or selling various lines of microprocessors. Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., sued Hitachi, claiming the company was using Motorola secrets to develop a series of micro controllers _ thumb-sized devices central to information-processing devices used in computers. The micro controllers were designed and manufactured in Austin. Hitachi filed a countersuit, claiming Motorola infringed on some of its patents. The complex case was packed into a three-day trial in January.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Finishes Mixed After Falling Overseas
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen to recoup its losses from the previous session but finished mixed against other major currencies in hectic domestic trading Friday. Gold prices were mostly lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $370.20 a troy ounce, off 60 cents from late Thursday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $370.25 an ounce, down $1.15. Although Japanese dealers and investors were largely absent due to the close of the Japanese fiscal year, trading in the yen was extremely active, dealers said. The dollar lost nearly two yen on Thursday in what some observers called a ``mini-correction.'' But the U.S. currency began advancing in Tokyo and ended the day a full two yen higher in New York. Bolstering the dollar were ``expectations that Japan may not get such a warm reception'' at the Group of Seven meeting, set to begin April 7 in Paris, said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. Finance ministers from the world's leading industrialized nations _ the United States, Canada, Britain, France, West Germany, Italy and Japan _ will meet to discuss world markets and currency levels. ``Japan is coming to the meeting with a very weak hand, with its stock market weakness and with all the trade negotiations going on,'' Flanagan said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 157.65 Japanese yen, from 156.65 yen on Thursday. Later in London, it slipped to 157.30 yen. But in New York, the dollar closed at 158.35 yen, up sharply from 156.35 yen on Thursday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6465 from $1.6350 late Thursday. In New York one pound cost $1.6455, more expensive than Thursday's $1.6395. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.6940 West German marks, unchanged; 1.4982 Swiss francs, up from 1.4935; 5.7020 French francs, down from 5.7025; 1,248.75 Italian lire, up from 1,248.50, and 1.1695 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1720. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.6875 West German marks, down from 1.6960; 1.4935 Swiss francs, down from 1.5005; 5.6765 French francs, down from 5.7070; 1.9008 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9083; 1,243.25 Italian lire, down from 1,248.75, and 1.1700 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1742. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $369.25 a troy ounce, from $372.25 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $368.75 an ounce from $371.70 bid late Thursday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.18 to close at a bid $373.11. Silver prices were virtually unchanged. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.945 a troy ounce, fractionally lower than Thursday's $4.946. In London, the metal was unchanged at $4.97 an ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Vacates Trader's 18-Month Sentence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to UPDATE with comment from lawyer.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-GAF Sentencing, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The perjury conviction of former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. trading assistant Lisa Jones was upheld Friday by a federal appeals court. But her 18-month jail sentence was thrown out. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled the trial judge wrongly gave her a sentence greater than the 10- to 16-month term recommended by new sentencing guidelines. The case was sent back to U.S. District Judge Leonard B. Sand for resentencing. The three-judge panel said Sand's reason for lengthening the sentence _ that Jones' perjury severely impeded the government's Drexel investigation _ was not justified. A federal jury in March 1989 found Jones guilty on five counts of perjury and two counts of obstruction of justice for lying to a federal grand jury in January 1988 in an investigation of trading involving Drexel. ``These instances of perjury, standing alone, do not constitute the type of egregious conduct envisioned by the guidelines as substantial interference with the administration of justice,'' the 24-page appeals court opinion said. Jones, who left home at age 14, climbed to a $100,000-a-year job as an assistant bond trader in Drexel's high-yield junk bond department in Beverly Hills, Calif., formerly run by now-indicted executive Michael Milken. In three appearances before the federal grand jury, Jones said she did not recall any discussions about stock ``parking'' in contacts with Princeton-Newport Partners LP, a defunct investment firm whose principals were convicted of securities fraud in July. Parking refers to placing stock temporarily with another party to hide its true ownership. The practice is illegal when it is used to circumvent regulations that require stockholders to disclose shares they own in companies. The appeals court upheld her conviction by ruling against three issues raised by her lawyer in the appeal: that Jones was denied effective counsel by her trial attorney; that the prosecutor conducted an improper cross-examination when she testified at trial; and that the judge made an incomplete examination of a juror whose son was a federal prosecutor in New Jersey. Jones' attorney, Daniel Bookin, said he had not decided whether to appeal her conviction further. He would not comment on the appeals court decision. Her resentencing was not yet scheduled.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Reported Ready to Trim Dozens of Job Positions
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. plans to eliminate dozens of jobs in an effort to cut costs, published reports said Friday. A CBS spokesman who was asked about the reports said only that the company was ``looking more closely at every opening'' before filling vacant spots. The New York Times reported in Friday's editions that unidentified network executives said CBS plans to ``cut dozens of employees from its staff ... either through a strict review of all job openings or dismissals spaced out slowly.'' The report said the reduction will be across the board with no specific target date or number set. The Wall Street Journal reported Friday that unnamed company officials said CBS News plans to eliminate about 50 positions, mainly through attrition. The Journal reported that the officials said CBS does not plan another round of sweeping layoffs, however. In February 1987, for instance, 215 people lost their jobs in CBS News as the division's budget was cut by $33 million, the report said. Asked about the reports, CBS vice president George Schweitzer said, ``There is no mandated staff reduction.'' ``When a job comes open, we look at it more closely,'' he said. He described the exercise as ``prudent management'' and said jobs still are being filled in some cases. The CBS television network is trying to climb out of third place in the prime time ratings race against NBC and ABC. The company has committed itself in recent months to pay more than $3.5 billion for major sports events including major league baseball, pro football and the Winter Olympics.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Taking $52 Million Restructuring Charge
DOC.TEXT: Chemical Banking Corp. said Friday it will take about a $52 million pretax charge in the first quarter to cover the costs of previously announced steps to cut operating expenses. The charge will provide for severance and other one-time costs of implementing the restructuring program, which is expected to yield annual savings of $60 million in the future. The banking company did not estimate how much its first-quarter net income would be reduced by the pretax charge. During the quarter, Chemical Bank in New York almost completed the reduction of about 1,100 positions through attrition, voluntary separations and job eliminations, it said. Certain operations in the New York area are being consolidated. Also, Chemical has been carrying out money-saving measures at its other subsidiaries. Staff reductions and consolidations are under way at Chemical Mortgage Co. and Chemical Financial Services Corp.

The Russell 3000 index of companies with the largest market value closed at 189.14 Friday, up 1.23, or 0.65 percent, from a week ago and down 8.14, or 4.13 percent, this year to date. The Russell 1000 index of the largest companies, closed at 177.28 Friday, up 1.24, or 0.70 percent, from a week ago and down 7.83, or 4.23 percent, this year to date. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies, closed at 163.64 Friday, up 0.02, or 0.01 percent, from a week ago and down 4.67, or 2.77 percent, this year to date.

DOC.HEAD: FOMC Decided To Keep Interest Rates Steady In February
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve policy makers decided at their February meeting to continue their high interest rate policies to keep inflationary pressures under control, according to minutes released Friday. The federal funds rate has remained steady at 8.25 percent since the Fed permitted it to drop from 8.5 percent on Dec. 21 ,following the previous Fed policy meeting on Dec. 18-19. The federal funds rate is the interest banks charge each other for overnight loans and is the primary lever the Fed uses to control short-term interest rates. The policy-making body, the Federal Open Market Committee, met again Tuesday and analysts believe it voted to continue current policies. Minutes of that meeting will not be released until May. The committee holds closed meetings eight times a year to formulate monetary policy and confers by telephone as needed. It consists of the seven Federal Reserve Board members and five of the 12 presidents of the Fed district banks. At the FOMC meeting Feb. 6-7, ``The information (on economic conditions) ... suggested continued but sluggish expansion in overall economic activity, with conditions uneven across sectors,'' the minutes read. ``Industrial activity remained weak, partly because of the depressing effects of an inventory correction on manufacturing output, while the service-producing sector of the economy continued to grow moderately,'' they continued. The minutes stated that prices increased more slowly over most of the second half of 1989, ``but unusually cold wather in December put temporary upward pressure on food and energy prices.'' And, they added, ``The staff projection prepared for this meeting suggested that the economy was likely to expand relatively slowly over the next several quarters.'' But while the policy-makers ``generally agreed that continuing growth in economic activity remained a reasonable expectation for the year ahead,'' the minutes said ``members acknowledged that there were considerable risks ... and some did not rule out the possibility of a downturn.'' At the conclusion of the meeting, the FOMC voted 8-3 not to change policies, although they agreed some firming or easing of credit would be acceptable depending on economic developments.

DOC.HEAD: NASD Listing Changes Could Eliminate Trading in Many Penny Stocks
DOC.TEXT: Companies with new stock offerings would have to show they have twice as much capital and assets than they do now to be listed on the National Association of Securities Dealers' stock quote system under a proposed rule change. Trading in as many as 500 ``penny'' stocks could be eliminated from the NASDAQ stock market, under the proposed rule which comes partly in response to a federal crackdown on fraud in the low-cost securities. The NASD, the self-regulatory agency that oversees the over-the-counter stock market, said Thursday it would seek Securities and Exchange Commission approval to raise the standards companies must meet to be listed on the NASDAQ stock system. NASDAQ stands for the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations system, a computerized stock price quotation system owned and operated by the NASD. Penny stocks, low-cost, high-risk securities that usually trade for less than a dollar, are often prone to fraud because most are not listed on any stock exchange or the NASDAQ system. About 5,000 stocks currently trade on NASDAQ. The new standards will not affect about 2,700 stocks traded on the NASDAQ National Market, which already has a higher standard. The changes, if approved by the SEC, would not go into effect until next January, to give already listed companies time to meet the new rule. Also, the NASD plans to provide an alternative system, the OTC Bulletin Board, for companies with securities that are not eligible for listing on the NASDAQ. The service, available through computer terminal screens, would allow members, for the first time, to enter, update and view price quotes on over-the-counter stocks not listed on NASDAQ. Brokers would not be able to execute trades through the Bulletin Board system, however. The new standards, adopted by the NASD's board of governors earlier this month, would require companies issuing stock for the first time to have a minimum of $4 million in total assets and $2 million in capital and surplus, compared to the present requirements of $2 million and $1 million. In addition to the currently required 100,000 shares of public float for an issue, the float would have to have a market value of $1 million. Float is the term used to describe the number of public shares circulating in the market. Stocks would have to have a minimum bid price of $3 per share. There is no minimum required now. Maintaining a stock listing on NASDAQ under the new rule would require a company to have $2 million in assets, instead of the $750,000 in effect now. Also, $1 million in capital surplus, up from $375,000 would be required. The float would have to have a market value of $200,000 and the stock would be required to have a $1 minimum bid price. NASD Executive Vice President John T. Wall said the changes reflected the effects of inflation since the requirements were last amended in 1981. Also prompting the changes was a Jan. 10 letter from the SEC expressing concern that unscrupulous promoters might seek to circumvent tougher rules for selling penny stocks by acquiring a listing on NASDAQ Stock Market. Such a listing would exempt them from the SEC rule requiring a client's written consent to buy stocks not listed by NASDAQ or a stock exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Sherwin Gets Six Months for Stock Manipulation; GAF Fined $2 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf pvs, The government... with 2 new grafs to CORRECT wording to ``substantial sentence'' sted ``significant sentence, UPDATE with further detail from government sentencing recommendation. Picks up 15th graf, Sherwin, his...
DOC.TEXT: A top GAF Corp. executive was sentenced Friday to six months in prison and the company was fined $2 million for stock manipulation convictions stemming from the government's crackdown on Wall Street crime. U.S. District Judge Mary Johnson Lowe said she ordered a prison term for GAF vice chairman James T. Sherwin because his conviction ``should be used as a lesson to others who may be tempted to engage in conduct such as this.'' Sherwin, 56, and GAF were convicted in December on eight counts of stock manipulation, securities fraud, conspiracy and record-keeping violations in a scheme to boost the stock price of Union Carbide Corp. after a failed takeover. GAF, a Wayne, N.J., speciality chemicals concern, was the first company outside of Wall Street to be convicted in the government's insider trading investigation that began in 1986. The GAF case was based on information indirectly supplied by convicted arbitrager Ivan Boesky. ``I do not believe that a sentence should be imposed upon you to punish you as a person,'' Lowe told Sherwin. ``... I do this with heavy heart because I believe you are a good man.'' But the judge said she felt compelled to issue prison time to send a message to Wall Street that if financial market participants break the law ``there will be a prison sentence at the end of the road.'' GAF attorney Arthur Liman said an appeal was planned. Sherwin remains free pending appeal. Under the sentence, Liman said, Sherwin would have to serve five months in prison, with one month off for good behavior. Sherwin, who once was the nation's third-ranked chess player, slumped in his chair as the verdict was read. He declined to comment afterward, and was embraced by his tearful wife, two of his three daughters and three stepdaughters. The case attracted wide attention on Wall Street when GAF, two subsidiaries and Sherwin were indicted in July 1988 for allegedly trying to inflate the price of Union Carbide stock in 1986. The illegal action allegedly occurred shortly before GAF sold a large block of Union Carbide shares it acquired in an unsuccessful takeover attempt. The case endured two mistrials, the first in early 1989 after the government inadvertently withheld a key piece of evidence and the second after a jury was unable to reach a verdict after 12 days of deliberations. GAF, a chemicals and building parts manufacturer, faced a maximum fine of $4 million. Sherwin faced a maximum five years in prison and $250,000 fine on each count. The parties recently paid $1.25 million to settle a civil lawsuit with the Securities and Exchange Commission on similar allegations as in the criminal case. Judge Lowe sentenced Sherwin to six months in prison on one count each of stock manipulation and record-keeping violations. She suspended sentence on the other six counts and placed Sherwin on one year probation. The government did not recommend a prison term for Sherwin, saying only that a ``substantial sentence'' was warranted. ``The manipulation was done purely out of greed and not out of financial necessity,'' the government said in its sentencing memorandum. ``...In short, the scheme was calculated and well-planned.'' Sherwin, his voice cracking, told Lowe: ``Any sentence the judge deems appropriate I am prepared to accept.'' Stephen Kaufman, Sherwin's attorney, asked Lowe to order only community service. He said Sherwin has a stellar reputation in business, is active in human rights causes, and was not a ``systemic violator.'' ``This was an aberrational act, an isolated act, an act totally out of character with anything he's done in his life,'' Kaufman said. Lowe said she could not recall a case in her 18 years as a judge ``that had caused me more anguish in attempting to fashion an appropriate sentence.'' Prosecutors based their case on testimony of former Los Angeles stockbroker Boyd L. Jefferies. He testified that Sherwin directed him to buy large blocks of Union Carbide in late 1986 in an attempt to raise its price to $22 a share and agreed to pay $40,000 to cover his losses. A higher stock price would have meant more money for GAF, which had accumulated 10 million shares of Union Carbide during the failed takeover bid that year. GAF later sold 5 million shares to Salomon Brothers Inc. for $23 a share. Jefferies also played a key role in two other securities fraud convictions last year, of Florida investor Paul A. Bilzerian and arbitrager Salim B. Lewis. Bilzerian was sentenced to prison, while Jefferies and Lewis were fined and ordered to perform community service.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices closed out a sluggish first quarter of 1990 with a mixed showing Friday in a session marked by late weakness in blue chips. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 20.49 to 2,707.21, reducing its gain for the week to 2.93 points. Advancing issues and declines were evenly balanced in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 730 up, 724 down and 499 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 139.34 million shares, against 132.19 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 165.95 million shares. Analysts said enthusiasm for stocks was restrained by continuing doubts about the outlook for interest rates. Rates rose in the government bond market Friday. Prices of long-term Treasury bonds dropped nearly $5 for each $1,000 in face value, putting their yields in the 8.62 percent-8.67 percent range. Traders also reacted warily to renewed selling in the Tokyo stock market, where prices fell 3.37 percent in the last activity of Japan's fiscal year. In recent weeks U.S. stock prices have been holding steady while the Japanese market has suffered a sharp setback. But some observers still worry that ripple effects from the drop in Tokyo could soon start to spread more generally to other financial centers around the world. The Dow Jones industrial average finished the first quarter with a net decline of 45.99 points, or 1.67 percent. Among actively traded blue chips, American Express dropped ] to 25}; Union Carbide [ to 21}; General Electric \ to 64\, and Philip Morris ] to 39|. International Business Machines was up [ at 106[. Amax, which rose sharply over the past few sessions on takeover speculation, dropped back 1[ to 27} as the volume leader among NYSE issues. Japanese issues traded in this country were broadly lower. Matsushita Electrical fell 6} to 135; TDK Corp. 2 to 37}; Kyocera 2[ to 95, and Honda Motor } to 22[. Motorola dropped 2{ to 65. As part of a court ruling in a patent case, Motorola was order to stop selling a microprocessor widely used in desktop computers. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $4.35 billion, or 0.13 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped .32 to 186.85. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 1.24 to 394.18, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 0.85 at 339.94. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose .12 to 435.54. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 361.75, up 1.52.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Fall
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices lost ground Friday in light to moderate activity, reflecting concerns that next week's economic reports may indicate some lingering strength that could keep the pressure on interest rates. The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond fell ] point, or $3.75 for every $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which rises when the price falls, climbed to 8.62 percent from 8.58 percent late Thursday. Its yield had been 8.47 percent only a week ago. Prices were weighed down by a report from a Midwestern purchasing managers group that suggested the economy is fairly strong, according to Kevin Flanagan, money market economist for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. He said the market is also concerned that Japanese investors, under pressure from their government to support the yen, may not buy as many Treasury bonds as they would otherwise over the next few months. Some traders stayed out of the market while they await a pair of important economic reports next week: the latest monthly survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management and the March unemployment figures. The Purchasing Management Association of Chicago reported Friday that its index of area business activity rose to 55.1 percent in March from 51 percent in February. It was the highest reading since April. A reading above 50 indicates expansion in the manufacturing sector and a reading below 50 indicates contraction. The Chicago index is based on a survey of company purchasing managers in northern Illinois and northwestern Indiana, one of the largest industrial areas in the country. It was viewed as an indication that nationwide business conditions may show improvement as well. Evidence of a revival in the economy would be hurt the bond market because it would reinforce the belief that the Federal Reserve might be leaning toward tightening its credit policy by nudging up interest rates. Bond prices recede when interest rates rise. In the secondary market for Treasury securities, prices of short-term government issues fell 1-32 point, intermediate maturities lost [ point and long-term issues fell as much as 15-32 point, according to figures provided by Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point equals a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 1.31 to 1,148.50. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell [ point to 91 7-32. The average yield to maturity edged up to 7.52 percent from 7.51 percent late Thursday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills dipped to 8.05 percent as the discount declined 4 basis points to 7.79 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 8.22 percent as the discount dropped 3 basis points to 7.80 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 8.32 percent as the discount fell 1 basis point to 7.75 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 percent, down from 8 7-16 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Increases Some Incentives
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. said Thursday it was raising rebates on six models, offering 6.9-percent financing on others and keeping buyer incentives slated to expire April 2 in effect through April 30. Effective Thursday, rebates were increased to $1,500 from $1,000 on Ford Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar cars and on Ford Bronco II sport-utility vehicles, to $1,000 from $750 on Ford Taurus and Mercury Sables models and to $750 from $500 on Ford Aerostar minivans, the company said. On Ford Escort, Probe and some Mustang cars, buyers could choose a $1,000 cash rebate or a $750 rebate and financing at 6.9 percent interest for 24, 36 or 48 months, or at 10.9 percent for 60 months, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: American General Files Suit Following Unsolicited Takeover Offer
DOC.TEXT: American General Corp. has filed suit to block an attempt by smaller insurance rival Torchmark Corp. to elect directors to the board following Torchmark's unsolicited $6.34 billion takeover bid. Six of American General's 15 directors are up for election at the company's annual meeting on May 2, and Torchmark is putting its own slate of nominees forward against the company's. American General said Torchmark did not comply with bylaws requiring advance notification for the nomination of persons for election to the board. The suit, filed Wednesday afternoon and assigned to U.S. District Judge David Hittner, seeks an order prohibiting Torchmark from soliciting proxies in its effort to elect its slate of nominees. Harold S. Hook, chairman and chief executive officer of Houston-based American General, said the company will discuss the Torchmark bid at the May 2 meeting. Torchmark, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., offered to buy about half of American General's 126.7 million outstanding shares of common stock for $50 a share and exchange $50 worth of Torchmark common stock for each of the remaining shares. Torchmark said all aspects of the offer are negotiable, including the possibility of an all-cash deal. At the end of 1989, American General's total assets were $32.1 billion and common shareholders' equity was $4.1 billion. Torchmark reported total assets at Dec. 31 of $4.9 billion and common shareholders' equity of $795 million.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Jump on Supply Fears
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices jumped to new life-of-contract highs Friday on New York's Commodity Exchange amid fears of a miners strike in Papua New Guinea and perceptions of a sharp drop in deliverable supplies of copper in London. On other commodity markets, precious metals retreated, grains and soybeans were mixed, livestock and meat futurs were mixed and petroleum futures advanced. Copper futures settled 1.7 cents to 4.5 cents higher with the contract for delivery in April up 3.4 cents at $1.269 a pound, eclipsing the high of $1.25 set by the April contract on March 22. Prices were supported in part by sketchy rumors of labor tension at the O.K. Tedi copper mining complex in Papua New Guinea, a small nation in the South Pacific whose Bougainville copper complex was shut down nearly 11 months ago after attacks by irate landowners. Bill Steele, an analyst with the brokers advisory service Research Department Inc. in Chicago, was skeptical of the rumors. ``The fact that there are no details leads me to believe it's yet another bullish argument in a market that thrives on any bullish news,'' he said. The market ignored potentially bearish news that 1,250 workers at Highland Valley Copper Co.'s mine near Logan Lake, British Columbia, may be ordered back to work by the government, ending a three-day wildcat strike. Meanwhile, a strike against the Southern Peru Copper Corp. stretched into its nineteenth day Friday, and the company was said to be seeking a state-of-emergency declaration from the government to force miners back to work. Buying also was linked to expectations that Monday's weekly stocks report from the London Metal Exchange will show a decline of 5,000 to 10,000 metric tons of copper certified as deliverable against futures contracts there. Precious metal futures edged lower on the Commodity Exchange in another day of cautious trading following Monday's collapse of gold prices to five-month lows. Gold futures settled 60 cents to $2.20 lower with April at $370.20 a troy ounce; silver was 0.1 cent to 0.5 cent lower with April at $4.945 a troy ounce. Soybean futures surged in late trading and settled strongly higher on the Cdicago Board of Trade while grain futures finished mixed ahead of two eagerly awaited government reports that were released after the close. The Agriculture Department's annual prospective plantings report indicated U.S. farmers intend to increase corn acreage 3.5 percent this year to 74.8 million acres, decrease soybean acreage 2.1 percent to 59.4 million acres and decrease spring wheat plantings 4 percent to 17 million acres. Analysts had expected a larger gain in projected corn acreage, a bigger drop in soybean acreage and a smaller decrease in spring wheat. The other USDA report, a quarterly estimate of grain stocks, showed supplies of soybeans, corn and wheat to be slightly lower than expected. Analysts pronounced the reports slightly bearish for soybean futures and slightly bullish for the corn and wheat markets. Wheat futures settled 1\ cents lower to \ cent higher with May at $3.51} a bushel; corn futures were } cent to 1\ cents higher with May at $2.61\ a bushel; oats were 3 cents to 3\ cents higher with May at $1.50 a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 7\ cents higher with May at $5.95 a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle futures finished mixed while most pork futures advanced ahead of the USDA's quarterly hogs-and-pigs inventory report. The report showed the nation's hog herd as of March 1 to be 4 percent smaller than a year earlier. The market had anticipated a larger herd, so the report was expected to prompt some buying of hog futures on Monday. Live cattle futures settled .30 cent lower to .12 cent higher with April at 77.87 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .20 cent higher with April at 82.15 cents a pound; live hogs were .02 cent lower to .50 cent higher with April at 53.40 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .33 cent lower to .93 cent higher with May at 53.57 cents a pound. Petroleum futures rose moderately on the New York Mercantile Exchange, boosted by news of a threatened Soviet oil workers strike in western Siberia and by buying linked to the expiration of the April heating oil and unleaded gasoline contracts. The contracts went off the board at 57.02 cents and 59.93 cents a gallon respectively. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 19 cents to 25 cents higher with May at $20.28 a barrel; heating oil was .18 cent to .56 cent higher with May at 54.34 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .45 cent to .55 cent higher with May at 65.36 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Merck & Co. Names Woman to Top Financial Post
DOC.TEXT: Merck & Co. has appointed its first woman chief financial officer, placing her in charge of about $2 billion in investments and pension funds at the pharmaceutical giant. The appointment puts Judy C. Lewent, 41, who was also named vice president for finance, among a small group of women to be appointed CFO of a major U.S. corporation. ``I do believe I was given this job on the merits and against stiff competition,'' Ms. Lewent said in a telephone interview Friday from the company's headquarters in Rahway. ``I think there are still some more firsts for women to achieve, but I think (the appointment) is a function of having the time and the experience to achieve it,'' said Ms. Lewent, who was also appointed vice president for finance. ``The phenomenon I've seen in my own career is tat there were not a lot of women coming out of business schools with MBAs in the early 1970s,'' Ms. Lewent said. Merck's board of directors Thursday elected Ms. Lewent, a graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management, to oversee all financial matters for Merck, which had $6.6 billion in sales last year. The appointment makes Ms. Lewent the highest ranking woman at the company and one of a handful of women who have served as CFOs at major U.S. corporations, said Merck spokesman John Doorley. ``We've done pretty thorough research and we don't know of any other major corporation (currently) with a woman as a chief financial officer,'' Doorley said. Ms. Lewent, who lives with her husband in New York City, succeeds Alfred Smith, who retired at the end of 1989. Ms. Lewent's responsibilities include supervision of the company's $1 billion in cash and short-term investments and $1 billion in pension funds. Her goals include developing a strategy to protect the company's overseas sales from losses incurred by wide swings in foreign currencies. On the domestic side, Ms. Lewent said the industry needs an articulate spokesperson to rebut congressional critics who have sought to bring pharmaceutical pricing under federal control. ``We are spending huge amounts on research and development to bring breakthrough drugs to the market,'' she said. ``There's got to be a marketplace that understands we need an adequate return,'' Ms. Lewent said. Ms. Lewent joined Merck in 1980 as director of acquisitions and capital analysis. She was promoted to assistant controller of the Merck Sharp & Dohme Research Laboratories in 1983 and to executive director of financial evaluation and analysis in 1985. She was promoted to vice president and treasurer in 1987, reporting to Francis H. Spiegel Jr., senior vice president. She will continue to report to Spiegel.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Lifts Restraining Order On Mr. Donut Sale
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has lifted a restraining order that temporarily blocked the sale of the Mr. Donut chain to its biggest competitor, Dunkin' Donuts. U.S. District Judge Franklin VanAntwerpen ruled Wednesday that Mr. Donut franchise owners could pursue their lawsuit to block the sale on antitrust allegations. But in dissolving the restraining order that been in effect since Feb. 13, VanAntwerpen said the franchise owners failed to prove they would suffer irreparable harm while they pursued their lawsuit. The owners claim the sale would drive them out of business or force them to make expensive conversions. Dunkin' Donuts is No. 1 in the nation with some 1,600 stores, while Mr. Donut has about 550 outlets.

The Bush administration accused 35 nations of erecting unfair trade barriers against U.S. products, the first step in a process that could lead to economic retaliation. The action on Friday was the latest salvo in a more aggressive campaign on the part of the administration, prodded by Congress, to find ways to reduce America's huge $109 billion annual trade deficit. Japan led the list of offenders, with 19 pages of the 216-page report devoted to its barriers against the sale of U.S. products.

A top GAF Corp. executive was sentenced to six months in prison and the company was fined $2 million for stock manipulation convictions stemming from the government's crackdown on Wall Street crime. U.S. District Judge Mary Johnson Lowe said Friday she ordered a prison term for GAF vice chairman James T. Sherwin because his conviction ``should be used as a lesson to others who may be tempted to engage in conduct such as this.''

The perjury conviction of former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. trading assistant Lisa Jones was upheld by a federal appeals court but her 18-month jail sentence was thrown out. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled Friday the trial judge wrongly gave her a sentence greater than the 10- to 16-month term recommended by new sentencing guidelines. The case was sent back to U.S. District Judge Leonard B. Sand for resentencing.

Orders to factories for manufactured goods in February bounced back 1.8 percent from their steepest dive in 16 years a month earlier but failed to regain the levels of late 1989, the government reported. The Commerce Department said Friday that orders for both durable and non-durable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $231.6 billion in February. That figure plummeted 5.5 percent in January, the steepest drop since a 7 percent decline in December 1974, the department said in revising the January figure downward.

A former Labor Department offical chosen by President Bush to regulate the nation's savings institutions won a narrow endorsement from the Senate Banking Committee. Two Democrats joined all nine Republicans on the panel in voting 11-10 on Friday to send the nomination of T. Timothy Ryan Jr. to the full Senate for confirmation as director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision.

Eastern Airlines blasted rumors that the carrier faces liquidation as it tries to overcome growing skepticism about its ability to survive. ``Liquidation is not in the best interests of any group involved in the bankruptcy,'' spokesman Robin Matell said Friday. ``The unsecured creditors would wind up with little at best and maybe nothing in liquidation. Eastern, which last year promised to repay creditors 100 percent and then slashed that by half, said this past week it wanted to cut the 50 cents-per-dollar payback plan even further. Immediately afterward, unsecured creditors discussed a potential call for Eastern's liquidation.

Hallmark Cards Inc. sweetened the terms of its proposed buyback of $270 million in junk bonds issued by its Univision Holdings Inc. subsidiary after its first offer received a very chilly response. Under the revised offer disclosed Friday, Hallmark would pay about 49 cents on the dollar for the two series of securities, up from about 39 cents on the dollar under the initial offer that was to have expired early Friday. A financial adviser to the bondholders called the revised offers ``constructive'' and indicated the bondholders intended to review them.

A federal judge granted Motorola Inc.'s request for a stay following his ruling that the company violated a key computer chip patent and order to stop selling one of its microprocessors. The stay was granted Friday pending an appeal to the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans, according to the U.S. District Court clerk's office in Austin. Motorola spokesman Dan Rogers said the company sought the stay of the court's injunction against domestic marketing and sale of its 68030 microprocessor and ``is studying other legal remedies.''

A judge dismissed the suit American Continental Corp. filed against federal regulators, which accused them of hurting the survival chances of its Lincoln Savings and Loan Association subsidiary by leaking confidential information. U.S. District Judge Richard M. Bilby agreed Friday to dismiss the case without prejudice, meaning it may be refiled or reopened. But Bilby added that unless American Continental took action by July 1, the claim would be dismissed with prejudice.

Stock prices closed out a sluggish first quarter of 1990 with a mixed showing Friday as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 20.49 to 2,707.21. The key market indicator gained 2.93 points for the week. The dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen but finished mixed against other major currencies. Bond prices lost ground. Copper futures prices jumped to life-of-contract highs; precious metals retreated; petrooleum futures advanced; and grains, soybeans, livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: TCI Plans to Offer Shareholders Stake in Program Unit
DOC.TEXT: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's biggest cable television system operator, says it will divest about $1.7 billion in assets that will include all of its cable programming interests except its 22 percent stake in Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc. John Malone, chairman of the company, said the new company has not been named. He said it will also include selected cable systems. Malone said TCI will conduct the spin-off through a stock rights offering to existing shareholders who will be allowed to acquire stock in the new company by paying for it with some of their interest in TCI. TCI intends to keep a minority interest in the new company. The proposal replaces a plan that TCI announced in January under which it envisioned spinning off to shareholders substantially all of its cable interests into a new company. Robert Thomson, a TCI executive, said the company devised the new plan because of uncertainties about how Congress may handle calls to impose new regulations on cable operations. He said the new plan would enable TCI to retain an interest in the programming company while those decisions are being made. He said the company could later divest its stake if Congress requires it, but would still have an interest in programming if Congress does not. TCI has been criticized for becoming too powerful in the three years since the industry was deregulated, and feels the spin-off will relieve some of the pressure by breaking off some of those assets. Malone, at the company's annual investors' conference on Thursday, said TCI will offer shareholders a first opportunity at ownership. ``We have it on the advice of counsel we could do something like that in four months. We are proceeding forthwith,'' he said. Malone said Peter Barton, now senior vice president for programming for TCI, will head the new company. According to company officials, the new company would consist of one management team presiding over several cable programming companies. The new company would develop programming and promote the programs on other channels it has a stake in. The new company's assets will include a 50 percent stake in Viacom Inc.'s Showtime Networks Inc., TCI's sports programming interests and a 50 percent interest in Discovery Channel Inc. Malone said the company will retain its 22 percent stake in Turner Broadcasting, which includes common and preferred stock valued at $950 million. The Turner company operates the Cable News Network, CNN Headline News and Turner Network Television as well as WTBS in Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: Companies in Takeover Case Exchange Lawsuits
DOC.TEXT: BTR PLC of Britain sought a federal injunction Friday to keep Norton Co. from delaying a shareholder proxy fight after Norton rejected a $1.6 billion buyout bid. The request was contained in a lawsuit that also challenges Massachusetts' anti-takeover law and Norton's ``poison pill'' defense against hostile bidders. Norton countersued Friday, seeking to halt BTR's tender offer and proxy solicitation. BTR, a London-based industrial conglomerate, announced its $75-per-share bid earlier this month for Norton, a leading manufacturer of abrasives. On Thursday, Worcester-based Norton turned down the offer, calling it ``inadequate.'' Its board of directors said it was canceling the company's annual meeting, scheduled for April 26, and set a special shareholders meeting for June 26. The board said it needed more time to explore its options, including the possibility of attracting a minority investor to help thwart the bid. But BTR's complaint, filed in U.S. District Court in Boston, said Norton's bylaws prohibit the annual meeting from being rescheduled within 60 days of the date set for the meeting. The British firm said it was prepared to enter a proxy fight at the annual meeting to elect its own slate of directors to the company. The change in the meeting date will ``destroy the opportunity for the Norton shareholders to hear the platform of the BTR nominees,'' the complaint said. Norton in its lawsuit accused BTR of making ``false and misleading'' public statements about its plans for the company. BTR intentionally has tried to ``obfuscate the critical facts'' concerning its past acquisitions and employment practices, in which the company has ``repeatedly closed or relocated plants, fired large numbers of employees and retaliated against organized labor and attempts by workers to organize.'' BTR's lawsuit claimed Massachusetts' anti-takeover law is unconstitutional. Judith Fabricant, an assistant attorney general, said the complaint essentially is moot because the state has not enforced the statute since a federal court raised questions about its validity in 1988. ``We do not intend to enforce it,'' she said. ``But we are not taking a position to whether it is valid or not valid.'' The lawsuit seeks an injunction against Norton's poison pill plan, which would boost the cost of a takeover unless the board of directors consents to the offer. BTR claims the plan breaches the company's duty to stockholders. The state, however, has challenged BTR's claims, saying Norton's responsibility is not limited to its shareholders. Under Massachusetts law, a company targeted for a takeover also may consider the impact on employees, customers, suppliers, the community and the state economy, Fabricant said.

DOC.HEAD: Porsche Recalling More than 53,000 Cars
DOC.TEXT: Porsche Cars North America Inc. said Friday it is recalling more than 53,000 cars to correct a defect in a fuel hose that could cause engine fires. The voluntary recall affects 1987-88 Porsche 924S cars, Porsche 944s made in the 1985-88 model years, 1987-88 944S vehicles and 944 Turbos made from the 1986 through 1988 model years. The fuel lines in those vehicles could harden, causing the devices to leak and perhaps prompt an engine fire, Porsche said in a statement. Porsche said it was aware of 16 car fires related to the hose defect, adding that it had no reports of injuries or accidents from the problem. Owners of the affected vehicles are to be notified of the recall by mail. Repairs are to be done at no charge to owners.

DOC.HEAD: Parent of Federated, Allied Seeks Bankruptcy Court Protection
With AM-Campeau-Interest
DOC.TEXT: Federated Stores Inc., the parent company of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., on Friday asked that it be placed under Chapter 11 protection of the U.S. Bankrupty Court. The two subsidiaries filed for similar protection in January. G. William Miller, chairman and chief executive officer of the parent company, said the petition was a procedural step ``to allow us to expedite the reorganization planning process.'' ``As the parent company of Federated and Allied, FSI is of necessity concerned with the total debt structure of these companies, as well as in helping to effect a solution to the financial difficulties imposed by this structure,'' Miller said. ``By bringing FSI more directly into the Chapter 11 process, we will be able to approach a reorganizatin solution for Federated and Allied in a consistent and logical manner, and in a way that makes the most sense for the companies and their creditors.'' The parent company, whose officers and headquarters are in Cincinnati, said the filing was made in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in San Francisco. Although the Federated and Allied divisions filed their Chapter 11 proceedings in U.S. Bankrutpcy Court in Cincinnati, the parent said it filed in San Francisco because that court has jurisdiction over other Chapter 11 proceedings by some of its intermediate holding companies. Allen I. Questrom, chairman and chief executive officer of the Federated and Allied divisions, issued a statement aimed at separating the action of the parent company from the day-to-day retail operations. ``Because today's action by FSI has absolutely no effect whatsoever on the ongoing businesses of Federated and Allied, we want to avoid any risk of confusion or misunderstanding by assuring that the record is set straight from the onset,'' Questrom said. ``The department store operations of Federated and Allied remain sound and profitable. Sales are steadily improving and are now runing ahead of plan. The companies' cash position is excellent. ``We have stabilized our work force and our organizations. Our employees are receiving all of the pay and benefits to which they are entitled, and we have returned to normal operations in virtually all areas of our business and at all levels of our companies across the country.'' Federated Stores, formerly known as Campeau Corp. (U.S.), was formed as the U.S. retailing subsidiary of Toronto-based Campeau Corp., which is owned primarily by Canadian real estate developer Robert Campeau. Campeau said in a statement Friday that it had amended agreements with Edward J. DeBartolo Corp. and with two subsidiaries of Olympia & York Developments Ltd. due to the bankruptcy filing Friday. The agreements require DeBartolo, a major shopping mall developer, and Olympia & York, a real estate concern, to refrain from taking any collateral they hold in Campeau without giving nine days' notice first. The amendment ensures the agreements remain in effect despite the Chapter 11 filing, Campeau said. Toronto-based Olympia & York helped ease Campeau's financial difficulties last year through a loan to the company. On Friday, Campeau said it will not pay interest due Saturday on two bond issues and wants to defer the payments. One of the issues, worth $260 million, is owned by Olympia & York. The second, worth 184 million Canadian dollars, is publicly traded. Federated and Allied, which operate 260 deparment stores in 28 states, filed for bankruptcy protection Jan. 15, listing $7.7 billion in debt. The Federated group includes Bloomingdale's and Abraham and Straus, both based in New York; Burdine's of Miami; Lazarus of Cincinnati; and Rich's of Atlanta. The Allied group includes The Bon Marche of Seattle; Jordan Marsh of Boston; Maas Brothers of Tampa; and Stern's of Paramus, N.J. Campeau acquired Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988, largely on the basis of borrowed money. But Federated and Allied were unable to meet the interest payments on that debt, forcing the bankruptcy filing.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Idles Plant for One Week
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. said Friday it will shut down a suburban Detroit assembly plant next week, idling 2,300 people, to reduce a buildup in inventory of the Dodge Shadow and Plymouth Sundance cars. Production at the Sterling Heights plant will resume April 9, Chrysler spokesman Doug Nicoll said. He said the company does not divulge how many cars a week the plant produces. Chrysler earlier announced closures next week at its plants at Toledo, Ohio, idling 4,200 people; Belvidere, Ill., idling 3,100 people; and Newark, Del., employing 3,100 people, also with production to resume April 9. General Motors Corp. said it will halt production next week at its Oklahoma City plant, idling about 5,500 people, to make changes for operations beginning April 9 at a slower assembly line speed. The plant is reducing production of Buick Century, Pontiac 6000 and Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera cars at the plant. Ford Motor Co. said it will halt production next week at its Lorain, Ohio, assembly plant because of a shortage of orders for the Ford Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar cars assembled there. That move will idle 2,700 workers.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler To Extend Rebates, Cadillac Announces Incentives
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. announced Friday it would extend its guaranteed rebate program on nearly all 1990 domestic cars and trucks through May 31. The rebates were scheduled to expire March 31. Under the program, the automaker will make up to the buyer any rebate increase it later announces on eligible models. The program now applies to vehicles purchased or leased between April 1 and Sept. 30. Meanwhile, General Motors Corp.'s Cadillac Division announced a buyer incentive program to start Sunday and run through May 31 for all Cadillac models, except Allante. Buyers of Cadillac DeVille, Fleetwood and Brougham models will be eligible for a $1,500 rebate. A $2,000 rebate will be offered to buyers of Eldorado and Seville models.

DOC.HEAD: Government, Savings Association Reach Agreement on Receiver
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf pvs to CLARIFY the thrift office's position on Franklin's assets.
DOC.TEXT: Franklin Savings Association and the Office of Thrift Supervision reached agreement Friday on the issue of receivership after an almost two-hour negotiating session among lawyers in federal court. The agreement essentially gives Franklin a chance to argue its case in court if the OS decides to put the state's largest thrift into receivership. A receiver could liquidate all of Franklin's assets. Franklin and its holding company, Franklin Savings Corp., withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction against OTS and the Kansas Savings and Loan Department in U.S. District Court. The injunction was designed to prevent appointment of a receiver until Franklin has its day in court to contest the Resolution Trust Corp.'s conservatorship of the thrift. The agreement, outlined to Judge Dale Saffels, provides that no receiver will be appointed or substituted for the present conservator without giving notice to the court and to Franklin 24 hours in advance. The agreement also requires the thrift office to justify to the court its reason for appointing a receiver if it attempts to do so. Earlier, the OTS only agreed to give Franklin the advance notice. Franklin, which was seized by the RTC on Feb. 16, believed the RTC's conservatorship was merely a prelude to a receivership. Once a receiver is appointed, the court can't intervene. The thrift said it will contest the validity of the conservatorship in a trial set to begin June 25 in Saffels' court here. Attorneys for Franklin came prepared with exhibits to argue their case. Attorneys for OTS said they also were prepared. Saffels, however, asked both parties to try to come to an agreement. The negotiating session involved a call to Washington, D.C., to secure approval of the compromise by OTS officials. OTS attorney Paul W. Grace of Washington said normally no notice is required for appointment of a receiver. He would not say whether he was pleased or displeased with the agreement. ``Let's just say it's a compromise both sides are willing to accept,'' Grace said. Ernest Fleischer, chairman of Franklin's holding company and on leave as chairman of the thrift, said he was pleased with the agreement. An attorney for Franklin, Charles German, said of the agreement, ``It's what we came for.'' The Justice Department was present at the hearing to argue the constitutionality of the appointment of former OTS director M. Danny Wall, who authorized Franklin's conservatorship. However, Saffels said he was not willing to take up that issue, which arose when a federal district judge in Washington ruled last week that Wall's appointment was unconstitutional. An appeals court later stayed that ruling pending its review of it. Franklin contends the thrift was not insolvent at the time it was taken over by federal regulators. The thrift and the OTS differ over the accounting principles used by Franklin. Franklin, through the president of its holding company, John Scowcroft, claims it has a net worth of $387 million, using generally accepted accounting principles. The OTS agrees with that figure, but only as of Dec. 31, 1989, said spokeswoman Cindy Williams. She said that figure likely would be down by next quarter's report but could not release a monthly figure. The thrift experienced a major writedown in its capital in March. The thrift was hedging itself against swings in interest rates by using the futures market.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Temporary Restraining Order Sought by Thrift
With AM-Franklin Savings
DOC.TEXT: U.S. District Judge Helen Frye on Friday denied an attempt to block the federal government from proceeding with its takeover of the Benj. Franklin Savings and Loan Association. The lawsuit was one of several filed around the country against the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision in the wake of a decision last week by a federal judge in Washington that the appointment of former OTS director M. Danny Wall was unconstitutional. An appeals court later stayed that ruling pending its review of it. The former directors of the thrift were refused a temporary restraining order that would have prevented federal regulators from taking further management actions involving the institution. Benj. Franklin, the largest thrift in Oregon and the 41st largest in the nation, was seized Feb. 21 by federal regulators who cited its failure to meet the stringent financial requirements of the new savings and loan law. The former directors filed a lawsuit March 23 challenging the takeover, calling it a ``capricious action'' that may have been unconstitutional. The lawsuit seeks to have the thrift returned to its stockholders.

DOC.HEAD: Troubled Home Builder Delays Annual Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Facing a major shareholder's call for leaner operations and new directors, General Development Corp. Friday announced a two-month delay in its annual meeting. The Miami-based home builder and real estate firm, which pleaded guilty last week to federal fraud charges, said the annual meeting has been rescheduled from May 4 to June 1 to give additional time to prepare audited financial statements. Meanwhile, the company on Friday increased its board of directors to nine members with the appointment of Newark, N.J., attorney James Wyer, a former vice president of American Cyanamid Co. On Wednesday, a major General Development shareholder, United Capital Corp., filed a restructuring plan with the Securities and Exchange Commission proposing General Development sell its time-sharing and utility businesses and undeveloped commercial property. The plan also offered short-term operating funds and pledged to complete infrastructure improvements at General Development's nine Florida communities. New York-based United Capital, which holds about 12.6 percent of General Development common stock, is also seeking the ouster of six directors and has offered a proxy slate, including United Capital President Attilio Petrocelli. United Capital paid an average of nearly $13 a share for General Development stock in 1988. The stock closed Friday at $5.87{, up $1.12{ a share, in New York Stock Exchange trading. General Development pleaded guilty March 22 to a mail-fraud conspiracy stemming from allegations it overpriced nearly 10,000 homes and mislead customers, many from the Northeast and Midwest. A U.S. District judge still must finalize a plea agreement that could lead to $500,000 in fines for the company and a maximum of five years in jail for two former executives.

DOC.HEAD: Government Sets Light Truck CAFE for 1992
DOC.TEXT: Fuel economy standards for 1992 light trucks will stay the same as for 1991 models, the government said Friday. Auto companies opposed tougher standards for 1992, saying people are buying larger trucks that bring average fuel economy down. Environmental groups had argued that the standard should be tougher. ``The biggest thing we can do to curb global warming is to improve the fuel efficiency of our cars and light trucks,'' said Sierra Club spokesman Dan Becker in Washington, D.C. The corporate average fuel economy standard for 1992 light trucks will be 20.2 miles per gallon, the same as the 1991 CAFE requirement and up from 20 mpg this year, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said. In addition to setting a CAFE requirement for cars, currently 27.5 miles per gallon, NHTSA annually sets a light truck standard applying to pickup trucks, vans and utility vehicles that weigh up to 8,500 pounds. NHTSA decided manufacturers couldn't achieve significant improvements for 1992 through technological or marketing changes, spokesman Jim Herd said. Ford Motor Co. backed the lower requirement because larger trucks are selling faster than smaller, more fuel-efficient ones, said David L. Kulp, Ford's manager of fuel economy, planning and compliance. ``We felt that the market was going to hold us at this kind of level. There are improvements being made in the trucks, they've just been offset by some of the shifts to the larger products,'' Kulp said. General Motors Corp. spokesman John Anderson said the decision recognized that tighter standards could reduce trucks' usefulness. ``Trucks have an enormous range of applications, from towing to agricultural and construction uses,'' he said. The Environmental Action Foundation argued on behalf of groups including the Sierra Club that standards should be raised, to 35 miles per gallon by 2000, said Dru Schmidt-Perkins, environmental analyst for the group. ``They are already 25 percent less efficient than cars,'' Schmidt-Perkins said. ``And for the most part these are not farm vehicles and not commercial vans, they are minivans and light pickup trucks which do nothing more than haul briefcases and groceries.''

DOC.HEAD: Utility Files Chapter 11
DOC.TEXT: Colorado-Ute Electric Association, losing a year-long battle against financial disaster, filed in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Denver on Friday for protection from creditors while it attempts to salvage itself. The case is one of the largest utility bankruptcy filings in the country, according to federal officials, and threatens the long-term cost of power for consumers in much of Colorado. With $1.2 billion in debt, Colorado-Ute filed for Chapter 11 reorganization to stave off its many creditors while it tries to solve its problems. Colorado-Ute, based in Montrose in western Colorado, is owned by 14 member rural electric co-ops and serves an estimated 600,000 customers. The filing will have no effect on day-to-day operations of the utility, President Ray Keith said in a news release. On March 31, 1989, Colorado-Ute defaulted on its loans, blaming the oil shale bust for leaving the company with excess capacity. However, the bust was triggered by Exxon Corp.s pullout from the industry in 1982, and Colorado-Ute not only pushed ahead with plant construction but also launched an expensive experimental power plant at Nucla that still loses money. Colorado-Ute lost an estimated $15 million in 1989. In its filing, Colorado-Ute listed liabilities of $920.2 million and assets of $888.3 million. The documents do not reflect the company's $300 million lease obligation on its Craig 3 power plant. The company says the lease obligation is not a debt. Most of the liabilities are held by two federal lenders: the U.S. Rural Electrification Administration and the National Consolidated Finance Corp., for a combined debt of more than $700 million to the federal government. Other major creditors listed on the court filing were: _Public Service Co. of Colorado, $31.4 million of debt. _ColoWyo Coal Co., $23.6 million for disputed coal royalties. _Craig 3 Lease Trustee, $11.8 million in current lease payments. _Norwest Bank of Minneapolis, United Bank of Denver and Manufacturers Hanover Trust, $10 million each. In the year since Colorado-Ute defaulted, the company tried to merger with both Public Service Co. of Colorado and Tri-State Generation & Transmission Co. It also attempted to raise rates by 23.7 percent. Public Service Co. withdrew its offer last summer. On March 8, state regulators denied the big rate increase, allowing only an 8 percent hike. Tri-State, like Colorado-Ute a generating company owned by its rural co-ops, halted merger talks after the rate hike denial and then cut off Colorado-Ute's access to a $40 million revolving loan. With no access to cash, and facing a Monday deadline for a $15 million interest payment to the REA, the utility filed in bankruptcy court late Friday afternoon.
